Here for a Respiratory Convention and got a hotel not to spend my whole day in. More for a place to sleep. Rooms are nice beds comfy but the seepage of smoke which in fact is a non smoking area is pretty strong. Who am I too complain when of course this is Vegas!!  Another minus was the resort fees WTH!!! Thinking I scored with the reasonable fees heck no!!!  Treasure Island is more like Pirate Island. They take your money.

"Come for the boundless array of BBQ, remain due to an inability to arrive at a conclusion. Recognize that the selection of sides is equally extensive, and simply seat yourself while consuming biscuits accompanied by apple butter until an individual informs you that it would be advisable to obtain the tri-tip sandwich complemented by a side of cornbread. 

I comprehend the reasoning behind individuals expressing their discontent regarding the exorbitant nature of the prices, however, come now, my fellow human beings; it is entirely plausible to partake in a meal alongside another person and depart feeling satiated (providing you consume your biscuits.) At present, at this moment, I am cognizant of the notion that you may harbor reservations concerning the sharing of meals within this particular geographic location, yet set aside your implements of war, since the proportions are, in fact, reasonable when considering their cost. 

Lucille's earns two stars due to its exceptional biscuit and cornbread offerings, respectable tri-tip and peanut slaw, and unsatisfactory brisket and mac 'n' cheese. Within a different region, I might award Lucille's an additional star, but within this town, where BBQ reigns supreme, only the finest will succeed in capturing my stomach's favor."

For the kitsch factor, for something to do for a day, this place is fine.  It's got games and the carousel bar and cheesy circus acts.  But it's dirty, it's run down, it's poorly planned, and I wouldn't stay here if my life depended on it.  (OK, MAYBE then.)  I tell people who come to visit all the time to not be taken in by the cheap rates here and at the Tropicana.  There's a reason WHY they're cheap.

I have used irrigation with SPR for over 30 years. They have really dedicated people who go out of their way to be helpful. The Zanjeros were always available and  ready to work out some water issue, and they  are varied and frequent (like a neighbors dead animal in a canal) . So for many years I have been a big fan of SRP.

Until today!

I needed to pay my water assessment so I went to the main office.
1. Now a security guard tells you you are in the wrong place, no more receptionist.
2. The payment  center was closed and turned into  a closet with some machines in it.
3. Customer service is now a telephone on a brown wall with a sign over the phone saying call for customer service.

Zanjeros are now computer baby sitters for the nee Water Master system. Getting a consistent flow is a real challenge now. They are ready to add time but after you get shorted 20 minutes you have to move to a new user and it really does not work to then get 20 minutes delivered the next day. The person responsible  for the Water master needs to be required to meet users at 2am when the order gets shorted by the system.

When I called today I spoke to an old style SRP person but you might as well visit the prison as use this facility, So no matter what the literature says SRP is now just another big faceless utility doing their level best to isolate the customer.

I had a craving for good BBQ and this was a disappointment. Ordered $35 worth of food and did not enjoy most of it. The pulled pork was okay. The brisket was mediocre. The chicken was okay. The beans were under cooked and pretty bad. Threw that away. The sauces were decent. I just ended up asking my father in law to make some brisket since I couldn't find anyone to buy some good southern style brisket. \n The staff was extremely nice and the place is really clean. Inside and a little outside seating. The portions were really small though so I was not impressed.

"As an individual hailing from the Philadelphia metropolitan region, merely passing by this establishment sparked a significant amount of enthusiasm within me. Upon entering the premises, I was immediately struck by the striking resemblance that Pop's Deli bore to Pat's King of Steaks, a renowned eatery in the city of brotherly love. Despite my initial excitement, however, I was sadly disappointed by the subpar quality of the food. Specifically, the cheesesteak sandwich that I ordered, which featured a combination of whiz, onions, and peppers, lacked any semblance of flavor or depth. In fact, I found it rather challenging to distinguish between the taste of the meat and that of the onions, which made for a rather unsettling dining experience. Furthermore, the bread utilized in the sandwich was unsatisfactory, possessing neither the crispy texture nor the rich, buttery flavor that one would expect from an authentic Amoroso roll. Aesthetically, the outdoor seating area was quite inviting, and the sweet potato fries that accompanied my meal were indeed delectable. Nonetheless, the underwhelming nature of the main course left much to be desired."
This was my first time trying Culvers. It's nothing special and is comparable to Wendy's or any other fast food burger place.

"Upon entering the establishment to retrieve an item from the ship-to-store department, I observed that the register was unattended, despite the presence of a sizable queue of patrons awaiting assistance. The gentleman manning the adjacent register informed me that the alternative lane was unavailable, which prompted me to request that he summon support staff to address the situation. In concert with two fellow patrons who shared my sentiment, I emphasized the need for expedited service, given that we were not present for layaway purposes. Fortuitously, our proximity to the employee entrance afforded me the opportunity to alert a staff member of the predicament, resulting in the timely arrival of reinforcements. Although the pace of service remained somewhat sluggish, it marked a considerable improvement from the previous state of affairs. Ultimately, it required approximately half an hour from the moment of my arrival to procure my items and secure permission to collect them from the rear of the store, owing to their bulkiness and the necessity of transporting them via a flatbed cart."

I guess I didn't order the right sandwich because out of all the awesome reviews my sandwich was just.... OK. I got the Italian and was not really impressed. It was just a small amount of meat and a slice of cheese with stock Italian dressing. So what's the big deal?? Ok I'm gonna have to go back and order something else because I gotta see what all the hype is about! To be continued...

I am a resident of the surrounding area and have been frequenting this establishment for an extended period of time, indulging in both takeout and dining in. Unfortunately, over the past six months, I have noticed a gradual decline in the quality of the cuisine, to the point where I question whether it is worthwhile to continue patronizing this restaurant. Specifically, the refried beans appeared to be from a canned source, which is unacceptable given my familiarity with the distinction between homemade and canned variants. Furthermore, the Cheese Crisp was subpar and excessively oily, while the shredded beef taco contained an abundance of fatty cuts. It is unfortunate that this establishment, which once prided itself on serving high-quality Mexican fare, has allowed its standards to slip. Consequently, my dining companions and I have decided to seek alternative options, such as Sylvia's La Canasta or Macayo's, which offer superior culinary experiences without relying on prefabricated ingredients.

I thought it was over-hyped for what  I spent and received service wise. I was overall very disappointed. i went there to celebrate my BF's birthday and told the hostess it was his birthday, then told the waitress, and even told the water guy....and my BF still DID NOT receive the birthday dessert. :( I ordered sweet potato tempura and a king crab California roll and could not believe how dry the rice was. I get a better California roll at my local place back home for a quarter of the price. When we finished eating, it took them 30 mins to bring us the check!? I was so annoyed at this point. I always tip, but in this instance i did not. I did explain on the receipt why I didn't tip too. For how much hype this place gets I am sad to say I was not impressed.

I'm conflicted about this place.  The wife and I were in LV for the first time since 2003, so we were exploring new places.  We saw this restaurant on our travels before heading to a show and we love sushi so we stopped.  The food was very fresh and drink selection was excellent, however portion size was tiny.  After $72 with tip my wife commented that is was the first restaurant that she had ever left feeling more hungry than when she arrived.  We then had to hurry off to get more food before the show.

First time there and sat at the bar. At first we were over whelmed by the customer service (two waitress helping us out) then after awhile there was absolutely no one we could get to order a second drink. We waited about 20 mins just to get our bill and to leave after waving down someone. The place was busy and I had ordered a sample drink but after getting no service we decided to leave.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition." 
The evening commenced with promise, as my gaze fell upon the menu, and my attention was captured by the presence of foie gras, which, to my delight, was not merely a pate, but a seared entirety.  Although the radicchio did not harmonize well with it, the flavor was passable, albeit slightly undercooked.  However, everything took a turn for the worse from that point forward.  I have yet to encounter a smaller or more insipid ceviche, and I must emphasize that if a dish is to be designated as ceviche, it should conform to Peruvian tradition and possess an unmistakable ceviche flavor.  The lobster risotto, though relatively satisfying, was meager in quantity, consisting of only three bites; while the black bass was unremarkable and quickly forgotten.  Furthermore, the prime rib eye was misleadingly named, as it excluded the eye, which is, in fact, the most delectable portion.  Though the complimentary soup and appetizer were appreciated, they failed to satiate our hunger, prompting us to seek a second dinner at Smashburger nearby.

Not four seasons worthy! Food was salty and amateurish, as was the staff. the transition from the bar to the restaurant was awkward. Our sides came after the main dish had been eaten and they were the wrong side dishes, which might have been ok if the entire salt shaker had not been dumped into it!  The only saving grace was the manager who realized how awful the service and food were.  Don't bother driving that far north, stop when you get to Mastro's.

If you want quality, quantity, and reasonable prices--don't go here.  The food could hardly be deemed within an authentic deli realm.  The service is poor, the offerings minute, and taste lacking (chicken soup too salty, sandwiches bland, and desserts hardly unique or fresh).\n\nEven though they are open 24 hours, you have 24 hours to find another venue.  This is a side-show at Circus Circus that is not worth attending.

pros:
They showed up on time

cons:
They took 5.25 hours to LOAD my PODS (I did 95% of the packing before hand). It should have taken them 3 hours to do that work. And they charged me $446 in materials!!  So todays damage was $1150. Buyer beware.

"Little Darlings, a purportedly adult entertainment venue, boasts an unadulterated nudity policy; thus, it is devoid of any alcoholic beverages. Although situated slightly removed from the Las Vegas Strip, its location does not pose significant challenges for those seeking to locate it. However, if one harbors expectations of experiencing a genuinely exceptional strip club adventure within the city limits of Las Vegas, they might wish to reconsider their choice of destination. The interior ambiance exudes an unmistakable aura of shabbiness and seediness, potentially arousing feelings of unease or discomfort in certain patrons. Furthermore, the physical appearance of the female performers falls short of the conventional standards associated with strip clubs. A considerable number of them exhibit visible signs of aging and/or lack of physical fitness, which may prove underwhelming for some spectators. Considering the abundance of alternative options within the city's nightlife scene, it seems judicious to bypass this establishment altogether."

I'm torn between the quality product and the poor service and WiFi.  

The coffee is exceptional but the entry fee (getting past the flaming hoops of attitude) to get your coffee is a little high.  Now I guess I'm one of the cool kids at times (working for the man - Buring Man), but unless that comes up in conversation, most often I'm not dressed the part in my business casual and just another target for the staff.

Beyond the slow service and attitude, the WiFi is crap.  They are riding a signal from a neighbor companies (Wet Paint) router.  I wish they'd get their own router and Cox connection!  Hell I'd even set it up for them, and when I suggested putting a WiFi tip jar the customers at the bar were all for it!

I like the location and the product but not the service and WiFi - both things that can be fixed.

I had heard from several people the food here was good.  As I travel to Italy often I'm fairly picky about Italian food but am willing to make allowances for Italian-American restaurants.

I had the lobster bisque which wasn't terrible but not great either.  A little too peppery and some pieces of what seemed to be dried fish.  I had ordered what I thought was the crab/shrimp cake appetizer but was brought the meal.  Since I hadn't actually looked at that part of the menu I didn't realize it wasn't the appetizer until I got the bill.  The crab/shrimp cake was adequate but there was too much filler for my taste.  The grilled potatoes and vegetables that came with the crab/shrimp cake were not warm.  Completely over-priced.

The service was glacially slow.

I will not return.

I think this place can do for a cleaning, some say it adds to the appeal, but you can get the same \"vibe\" without feeling like needing extra soap when leaving. Drinks are cheap and pretty strong for the price or at least what I expected. I went out on my own looking for chat with some new people to have drinks with and shoot the breeze but it seems like this place is full of groups of people not really into expanding outside of their clicks. Dive bar that will get a group of people drunk reasonably quickly. No music going on the night I went, so maybe I missed a lot of the appeal of it, I will re-visit and update if I feel it's needed.

Not pleased. 

Yes, they have good portions.  Yes, its cool they deliver and are open til 930 every night.  Yes, the receptionist can speak English, which is not a prejudice comment, just a general fact after calling literally 7 Chinese restaurants who could not understand a single word i was saying. 

But the food that I received was sub-par.  It just didn't have any flavor!  The pot stickers were way overdone and oh too crunchy on the outside with very little filling on the inside.  The lo mien noodles were...awkward.  Half were bunched together , some were overcooked, some were undercooked; the veggies were waxxy and the beef in it was overcooked and under seasoned.  Seriously you messed up lo mien???  The generals chicken was just OK, not horrible but I've had better.  

All in all a poor experience, so bad I didn't even bother with the leftovers, which is usually my favorite part of a good Chinese meal!

Stopped by here for lunch and started off with the crab mozzarella appetizer and the mushroom morel soup.  The crab mozzarella was pretty good and the mushroom morel soup was also very good.  The soup reminded me of the Cheesecake Factory mushroom soup but I still prefer the one from the Cheesecake Factory.  No reviews on the beer for now but if I ever go back and I'm off the meds I'll be sure to give it a go.

The baked seafood combo consisted of a couple of clams, a mahimahi fillet, scallops and stuffed shrimp.  I was not excited about the gooey imitation crab stuffing on the shrimp and both the mahimahi fillet and the scallops lacked seasoning.  The clams were OK.

For dessert we had the nutter butter ice-cream cake which was good.  Nothing too exiting about the food here.

Close to my humble abode, I opted to investigate this establishment once more. Upon entering, I was met with an underwhelming experience, as the bartender seemed to prioritize his personal electronic device over providing adequate customer service. Despite my eagerness to indulge in their offerings, I found myself having to plead for a beverage, the cost of which was $45. Perplexed by the lack of attention from the staff, I decided to depart, questioning whether any improvements would be made in the future. Unfortunately, based on past experiences, I harbor doubts about the likelihood of change.

"Although the pizzeria offered an adequate array of flavors and toppings, I was somewhat disenchanted by the limited number of non-fat options available, which seemed to be lacking in variety and depth, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction with the menu selections."

Being from the Midwest, I'd never had Del Taco. Can't really say I've missed anything: the bag probably had more flavor than the cold, limp fries and unmelted cheese on the all-lettuce \"chicken\" tacos.

"Upon perusing the reviews, I had anticipated a superior dining experience at this establishment. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, to say the least. The ambiance was not conducive to a pleasant dining experience, as it was a smoking environment, which proved to be a significant disappointment, particularly during dinner. The service was sluggish and lacked warmth, which further contributed to an unpleasant dining atmosphere. Our order consisted of cheese sticks, which were unimpressive and lacking in flavor, beer-battered pickles that were excessively greasy, and a BBQ chicken sandwich that was unfortunately overcooked, resulting in an inedible batter that was nearly burnt. Despite our attempts to salvage the sandwich by cutting and removing the batter, it proved to be a futile endeavor. The garlic Parmesan fries failed to deliver any discernible traces of garlic flavor. Ultimately, the dining experience was a disappointment, with my boyfriend opting not to consume his sandwich. The lone redeeming quality was the beer, which was quite satisfactory."

We went for sunday brunch , i like the fact they open at 7am, i figure everyone still sleeping nursing late night hangovers. I was right at 7 am only a handful of us old folks in line. . The buffet was very limited and not many items. For about 25 bucks a head you should get more. The hot foods were mostly breakfast items what happend to the lunch part of brunch. Very sad. Everthing was fresh as it should be since we were their early. Still can't believe a beautiful casino , ' upscale\" would have a brunch that was so simple. Spend a few more bucks and go to wynn, or bellagio.  Service was fine.

"A further gem in the Fox culinary diadem, boasting an extraordinary appearance and sensation, yet accompanied by exorbitant prices for fare that, while undeniably delectable, fails to justify the cost. In a recent visit, a member of our party opted for the prime rib French dip, to which the server inquired whether they desired mushrooms, peppers, or onions, to which my acquaintance responded affirmatively. Subsequently, they had the audacity to impose an additional fee of $2 per item, totaling $6, for what can only be described as meager embellishments. It is utterly preposterous; I could procure ten pounds of onions for a mere $2... Ultimately, I chose to share a chicken club and a minuscule cheese platter, accompanied by iced tea, amounting to a staggering $24. To compound the disappointment, the server exhibited a discourteous demeanor. In light of this experience, it is improbable that I would voluntarily frequent a Fox establishment again, unless presented with the occasional gift card."

My husband and I were so excited to see a trendy and family friendly restaurant pop up near our neighborhood we couldn't wait to try! We gushed over the decor for the entire time it took to get our wine (15 mins) which was sub par and room temperature. The menu was good, but only if you were on a \"cheat day\".  We ordered the only 3 healthy options on the menu and were VERY disappointed. The hummus app was the smallest portion of hummus we've ever encountered, but the stale pita chips were enough for a portion 10x the size.  My Caprese salad didn't feel fresh and his garden salad was blah.  Again we pondered, \"maybe we ordered wrong\" but come on, you shouldn't have ANYTHING on your menu if you don\"t stand behind it.  It was so disappointing that WE WENT TO ANOTHER RESTAURANT  AFTER ON A WORK DAY THAT CRAZY!!!    This place makes me soooooo sad because its the first trendy thing within 7 miles of our house! PLEASE PLAESE FIX THIS WE WILL BE REGULARS!

Service was slow and the burger came out on a soggy bun.  Asked for a fresh bun but took forever so ended up just eating the meat.  Also, the place was super hot.  Everyone at our table was sweating.  Maybe they were just having a bad night but I wouldn't go back to this place after this experience.

My husband and I came here right before seeing a movie. We chose it based on the fact it is right next to the movie theater. The staff was great, prompt with seating and taking our order. \nYummy watermelon margarita! The food...... Not so great. I got the chopped salad but couldn't eat more than two bites because the dressing was far too spicy. The waiter was nice enough to substitute my salad with a quesadilla, which was nothing great, but at least my mouth wasn't on fire. My husband got the rancho burrito which wasn't too bad. \nWhen we go back to the movies, we'll go somewhere else for dinner. I wouldn't suggest this place to anyone.

It's 7:30 am. Time for breakfast. Let's see... Hmmm... no eggs of any kind. Do I want a plate of sausage gravy or some turkey sausage? Maybe a banana that was ripe about 2 weeks ago. Maybe I can have both the gravy AND the turkey sausage...

After 10 minutes of this and watching Magdelina make sure that there were PLENTY of froot loops to go along with the over ripe bananas, the sausage gravy, and the turkey sausage,, I grabbed a cup of coffee and went on my way... Hungry.

There are literally HUNDREDS of hotels in Las Vegas. Stay elsewhere.

Huge rooms. Soft towels. Comfortable bed with tons of pillows.  
Three things that make me happy when I'm traveling.  

What's wrong with this place, then? First of all, the location is central to nothing aside from the mall which houses several chain restaurants.  Second, the staff could not care less about pretty much anything. While the woman who checked us in was helpful and friendly, that was the end of that. Despite requesting my Hilton status "amenities" (just a package of snacks and water...not much), I never received it.  I was also charged $30 for internet when I shouldn't have paid a thing (got the bill corrected at check out). And housekeeping didn't leave enough towels or replace the water.  

Considering we paid over $200 a night, the blase attitude of the staff is very disappointing.

When you enter the eatery and peruse the menu, you may perceive yourself in "Poultry Paradise," owing to the diverse array of flavors and seasonings available for your potatoes. Nonetheless, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. I opted for the chicken wing and strip combo, accompanied by a side of fries. The poultry was cooked to a golden, crispy texture and presented at an adequate temperature. My selection of garlic Parmesan was unfortunately overpowered by excessive saltiness. Furthermore, some pieces of my chicken were regrettably undercooked. Due to spatial constraints within the dining establishment, I was compelled to retrieve my meal for consumption elsewhere. Despite receiving mixed feedback, I remain open to offering Chicken Shack another opportunity to demonstrate their culinary proficiency.

"My acquaintance and I opted to utilize the recent $25 for $50 Groupon to experience Pewter Rose on a Saturday evening. Honestly, I considered the pricing to be somewhat steep for the ambiance presented, thus I was grateful for the voucher. Although the atmosphere was agreeable, I felt that the plastic tablecloths were incongruous with the menu prices exceeding $20 per plate. Notwithstanding this, the venue was teeming with patrons; we had booked a table for 8 pm and arrived punctually, and the hostess promptly seated us within five minutes. Our server, however, immediately intimated that we should anticipate a prolonged wait for our cuisine, given the high volume of clientele that evening. As we were not pressed for time, we acquiesced to the delay. Our server was attentive and maintained our hydration, but despite placing our order without delay, we did not receive our initial course until well after 8:30 p.m., and indeed, it was closer to 9:20 p.m. before we were served our main dishes. While the restaurant was bustling, it is not particularly expansive, which made the extended waiting period slightly unexpected. Personally, I relished the seafood risotto and would certainly partake of it once more. My companion had the herb-encrusted lamb, which was palatable, albeit a tad too salty for our taste. I might consider returning to sample their brunch, yet I would hesitate to pay the full tariff for an evening meal."

Not the first time and only because it's a party. Horrible service waiter picks up my salad plate take the knife off of it and places it on the table with a big wad of lettuce still on it. Appetizers where horrible I'm hoping I don't get sick from the mushroom caps, drinks where watered down. Main course wasn't so bad steak was ok but potatoes where cold and veggies had a horrible taste.  So many great places to eat in town and they pick this dump.

It took me more than 20 minutes to get my single to-go order at this location. On a thursday night when there was hardly anyone there this was ridiculous. The food was OK, I've had better Hawaiian BBQ in the valley for less money. At almost ten dollars for the whole meal, it was not worth the money. Fortunately they do have a smaller, less expensive portion that would fill most people up for lunch.

I like Durant's out of principle, but this is by no means a great restaurant by my estimation. The three separate times I've been were riddled with lackluster service, improperly prepared seafood, and meat with the wrong temperature (medium means medium, right? or has beef fallen into the \"rare is the new medium\" fashion continuum?). \n\nI remain altogether unimpressed. I would, however, hide here if the law was looking for me. It's just that kind of place.
While it wasn't 'bad', there are far better places to have an enjoyable meal in the area, even if you want to catch a game.  We went once.  We saw.  We haven't been back.

My boss asked for a referral for an interior designer to decorate our new office building so I reached out to the Yelp community and got turned on to Neilsen. I sent all the contact info on to my boss and she was thrilled that I had a referral for her so quickly! Brownie points for me! 

Nosomuch. While Nielsen might be extremely talented, his follow through and time management were less than adequate. He wouldn't return my boss' phone calls without her leaving him several messages, was 2 weeks late turning in his proposal, and would go out of town for weeks at a time without letting her know he was gone....I could go on and on, but really, I don't want to re-live the embarrassment again. 

I know there is the chance that perhaps there were some crossed circuits here, especially since there are so many positive reviews, but honestly, something was amiss with this experience and that's why the low marks (I don't give a lot of low marks normally and it pains me to do so).

I'm not saying don't use this company, because they are probably extremely talented, but I would evaluate the situation you're in before you recommend them to someone so you don't end up in the same predicament I am in.

I get really annoyed with these "fancy" hotels who don't offer the refrigerator and microwave in their standard rooms, which I can get at a Holiday Inn Express or a Comfort Inn for probably half the price.  

Also, for the love of all things holy, don't charge people for WiFi in 2011 after they already paid you an arm and a leg for a room that isn't worth it.  That is RIDICULOUS.

There's at least a half-mile walk (without a sidewalk) to anything except a small convenience store.

The room was comfortable enough, but no greater than any 3-star hotel I've ever stayed in.

I recently consumed a grilled cheese sandwich that was utterly devoid of any semblance of culinary expertise, with a solitary slice of cheese haphazardly placed upon the bread, failing to extend its melted tendrils to the edges of the bun, thereby creating an unfortunate visual representation of the lackluster quality of the dish; I must express my profound disappointment at the stark contrast between this uninspired creation and my previous experiences at this establishment, where the fare was not only palatable but indeed tantalizing, leading me to surmise that the current preparation of comestibles within these walls lacks the fervor and dedication that once characterized the culinary endeavors of the kitchen staff.

I'll be honest, I am hard on Tex Mex restaurants in the Burgh. I want so much to believe that I will find a place that does good tacos and I am disappointed over and over again. Here's the thing about tacos that no one in this city seems to understand: the tortillas are the part of the taco that touches the tongue first and will be the source of much of the mouthfeel that you experience while chewing.  (Yeah, I am a bit upset with myself for using the word \"mouthfeel\" but I wanted to use something besides \"chewiness\" and my thesaurus is out of reach).\n\nI lived in San Antonio for years before moving to Pittsburgh and in most of Mexico and Texas a \"taco\" is expected to be a soft tortilla (can be flour or corn) that is freshly made in house. A fresh tortilla makes a world of difference to the enjoyment of the taco. Some of my favourite tacos in the world are just plain, $1.50 tacos that are with some plain 'toppings' a good verde salsa, in a warm, fresh tortilla. I say all this because I think that Verde puts too much emphasis on the ingredients (Which are still under-spiced and boring with some store bought hot sauces on the table giving all the flavor) and then put those toppings into a boring, store bought tasting tortilla. So there you are spending $5 for a taco that's substantially underwhelming.

I liked the menu a lot and can tell that there is some serious potential here, but had a really bad experience. 

They couldnt help the obnoxious, loud, drunk group that came in, so I will give them a pass on that. 

But when my 1 pound burger came out, the fries were already cold. They seemed like they may have tasted pretty good if they had come out about 10 minutes earlier. 

Unfortunately they also forgot my biscuit until I mentioned it. They then brought it out and it was reallly dry. Again, seemed like it could have been better if it had been quicker. 

Again, I reallly wanted to like this place and was hoping to try a breakfast here before I left, but I'm really not sure I should risk it now. Bummer.

Alas, this place seems to be getting worse and worse over the years. I tried it again last week because it was Monday and Saigon Noodles was closed. I just wanted soup. I ordered the Tom Yum. 
It comes with a little salad. It was fresh and good but the dressing was pure sugar. My daughter had the chicken satay. The peanut sauce barely resembled peanuts. It was also really, really sweet and had a few peanuts in it. My soup was sour-- not that nice sweet/sour mix that is typical with Tom Yum-- just sour. It was edible though so I ate it.
To get in and out for under $20 was nice and the service was pretty good.
Bottom line: if you are on the West Side of Madison on a Monday and want soup... lower your standards and eat here. Otherwise, go to Saigon Noodle or (if you really, really need Thai food) head to Ha Long Bay on Willie Street.

Like many other reviewers said, this is basically an economy motel in the guise of a nice hotel.  The water came out so quickly in the shower that it couldn't drain fast enough and crawled up to ankle level. And there is no control to reduce the water pressure. Brilliant! Especially in these times of water shortages. I actually had them switch rooms because I thought my shower was busted, but the second room was no different and I see that other people here had the same issue.  No premium channels on TV. Like 15 bucks for internet service in the room and no wireless, just plug in with a tiny cord that can't even reach to the bed.  Their business center charged 8 bucks for 15 minutes of internet use!  And the customer service was beyond horrible. Everyone acted like they didn't want me to be there. You'd ask someone behind a desk a question and they'd just ignore you, as if pretending you weren't there.  Maybe an okay place to gamble at, but certainly not worth staying there. I've legitimately had better service at random cheap motels.  The only reason I'm not giving one star is because the room was clean.

If I were at the helm of an M&M store situated on the famed Las Vegas Strip, I would have implemented various innovative and attention-grabbing elements to create an immersive experience for patrons, including but not limited to:  

1. Complimentary samples of the iconic candy to entice passersby and lure them into the establishment.  

2. Life-size, huggable M&M characters strategically positioned throughout the store to engage customers and foster an atmosphere of whimsical delight.  

3. An interactive demonstration showcasing the unique attribute of M&Ms candies, specifically their ability to melt in one's mouth and not in their hands, even in the sweltering heat of the Las Vegas desert climate.  

4. A sleek and modern bar/lounge area, offering an assortment of candy-colored cocktails and specialty beverages, further enhanced by the novel incorporation of M&Ms as a visual element within the drinks themselves.  

5. A collaboration with Cirque du Soleil, featuring acrobats adorned solely in M&M-inspired attire, performing breathtaking feats amidst a visually stunning backdrop, all while maintaining a playful and lighthearted tone consistent with the M&M brand.  

6. High-stakes poker games, presided over by the aforementioned life-size huggable M&M characters, serving as both dealers and ambient decor.  

7. A section dedicated to adult entertainment, catering to diverse preferences and interests, with a subtle integration of M&M-themed elements to maintain a cohesive atmosphere.  

However, it appears that the current management of the M&M store on the Strip has chosen to adopt a different approach, focusing on more traditional merchandising methods, such as offering four levels of M&M-branded products for sale, a 3-D movie experience, and a guided tour, but regrettably omitting complimentary samples, which seemingly contradicts the essence of the M&M brand's playful spirit. This disconnect prompts me to ponder the rationale behind the store's presence on the Las Vegas Strip, as its offerings appear to diverge from the expectations typically associated with this famed destination.

Four (4!!!) overcooked shrimp on a whole shrimp po boy for 12 bucks?!? How can they serve this without being ashamed of themselves? Red beans n rice was average at best. Nothing close to authentic. Gumbo? Meh. Bland and boring.\n\nI will say though that the service was above average...though it didn't make up for NOLA's lazy take on Cajun cuisine. This restaurant wouldn't last a day in New Orleans.

"Positioned along the continuum of burgers, these offerings can be classified as relatively satisfactory. It is conspicuously superior to the fare offered by McDonald's or Burger King, although I Love Burgers might prefer their experience to be differentiated from that of fast food establishments, and thus, I shall refrain from drawing such comparisons. When evaluated against other upscale burger restaurants, however, I Love Burgers falls short of exceptional standards.

Commencing with the service, a brief delay ensued before securing a table, despite an abundance of unoccupied seats. While it is true that the venue was bustling with activity, a judicious allocation of seating and efficient management of waiting times could have facilitated a more comfortable dining experience. Moreover, the omission of fries from our order, despite their inclusion in the meal, necessitated a request for their delivery, exemplifying a lapse in attentive service.

Regarding the culinary aspects, the burgers, while palatable, fail to transcend mediocrity. My selection, the 'I Love Bacon Burger,' composed of a sirloin and applewood-smoked bacon patty, surmounted by crispy bacon, bacon mayo, gouda, and onion strings, satisfied my hunger, but its unremarkable quality precludes any compelling reason for future visits."

Been here 3 times. I must admit it is not so great and over priced. The service lacks but they are open late. On a sunday night when I rip off a nail before a big dinner meeting, they are open for a quick fix. I give them props for the crazy late hours but there would be no reason to visit them otherwise.  Last resorts and emergencies only.

All of our food had a hint of Italian seasoning, which was strange and unappealing.  The veggie enchilada is chock full of zucchini (the menu just said veggie, and I had anticipated the usual peppers and onions...if you love zucchini, get the veggie enchilada and a side of Mexican veggies - also just zucchini - unfortunately I really don't like zucchini!).  All around the place is nice, service was friendly, but the food just wasn't good.

This place is clearly very popular, it was filled the entire time we were there with many people who appeared to be regulars.  We went there for the veggie options.  The seitan appetizer was really good, and a huge portion, but the rest of the meal was not so great.\nThe service was kinda crazy.  Our waiter was nice, but pretty non-existent, and the rest of the staff seemed crazy and frazzled.

My boyfriend and I decided to go out to a late dinner at Hash House, service was okay.  The hostess were friendly and welcoming, but leaning on the host stand a little to much.  We had to order off the late night menu, I got the grilled cheese sandwich, It was decent.  Way to much tomato and only one big chunk of avocado.  It was thrown together and sloppy, hard to eat.  Mike was our server and was good. Took him about 15 min to get my strawberry lemonade margarita, but was a very good drink for only $8.  All in all it was a decent dinner but hope for better service and food next time.

I remember coming to this location with my family every time we were in Vegas. I wanted something cheap and delicious. I found the latter! 

Ordered the: 
* 1/2 Roasted Duck - It was actually quite good here but my boyfriend commented on the small portions compared to Cali Sam Woos. 
* BBQ Pork & Chicken Rice - Ahh tasted just like home
* Veggies (suggested seasonal veggies) - simply sautéed with some garlic & salt. Srzly can't go wrong. 

It was quite expensive here though - bill came out to be around $50 or so. I mean sure we ate for 3 MORE meals but....
AND it's cash only. 

I think I'm going to try Capital Seafood upstairs next time.

we went back out this weekend to get some more white balsamic vinager (it is realy good) and decided to have lunch this time.

The kids split a kids grilled cheese and liked it.

My wife had the antipasto.  she enjoyed it, but it was very small for $12 and had thress baguette sized slices of bread that were not toasted or warmed.

I had the Abrequine - sold as a roast beef panini but this sandwich never saw a panini press.  It was small and really need some kind of spread to add some flavor to it.  

the potato(e) chips were crispy but oily.

The kids like the gelato and I liked what I tried.

I picked up a bottle of the mexican lime olive oil, it is too fragrant and sweet.  The taste comes off as artificial/

  My wife like the spicy green beans and hte feta stuffed olives are ok.  Nice family trip ever 6 months or so but not a place to make a regular stop.

Because I stayed in Luxor, I ate here because of convenience.  I ate here 3 out of the 4 days.  For the most part, the sandwiches, soups, and salad was pretty good.  It's cafe food yanno?  However, the last day, the  drink server poured too much water in my teapot and when i barely moved it, it swished around and splashed on my leg!  It was so hot that i almost dropped the entire teapot of hot water on my leg but i managed to put it down.  \n\nI was hungover and tired and trying to eat something before I catch my flight out so I didn't complain, I just wanted an icebag so I don't blister.  Now here's the bad service part....i had to ask another waitress to find our waitress, our waitress had to call the manager, the manager had to call security.  When he finally came, i said i just needed a bag of ice.  I should've just took it up with the drink server, told her that she filled up the pot to the absolute brim, and had her get me a bag of ice from the kitchen.  oh well.

I have had the privilege of visiting this establishment on three separate occasions, with the most recent visit being motivated by my desire to sample their taco offering, thereby enabling me to provide a comprehensive assessment of the restaurant's culinary prowess.  Upon ordering, I was somewhat dismayed to discover that the taco in question was rather diminutive in stature, measuring a mere 3-4 inches in length, and lacking the crispy shell option which I had been anticipating.  Notwithstanding this initial disappointment, I must admit that the shredded beef utilized in the taco's composition was indeed of superior quality; however, considering the paltry sum of $2 requested in exchange for this item, I cannot help but feel that its value was not entirely commensurate with its cost.  During a subsequent visit, I opted to sample the fried fish dish, and I must confess that the end result was utterly unsatisfactory.  The fish itself was presented in an unfilleted state, with only half of the meat remaining attached to the bone, and the method of preparation employed seemed to consist merely of placing the fish in a fryer, sans any semblance of finesse or attention to detail.  Furthermore, the ambiance of the restaurant struck me as decidedly juvenile and aesthetically unpleasing, with certain aspects of the dÃ©cor bordering on the offensive.  In conclusion, while the service at this establishment may be deemed passable, the prices charged are hardly reasonable, and the cuisine, with a few notable exceptions, falls short of expectations.

Can't comment about too much yet , but one thing that bugs me is certain things at the school must be paid for online at the schools website, seems that they want the parents money so badly that all your information is there,all they need is your credit card number.They also charge a 90 cent fee to pay online,but you can only pay online,WTF?who gets this fee?if it's a convenience fee,I'd just send 15 bucks to the school,but you can only pay online so if the extort .90 per paying parent,sure it adds up.

Visiting Phoenix and noted the rave reviews on this place, so decided to try this on our way back to our hotel. When we came at around 8:30 PM on Friday night, there was only one other couple in front of us so we were served pretty quickly
Service: Only 2 people working. We were greeted immediately when we walked in, but I got the feeling that I was supposed to have known what I wanted at that time.  The employee who helped us was not super friendly, but maybe it had been a long shift or...?
Ice cream:  My husband got the TC^2 and the salted caramel, and I got the almond buttercrunch and apple cinnamon. I also sampled the honey blue cheese and the sugar and spice.  I didn't get much of the almond flavor out of the almond buttercrunch, but the other flavors were alright. The texture was not great - kind of icy, not very creamy for all the hype around this place.
Pricing: Reasonable.
If one is in the area and wants ice cream with "original" flavors for a decent price, might stop in. Otherwise, I would not recommend going out of one's way for the ice cream here. All-in-all my husband and I were non-plused (we're also spoiled by some really great ice cream in the SF bay area).

Nothing special, to be honest.  I am a huge supporter of small business owners. Sadly, Sonic has better tasting hotdogs and buns. Also his lemonade offered with special (says machine is broken, awaiting repair) is disgusting, watered down. Sadly, after all these years driving by... I know why I have not ever stopped in....and never will again.  :/

"The culinary experience was satisfactory, and the ambiance was engaging; however, upon consuming a single draught of my beverage, I detected an unpleasant metallic flavor and subsequently discovered an unsettling crunch between my molars. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that the beer contained shattered fragments of glass, which understandably elicited my indignation. Despite my attempts to bring this issue to the attention of the manager, he displayed a dismissive demeanor and implied that I was being dishonest, citing the lack of visible damage to the container as evidence. Notwithstanding the replacement of the contaminated bottle, no additional measures were taken to address the unfortunate situation or alleviate my discomfort."

If not for the delicious turkey crepe and cookies I would have given this one star. The service was horrible, the decor obnoxious and the cupcake desserts were, I kid you not,  4/5th icing (seriously gross).  Our waitress was no newbie, but maybe she had too many tables, maybe she wasn't too bright or maybe she was just so slow that she couldn't recall the order by the time she got to the computer. She totally forgot our appetizer and I appreciate the fact that she owned up to it twenty minutes later.  By the time our food finally arrived, the pasta was cold, but we were so hungry we didn't send it back.  Stick to the carry out desserts.

I hate the quality of tint used on my car. I had my previous car tinted years ago and it noticeably kept the heat out of my car to a more normal level.  I again chose a dark tint for my new car and everyday my car is EXTREMELY hot. It was not worth the hundreds of dollars since my car is still hot.  I'm not happy at all.!!!! It's as if I have no tint at all. If that's the case, what's the point??? I just wasted my money.

"The Flamingo exemplifies a bygone era in Las Vegas's history, serving as a tangible reminder of the city's rich heritage. Despite its venerable age, the hotel has managed to maintain its relevance, albeit in a somewhat anachronistic manner. While it may lack the glitz and glamour associated with contemporary Vegas establishments, the Flamingo's understated charm remains an enduring draw for those seeking a respite from the city's frenetic energy. Notwithstanding its relative dearth of modern amenities, the hotel's guestrooms are functional and comfortable, although some may find the absence of reliable cell phone reception in certain pool-facing accommodations to be inconvenient. Regardless, the Flamingo's proximity to other prominent Strip hotels renders it an ideal base for exploring the city's myriad attractions on foot."

Nothing about this hotel rises above mediocre. Rooms are aging fast and staff service is about what you'd expect  from a typical DMV. They may choose to do their job, but they definitely won't \"help\" in any sense of the word.\n\nThe whole hotel is about a decade and a half past it's prime (if it ever had one). I only stayed here because it was the designated lodging for a conference at the hotel. Never again.

"This gastronomical establishment has been my utmost preference for an extended period of time, specifically since my residency in this locale during the nascent stages of the twenty-first century; however, my most recent visit proved to be a letdown. 

The customary Cuban bread, a staple of their menu, was unavailable, yet the staff assured me that they could still prepare it upon request. Unfortunately, the resulting bread was conspicuously dissimilar, boasting an unacceptable density and an absence of the customary crispness associated with toasting. 

Furthermore, my selection of the bacon and cheese burger failed to meet my expectations, as the patty itself lacked flavor and texture. I did not complete the meal. The fries accompanying the dish were unremarkable, to say the least."

"Smoothie King bears an uncanny resemblance to a financially challenged Jamba Juice, evidenced by the throngs of patrons that crowded the establishment during my visit, which was further marred by a lackluster customer service experience characterized by inattentive and sluggish staff members who struggled to competently fulfill their responsibilities; furthermore, the layout of the store was illogical and nonsensical, leading to confusion and inefficiencies during the ordering process; additionally, when it came time to settle the bill, the individual tasked with processing our payment made an egregious error, erroneously charging us $18.00 for a mere two smoothies, which, despite the inconvenience, were of satisfactory quality, albeit not sufficient enough to warrant a future visit."

Came here for lunch. Masaman curry had tomatoes in it, so I ordered it without tomato (cause who has ever heard of masaman curry with tomato).

Order medium spice. It tasted bland. Dish had a lot of chicken, but barely any vegetables. I would have liked a better balance.

Soup was okay, as was the spring roll that came with the lunch special.

Peanuts in the masaman were raw. I had ordered extra peanuts, as I have had Masaman curry at a lot of places, and I love the cooked peanuts. The raw peanuts were a raw deal.

If you have time, head over a few miles to Chanpen Thai Cuisine. MUCH better quality food.

If you work nearby and need a quick bite to eat, the prices were reasonable and service was good. But there are better Thai places close by.

Had a decent enough experience buying the car, but the service department was another story when I went to get my accessories installed.  They forgot to tighten a hose after a routine install, and my car died while merging onto the freeway immediately afterwards, putting me into a dangerous position.  I was not offered any kind of compensation for my time since I live an hour away and had to make a second trip, the inconvenience, or the danger they put me in due to their complete negligence.  Not even an apology.   This doesn't bode well for my trust in their mechanics.

"The cost of the meal was exorbitant relative to the quantity and quality of the culinary offering, which was subpar. I opted for the Dan Dan noodles, priced at twelve dollars, inclusive of tax and gratuity. Unfortunately, the potency of the sauce's spices overwhelmed the flavors of both the shrimp and noodles, rendering them barely perceptible to my palate. While superior Asian cuisine may be procured at other establishments within the vicinity, this eatery represents the most suitable option for a rapid and convenient dining experience, provided one is willing to accept the compromise in gastronomic excellence."

If I had to sum up my meal in two words: odd brunch. I started the meal with a kugel & strawberries based on another yelper's review - ate almost the whole thing! Would def order it again or serve it for guests at a brunch. Yum. The matzo soup tasted OK, felt like it was surrounded by canned chix noodle (ala Cambell's) though. Entre was holishkes (bland cabbage rolls with chunky marinara sauce), the sides seemed like random afterthoughts and portion size was enormous. My daughter ordered the kid's mac & cheese with a side of applesauce (which is always served in a ridiculously tiny cup). The wait staff were friendly and accommodating. It can be overwhelming and claustrophobic on a busy night but Sunday night was as chill as it gets. Next time I'm sticking with my fave dish there: open-faced tuna melt. Can't go wrong there.\n\nThe menus just kill me... I have learned over the years how to navigate them quickly but seriously Restaurant Impossible needs to come in and revamp here! A simplified menu featuring well made dishes to compliment some home made ice cream would have an immediate positive impact. That and some cleaned up, contemporary, functioning decor would really breathe some life into this place! We'll never stop coming here but will enjoy it MUCH more with some improvements. I'm rooting for ya Ella's!

I have had the dubious pleasure of visiting this establishment on two separate occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been less than satisfactory. During my initial visit, I opted to situate myself at the bar and indulge in a few alcoholic beverages accompanied by a serving of nachos. While the service provided by the bartender was relatively prompt and amicable, the quality of the nachos left much to be desired, falling squarely within the realm of mediocrity.  
Upon my return, I was unfortunately subjected to an utterly disappointing dining experience. Our server, a veritable space cadet, displayed a complete lack of attentiveness and competence. Following a prolonged wait, she finally arrived with our water, only to disappear for extended periods of time, reappearing at irregular intervals to check on our progress. Furthermore, her ignorance regarding our beer order was nothing short of astounding. The food we received, arriving tardily, was also unimpressive, with the temperature being rather chilly, rendering it utterly unpalatable.  
It is worth noting that the same group of regular patrons was present during both my visits, their boisterous behavior and visible intoxication detracting from the already unpleasant ambiance. In light of these experiences, I would strongly advise against frequenting this establishment, instead opting for one of the numerous alternative bars in the vicinity.

I am not a big fan of seafood so it takes a lot to win me over.

I tried several of the dishes at Original Fish Market including the lobster bisque, the halibut, and the pork-chop with coleslaw.  The lobster bisque was bland and cold.  The halibut was decent.  The pork chop was so bitter and dry.

The whole atmosphere of the place seemed standoff-ish and was not friendly.  Furthermore, it took forever just to get our waitress's attention.  When we finally got her to look our way, she was short with us.  It was as if we bothered her.  I would rather go get sushi than spend more money here.

We went wIth a Groupon for our anniversary 11/11. Wanted Texas but it was booked. Thought we would try this one since its close to home. Salad bar was sad. Very small and food looked like it was out of cans and had been sitting out for awhile. Nothing like Texas and Via. My husband prefers meat well done, they offered to cook a little more. Meat came back just as rare. We asked for a coke, they brought a can with a glass of ice. Meat selection was limited and was ok. Got the bill, couldn't believe Coke was $3!! Prices for meal are pretty much the same as other places. We will make the trek to Via or Texas.

Food is good but service is awful!!! We went twice and each time it's the same thing, takes forever to get waited on, servers don't check back to see if you need anything and one time they took so long to wait on us that dim sum ended. Don't waste your time go to Changs on Decatur instead! I would not recommend unless you want subpar food at over the top prices.

So thank you groupon for saving me some money as this place is not worth the admission fee.  

I grew up in Seattle so aquariums and sealife are something I really enjoy and usually when traveling I like to go to them to see different regions sea creatures.  

Well that's the first problem Phoenix is a desert and I should know better than to go to an aquarium here but I was intrigued as it was new and I got a good deal on tix.  

The tanks were small and too many people in too much of a confined area for my liking.  I felt people were angry for you taking more than 30 seconds to look at something or take a picture.  

The talk times were a waste as they were all too crowded and you couldn't see anything.  There was one cool tank that had a second level to go above and look down on it which gave the best view in the place.  

Overall I say drive to California go to a real coastal aquarium and save your money.  Heck even go buy a DVD or something.

First of all, I REALLY want to like JJ's. They have a great concept, a cool and clever menu, and a good atmosphere. They seem to be really involved in the community and use and sell a lot of local products (Local Beer, King of Pops, etc.) 

We have been 3 times now, and really just find it to be sub-par for our expectations. We have tried various dogs and sandwiches. Most recently, we both had the "signature dog" with Chili, onions, beans, bacon, jalapeños and mustard. We found the Chili and beans to be lacking in any flavor whatsoever. The bun and hot dog were high quality, and the hot dog gave that nice "snap" when you bit in. Despite all of those delicious sounding ingredients, we found it to be a bit pedestrian. 


We also split a side of onion rings, which were greasy and flavorless. We each took a bite and decided to throw the rest away. 

Overall, just disappointed.  I hope in time, JJ's becomes the Charlotte institution that it could be.

"The Excalibur Roundtable buffet elicited a sense of familiarity akin to that of a cafeteria-style eatery, which served as the backdrop for my critical assessment of its offerings, specifically pertaining to the morning repast. Frugality being a virtue, we opted to capitalize on a dual-benefit coupon, thereby reducing the tariff to a mere $9 per person. 

My consternation regarding the edibles was rooted in their lackluster quality, as they exhibited an unfortunate tendency towards desiccation and an unpleasant soddenness. The culinary selections, encompassing the customary breakfast items, were regrettably devoid of freshness. Such deficiencies precluded me from partaking in additional helpings. A dedicated area showcasing sweet treats, including pastries and donuts, proved underwhelming, inspiring a dismissive attitude. 

A silver lining emerged in the form of our server, whose endearing efforts to elicit mirth proved successful. 

In response to a remark posted below, it is indeed true that large-scale food production does not inherently imply mediocrity. Numerous buffets excel in providing exceptional cuisine. It is advisable to explore such establishments and avoid this particular venue."

"Encountered a predicament pertaining to the return of a gift item received during the festive season, specifically pertaining to the absence of a price tag, which led to a refusal by the retail staff to offer in-store credit, despite the fact that the identical item was prominently displayed on the shelf, thereby necessitating the involvement of the customer service department, whereupon the issue was successfully resolved through the diligent efforts of the corporate customer relations team, thereby warranting a positive rating, albeit with a slight deduction due to the initial inconvenience caused by the price tag-related debacle."

This was sad sad place. Even being the weekend the place didn't have many patrons. Maybe it was one of those off weekends but since were told that we are on the guest list and thus won't have to pay any cover so we said why not. Went in and saw some go go dancers but that just about it. We had a beer and after  that bolted out of there in less than 30 minutes.

*bed bugs* Stayed here for a conference this week. The place is big and they seem to have nice pools and lounge areas, however, our room smelled bad... Like musty and also like smoke. I really was unhappy with the smell. My girlfriends and I stayed in two separate rooms. After the first night one of my gf's woke up with 6-7 bites and was left uncomfortable and itching the entire trip. The second night of our stay ( i was staying in a different room) I was also bit! I went to sleep fine and woke up with two bites on my ankles. Just a side note, we never had the doors open and we were in two separate rooms.  We both sleep with the blankets covering us as well so I have determined that this is most likely a bed bug issue. My last night I was bit again twice and now I'm home and happy to be here. I am frustrated though that I am itching like crazy, just felt dirty yuck! I gave two stars because the facility is nice, but I don't think getting bit is acceptable.

First and foremost, it is imperative to acknowledge that this particular establishment is not a traditional Costco, but rather a specialized "business center." This distinction is crucial, as it significantly impacts the products and services offered, and thus, it is essential to emphasize this point to avoid any potential disappointment or confusion among patrons.  

In light of this, it is relevant to highlight that this specific Costco does not sell alcoholic beverages, which may come as a surprise to some individuals who are accustomed to purchasing such items at other Costco locations. Furthermore, there is no food court available on the premises, which may also be a departure from the typical Costco experience that some customers are familiar with. However, it is worth noting that this absence is compensated by the abundance of exceptional dining options and buffets in the surrounding area, which can easily satisfy any culinary cravings.  

This particular Costco focuses primarily on providing an extensive selection of snacks and beverages, intended for the purpose of restocking vending machines. In fact, they even offer vending machines for purchase, which speaks to the unique nature of this business-oriented store. One redeeming quality of this establishment is the diverse array of beverages available, ranging from juices, sodas, sparkling water, cider, and more, which is undoubtedly impressive.  

Unfortunately, this Costco falls short in terms of staffing, with relatively few employees present, and those who are on duty often appear uninformed about various aspects of the store's operations. For instance, upon inquiring about the availability of coupon books, a staff member incorrectly directed me to the guest/member service desk, only to discover that they do not, in fact, accept coupons at this location.  

In conclusion, given the distinct characteristics of this Costco "business center," it is advisable to carefully consider one's shopping needs before visiting, and perhaps opt for a different location, such as the Costco in Los Angeles, before embarking on a trip to Las Vegas.

How frustrating!

Best part of today's lunch was service - Anthony, originally from Astoria Queens NYC, has been here for 8 months, sounded exactly like he should sound with the NY accent, serving in an Italian restaurant!  He was helpful, attentive, interactive and one of the best servers I've had in this city.  He also brought a sample of the soup of the day to the table for tasting prior to ordering.  Very attentive service - bravo, Anthony!

Food?  Very mixed reviews.  The tilapia special was thoroughly enjoyed by both diners at our table who ordered it.  Note to kitchen - the portion sizes on the two plates was noticably different (although the smaller portion did happen to go to the lighter eater so it wasn't a problem).  If the same dish is going to two people at the same table, they plates should look alike!

I started with the minestrone soup (a menu staple) and while the flavor was good, it was tepid when served.  Made me sad.  My meatball sandwich was also a bit lukewarm and heavy on the salt.  It just didn't taste as fresh as I wanted.

This lunch was a birthday celebration so the lemon cookies with two dramatic candles was a very nice end to the meal.  And the cookies were great - not too sweet, enough lemon flavor without being bitter and enough to share around the table.

Note on the door says that as of Feb 1, this will be a smoke free establishment.

"The erstwhile charming ambiance of this establishment has been obliterated by the recent renovation, leaving an aesthetic vacuum that is utterly devoid of character and personality. The utilitarian inclusion of bulky, dark wooden chairs only serves to exacerbate the dearth of comfort and elegance, while the absence of sufficient upholstery and fabrics further contributes to the overall sense of starkness and severity. Notwithstanding the abundance of natural illumination and lofty ceilings, the space remains aesthetically unappealing, a state of affairs that could potentially be rectified by the judicious deployment of vibrant Mexican ceramics. The incongruous presence of a conspicuous cross-shaped arrangement of wooden planks and exposed metalwork evokes a jarring sense of dissonance, eerily redolent of Nathan Lane's garish abode in the film adaptation of The Birdcage. Laughter ensues.

Notwithstanding these aesthetic shortcomings, the venue remains suitable for small-scale nuptial celebrations, accommodating up to 150 guests within its expansive confines. A centrally positioned dance floor facilitates convivial merriment and communal revelry.

Regrettably, the culinary offerings fail to match the promise of the establishment's refined decor. Rice, once a staple of Latin American cuisine, has been reduced to an insipid, flavorless substance, devoid of the rich, savory essence that defines its very purpose. Beans, too, have suffered a similar fate, their natural zest and vitality supplanted by an uninspired, unremarkable taste.

Furthermore, the table salsa, ostensibly crafted from canned tomato sauce, pepper seeds, basil, and a hint of sugar, bears a closer resemblance to marinara than salsa, thereby betraying the expectations of discerning patrons who seek a genuine, spicy experience. Guacamole, once a proud symbol of Mexican gastronomy, has been debased by the incorporation of cottage cheese, an ingredient that not only undermines the authenticity of the dish but also imparts an unpleasant texture and consistency. Chili colorado, a dish historically renowned for its bold, fiery flavors, has been reduced to a bland, uninspired concoction, lacking the very essence that gives it its name.

Incongruously, the cost of such unimpressive fare remains stubbornly high, while the quality of service, regrettably, leaves much to be desired. Patrons encounter sluggish, unhelpful attendants, whose indifference and apathy only serve to compound the disappointment engendered by the food and ambiance.

Yet, amidst this litany of disappointments, one item stands out as a beacon of hope, a shining exemplar of culinary excellence: the cheese crisp, priced at a reasonable $9, offers a satisfying crunch and a delightful blend of cheeses that, momentarily, transcends the surrounding mediocrity, providing a fleeting glimpse of gustatory nirvana."

"Having opted to lodge at the Sunset Station, which, incidentally, surpassed my expectations considerably, I found myself unaccompanied during the evening hours, as Gus had arranged to convene with several acquaintances for dinner. In light of this, I chose to procure sustenance and transport it to my lodgings, and, after perambulating the vicinity a couple of times, I settled upon Fatburger as my culinary destination.

Upon entering the establishment, I encountered a youthful female who demonstrated considerable amiability towards each patron, taking my order with alacrity and assuring me that the onion rings, as indicated by the signage, were indeed of superior quality. Thus, I opted to sample both the burger and the aforementioned onion rings, in addition to a shake, out of curiosity regarding the veracity of the sign's claim.

However, upon receiving my order in a remarkably brief span of time, I was thoroughly dismayed to discover that the burger was an unpalatable, amorphous mass, devoid of any discernible flavors, and the onion rings, unfortunately, lacked even a modicum of zest. The shake, while not utterly devoid of taste, failed to impress me profoundly.

Subsequently, the recollection of this experience resurfaced when the suggestion to visit a Fatburger was broached, prompting an involuntary shudder and a fervent resolve to avoid such an establishment in the future."

Not what I expected.  Food was good, but nothing special.  Portions seemed small.  I really did not expect the stand in line to place your order, go find a seat and wait for someone to bring your food, and then you never get spoken to again. Reminds me of McDonalds.  We got Thai Dynamite, which sounds spicy, but was bland, and sesame chicken, which was so so.\nWhile we were there, we saw someone spill a large amount of salt or sugar on the floor right by a door.  Saw a server going out the door about fall, and then 4 employees walk by it before it got cleaned up around 5-10 minutes later.  Lawsuit waiting to happen.\nDon't think we'll go back :(

I came to check this place out because it had four stars on yelp and my boyfriend and I were in the mood for Mexican food. I ordered the green chili plate and my boyfriend got the carne asada burrito and we shared the menudo. I was expecting the food taste more authentic but when we got our food, it was bland and not very tasteful. We felt like we could have just gone to Filerberto and got better food. The only thing good about this place was our food came out fast and the person who took our order was nice. Other then that, I will not be coming back to eat here. We left very unsatisfied!

"Let me yelp this place really quick.." I said to my friend before we came in. What a mistake it was to give up that idea.

As you walk in, the place is clean and cosy. Service is fairly prompt, even though there was only one waiter working during lunch time.

I had a fish burrito that arrived ~15 minutes after ordering. It consisted of undercooked rice, a pinch of vegetables, and fried breaded shoe sole for a fish. Honestly I once had a better fish burrito at Del-Taco across the street.

My friend had chicken sizzling fajita, which was rushed in sizzling and smelling pretty good. Unfortunately, it lacked flavor and had the same undercooked rice and 97 year-old salad for sides. The guac and sour cream were fresh, though.

Worth noting is that the salsa was pretty good, full of flavor with just the right bite of hotness. So if you're looking for some chips/salsa and beer, go for it. Otherwise, don't do this to yourself.

We had their special Tomahawk steak $98, Glazed Sea Bass $39, sides with asparagus $14, and hand cut fries $12. We don't eat our food bland, in fact slightly on the salty side, but all the food here was just a bit too salty. It will definitely spike your blood pressure. The best part of this experience was the ambiance. Definitely chic and their bathroom is really different.

"My affection towards the apparel offered by this establishment is juxtaposed by my utter disdain for the service provided by its employees. It appears that an inordinate number of errors occur during my visits, with today's experience being particularly egregious. Upon presenting five items at the checkout counter, I discovered upon returning home that one item was missing. This managerial malfeasance was perpetrated by a junior manager who, after a ten-minute duration of fumbling and blatantly disregarding my queries, ultimately managed to process the transaction. My ire towards the necessity of revisiting this store is palpable."
Prices are fair but 45 minutes to wash and vac my car? That's a little much. Undecided if I'll be a returning customer.
Average food.  Great concept and enjoyed my first visit.  However, the only really good item is the Red Jade Chicken.

"Extremely sluggish, even in the absence of an abundance of patrons, and utterly chaotic, this establishment exhibits a palpable lack of efficiency, rendering it arduous for clientele to effectuate transactions expeditiously; furthermore, the utilization of the Starbucks application as a means of payment is unfeasible, as staff members are compelled to manually input the requisite numerical information, thereby exacerbating the already prolonged duration of the purchasing process."

I arrived at this establishment in the company of my parental units prior to attending a performance of Zumanity, primarily due to the fact that it did not possess a waiting period. In retrospect, it would have been more judicious to await a brief interval before being seated elsewhere.

BEVERAGES:
I requested a glass of Sangiovese, a wine that I typically relish. However, on this particular occasion, I did not even desire to complete the consumption of the beverage. My maternal figure acquired a mixed drink infused with limoncello, which was not particularly unpleasant.

OVERALL: B

CULINARY OFFERINGS:
I opted for a bowl of soup and a specialized salad, consisting of cucumbers, "fresh" tomatoes, onions, red vinaigrette, and feta. Unfortunately, the salad was rather unpalatable. Initially, I presumed it contained marinated tomatoes, but upon further inspection, I deduced that it had simply been stored in a refrigerated state for an extended duration, as the tomatoes were unpleasantly cold. I merely picked at it without consuming it.
My maternal figure chose the rare veal, priced at over $30, yet she, too, barely partook of it, owing to the fact that it was excessively marinated, resulting in a lingering vinegar flavor. As an individual who greatly enjoys the consumption of red meat, even I did not find it appealing, thereby indicating that my maternal figure was not simply being fastidious.

OVERALL: D

SERVICE:
Our server did not inquire about our satisfaction with the meal until we had nearly completed consuming it, approximately thirty minutes later. Upon recognizing our discontent with the cuisine, she summoned one of her supervisors, who extended an offer to provide us with an alternative dish. Given that we lacked sufficient time to sample another offering, they elected not to charge us for either the salad or the veal.

OVERALL: C

Food was average, waitress was the worst.

We had 4 people in our party. 3 of us had failrly good meals my son however ordered the Philly ckeese steak which was a soggy mess. We thought about sending it back but the waitress never came back to ask how everthing came out. When the waitress did come back she just went through the motions of being a server she truly didnt care and should find a new line of work. My son ordered water, she forgot.. 

I will not be back on our next visit to Vegas...

Slow service and 15-20 for mediocre philly cheese steaks.  Sandwiches and fries do not have a lot of flavor.  Also the televisions are blaring loud, if you have sensitive hearing beware.  Seating is limited.

Avenue Q was brilliant.  Keep in mind, however, that Avenue Q comes with a traveling cast.

The Gammage Auditorium itself?  Not impressed.

From the outside, yes, it looks really cool. Some of the lights are out, but over all, it looks really cool from the outside.

Inside? It's a bit outdated. The bathrooms are gross, and half of the floors are completely handicap inaccessible. Of course, they don't tell you this when you get your tickets.  We showed up, and asked where the elevator was. Rudely, we were told there wasn't one, and if I had wanted accessible seats, I should have bought full priced orchestra ones.  I walk slowly and with a cane, and while I can handle a few stairs when I must, the 2.5 flights of stairs nearly killed me on the way up, and then I didn't go to the restrooms when I wanted too at intermission, because there was no way in hell I would have walked back up there.  I almost burst into tears as it was.

I then had to rinse and repeat to get down at the end.  Again, multiple flights of stairs, people pushing me, and rude ushers chiding me for not buying outrageously priced orchestra tickets which were accessible.  Way to be classist AND ableist at the same time.

Funny, isn't it, that such a tongue in cheek commentary on discrimination should be held at a place that both architecturally AND verbally discriminates?
Waited an hour and was disappointed by the food.. I had banana pancakes and a breakfast skillet.  The pancakes were chewy.  The skillet had no flavor.

Mid Town Pub has been a frequent haunt but am going to have to find a new spot. A few weeks ago I ordered  the chicken cordon bleu sandwich. I was served another menu item that was chicken served with mounds of jalapeños. When I pointed out the error, they quickly replaced it... With the same sandwich sans jalapeños and added ham. Chicken was still steeped in jalapeño flavor. I didn't eat it but was charged for it.

 Wanted to give the kitchen another chance on a recent visit and was served yet another in edible sandwich. It was so salty and pepper ladened that the first bite was my last.

This kitchen needs some guidance! Adios mtp!

During our brief sojourn at this establishment, my spouse and I had the pleasure of occupying a luxurious suite that offered a panoramic view of the interior courtyard. Unfortunately, our stay was marred by the cacophony generated by the delivery trucks and tour buses that converged on the premises at an ungodly hour, creating a racket that was nothing short of deafening. Moreover, we were dismayed to discover that the suite was bereft of even the most basic utensils, including spoons and bottle openers, which made it challenging to enjoy our complimentary continental breakfast. However, the piece de resistance was the nightly happy hour that took place in the expansive breakfast room from 5:30 pm to 7:30 pm, during which time complimentary cocktails and light beer were served to a motley crew of mostly elderly patrons who seemed to be taking advantage of the libations to medicate themselves for the evening ahead. The scene was both amusing and surreal, as my wife and I observed the throngs of seniors shuffling around the pool table with their tiny plastic cups of cocktails or light beer, creating an atmosphere that resembled a nursing home on steroids.

I agree with another reviewer that it is a well intentioned concept.  Decor and atmosphere was, clean, comfortable and inviting.  Service wasn't great, but was OK.  If the food was better I would plan a return trip, but it was unfortunately not good.
