Subsequently, we endured an extended period of waiting, which ultimately resulted in our being seated and enjoying a satisfying culinary experience, both in terms of the quality of the food and the ambiance. However, fast forwarding to my second visit, which took place this evening, proved to be a vastly different story. Having secured a reservation for 5:30 PM, specifically to commemorate a birthday celebration, we were apprised at 7:09 PM that our table was required for another patron, despite the fact that we had explicitly reserved it for the entire evening. Not only was this an egregious breach of business etiquette, but it also contravened the fundamental principles of customer satisfaction. Furthermore, the fact that we were celebrating a milestone occasion and had been accorded a complimentary birthday surprise for the honoree only served to exacerbate the situation. While the cuisine itself was generally satisfactory, with my tenderloin tips being slightly over-salted yet still palatable, and the key lime pie eliciting praise from my fellow diners, the overall experience left much to be desired. In light of these events, I am left feeling utterly perplexed as to why such an esteemed establishment would deliberately jeopardize its reputation by alienating loyal patrons in such a manner. Suffice it to say, I shall not be returning to this restaurant in the future."

Chez ma grosse truie cherie was not really on my list of must try Montreal's restaurants. I ended up here because with a group on 5, it was not easy to get a reservation on a busy Saturday night. This restaurant seems to catered to large groups with communal tables and family style menu, which seems to be well suited our party of five.

Service was attentive and excellent. I wish the food can match the service. 

We shared: 

Oysters ($15) - Apple ice cider vinegar from Vergers de la Colline
- Not bad, I had better oysters..

Chef Choice Seared Foie Gras ($23)
- The best part of the meal... I would just come back to have that
- Love how the sourness of the fresh grapes compliment the fattiness of the foie gras
- No sharing! All mine!

The Whole Hog ($32/pp) - Baby back ribs, smoked grilled pork chop, braised shanks, braising juices and parmesan cheese French fries 
- The platter looked amazing for photos but most of the meat tasted bland and dry
- The only thing I enjoyed was the shank which was tender and moist
- I did enjoy the roasted vegetables... 

The only saving grace might be some local beers in bottles... Dieu du Ciel did make the dining experience a little more enjoyable.

Sadly I doubt I will be coming back again really soon...... unless I can have that foie gras all for myself!

"The culinary offerings were of satisfactory quality, however, our server, Maggie, displayed a remarkable lack of acumen and social grace, leading to an unfortunate series of events that ultimately resulted in a successful resolution through my personal intervention and discourse with the proprietor, yet, unfortunately, my dining experience was irrevocably tarnished, thereby precluding any future visits to the establishment."

People throng this establishment, as evidenced by the capacity crowd on a Thursday evening, compelling us to dine in the bar area to circumvent an approximate delay of twenty minutes for a table. The prices listed on the menu are exorbitant, rendering our dining experience financially untenable, save for the fortuitous possession of a $50 gift card. Our desire to partake in a shared culinary experience accompanying our alcoholic beverages proved futile due to the waitstaff's inability to proffer any gluten-free options with certainty. Thus, I consumed the complimentary bread and butter, followed by our ordering of dessert - his, an ice cream sundae, and mine, a lemoncello raspberry cheesecake, albeit unimpressive in taste, prompting me to consume only a few bites, cognizant of the unnecessary caloric intake. Our total expenditure, inclusive of three mixed drinks (a mojito for myself and two gin and tonics for my companion) and the aforementioned desserts, amounted to $45, which we deemed excessive. Notably, the gratis bread proved the most satisfying aspect of our dining experience, while the quality of service we received fell short of expectations.

Firstly, this establishment exudes an ambiance reminiscent of a national chain franchise, complete with staff who appear to be feigning enthusiasm in accordance with their prescribed guidelines. Notwithstanding, the culinary offerings, specifically the burgers, are of satisfactory quality, albeit the standard iteration boasts two patties while the diminutive version consists of a solitary patty. Furthermore, the fresh-cut fries merit high praise, perhaps ranking among the finest in Tempe. While we may consider returning, it is unlikely that we would venture out of our way to do so.

The rooms are very nice, clean and comfortable. 

Family above us was very loud, early in the morning I could hear them eating stomping on the floor.arguing...chairs sliding etc.. really took away from the experience.,

We were in the Lily building right behind the office. The parking was horrible, there were never any spots near the building open. Had to dump the in-laws on the curb since they are not able to walk so much. Then Id drive around praying for someone to leave. the casino next door was closer than the parking garage to our building.

WiFi is an issue too.. 40 bucks for the week on 1 device.. gosh every hotel we were at on our trip had free WIFI but not the most expensive.. .. I only pay 19.99 a month at home.

One of my guests was approached at check in to do the time share presentation. The lady started filling out a form for him for the next morning and he said he may not be able to go but would try, she rudely asked him if he was going or not? He told her he didnt know, she tore up the slip and said never mind have a nice day.. REALLY??? Welcome to Vegas!

My wife goes here ever chance she get, but I refuse to go with her. Coffee deserves 5 stars but the chick behind the counter is so rude. I refuse to spend money at a place that lets it indie hipster staff treat regular Joe's like my self rudely.
We have been here 3 times, and the service has been bad every time. The view is AMAZING, but because of the poor service we will not return.

Had dinner there last week ...... went there with great anticipation because of its legendary status in New York ....... mildly disappointing but easily correctable .... the place itself is fun ... its old-timey Italian restaurant decor with all the celeb photos hung on wall ... very professional and most attentive service...... good food but not great ...... seems like the kitchen is trying to '' play it safe'' and the result is a very ample portion of just slightly above average entrees ...... my veal dish was good but not as good as I had hoped based on the Rao's reputation ( hype ? ) .... so they have a nice,fun setting,great servers and decent offerings but if they really got into that kitchen and tweaked their prep a bit ...... they'd improve on a product that is just a tad on the bland side. I hope they address this as it is a fun restaurant with good personnel .

Meh. Sure, the hot dogs are good, and you can get it piled with toppings. But it's quite expensive for what you get!\n\nAnd I was really excited to see they had Poutine on the menu, as my Canadian brethren had told me legends about the stuff. But I came away a little disappointed. Guess I'll have to wait until I end up in Quebec to try it again!

My principal annoyance with this aerodrome is the indispensable utilization of a tram, which must be boarded each time, an inconvenience that is particularly vexing in light of the fact that SFO, a comparably sized airport, does not necessitate such a conveyance.  Moreover, while awaiting my return flight, I had the misfortune of being subjected to an excessively loud and distorted public address system in the vicinity of gate D1, the cacophony of which was further exacerbated by three prolonged and piercing horn blasts, an assault on the auditory senses that prompted me to shield my ears, along with numerous other passengers, from the sonic onslaught.  It is mystifying that the airport staff appears to be either oblivious or impervious to this egregious infraction, a state of affairs that raises questions regarding their attentiveness to the comfort and well-being of their patrons, particularly when juxtaposed with their stringent adherence to policies regulating the transportation of certain beverages onboard aircraft.  Furthermore, I find it curious that the cost of a taxi journey to a hotel is $25, whereas the fare for a trip to the airport is a mere $15, despite the fact that both destinations are effectively equidistant.

Yesterday, I visited this establishment and unfortunately had a subpar experience compared to my previous visits to other Yard House Restaurants. Upon arrival, we were promptly seated, which merited a positive assessment of one star. Our server approached us in a timely manner, and we placed our orders, consisting of a lunch special featuring pizza and tomato basil soup, a children's meal accompanied by pizza and vegetables, an ahi appetizer that served as a main course rather than an introductory dish, and a beer that required an excessive amount of time to be delivered to our table, allegedly due to a keg replacement process. Following a ten-minute delay, the beverage was finally presented to my cousin. Subsequently, we awaited the arrival of our culinary selections, enduring an extensive period of time before their presentation. Fortunately, I had prepared snacks for my three-year-old child, which helped to pacify him during the prolonged waiting period. When the food was eventually served, the cheese on the pizza appeared aged and desiccated, suggesting that it had been exposed to the heat lamp for an extended duration. We sampled a few bites before shifting our focus to the soup, which my child and I essentially shared due to its delectable quality, earning it an additional star. Ultimately, we discarded the remaining pizza slices since they failed to meet our expectations in terms of taste and quality.

"Wait, wait, wait; this establishment is still in operation? Perchance my incredulity stems from the notion that a venture of this caliber could continue to flourish within an economic climate seemingly designed to foster exclusively the prosperity of a select few. However, upon further deliberation, it appears that my consternation is rooted in the enigmatic nature of this enterprise's conceptual framework. Specifically, the dichotomy between the tangible aspects of 'Air,' 'Earth,' 'Fire,' and 'Water' and their abstract representations within the context of this venue eludes my comprehension. Furthermore, the juxtaposition of such elements with the opulent decor and extravagant prices serves only to exacerbate my perplexity. Alas, my limited understanding of fiscal dynamics and entrepreneurial acumen renders me incapable of fully grasping the intricacies of maintaining a business of this caliber. Nonetheless, I must commend the investment evident in the initial stages of this undertaking, as well as the ostentatious elevator leading to the exclusive VIP area; an eccentric display of luxury, indeed."

"Forty-five minutes of waiting, instead of the twenty minutes promised, to indulge in an outdoor dining experience, only to be greeted by an excessively boisterous ambiance, marked the beginning of an underwhelming adventure. The assertion that they served the best pizzas in Montreal initially piqued my interest, but alas, the culinary offerings failed to live up to expectations. The chef's pizza lacked any semblance of flavor or originality, much like the uninspired pasta dish ordered by one of my companions, which was submerged in a bland and insipid sauce. An exorbitant price tag only further solidified my decision to award a paltry two stars, with the sole redeeming quality being the agreeable terrace area. In conclusion, this establishment is best avoided by those who harbor even a modicum of appreciation for authentic Italian cuisine."

The exact definition of two stars: MEH. I'VE EXPERIENCED BETTER.

As for someone who LOVES Korean BBQ and always eats it every other week, I do not recommend this place for KBBQ. I've been to many KBBQ places, but I have never seen KBBQ to be $30+. It's not very surprising that this place would be $$$, I mean almost everything on the Strip is PRICEY. Since $30 for a very small portion of kogi was definitely out of the question, I decided to order dolsot bimbimbap instead. This dolsot bimbimbap was the most expensive I have ever paid for. There's nothing special about this place. I'm giving it two stars because the food was descent and the waitress was nice enough to be honest about size portion of the KBBQ meat.
Never again.

There are two types of people who are patrons of this establishment: the elderly and people with free passes.  We had free passes.

My fiance's work gave him two sets of Regal movie tickets.  That would be great back in Seattle where the company is because Regal's are all over.  Here, however, there are only two theaters in the Regal family and this is one of them.  The other is on Northsight somewhere.

We saw a 645 movie and it was all old folks.  Even with them, the place was deserted!  There is one guy working concessions (with his first AND last name on his name tag - I thought that was a little weird...), one chick in the ticket booth, and that's about it.

The actual theater was even worse.  The screen wasn't all that large, the sound was awful, and it was an "old school" theater.  I consider a "new school" theater to be one with stadium seating.  This theater you actually walked uphill when walking towards the screen.  Sounds backwards to me!  It actually might have been worse than a regular "old school" theater.  If we hadn't had free passes, we would have left.  Instead, we stayed and toughed it out.  

I guess we'll venture to the Northsight location for the other two tickets.  I thought most of Scottsdale was upscale with a lot of folks around, not scarce and geriatric like Sun City.  I am no longer wondering why no one has reviewed this place - it needs to be put out to pasture!

This is NOT a 3 star hotel/resort. It is a 2 at best. The rooms smell musty, the interior and linens are not clean, and the entire place just looks worn out. Maybe back in the day it was something more but not now. The beds were lumpy and the linens were of questionable cleanliness which made me look for bed bugs - which there were none although there some type of small critter in the tub. On the plus side, the Speakman shower heads are great as was the water pressure and hot water.  Still, not a place to which I will return.

So we were back on this side if town and excited to have an excuse to return. Hate to say it but we were disappointed. Zucchini fingers were not crisp. They actually bent in half when you picked them up. Also, they no longer serve them with tatziki (sp?) sauce but will charge you $1 extra for a really small container. Um, isn't that like going to an American diner and being charged extra for ketchup?  Also, the zucchini desperately needed salt. 

My beef and lamb gyro was ok. A little dry. Hubby had their famous Oscar burger that comes with pastrami on it, which was dry. 

The little salad that came with the meal seemed to have a cup of dressing on it. Yikes!

Sorry to say but won't be stopping by again. Better Greek food at Stephanos which is closer to us anyway.

Speak up if you want a drink before you've dropped $300 in the machines. It's pretty hard to get served. -especially after 10pm, even if its not busy. When you do get your drink, you may want to order a double b/c it's gonna be a short jigger of whatever you ask for. \nThe only reason I give this the 2 stars is because they have a really great \"Rooster\" salad.\nUnfortunately most of the regulars don't seem like the kind of people that eat much. They seem more like the kind of people that took a break from feverishly cleaning their grout & thought they would take their teeth grinding out in public... Very intense. Lol

They ought to consider incorporating the flies as a culinary option on their menu, as our dining experience during the afternoon hours was significantly impaired due to an excessive number of airborne pests, which rendered the food essentially unpalatable; thus, it is advisable to prepare oneself for such eventualities.

I was sadly disappointed, after reading all the excellent I thought it was shoe in. not so much. Long wait for food then it was just ok. Id rather pay more for food that tastes amazing and doesn't take forever to get.

I was a skeptic of this chemist of brew.

Needless to say, I wasn't too far off.  This is great for a night out with the boys to watch the game.  That's all I can say since I wouldn't recommend coming here to chat.  

I ordered me a beer and some fried fish and chips.  I don't like soggy food, but I guess that's how it comes here.  The fried fish was laid on top of my garlic fries, which were way greasy.  As the fish and fries came together it was a hot soggy mess.  I might want to add tasteless too.

The place definitely has a pub look and feel.  Live music when I came that night, but the football game was going on too.  Rowdy fans and loud music doesn't go well, but I guess it wouldn't matter after a few drinks.  Our service was good, but splitting checks again can be a challenge. - Enjoy!
I went for their lunch buffet and was expecting a buffet. It was a few dishes and the honey chicken turned my mouth into a glue trap. Haven't been back since.

After an exhaustive examination of the evaluations, it was determined that giving it a try would be a worthwhile venture.  WOW, capacity crowd on a Sunday evening with a protracted waiting period of twenty minutes. Familiarity with the culinary aspects of Houston, having resided there for seven years, facilitated an informed decision regarding the consumption of the piquant mudbugs.  The crawfish possessed an exceptional quality, devoid of sogginess and moderately seasoned to accommodate my gustatory preferences, opting for the fiery and succulent temperature.  Unfortunately, the establishment had exhausted their supply of stone and blue crab, thus limiting the options to king legs and snow crab.  I selected the diminutive sized snow crabs, while my acquaintance chose the shrimp platter.  Both dishes were predominantly composed of fries.  This eatery would suffer a swift demise in South Texas or the bayou region.

Pros:  Prompt delivery of the culinary offerings, Miller Lite served at a refreshingly low temperature by the bottle.
Cons:  Limited selection of items available during the visit, purporting to offer alcoholic beverages, specifically wine, though solely by the bottle the previous evening.  Ambiance garnered a zero, as the patrons were compactly arranged, evoking the image of sardines, pardon the pun.  Overwhelmed waitstaff, possibly attributable to a lack of experience.  Lemons had to be requested, prompting incredulity.

Disgusting food, disgusting desserts. 

It's all superficial here - everything looks good until you take a bite out of it. The pastas and noodles were overcooked and oversauced, the fried foods (you usually can't go wrong with those) were good until I bit into one that was all breading and oil, and the mac n' cheese didn't fail to disappoint.

The desserts were bitter or plain disgusting and the soft serve ice cream was icy and cheap tasting. The cookies, which looked really good - did not live up to their looks.

I do give Hometown Buffet two stars however, for their dinner rolls and mushrooms. THOSE, well... Those were pretty awesome.

I reserved two accommodations for myself and my associates to indulge in a period of leisure and enjoyment in Las Vegas; however, we were not entirely satisfied with our experience at this particular establishment. Despite our initial enthusiasm, several unforeseen circumstances and subpar service hindered our overall satisfaction. Firstly, upon arriving at 1:30 pm, we discovered that only one of our rooms was ready, whereas the second room, which was supposed to be adjacent and connected, was not prepared until 6:15 pm. Furthermore, we were lacking essential bathroom amenities such as shampoo and conditioner in the second room, which necessitated a delay of one hour for their delivery due to an overwhelmed attendant. These inconveniences were merely the beginning, as we encountered further miscommunication and inadequate assistance from the concierge. Specifically, they failed to inform us that the club we intended to visit, Marque, was not operational that evening, and instead, only one of its auxiliary rooms, Boombox, was accessible. This oversight led to unnecessary effort and disappointment. My companions and I collectively agree that for a luxury hotel, the personnel, ranging from the front desk attendants to the concierge and security guards, require more comprehensive training and education. Their present level of proficiency falls short of expectations considering the high rates charged by the establishment. Consequently, I would opt for a more seasoned and refined hotel, despite its age, for a superior experience.

This is an alright place if you haven't experienced some of the much better places in Arizona.  I think it is somewhat overpriced compared to similar restaurants and the food isn't anything to rave about.

This fitness facility provides an extensive array of exercise classes, but unfortunately, the drawbacks outweigh the advantages. Notably, securing parking is a challenge, and a fee is associated with its usage. Additionally, the staff exhibits a lack of warmth and friendliness, the cost of utilizing the subpar equipment is prohibitive, and it would be preferable to have a staff member stationed at the downstairs desk rather than the upstairs location. Furthermore, I am eagerly anticipating the expiration of my contractual obligation, which I now regret having entered into. Undoubtedly, superior fitness centers exist in close proximity.

Popped in for a take out order on a very busy Sunday afternoon. I don't know why the OG gets so busy on family holidays like Mother's Day, but on this one it was packed solid with people waiting outside, inside and in the bar area.

We were able to place our to go order with the very busy takeout manager. That guy should get five stars. But the rest of the place, not so much. We sat at the bar for 30 minutes waiting to place the order and then waiting for it. Could someone have asked us if we wanted a drink? Maybe offered a glass of water? Nope.

The food was OG standard but again it was packed perfectly with the salad in an interesting container that kept the lettuce and such fresh with the dressing and croutons separate. They also put a separator to keep the cold stuff from affecting the hot stuff.

Two stars because the place was less than tidy and the bar staff didn't seem interested in customers. Otherwise, it would have been pretty good.

If you are going to serve New Mexican food, then serve it, don't water it down and serve things up like they do in the real state. I spent a month there and nobody in hell would use a whole Green chile in making the Chile Relleno. You use either a Poblano or an Aneheim and then cover it in your green chile sauce. The guy next to us eating his meal was complaining alot about how the sauce wasn't hot at all. \n    Chips and salsa were free at the bar - they were decent with two salsa's. Also noticed like another Yelper did that the food comes out like 2 minutes after ordering. This can only mean one thing, nothing is made to order and that means you can do alot better than the food here. The fake Chile Relleno was enough to send my running.

We have placed orders for pizza from this establishment on three separate occasions, and unfortunately, the quality of the product has deteriorated with each successive order. The most recent pie, which featured a Hawaiian-style topping configuration, arrived in a state of utter saturation, rendering it unpalatable until we attempted to restore its crispness through the application of heat in an oven, an endeavor that proved unsuccessful. 
Upon contacting the proprietor of the business, we were met with a dismissive and unhelpful demeanor, as he initially claimed that the sogginess of the pizza was an inherent characteristic of the Hawiian variety, a statement we vigorously contested. He then shifted his stance, asserting that the ingredients used in the pizza's preparation were fresh, a fact that we found to be utterly irrelevant under the circumstances. Finally, he offered a half-hearted compromise, suggesting that we might receive a credit towards a future purchase, a gesture that struck us as wholly inadequate given the magnitude of our disappointment and frustration. 
In light of these events, we feel compelled to advise potential patrons to avoid this establishment at all costs, as the quality of the food and the level of customer service are woefully substandard.

Beer and apps were okay but if you are looking for any sort of craft brewing atmosphere this is not it. Service was below average yet the place was slow. I like Sleepy Dog in Tempe but will never return to this location. Maybe it's an attempt to appeal to everyone but it just doesn't work here.

I was excited to dine here... Until I dined. Unfortunately, I was disappointed by the food--simply mediocre and along the same line of Chinese food I could get for $40 rather than $240. The dim sum was decent but the snapper was dry and the prawns and curry just didn't work for me. The nightclub, to add, felt like a cave and my party and I left shortly after being escorted in. I will say, however, service at the restaurant was excellent.

Expensive for what it is. Burger (6oz) fries and soda over 10 bucks. The fries were 2.40... And not for a five guys portion either! \n. Service was slow too... And the place was not packed out. I predict they will not last long.... Like johnnie brusco's.

"It is utterly perplexing that individuals would bestow such effusive praise upon this establishment, ostensibly in an attempt to convey their sophisticated taste and familiarity with unpretentious, off-the-beaten-path venues in less affluent neighborhoods. The reality, however, is that our dining experience was utterly unpleasant. We sampled the queso with chorizo, which was palatable, albeit somewhat unremarkable. Our main courses, on the other hand, were nothing short of gastronomic abominations. The green sauce accompanying my chilaquiles was eerie and unsettling, while the steak was woefully underseasoned and sported an unpleasant, almost acrid flavor. I requested a to-go container and appropriated the steak for the benefit of my canine companions. My associate opted for their torta, which elicited a dubious response. Upon sampling it, I concurred that it was, indeed, quite revolting. She attempted to consume it again the following morning but ultimately discarded it due to its unpalatability. We shall persist in our patronage of Gallo Blanco, despite their subpar service, as their torta is undeniably exceptional. In conclusion, the culinary offerings of this establishment are, in my opinion, utterly reprehensible, despite the friendly demeanor of the staff and the immaculate condition of the premises."

I became a patient of Dr. Barrettoko after my favorite doctor at Nevada Family Care moved on.  What a disappointment that was. I would have followed her, but her new facility did not accept my insurance.  

Dr. Barrettoko is not of the same caliber as the previous doctor. The final straw was during my last appointment. As I was telling Dr. Barrettoko what I was feeling, what symptoms I was experiencing and I caught her texting on her cell phone.  She works with an iPad-like device that has the patient's medical records on it.  She was trying to hide her cell phone behind the tablet as she was texting away. Unbelievable!  If want a doc's I undivided attention do not visit Dr. Barrettoko.

The rest of the staff is nice enough. I do not have experience with any of the doctors at Nevada Family Care.

"The restaurant's happy hour pricing strategy, while economically advantageous, does not necessarily translate into commensurate culinary quality. In fact, my colleagues and I have experienced better-tasting sushi rolls at local grocery stores. Our recent early evening visit, during which we sampled their hot and spicy tuna roll and 'lollipop,' unfortunately confirmed a decline in gastronomic standards. Specifically, the tuna was excessively diced, resulting in a mushy texture. Upon bringing this to the attention of our server, his response was a mere scowl and a perfunctory apology, followed by the abrupt removal of the still-full plate. No tangible gesture of compensation or genuine effort at reconciliation was offered, leaving us with an unsettled bill and a lingering sense of disappointment."

There's free parking in the back which is a plus & with your receipt, you get 10% off any souvenirs in the upstairs gift store.  The food's ok but one of our group of 5 substituted the touted mac n cheese instead of fries but when his plate came, no mac n cheese.  The waitress dumbfoundedly stated what? no fries either? when it was brought to her attention!!

"The atmosphere was rather agreeable, albeit the service was utterly chaotic and disorganized, rendering our dining experience utterly unpleasant. Notwithstanding the palatable quality of the beverages, the prolonged delay in the arrival of our culinary selections, coupled with their frigid temperature, precipitated an unfortunate concatenation of events that rendered our evening meal an unmitigated disappointment. Moreover, the cacophonous ambiance militated against any semblance of tranquility or conversation, rendering it patently impractical to engage in even the most basic dialogue while partaking of sustenance. Furthermore, the absence of any semblance of organization or efficiency in the processing of separate checks for our party only served to exacerbate the already untenable situation, leading us to conclude that this particular establishment was woefully ill-equipped to accommodate the demands of its clientele. In light of these considerations, it is abundantly clear that a radical transformation is imperative if this venue is to avoid the fate of so many of its predecessors in the local hospitality industry."

"The most economical dining establishment within the Wynn resort complex, the Pizza Place, offers a comparable culinary experience to that of New York-style pizzerias, according to Mr. Wynn's assertions. However, my personal assessment diverges from his viewpoint. My expectations were high regarding the quality of the pizza, but unfortunately, it fell short of excellence. Patrons have the option of ordering an entire pie or individual slices, commencing with a straightforward cheese pizza and subsequently adding desired toppings and incremental costs. 
 
I opted for a pizza with pepperoni, onions, and peppers, anticipating that the peppers would be green; however, they were, in fact, red. Moreover, I expected the ingredients to be finely chopped, but they were not. While the pizza possessed a satisfactory taste, it was slightly too oily for my preference. Notwithstanding the provision of an elegant napkin, I chose not to utilize it to blot the excess oil. A positive aspect of the pizza was the generous size of each slice. 
 
In addition, I sampled their basic vinaigrette salad, which was unremarkable, and the dressing did not blend harmoniously with the greens. The iced tea infused with a hint of passion fruit was my favorite beverage, as it maintained a perfect balance between flavor and sweetness. Unfortunately, due to strong winds outside, we were compelled to dine indoors and could not fully appreciate the soothing sounds of the adjacent waterfalls."

If they could only devise a methodology whereby they could efficiently process telephonic orders without subjecting patrons to extended periods of time on hold, thereby negating the need for an interminable waiting period, they would be performing optimally. This particular Dominos establishment is situated in close proximity to my domicile, thereby rendering it a convenient venue for me to visit and place an order when I experience a yearning for their newly introduced, rather delectable, thin crust pizza. However, upon arriving at the aforementioned establishment, I am often compelled to wait in a rather uninspiring and uninviting waiting area. Furthermore, I would not advocate for visiting this location after sunset, as it has been associated with certain incidents of a violent nature occurring within the confines of the parking lot.

The decor is the best aspect.

TERRIBLE service. The waiter could not show us on the wine list where anything was.  He did the fly by "is everything ok" without stopping. One glass of wine i ordered was corked--but nothing from the waiter.

We ordered first soup, then appetizer, then our meal.

They rushed out the soup and appetizer together (this on a not busy night). We asked them to slow it down but apparently they don't know how. it felt like Applebees' services with higher priced food.


The food is not tapas--there is a very small appetizer menu. Of that the octopus was delicious, as was the onion soup.  the entrees were not at all memorable. We did not bother with dessert.

Even had we decent service we felt like this is a restaurant trading on the chef's name with no hint of the august heritage. a misuse of a brand name chef--or an over extension of a name with one restaurant that does not meet the standards. This restaurant could not survive without the Hubert Keller name.

This proved to be a vacillating encounter, characterized by fluctuations in quality; specifically, the hospitality aspect was deficientâupon entrance, we were not greeted by a porter to assist with our luggage, and the state of our lodging left much to be desired, including an unsightly coiffure in the shower and a reprehensible stain on the parlor's couch (truly repulsive). Nonetheless, I must acknowledge that certain aspects of the accommodations did possess merit, such as the presence of balconies and some spectacular vistas. Furthermore, the gaming facilities were quite pleasant, and the locale was conveniently situated, practically in the center of the famed Las Vegas Strip. Be that as it may, when considering the tariff, superior alternatives become apparent.

It is indeed regrettable that there are only a limited number of exceptional Mexican dining establishments available, and what currently passes for quality is merely unremarkable. While the portion size at Lindo is generous and the prices are not exorbitant, the culinary offerings do not possess the qualities that would compel one to return. In contrast, those residing in Henderson must travel a considerable distance to access the World Market Center, whereupon they can indulge in intriguing and inventive Mexican cuisine at Mundo Restaurant (which, incidentally, has relocated from its previous site on Ft Apache, prompting a desire for them to have chosen Henderson as their new locale instead). (509 tokens)

My maiden escapade at this establishment proved to be an unmitigated disaster, as my manicurist, a male individual, seemed to possess scant proficiency in his craft, leaving my nails in a state of utter disarray and disrepair. Furthermore, my epidermis suffered lacerations courtesy of the cuticle clippers, while the nail buffer inflicted an unsightly abrasion upon my person, necessitating prompt remedial measures upon my return home. To further exacerbate matters, the pedicure was executed in a frigid aquatic environment.

The entire episode was nothing short of a calamitous ordeal, culminating in a finished product that was aesthetically subpar and conspicuously shoddy. Regrettably, my customary salon was not patronized on this particular occasion, as I opted to experiment with one of the newer venues in town, but my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated by the sheer ineptitude displayed by the staff. In conclusion, 4ur Nails is emphatically not worthy of my consideration.

"Desirous of expending a substantial amount of currency on culinary delights reminiscent of those served at traditional American diners? In that case, a visit to BLT Burger may be in order. Upon perusing the menu, one might infer that the prices are marginally reasonable; however, be aware that fries are not incorporated into the cost of the meal. Indeed, they are an additional expense. My dining experience at this establishment involved consuming a Tex-Mex burger, which, while palatable, did not surpass my expectations in terms of quality or quantity. Specifically, the bun was unpleasantly soggy and disintegrated shortly after the initial bite. Nonetheless, the spiked milkshakes offered by BLT Burger are undeniably impressive. Grandma's Treat, in particular, boasts an inventive blend of Makers Mark bourbon, vanilla ice cream, caramel syrup, and chopped nuts, yielding a delectable beverage that warrants a return visit. Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, I would still consider patronizing BLT Burger again, albeit primarily for the $11 (gulp) milkshakes."

You get what you pay for. 

The good things about this place is that its close to the middle of the strip with access to the city center, crystal shops, Aria, and Belligio through the tram. The hotel was cheap and the lobby is nice. 

Now the bad things: 

- The walls are extremely thin so you could hear every conversation, every toilet flush, every shower, and every door being opened and closed. They were so thin that you could hear your neighbor having SEX! Very disturbing!!
- Housekeeping is horrible: we had five pillow and all but one had a stain. Even the comforter had a stain. 
-The bathroom, most of the furniture, bed, and television were outdated or old and need replacing.
- There was no coffee maker. Why provide free coffee when you can charge $3.75 for a Starbucks coffee downstairs. 
- No mini bar
-The smell of so called rose petals smells good at first, but soon gets overwhelming and give you a headache. 

If you are looking for cheap stay in Las Vegas then this is your place. If you are looking for more comfort then I recommend somewhere else.

I've come in here during my previous business trips and gotten great food. 
I have specific food allergies which they were able to previously accommodate, however not this time.
I called in my order as usual, but they told me they changed their menu and what I wanted was a lunch menu item. The menu online hadn't been updated yet they still told me they wouldn't give me the food I was trying to order. 
This to me is false advertising, and poor customer service. 
Dont get me wrong, the food I had was good, but now I wont be going back because of this.

We went to Tryst on a Sunday during lunch for a family member's bday. The menu seemed promising. I decided on the seared ahi tuna salad for myself and spring rolls to share. I didn't think to ask if anything I ordered was going to be hot. I assumed the spring rolls would be hot because I've never experienced raw spring rolls before and any time I've ever ordered a salad with some fish in it- the fish has always come out hot. This was not the case. Which is not a big deal but cold seared ahi tuna is not good. The seared part of the title is misleading. When something has the word seared, I expect it to be HOT... but that's just me. The spring rolls were tasty -I just did not expect them to be cold/raw. Nothing to write home about but it wasn't terrible. \nAnd my fianc\u00e9 found a hair in his salad and I lost my appetite.

I just have to say its sad that I've not experienced some of the great wings I've heard so much about! I ordered chicken Parmesan and was so excited to dive into my half off happy hour wings! You get 10 whole wings for five bucks... That's gotta excite you! 

Sad thing was, they were tasteless and greasy.  I kept biting into them thinking it would get better. I assure you, it did not. I ate three and had to stop.  It was like eating grease flavored chicken.  

The only redeeming thing about the meal was the tomato salad with huge pieces of mozzarella cheese. I really want to like this place... And I'll probably be back at some point. Heck, they still server beer.  That's good enough for me!

Hoping and wishing it will turn around though!

"Commencing with an affirmative assertion, the Cupcakery's red velvet cupcakes are indeed exceptionalâpossessing an optimal level of moisture and a profusion of flavor, while the accompanying frosting serves as a harmonious complement. A friendly individual presented me with one, and I was eager to share this culinary destination with my significant other. Unfortunately, their remaining cupcakes fell short of expectations, particularly in relation to their cost. For $3.75, I anticipate a product of considerable quality and quantity. However, the cupcakes we acquired were comparable in size and caliber to those offered at a supermarketâexhibiting a notable lack of moisture, minimal flavor, and an unsatisfactory cream cheese frosting that failed to enhance the coconut variety. While the shop's appearance was adequate and the decorations were acceptable, they did not exceed my modest decorative abilities; thus, I cannot recommend visiting this establishment unless an unwavering craving for sweets necessitates it."

The ice cream is delicious but the place is filthy. Sinks, counters disgusting. Dust on the inside of the glass where ice cream is held. Only ordered because ice cream was covered. The door to the back room was open and that room was equally dirty. No health rating sign up, which is not good. Too bad because the ice cream was delicious. Clean this place up!

It has been an entire triennium since my last visitation to Sam Boyd Stadium, and upon my return, it became apparent that little to no alterations have transpired within this temporal span. The Rebels continue to exhibit a profound lack of proficiency, and the stadium itself remains inferior to its counterparts among institutions of higher learning. A solitary victory against Western Illinois on the evening of my attendance served as a minuscule source of gratification. The arena's antiquated design and the unimpressive nature of the amenities available for purchase within its confines persist in perpetuating the same concerns I articulated in my original assessment. It is my sincere expectation that at some point in the future, UNLV will elect to erect a novel stadium, thereby potentially enhancing the overall experience for spectators. Until such a time, the Return Factor for this venue shall remain at a meager fifty percent.

I guess that I sport a very simple haircut and like to keep it that way. Unfortunately, the person who cut my hair here must have slipped with the razor just behind my ear and tried to make it look normal by cleaning it up and making the other side look the same. Since I don't typically look at myself for extended periods of time, I actually didn't notice until last night when I was washing my hands in a resteraunt bathroom.  I will be speaking with manager come Monday. \n\nI had no wait and the lady who can't cut my simple hair do was very nice, until she didn't say oops I sort of f*'d your hair up. It isn't really bad and I'm not horribly upset but it IS noticeable! It would have been nice if she said something to me about it. I think this warrants a refund of my money. I will let you all know if I got my money back.

This place was alright, just not what I was hoping for. The curry was a little too soupy for my liking. The customer service was great, we had a really nice waitress but unfortunately I don't think that would be enough for me to want to go back.

I'm afraid I'm going to have to downgrade my prior review as I've been disappointed the past couple times I've purchased from the Meat Shop.  The staff is still great, very helpful, but the product has let me down. \n First it was pork belly, the quality was not good-much fattier than my normal Asian market source but I figured homemade bacon's kind of a tough standard to judge quality as it's smoked and cured.  I then did a head-to-head with spare ribs and the ones from the Meat Shop were thin and tough while the ones I got at Smart & Final were meaty and juicy.\nI suppose if I better express what I'm looking for I might get better results but just because I don't that shouldn't mean I get crap, especially for triple/quadruple the price of the regular grocery store.

the salsa bar is good, free chips and salsa.
the  people working on the counter are rude.
had the california tacos so plaine has no flavor
wont be back

I had the house special chow mein to-go for 8.10.

- a bit better than panda express. pretty bland. 
- small portion for the price. few meat for their combo
- 8.10 for chow mein and their AYCE dinner is10.50? bad pricing. 
- i have to come back to try AYCE. eating individual platters aren't worth it.

I just noticed this was so highly rated and wanted to send a little more reality the way of the burrito drive. The only thing it has going for it is the fact it delivers, and would pass for a business meeting or simple catered event. If you are looking to go out to enjoy some Mexican food-you can look pretty much anywhere else and be happier.  

I've tried this place a couple times over a year ago now, but doubt anything has changed. I disagree with the implication that chipotle or qdoba is inferior to this place. They are comparable, but I would rank chipotle significantly higher. So long as you don't think of this place as a mexican restaurant or receive the food for free, you might not be disappointed.

Come here to remind yourself just how good places like El Pastor and Taqueria Guadalajara are.

My friend and I swung by Phillip's for a quick bite while our plane made a stop in Charlotte (our gate was right next to the restaurant). It's pretty simple - sit down, place your order when a waiter comes around, and get your food pretty quickly. The only real complaint is that the food's a bit expensive (as all airport food is) and that they didn't have BBQ sauce when I requested it for the chicken tenders. Aside from that, the food was pretty much what'd you expect overall from this kind of joint. The tenders were pretty standard, served with honey mustard sauce. The seafood platter comes with fried shrimp, crab cakes, and some spring rolls. I felt better for not getting the bigger crab cakes when I had theirs - the crab meat was extremely nondescript, coated in fried breadcrumbs but with an indistinguishable taste aside from that. The spring rolls were okay, if unspectacular, and the fried shrimp was decent.\n\nYou're not going to get much service here - our waiter had to be flagged to give us our check - but it's an airport spot, so you can't really set expectations too high. I'd probably stop by if I wanted something other than standard fast food in the airport, but there's not much any other reason to come by here.

The food was pretty good and the guacamole was awesome, but my boyfriend and I were not treated very well. I guess it's just Scottsdale, but the waitress asked us incredulously if we wanted a table, seated us, and then didn't speak to us for a good ten minutes. She was nice to everyone else, but she acted like our presence was bothering her. I'm sick of going to restaurants in Scottsdale and being treated like I'm not welcome.

We have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, we have been impressed by the vast array of fresh salads and vegetables available for our perusal. Our significant other, being a vegetarian, has expressed great enthusiasm towards the diverse selection offered, praising the quality and freshness of the produce. However, we must admit that the prices charged for these delectable delights are somewhat prohibitive, especially when compared to other eateries in the vicinity.  

The service at this establishment has consistently been prompt and attentive, with the staff displaying a commendable level of professionalism in their interactions with patrons. Additionally, they offer complimentary cookies to guests, which has been a delightful surprise for our children. Unfortunately, we cannot say the same for the beverages offered, as the prices charged for fountain drinks are, in our opinion, exorbitant.  

Upon closer inspection, we have noticed an unpleasant odor emanating from the rear section of the restaurant, which has been described as akin to the scent of feet. While this may seem a minor inconvenience to some, it has been a source of discomfort for us.  

The pasta dishes served at this establishment have been found to be merely satisfactory, with some of the soups being quite palatable. A friend of ours once commented that the portion sizes served do not justify the cost, leading us to concur that the value proposition presented is not entirely convincing.  

Despite these shortcomings, the restaurant has consistently maintained a high level of popularity among locals and visitors alike. Perhaps the appeal lies in the ambiance or the convenience of the location, but we cannot help but feel that there are superior options available in the surrounding area, such as Sunset Station, which offers a more affordable and satisfying dining experience, including complimentary beverages.  

In conclusion, while this establishment has its merits, we cannot help but feel that there are areas where improvement could be made to enhance the overall dining experience for patrons.

If you want to be squished by hundreds of sweaty strangers with out even room to dance then come here. The restaurant is nice and I like the atmosphere the club has but Tao needs to seriously crowd control they let too many people in too fast, I was over it after 30 min. Not to mention the quality of people we ran into, maybe it was just random but this fat drunk Mexican literally feel on top of my girlfriend. My GF playfully smacked her ass when she got up. Apparently she didn't like that and started charging at my GF then tried to swing at her. Held back by all of her friends she finally stoped acting dumb and went away. I latter saw the same girl trying to dance on the stage where the bouncer kicked her off for being to raunchy. Thursday night might be better but I won't be going back. I've heard marquee and XS are much better clubs.

I hate that feeling when you tell your server that you have a travel zoo, and wait to see whether they are cool, or treat you like a leper, guess where we fell? The couple behind my husband got the most amazing service because they got a prix fix meal with the wine pairing ( good for them!) the cocktails we ordered ( not included in the TZ) were short, and the drinks that came with the voucher tasted like sea water. Our bar bill itself was $100 so we always pay way over our coupon voucher. My husband ordered the seafood pot and salmon,which he found to his liking. I ordered the beef carpaccio and chicken with the sauce on the side. My chicken and the little side thing ( veggies?) it came with were dry. They also gave us a palate cleanser of squash soup ( was it supposed to be cold?) and some fishy paste, blah! I don't know, I was expecting the same service that I got from their sister restaurant, Andres but there was no comparison. The views are pretty. The only great thing was the crime br\u00fbl\u00e9e, that was good stuff. Not enough for us to be back though. Thank god we didn't tell the host we had the TZ like that other unlucky poster! I would've really had been pissed if we were sat facing a wall. if you don't like people with coupon vouchers stop listing them, it's as easy as that.

I went here several times. It's usually good. The service is usually good.\n\nBUT the reason I put 2 stars is because they need to learn how to train their workers better. I usually get workers that work well. However, today I ordered gauc and chips, barbacoa bowl, and a carnitas quesadilla... and the only items I received were the quac with NO chips and a barbacoa bowl. I think the workers were either new, untrained, or deaf. And the line also literally didn't move for about 10 minutes... two girls were working at the time.. I don't know there names, but they don't do there jobs well and need to find another one.

I shop at this location often because its so close to my home.

The majority of the time they have the products that I use in stock.

The downfall to this particular store is the lack of customer service. I don't typically need assistance on the sales floor since I know what I need. However if I did need help there would not be a soul around to assist me. I don't ever see any staff around except at checkout. When I get to the checkout counter the staff is not personable at all. I don't need a full blown conversation to occur but I would think a "How are you?", would suffice.  Instead of talking to a coworker or the typical "Do you have an Ulta card?", etc. You know the questions they are trained to ask . I would appreciate a thank you after my purchase.

Again I will continue to use this Ulta but only because it so close to home. If the customer service does not improve I will have a chat with a manager.

$3 for a bowl of rice!!! Yikes! Late night dining options at the Wynn were limited and led us to this place. We ordered bbq pork, bbq duck and two bowls of rice $45. OMG! Sam Woo bbq we could of eaten the same thing for like $15 and it would of tasted better. I don't mind paying for a good meal, but being over charged for mediocre food just makes me pout. The server was an automaton, no smile, no energy, no emotion. Sad, Wynn, Sad! I just wanted a tasty late night dinner but no go at Red 8.

Lost baggage and poor child wrangling. It's all about employee empowerment.

I have the patience of the Madonna - all right maybe more like the Material Girl - but I am pretty laid back. After my humbling experience in the wine industry, I've been much more appreciative of service industry related jobs. But when employees are not empowered to answer the most simple of questions, and we're checking in on machines with nobody around to handle luggage, well...it's a disaster waiting to happen. It's an unfortunate thing that is supposed to help in keeping costs down and help with efficiency - but there's been consistent problems with all of my US AIRWAYS flights.

Let's throw JFK airport into the mix to help maximize the disaster...we ended up in Orlando. Waiting for our luggage. Luckily our toddler was entertained with the luggage roundabout...because we waited through two flight arrivals to retrieve one bag. 

Family that met up with us for the 4th assured us US AIRWAYS used a really efficient delivery service...Apparently the lost luggage situation is pretty common.

Good thing the baby bug is a trooper when it comes to traveling - because Orlando trips tend to be family-heavy and the on-board US AIRWAYS staff consistently doesn't seem too thrilled to be dealing with even the well-behaved ones.

Maybe we just picked an off night, but I was very unimpressed. We walked in at 6:45 on a Saturday night, expecting to have to wait for a table. Instead, we had to wait for the hostess, who was nowhere in sight. With all of the NCAAF on tv, I was surprised how many seats were empty. Once we were finally seated, our waiter appeared promptly to take our order. We started with bruschetta, which was good, but not good enough to bring home what we didn't finish. And at nearly $10, seemed very pricey for some bread with tomatoes and dressing. 

We had heard that the mac & cheese was award winning, so my daughter ordered it from the kids menu. When it arrived, it wasn't the "real" mac & cheese, it was the open a bag and microwave kind. She was hungry, so we let it be. My Wife ordered the lasagna, which she liked, but again at $12, was too pricey for what she got. I ordered the Tuscan Panini, which was very tasty. 

I don't think we'll be back, and if the number of empty seats on a Saturday night is any sign of what is in their future, they might want to think about changing things up.

We tried this carwash for the second time yesterday hoping for a little better results.  Once we saw our car come through the carwash, it was evident that there were too many cars and not enough employees to handle them all.  We ordered \"The Works\" which includes vacuuming and wiping the interior.  The exterior looked great, but as we drove away, we realized that the entire dashboard area hadn't been touched.  The guy was obviously too rushed to realize he completely missed that part.  Third time won't be a charm because we probably won't be back.

Meh. Lot of hype around this place, but I was underwhelmed with the food. 

The decor is really nice, and a great location but overall I wouldn't come back except for their extensive beer on tap.

I ordered:

Squid Salad - not bad, not great.
Sake Nigiri - salmon was not fresh too much rice
Spicy Tuna Roll - tuna mix wasn't fresh and zero flavor

To top it all I asked for Nigori Sake. The server didn't know what it was since apparently they only have WARM sake. Not much of a Japanese restaurant.

Well we got free passes since we stayed at the Treasure Island...and when we got there it was still super empty....and they were playing trance music that kinda just made me take a good nap....

they had free drinks that night "Lemon Drops" more like lemonade and water!!.... it was hard to tell if this club was going to get any better, and we didnt want to risk it so we left and were planning to come back latr since they had "in and outs"...but we never made it back..... HmMmM wonder if it got better....

the patio did have a beautiful view of the strip and the little "lake" very nice club.

I went here after a late flight from Denver, as it was the only restaurant at our hotel that was really open, and we did not want snacky food. Let's just say the food was definitely lacking. I ordered a burger and it pretty much tasted like a hockey puck it was so burnt. Maybe try it Medium instead of Medium well next time? Scratch that I probably wont be going back next time I am in Phoenix, The service was OK but I have experienced better. I would not recommend this place, but if it is the absolute only place and someone else was paying I would not pass it up.

"My sentiments regarding our recent visit to SMG can be adequately conveyed by the expression 'Meh...'. The offer of a Groupon for a $5 movie, albeit with a $3 surcharge for 3D glasses, was sufficient to entice us into the establishment. However, the limited number of showtimes available left much to be desired. 

Upon entering the theater, we were struck by the diminutive size of the screen, which was further compromised by the distracting illumination emanating from the stairs. While we appreciate the concept of reserved seating, it proved challenging to secure four contiguous seats without fragmenting the rows. Consequently, we were relegated to the rear row. 

The sluggishness of the service was conspicuous, further exacerbated by the waitress's propensity to station herself in the rows, thereby obstructing our view of the screen. This became increasingly vexing... 

It is worth noting that the ticket counter is situated on the second floor; hence, it is advisable to halt there initially before proceeding to the theaters. Additionally, remember to bring your parking ticket, as they offer validation services. Although SMG does not rank as my premier choice, I would consider returning in a pinch."

The cheesecake is good and the waitstaff tend to be friendly, but the food definitely leaves a lot to be desired. I've had several entr\u00e9es and appetizers here and not been impressed by any of them. I'd especially recommend avoiding the nachos!\n\nThat said, it's a decent place to go late night for dessert.

This place isn't all that. Maybe its cause I went in there to early in the day.  Didn't really look like a great place to party or waste a lot of time in. Although it did have a nice Irish look. But I still won't go back.

A very large restaurant in the New York New York Casino. They offer "outdoor" seating - meaning on the fake city streets within the casino. We chose the outdoor seating so we could people watch while we ate.

The Margarita was too sweet and a little watered down. They served it in a plastic cup rather than glass. That was a bit of a disappointment. They are generous with their chips and salsa. They also made us table side guacamole which was very good.

For dinner, I had a beef burrito. I've had better.

Prob the most screwed up restaurant in Scottsdale. If you like to dine in dirty, outdated dive bar style restaurants so small you literally eat as one big family with strangers, who by the way consisted of drunk kids from the skatepark next door and large individuals who pretty sure spent most their time in jail. Your in heaven. They even have this bartender who you can read about in other comments who I'm certain is on Breaking Bad's blue meth. Nobody can talk as loud and as much as this guy. It's really quite the show. The little server girls who probably get lashed by bamboo canes from this guy are nice, the food was hot with good portions are the only thing they have going on here. Be prepared if you accept this challenge.

Service was exceptionally poor. 

Went here for a late lunch and we were the only couple in the restaurant. The waitstaff neglected us for 20minutes. 

The food came out 30 minutes after we ordered and was awful! The pasta I ordered had dried out from sitting for so long.

Avoid this restaurant on your next visit to lake Las Vegas.
It's Chili's which means it tips out at three stars, but in this ones case it is small with slow service. Better to wait in line at Burgatory...

"My sentiments regarding this event are somewhat ambivalent, as my expectations were not particularly elevated due to the underwhelming nature of last year's participant roster. Furthermore, I would prefer to allocate additional financial resources and partake in more extensive and renowned culinary festivals such as Devour, Feast on the Streets, or Taste of Biltmore. Notwithstanding, I can appreciate the allure of this event for my associates who value its family-friendly atmosphere and its capacity to inaugurate the summer season in a convivial manner."

Hmm... I read so many positive reviews on this place that I was really excited to try it. I got the pat's pounder platter with pulled pork, beef brisket, added on ribs for 3.99 and collord greens and hush puppies for around $23.00, kinda pricy, but I was hopeful on the quality.  Here is what I thought:
Pulled pork - really dry, and almost crunchy at times... definitely pass on this if I had to do it again
Brisket  - pretty good actually, salty but good and flavorful 
RIBS - Never again! They were pretty much all bone, and so dry that I nearly broke a tooth! Given that this was a $4 add on to the plate I feel somewhat angry about it
Hush puppies - ok, nothing earth shattering 
Greens - really bland, although it didn't taste salty, kind of a shame, because a pound of salt may have actually improved the taste.

We went with a group of 10 including 2 small kids for an early dinner at 530 on a Thursday. It was already packed. The service was very friendly but we waited over 25 minutes for our first round of AYCE. The food quality was ok but nothing to get too excited about. Prices were average. My biggest gripes were the layout- crowded floor and you have to walk through a wait station in front of the kitchen and not run into any servers to get to the restrooms...and the music. It was nightclub music- ok whatever- but it was as loud as a nightclub. The group consensus is that we probably won't go back. It wasn't a comfortable atmosphere and not worth that for the sushi.

"I wholeheartedly endorse investing the additional funds at the Bacchanal buffet within Caesars Palace, as it offers an unparalleled gastronomic experience. My initial visit to this esteemed establishment occurred twelve years ago, and I must say that I was thoroughly enamored with it. However, during our recent sojourn at the Mandalay Bay, we opted to partake in the culinary delights within the vicinity. The tariff for this indulgence amounted to a trifling sum of thirty dollars per adult and a mere twenty dollars for my five-year-old progeny. Although the comestibles presented were undoubtedly delectable, the array of options appeared somewhat limited in comparison to my recollection of previous visits. Moreover, certain edibles necessitated a brief waiting period, which proved somewhat vexing. In light of these factors, I would not advocate returning to this establishment solely due to the abundance of alternative dining venues within Las Vegas that offer a more extensive variety of cuisine and seafood for a slightly higher fee of fifty dollars per individual at larger resorts and casinos."

I had originally posted a 5-star review, but have now retracted it. While at The Brake Shop to have my brakes inspected, I also asked for an oil change and tire rotation. After they drained the oil, they realized they didnt have the proper oil filter, and could not locate one. They added some oil back in my 2012 Audi, and replaced the oil filter.

When I went to Jiffy Lube the next day, the service guy there wouldn't touch it - there was oil all over the engine. I had to immediately go to the nearest Audi dealership, where they stated that either the oil filter was replaced improperly, or an incorrect oil filter was used. Had I driven any longer, this could have cause severe damage to my 1 yr old Audi.

2 Stars because the store manager was very friendly, and didn't try to upsell me anything. Negative 3 stars for the poor garage staff.

Went here once for your curiosity and once because I was dragged here. Fat burger is mediocre at best. Its overpriced and takes wayyyy too long to get your food. In N out kills this place and is almost have the price. I would rather go to burger king or carls jr and those places are shit.

"The atmosphere was thoroughly enjoyed, as was the melodic background tune that allowed for effortless communication between our party of five females, who were indulging in the establishment's Monday night complimentary dinner and beverage offering, with a recommended gratuity of $15 to $20 per person, an undoubtedly advantageous arrangement. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with the majority of dishes, specifically the miniature beef burgers and salmon fillets, being only partially cooked. It appeared that the kitchen staff had been hasty in their preparation, leading us to question the quality of a full-price meal at this venue. Thus, we would not consider returning as paying patrons."

The food was alright and I thought that the portions were a good size. But i think that the service was absolutely terrible. My friend and I walked in and two women at the counter ignored us for a couple minutes, said they would be with us in a second, continued to ignore us until we finally asked if we could just seat ourselves and they just said yes. We then sat ourselves - and waited for about 15 minutes before someone came up and asked if we were going to be eating there. From then on out - the service still was not very good and everything took a long time. The waitress wouldn't even look at us when we were ordering - as if she just did not care. The food definitely does not make up for the terrible service. I will not eat there again.

My wife and I have been here two days, with two more to go. Room is tiny, shower is tiny, bed is tiny. Shower head is broken, ice machine doesn't work, breakfast is terrible, wi-fi is poor (weak signal everywhere in the building). But it's a good location, and the staff has been friendly, so I give it two stars.
what a messy place! If you want to look a good bargain you have to look carefully because everything is chaos! Even Big Lots has more order. Not worth my time.

Love Costco, have been a member for 15+ years now.  A word of caution, you may want to count your pills before leaving the pharmacy.  Since May 2014, now Sept 2014 I have had three prescriptions shorted by several pills.  Picked up my latest prescription less than an hour ago, came home, and this one was short.  Dang, going back right now to have them get the quantity right.

I had the privilege of partaking in a celebratory dinner at this establishment on a Thursday evening, in honor of a close acquaintance's birthday. As an ardent devotee of Asian cuisine, my expectations were elevated, particularly in light of the acclaim that Pittsburgh's latest restaurants have garnered (especially upon my return to the city). Unfortunately, my culinary experience fell short of my expectations, with both the food and service leaving much to be desired. The dishes we sampled lacked a profound Asian influence, with the skate cheeks, situated atop minuscule pieces of white toast, being rather unremarkable. The fried Brussels sprouts proved to be the standout dish, albeit it paled in comparison to other eateries specializing in meat and potatoes. Avoid the desserts at all costs, as both options featured a vanilla custard base, with one variety topped with Fruity Pebbles in a feeble attempt at cuteness, but ultimately underwhelming.

Moreover, our server appeared to be somewhat inexperienced and self-conscious, neglecting to introduce herself and solicit our order, leaving us to take the initiative in placing our order and seeking recommendations. It is my sincere hope that future menus will incorporate more authentic Chinese and/or Southeast Asian flavors Ã  la Red Farm in NYC, as the current offerings seem contrived and miss the mark.

I'm going to give the Luxor 2 stars because I have alot of good memories of my stays there over the years. The Pyramid Cafe is a nice place to stop and have a bowl of soup and rest your weary dogs after walking to the Luxor from Bellagio.\n\nThe powers that be who \"upgraded\" Luxor ruined it, plain and simple. It's a Pyramid, why in God's name would they get rid of the Eyptian motiff? It's beyond me. The new look is awful, really really bad. Knowing what they've done to Luxor and knowing how far down the strip it is from everything else that we go to Vegas for, I don't think I'll be spending any more of my time - or money - in the Luxor while in Vegas.

Note: I judge Vietnamese places on four things: pho, spring rolls, peanut dipping sauce and avocado shakes. 

Vietnam Grille just didn't impress me on any level. For such a highly regarded Vietnamese joint, I expected a lot more. The spring rolls were on the the smaller side. While the fillings were fresh, they were missing something. The peanut sauce was overly sweet and not that peanuty. The pho was severely over spiced and much too fragrant. The star anise was an overpowering flavor in the broth. The pieces of flank steak weren't the beautifully, paper thin slices that I've had at every other Vietnamese place. The tendon was undercooked and too chewy... Definitely not my fave. The avocado smoothie was no where to be found on the menu... One of the things I love about Vietnamese food is how much food you get for the price. I thought that Vietnam Grille's prices were on the higher end of what I'm accustomed to seeing. 

The positives... The service was fine and the parking was plentiful. 

Needless to say, I'll be continuing my search for my go-to Vietnamese joint in Charlotte.

It Seems that Eliseevsky is under new management, While the experience was not bad it does not come anywhere near the previous reviews. First off gone are the Horseradish  / cranberry flavored vodka shots. When I went Eliseevsky no longer had a license to server alcohol. 

Secondly the menu has been reduced by a fair amount. The menu on the website (which has not as of this posting been updated) speaks of caviar, veal, beef in sweet & sour sauce, Shashlik" (kebab) and many more all of which no longer exists. 
 I had the chicken Kiev  (butter filled); also sampled the borscht and my friend said the pork soup was good. The food was still good but none of it knocked me off my feet. 

The atmosphere seems to have remained largely unchanged. Still looks like a log cabin, modern Russian music plays in the background. Our server also performed a selection of Russian titles (not sure if he was lip syncing or not).  The service was a bit slow even with the restaurant being mostly empty. But I attribute that to a loss of the art of dining on my part.  I will probably go back and try another dish or two but buyer beware the price remains at about 12 -16 a dish. I believe this to be a bit steep for what you are getting.

"Punked! An egregious discrepancy in the quality of service and culinary offerings, resulting in a reprehensible dining experience, characterized by an unacceptable disparity in the value received for the price paid. We had selected this establishment with the expectation of indulging in a refined dining experience, replete with delectable cuisine and exceptional service. However, our expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated, as both the fare and the service fell woefully short of our standards. Specifically, we communicated our time constraints to our server, who assured us that we would have ample time to savor our repast at a leisurely pace. Yet, one hour and ten minutes later, our steaks arrived, while the two parties seated adjacent to us, who had arrived subsequent to our arrival, had already consumed all three courses of their meals. This anomaly can be attributed to either favoritism, inadequate planning, or a combination of both. Consequently, we were compelled to devour our meals in haste, precipitating our tardiness to our scheduled event. Furthermore, our server neglected to include the mushrooms that I had ordered, opting instead to expedite their preparation and subsequently include them on our bill, sans any consideration for complimentary compensation. This instance highlights the dearth of common sense and customer-oriented values in the realm of hospitality. In conclusion, if a premium dining experience is what you seek, it would be judicious to reconsider your choice of dining establishment, as Delmonico fails to deliver an experience commensurate with its pricing."

Very nice place to live in a very good area; however very pricey and the manager Nancy is horrible!!!!! She despises children by enforcing ridiculous rules for kids in summer by not allowing them
outside without an adult at all times. Sh sent a memo stating absolutely no bicycles allowed in the courtyards( which was one reason that lured me to the place . I liked the fact that it was quaint and had a courtyard for kids to ride bikes) On top of it all Nancy also is such a control freak who despises children she took the liberty to call me to "warn" me that kids aren't allowed to take out trash and what kind of mother allows their 10 year old to do this, This is not acceptable for residents living at Altessa. There's more, Nancy is so asphyxiated on emphasizing her power she even took liberty with putting a chain lock around the pool during summer nights after 9pm. How's that for controlling! Last I checked Altessa was kid friendly and not a senior 55+ community. Nancy seems to think otherwise!

If it weren't for the Hitler style management who tries to make the community a senior citizen one, and the rent being so high I would still be there, as to me it's best choice if you are limited to apartment living.

I have been on the search for a good nail salon for some time now and this is NOT the place.  I get gel manicures every two weeks like clock work and every two weeks I am going somewhere new. I don't like when they use Acetone to soak off the old gel polish, it it extremely bad for your nails, and I'm not even sure what the half cut lime rubbed on my nails was for.  Also I asked her to just cut them a tiny bit and she cut them almost all the way down.  Not going back and the search continues..........\n(4)

Had lunch here before attending the Dec. Yelp Hours at Cartel down the street.  $6.95 Green curry w/ chicken called my name.  It's a good thing the server took my order before I had a chance to wait much longer- the noise level was driving me up the walls!  Sure, it was during lunch, but I've been here during dinner, too, and even though there were only four or five tables going at that time, the noise level was high.

Veggie soup with tofu came in a small bowl.  Lightly-salted, fresh-tasting, perfect to get the juices flowing.  Soon after, a plate with jasmine rice, an oval bowl of green curry, and a small eggroll arrived.  Took a bite of eggroll and was disappointed to see * in the mix.  This is the first time I've seen * in eggrolls served in a Thai restaurant... Thai coworkers tell me that's not the norm.  (Another inauthentic dish served here is their pad woon sen- silver-bean noodles with veggies, tofu/chicken, and egg.  TB serves it dripping with sauce when it should be on the dry side.)

Curry sauce was good, but looked too watery and not silky enough.  Medium-spiced, perfectly light.  However, the noise level, soggy pad woon sen, and eggrolls with * will keep me away.

I had the Firehouse Hero, hot roast beef, turkey and ham. It really lacked in flavor, just tasted like warm mystery meat. This is my first time eating at Firehouse and I wasn't impressed. The meat was piled up in the middle so I opened it up to spread it around and with 3 meats it barely covered the bread. Expensive for a toasted sub. Also they made my sandwich on wheat but I asked for white, not a big deal, but when I asked to have it remade they didn't even apologize. And I had to wait until they finished making the other guests sandwiches. I won't be coming back, customer service isn't there, no flavor and overpriced.

It's ok, good for a quick bite. I don't understand the almost cult like following.\nMade a mistake and had the shake instead of pop and was sick for hours.\nStaff was very friendly, but they needed someone dedicated to keeping the place clean.

Is my bartender supposed to be drunker than I am?  I thought there were some rules about that.  This is the old Nick's Fat City building reskinned to look like a swanky deal.  It's really not a bad place for a show unless it is incredibly crowded.  If it is, you'll quickly learn what human sweat tastes like, and you'll forget what it was like to drink beer because you will never get back to the bar.  The last time we were there, I made it to the upstairs which was great, but since the bartender up there was seriously hammered, he didn't seem super interested in giving actual service.  The sound is good, the space isn't bad, and lord knows it's good to have concert venues in the area, but the bartenders kind of blow, and security was having trouble keeping up with the crowd.

"An atmospheric ambiance permeates this edifice, enhanced by an expansive outdoor seating area that invites patrons to linger and luxuriate in their surroundings.
