My companion and I opted to engage in an unprecedented escapade and halted at The Lodge for a Happy Hour experience. We were thoroughly delighted with the tariffs, and every bartender/server we encountered exuded cordiality. The deep-fried cheese curds were utterly delectable, incidentally; their flavor was so intense that it nearly eclipsed my capacity to articulate a coherent thought (being a native of Wisconsin, I have an innate proclivity for such culinary delights). Unfortunately, the seating arrangements at the bar left much to be desired in terms of comfort; the stools were so uncomfortable that they bordered on the unbearable. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, we derived sufficient enjoyment from our visit to consider repeating the experience in the future, albeit while occupying a table instead.

P.S. My companion and I found ourselves in a state of utter perplexity regarding whether to document our observations concerning the server whose attire was so scanty that it approached the realm of impropriety. While acknowledging the reality that bars often employ scantily clad servers to augment their patrons' experiences and boost their gratuities, we could not help but wonder if such an outfit was truly necessary or appropriate within the context of a family-oriented establishment like The Lodge. Ultimately, we elected not to comment publicly on the matter, primarily to avoid any potential misunderstandings or conflicts.

This venerable eatery in Edinburgh's West End boasts the distinction of being the city's oldest Chinese restaurant, a claim that has been proudly proffered by its proprietors for over five decades. Its enduring popularity among locals has resulted in a devoted clientele who have been patronizing this establishment for multiple generations. Despite its questionable moniker, the culinary offerings at this restaurant are undoubtedly exceptional, showcasing a masterful blend of Cantonese and Peking cuisine. The menu presents an array of delectable options that can make selecting a dish a formidable task, a predicament exacerbated by the limited variety of desserts, which, unsurprisingly, feature bananas as a primary ingredient. However, the presence of authentic Chinese patrons frequenting this restaurant serves as a testament to its genuine fare and commitment to catering to the discerning tastes of its clientele.

"Although we did not avail ourselves of the accommodations offered by the establishment in question, we must confess that the craps game available therein was truly exceptional, boasting a payout ratio of double on 12, complemented by the unparalleled offer of 100X odds, thereby rendering it an unmitigated delight for those seeking economical diversion within the illustrious Las Vegas Strip. Notwithstanding the somewhat advanced age of the edifice and the pervasive aroma of smoke that permeates the atmosphere, the native patrons are remarkably affable, while the beverages served are passable, if not particularly remarkable."

C'est avec une certaine impatience que je fantasmais sur ce restaurant... un peu trop peut-être.
Nous avons partagé des "croquettes" au foie gras : vraiment rien d'extraordinaire.
Ensuite, je me suis laissée tentée par la cote de cochon heureux: viande tendre et bien cuite, mais la sauce n'était pas assez tasty à mon gout. Mon ami a pris le magret de canard, pour le coup clairement décevant.
Tarte aux pacanes excellente, mais vient-on ici pour ça?

Vraiment contente d'y être allée, mais plusieurs restaurants dans la meme gamme de prix me rendent bien plus heureuse.

This particular venue and other adjacent locations, such as the Teepee, serve as poignant reminders of a bygone era in which the culinary offerings associated with Mexican cuisine were unwavering in their consistency and our expectations were decidedly modest. However, there are instances in which such familiar and unsophisticated fare strikes an emotional chord, thereby eliciting a profound sense of nostalgia. It is worth noting that this establishment boasts a rich and storied past, as evidenced by the numerous accounts chronicled by the illustrious Marty Robbins.

You get what you pay for, yet I wish you could get the basic needs. This place doesn't provide a mini fridge, tea kettle, coffee maker even less a microwave, so you are forced to spend all you pennies buying street food. Also the carpets are pretty old and stinky. Our faucet didn't work, we complained and the next day it was fixed.\nThe plusses were: silent after midnight, so you can sleep pretty well :) and pretty close to everything as well. \nWouldn't mind going back but would check other options first.

This sushi spot is average at best. The rolls have too much rice and hardly any fish. I would rather pay extra and get more substance than just eat a bunch of rice. I wish they had some sort of seating. I go here when I need to grab a quick work day lunch. It's on par with grocery store grade pre made sushi

This place was aight,

$4 Beer specials were a pretty good deal but the sole reason I'm not rating this place any higher is because of the food. (Better options at 4Peaks and Santan)

It was Underwhelming and Overpriced~ The ambiance of this place was nice though

Had the Oyster Po Boy and well.... if you want seafood I guess one should move a bit closer to the W-Coast.

I came here after getting absolutely no help at Fry's. It was nice to see that all of their mini computers,ereaders and the Kindle I wanted were at the very front of the store! I'm glad I didn't have to walk all the way to the back. I was wearing heels for the first time in a long time so my feet were aching. I just wanted to get the Kindle and go. I couldn't leave without a cute case for it though. They don't have a  huge selection so I settled for a bright blue case. My ideal case would have been pink or had Hello Kitty on it.\nThe employees were so much more willing to help here. It wasn't like Frys where it was like pulling teeth to get answers. When we were about to pay the cashier asked if we had their rewards card. We had one but I didn't want to use it because of what happened before. We made some big ticket purchases a couple of years back and the gift rewards were going to some random address in Illinois.  We tried to get it corrected through their call center and even talked to the manager. When we told them that the address on file was not ours and we could prove it they still would not change the address. This is why I will go no higher then a three star rating. I can never fully trust this company.

The nightclub within the Palms Casino Resort boasted a panoramic view of the city skyline from its lofty perch on the 53rd floor, yet the distance from the Las Vegas Strip rendered outdoor excursions impractical, save for the fortuitous meteorological conditions that prevailed during our visit; in essence, the club's unremarkable attributes, with the exception of its prime location, constituted a considerable achievement for the resort.

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment approximately seven days prior, and our gastronomical experiences were somewhat mixed. While neither my dining companion nor I were particularly impressed by the fare, we did find the victuals to be satisfactory. We opted for the gnocchi accompanied by marinara and the ravioli al formaggio. The former was cooked to a delightful consistency, while the latter's filling was appropriately savory. However, it was the marinara sauce that truly captured our attention, as its flavor profile was remarkably well-balanced and rich. As a connoisseur of this particular condiment, I must confess that it ranks among the finest specimens I have had the pleasure of sampling in recent times. In addition, we requested the caprese as a precursor to our main courses, which, while aesthetically pleasing, failed to elicit any extraordinary enthusiasm. Our server, though, exhibited commendable proficiency in their duties, fostering a welcoming ambiance within the dining area. Notwithstanding, the tariffs charged for the meals were, in our estimation, somewhat excessive given the venue's unpretentious nature and its location within a commercial complex.

"As an ardent admirer of Gordon Ramsay, I have always been captivated by his unwavering dedication to culinary excellence, which resonates with my own unyielding pursuit of perfection during my college years while manning the cast iron grill at Buffalo Wild Wings. Thus, it was only natural that I would be eager to experience the epicurean delights offered at his establishment. Upon entering, I was faced with a daunting dilemma - what to order from the extensive menu? This proved to be a formidable challenge, rivaled only by the complexity of the ACT exam. After deliberating at length, I decided to deviate from my customary burger and instead opted for the pie sampler, reasoning that it would afford me the opportunity to sample a variety of flavors without committing to a single entree. However, this decision ultimately proved to be a miscalculation, as the sampler, though replete with an array of savory pies, left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied due to its modest portion size. Each individual pie boasted exceptional quality, yet this was somewhat mitigated by the fact that it was merely an appetizer, leaving me still yearning for a more substantial meal. In retrospect, I would have been better served by selecting either a whole pie or a burger, or perhaps even pairing the sampler with one of these options. My companion's burger, which I surreptitiously sampled, appeared to be of exceptional quality, and I must admit that I was tempted to pilfer a few more fries had my friend not been vigilant. Notwithstanding this minor disappointment, I am resolved to return and indulge in the delectable burger that had eluded me on this particular visit."

"The computer science program leaves much to be desired, but the institution's size is quite impressive.  Its ambiance is reminiscent of Arizona, with an oppressive heat that can be overwhelming at times, especially for someone who currently resides in Las Vegas.  Despite this, my fellow students were quite cordial, although the instructors occasionally exhibited an excessive strictness.  A peculiar aspect of this school was the prevalence of bicycle thievery, resulting in the creation of Frankenstein-like vehicles, composed of various parts and colors, which provided a source of amusement.  Additionally, there were numerous individuals who enthusiastically promoted their religious or ideological beliefs, contributing to the diverse and eclectic atmosphere that I found appealing, even though my expectations regarding the teaching staff were not entirely fulfilled."

This lodging establishment had its fair share of both advantages and disadvantages during our stay. Upon arriving late on a Friday evening, we discovered that the non-smoking accommodation we had requested had been allocated to another guest, thus we were compelled to accept a smoking room instead. We were informed by the reception staff that we could exchange our room the following day between the hours of 12-3 pm, as they had inadvertently assigned our reserved room to someone else. 

The subsequent day arrived, and following a delightful time spent at both the pool and fitness center, we contacted the front desk to inquire about the status of our room. Unfortunately, they persistently postponed the estimated time of availability, causing us to squander five valuable hours of our day confined and awaiting the readiness of our non-smoking room. Considering that our weekend visit was restricted to a finite amount of time, it was truly frustrating to fritter away such a substantial portion of it. Following five hours of persistent complaints and expressions of dissatisfaction, we were ultimately provided with a non-smoking room, which put an end to the unpleasant experience. Despite this unsatisfactory occurrence, I chose to award three stars because the hotel's overall quality was not particularly impressive. However, the upgraded room we received was quite pleasant. 

In addition, it is worth mentioning that the hotel boasts a prime location, situated directly in the center of the renowned Las Vegas Strip and positioned directly opposite Cosmo and Bellagio. Moreover, we thoroughly enjoyed indulging in some retail therapy and savoring a delectable meal at Gordon Ramsey's esteemed Burgr restaurant.

"It is my ardent desire to possess articulations of greater quality, yet this establishment unfortunately hearkens back to my undergraduate era. I yearned to convey that this venue caters to those with limited financial means, however, the prices are not particularly affordable either. 

The ambiance is satisfactory, with a clean environment and a welcoming sushi chef who extended a warm greeting upon our arrival and departure. 

I must caution against consuming any raw items here, as the culinary offerings were merely mediocre. The tonkatsu was unfortunate in its desiccation, and the batter lacked substance. At $14.50, it fails to compare favorably to the superior value offered by King Muramoto at $10 for their lunch menu. 

The sole redeeming feature was the steaming bowl of miso soup that provided solace on a chilly day. 

The dearth of clientele on a Friday evening raises concerns regarding the freshness of their sashimi and sushi, rendering it an establishment that does not warrant consideration."

"GIGANTIC SERVINGS. ENORMOUS. Located within the unremarkable Imperial Palace hotel, situated on the Las Vegas Strip (upstairs), this eatery boasts voluminous compartments, partitioned into two distinct rooms. Upon entering, I was taken aback by the cavernous interior, which belied its unassuming exterior. A humble breakfast consisting of eggs, hash browns, a biscuit, and coffee was my selection. The biscuit, in particular, was suffused with an abundance of butter, exuding an irresistible aroma and warmth. Unfortunately, the sheer magnitude of the meal proved to be too much for my digestive system, as I was unable to consume the entirety of the biscuit or the remainder of the dish. The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, with prices commensurate to the copious amounts of food served. My entrÃ©e, one of the more basic options, cost a reasonable $9, while other dishes exceeded that amount. However, an unfortunate incident marred our dining experience, as a patron, seemingly recovering from a vigorous night of Vegas revelry, precipitously vacated the premises, leaving behind a trail of regurgitated contents. Witnessing such a scene before even finishing my meal was indeed unsettling. Nonetheless, this establishment remains an optimal destination for those seeking a satiating dining experience, perhaps best enjoyed donning protective attire..."

This hotel looks really nice and the staff are really nice. The fitness room has a few different things and they work. The free breakfast is amazing. The room isn't very functional. There's a refrigerator, but no microwave. When I eat out I have leftovers and I hate wasting food. The shower in the single bed rooms is something you would find in a dorm room. It's a tile shower only with a single shelf and there isn't a full shower door. When you stand in the shower, there's always a draft. I'm getting kind of tired of staying at \"nice\" places that are just pretty and serve no function.

I go to this restaurant usually on Sunday morning because they have their awesome double stamp days. 

Now for the restaurant-The wait can be a little annoying especially on the weekends. But, that's expected. 

The atmosphere-I usually  go to the one in Chandler off of Ray Rd. The atmosphere is very friendly and the restaurant is clean. I like the little breakfast bar they have. 

Food-The food is delicious and they have the perfect portions for me. However, my husband often complains that they don't give him enough food. But, this is where the cool little $1 menu comes in. They have a wide  range of things that you can add to your meal for $1. I usually add the fruit cup or mini-pancakes. I haven't had a chance to try a lot of their menu items. They have a pretty long list of items and I often get overwhelmed trying to figure out what to order. I have had the 7 Veggie Omelette. It was very tasty! What made it more enjoyable was knowing that I was eating a healthy omelette. Some of them have tons of ingredients and even one with all meat. The one thing that I have tried that I DO NOT recommend is the biscuits and gravy. I have had better. The gravy can taste a little bland and the biscuits taste chewy on the inside. 

Services-The service can be hit or miss. But, I do like that they give a large cup of your beverage to go. 

Great place overall.

I've been in here a few times, each time deciding that this time I'll do what they tell me to and I'll feel like Superwoman. I still haven't!!

Basically it's a health food shop. Kinda. They sell the likes of cod liver oil tablets and garlic capsules etc etc, the staff are WONDERFUL. Can'tt fault them on that!! I went in on day hearing that if I took a spoonful of Manuka Honey at bed time it helps your skin and makes you lose weight, and it did! I was glowing. Ok it wasn't like a heap of weight, but enough to make me feel better about myself. The staff gave me the honey and some cider vinegar to cook with, they knew all their stuff....but it cost me over £40!! Hence the missing 2*.

If you're serious about this sort of stuff then this is a great place. If not, then go to Boots.

It's K Mart, not bad just nothing special. Nothing really sets K Mart apart from any of the other conglomerates. Gotta shop here from time to time for MH exclusives so you'll see me busting out my Maverick patch & showing it off with pride

"The server exhibited remarkable attentiveness and helpfulness throughout our dining experience.  The egg-based dish known as an omelet was quite satisfactory.  However, we strongly advise against ordering the grape leaves, as they were liberally coated with a mysterious, reddish substance that resembled a gelatinous paste.  Upon taking a single bite, we promptly returned the dish, as it was unpalatable.  The ambiance of the establishment was reminiscent of a yellow mausoleum, complete with numerous small, enclosed spaces surrounding the primary dining area, which bore a striking resemblance to niches designed to house urns containing cremated remains.  Given such inconsistencies in the quality of the cuisine, it was apparent that the success or failure of any given dish was largely dependent on chance."
Decent pizza, pretty close in quality to Setabello. Menu has gotten a lot smaller and the price is a little on the high side for pizza. Good service and cozy environment.

I had the smothered chicken with mac and cheese and green beans.I can say it was worth the drive from Balyntyne suburbs to get some good ole southern cooking. i got there at 11:30am on a Wednesday... the lunch crowd has not even came in yet so I was 1 of the first customers I gave it a 3.5  star wish could have given it a 4 star mainly the it was too pricey for the amount of food given... A fair price for that plate should have been $7 tops.. I paid $10 an didnt get a drink with it.. Don't think I will be visiting this place anytime soon..

"During our most recent leisure excursion, we opted to halt for a repast at Braddah's Island Style for the second time, and decided to partake in a Kalua pig burrito, replete with seaweed rice, black beans, charred pineapple verde, lettuce, and tomato. Despite the fact that the administration had the temerity to deplete their stock of cilantro, an herb commonly used as a garnish, our burrito remained palatable. However, we noticed a perceptible decline in the cordiality and attentiveness of the staff during this visit, as evidenced by the absence of complimentary samples, uncleared tables, and the delayed provision of condiments, which were only provided following a patron's request after a considerable interval of ten minutes had elapsed. Consequently, we would assign a rating of 3.5 to this dining experience."

"This culinary establishment presented itself in a relatively satisfactory manner, prompting us to peruse their menu and select the egg rolls and grilled pork dishes. However, the duration of time that elapsed between placing our order and the arrival of our meals was truly protracted, particularly considering the modest number of patrons present within the restaurant during our visit. 

Notwithstanding this inconvenience, the interior of the eatery appeared well-maintained and organized. Unfortunately, a considerable quantity of smoke emanating from the kitchen region managed to permeate the primary dining area, perhaps indicative of an issue with ventilation. 

Upon receipt of our order, it became apparent that the egg rolls were diminutive in stature and accompanied by a sweet and sour sauce, rather than the customary fish sauce typically associated with such fare. Furthermore, while the flavor of the grilled pork was undeniably palatable, its portion size seemed somewhat meager in relation to the cost. 

In conclusion, although our experience at this restaurant was not without its drawbacks, it did possess certain redeeming qualities that rendered it a worthwhile excursion. However, it remains uncertain whether a subsequent visit would be warranted."

"While indulging in some leisure time in Las Vegas, I opted to peruse online reviews in pursuit of an exceptional breakfast establishment. Upon conducting my research, I stumbled upon this particular venue, which boasted an impressive array of delectable offerings. On a Sunday morning around 10 am, I decided to pay a visit to the restaurant, only to find a considerable queue of patrons anxiously awaiting entrance. The delay was approximately thirty minutes, which I deemed acceptable given the prospect of savoring a scrumptious meal. Upon being seated, I was immediately struck by the generous portion sizes, which seemed to bode well for a satisfying dining experience. I elected to sample the traditional Benedict, which, unfortunately, fell short of my expectations in terms of temperature. The dish was rather tepid, lacking the warmth that would have elevated its flavors to a truly gratifying level. Thus, while the presentation was undoubtedly appealing, the culinary aspects left something to be desired."

Le Marly, a seemingly ordinary establishment, proved to be satisfactory. Although I did not partake in their culinary offerings, I did indulge in their unique beverages. Specifically, their signature raspberry martini, crafted with vodka, raspberry puree, and a fragrant basil leaf, was quite palatable. The majority of their potations, including liquor-based drinks, were priced below $10, with a standard 20-ounce beer costing approximately $7.50. The delectable appetizers sampled by my associates appeared visually appealing, although I did not have the pleasure of consuming them myself. Unfortunately, this modern, purple-themed watering hole, situated in the heart of downtown, does not seem to attract a considerable clientele. During our nearly three-hour visit on a Thursday evening, no new patrons entered the premises. The hospitable staff members, who graciously accepted our outerwear without charging a fee, were attentive to our needs, particularly regarding beverages. While I would not select this venue for an exclusive evening excursion, I would accompany a group if they chose to frequent it.

We have a propensity to partake in the first meal of the day at this establishment with considerable regularity, as it offers a familiar ambiance and culinary offerings that are representative of the standard fare associated with the International House of Pancakes franchise, and we have been consistently impressed by the attentive and hospitable demeanor displayed by the servers and other personnel who attend to our needs during our visits.

This hotel is really cool for the younger group, I'd say 27 years and below.  I am thirty and I have to say that although its a great hotel, its not quite my style.

The rooms are pretty good.  They are decorated very sexy but there were a few little things that could have used repair, such as the wall plugs were a little loose and rattley.  Be warned, they have vibrators and lube in the mini-bar, so if you have little kids, probably not the best.

I definitely think that the pool brings in a younger crowd.  I didn't go to the pool, but there were so many guests there in their early twenties, clearly coming from the pool and highly intoxicated and loud that I think the hotel could do without. 

I do recommend eating at the Pink Taco inside the Hard Rock while you are there.  Very good Mexican Food.

I think its a great hotel, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to people over thirty and definitely not to people bringing kids.  However, if you are in your twenties, this is the spot.  The guests that were there in the appropriate age range were having the time of their lives.

If you are from out of town, which I assume most people in Vegas are, please note that this is not on the actual strip.  It is really close, but you will have to take a cab ride to and from.

"It appears that our initial intention of partaking in a leisurely luncheon at L'Avenue was thwarted by an extensive queue that extended beyond the entrance, thereby necessitating a modification of our plans. Subsequently, we opted to traverse the street and visit a nearby eatery with an inviting outdoor seating area, whereupon we were delightfully surprised by the culinary offerings, generous portion sizes, and attentive service. Notably, the prices were rendered eminently reasonable due to the copiousness of the servings, and furthermore, pints of Boreale draft beer were available at the exceptionally affordable rate of $5, which struck me as a veritable bargain. It is worth mentioning that the prevalence of individuals in Montreal who customarily consume alcoholic beverages during the midday repast appears to be somewhat reminiscent of certain European traditions, a phenomenon that I wholeheartedly endorse. In conclusion, this establishment may be deemed a reliable venue for a satisfying dining experience."

My boyfriend and I dropped in for the first time on a Sunday afternoon.  The atmosphere was nice and the restaurant was very clean.  Our server Dan was knowledgeable and pleasant. The food was average but good for the price. We will definately be back.

I went here for the first time yesterday and was waiting to meet someone.  When I arrived I wasn't greeted for a good 5 minutes in a mostly empty dining room.  I had to wonder around until someone attended to me.  After telling them that I'd like a table for 2 they sit me at a big table with 5 places as opposed to a booth.   

After my friend arrived our order was taken promptly and our waitress was nice. The food was lukewarm and could have been seasoned better although the meat on my dish was cooked tender and came in a good portion size although there were a TON of onions I'm contrast to the meat portion.  The rice was bland and boring as well.  

The decor looked great and very classy and the staff was overall friendly.  The price was fair for the portion size and I'd be willing to give this place another go, but I hope for better food and someone at the door to greet me right away.

This is one of those three and a half star moments for me, Bison Witches is a sandwich shop with a fairly impressive beer selection and fair prices. I like their chili cheese nachos quite a bit and Kristen likes the miss pris. There's really nothing extraordinary here though, good food, good booze, good service, good prices. It's all good. Three and a half.

"I am thoroughly convinced that this quaint, family-owned eatery is utterly remarkable! The culinary offerings are truly delectable; specifically, I relished every bite of their sumptuous lobster roll complemented by an array of flavorful clam chowders. Although the portion size may not be as substantial as those found at seaside establishments, it nevertheless serves as an effective remedy for my intense yearning for fresh seafood, given my current geographical location in Las Vegas."

"Upon perusing the menu, we opted to sample their culinary offerings, specifically the tamale burger, which unfortunately did not meet our expectations due to its arid nature and an unpleasant aftertaste. However, the fries accompanying the dish were quite delectable, boasting an inventive blend of spices that included a subtle hint of nutmeg and cinnamon, thereby evoking a sense of warmth and depth. Despite the underwhelming experience with the food, we were thoroughly impressed by the ambiance, characterized by dim lighting and a welcoming atmosphere that fostered a convivial ambiance, which was further enhanced by the bartender's proficiency in crafting expertly mixed cocktails. Moreover, the staff demonstrated exceptional customer service, as they graciously offered us a complimentary replacement drink following an unfortunate spillage. Consequently, we intend to revisit this establishment, primarily for the purpose of indulging in their beverages, and perhaps experimenting with alternative menu items, such as the sweet and spicy burger, which our server enthusiastically endorsed."

"Our inaugural visit transpired two days prior to the culmination of the year, and we partook of their midday repast.  The Green Papaya salad and Panang curry, both piquant and flavorful, garnered our unwavering approbation.  The hospitality we received was quite satisfactory, and the beverage, an icy brew, was quaffed with relish.  However, a cursory inspection of the premises revealed a minor shortcoming; specifically, a negligible amount of detritus was scattered about the floor, which remained unattended throughout the duration of our meal.  Nonetheless, we would unhesitatingly recommend this establishment to any individual who takes pleasure in Thai cuisine...nota bene:  The thermostat settings, purportedly the most scorching, did not quite live up to our expectations."

Not so bad. The entrance looks like a hotel check-in. The security team here was cool, which is refreshing for a club on the strip. Usually security crew's think they are real cops with a Napoleon complex.

It was a week day when I went, so it wasn't too crowded. Lil Jon was playing and he's a decent DJ. 

Since I'm a local and I usually avoid the strip, I was (as usual) SHOCKED when I was told it was $52 for a beer, wine, and a shot for the the birthday boy. This is why I stay away from the strip. Not that it is their fault - that's how they pay their rent. I wish clubs like this would offer local prices even when it comes to drinks. Because seriously we could just stash alcohol in our car and run in and out of the club. It's not like we're staying in a hotel and have no way to get more booze. Just a thought!

Overall, compared to Haze, Tryst, ... (and all the other clubs I've been to but can't remember at the moment), this one was pretty decent. Moon is still my favorite, but XS wasn't bad.

I'd give this place 3.5 stars... after reading the other reviews I expected a half of a cup of pasta or something ridiculous but I thought the portion was adequate. And, I was REALLY hungry when I got there. 

We ordered the olives as a starter (they are all green and served warm) and were able to get some bread to accompany the reserve oil. 

Our server voluntarily explained menu items with important details like: it's ricotta gnocchi, not potato and the extra items in the puntanesca sauce (my recipe only has 7). We both had the orecchiette with sausage and greens. I found it to be a bit oily but the pasta was cooked well. 

He described the deserts perfectly and the chocolate bark with almonds was a nice finish with a second glass of nero d'avalo, and, by the way... I though the wine prices were very reasonable! 

Without tip, we spent about $36 a person and we each had two glasses of wine and left satisfied!

Seemingly, bars such this are effected massively by the clientele. This particular All Bar One, nestled in the middle of Edinburgh's financial district results in mostly desk job monkeys frequenting the place.

One thing I've learnt in my time in Edinburgh is that such clientele and students don't mix. Thus, All Bar One is best avoided .

Drinks, food etc are all pretty standard - not that dissimilar to Wetherpoons in what it offers.

After having witnessed the ostentatious display of Fry's Signature in Scottsdale, my anticipation for this supermarket was elevated. Although the establishment did not boast the same level of opulence, its appearance was still rather captivating.

Proceeding toward the restrooms, which were situated adjacent to the pharmaceutical department, I was pleasantly surprised by the subtle yet effective implementation of air fresheners, which contributed to creating a welcoming ambiance within the facilities.

It is worth mentioning that this supermarket houses a diverse array of amenities, including a Starbucks and a sushi bar, thereby catering to a wide range of consumers' preferences. However, it is important to note that the absence of price scanners was a notable omission.

Despite its location in a relatively remote area, this supermarket manages to attract a considerable volume of patrons, a testament to its enduring popularity among local residents and visitors alike.

Not a bad place. Service is good with friendly employees. The food, although not the beat does taste good and is fresh.  While there I had the angry whopper. Im not a fan of thick french fries, but theirs was still good. 

What I liked most was their choices of soda. They have "orange coke" flavored soda. I never even heard of it before, so I had to try and and wow. Was it good.  

Sadly the whole time I was thinking there they never swept the floor that needed it. Yeah its a small thing and I am not going to eat off it, but visually it is not appealing. The same is true of their bathroom floor.

"I am attending a conference at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, and I have opted to frequent this establishment for two meals during my stay. On my initial visit, I indulged in a delectable Angus steak burger, complemented by an assortment of mushrooms and a tangy bleu cheese, all for the reasonable price of $20, inclusive of tax. Although not particularly economical, this culinary delight proved to be the most satisfactory value within the vast confines of the resort's dining options, especially considering the late hour of 9:47 p.m. upon checking in. 

The following morning, I returned to partake in their breakfast offerings. While the individual dishes were quite expensive, I elected to exercise fiscal prudence by ordering two side dishes instead: two eggs prepared to my liking for a moderate fee of $8, accompanied by a portion of home fries for an additional $3. Furthermore, I treated myself to an oversized cup of tea, which, although priced at a somewhat exorbitant $3.50, was nonetheless a worthwhile investment due to the inclusion of a high-quality English Breakfast tea bag, honey, and the availability of soy milk. 

The staff at this establishment has consistently displayed warmth and efficiency in their service, creating a welcoming ambiance that more than compensates for the lack of a sophisticated dining experience. In conclusion, while not an exceptional eatery, this venue provides a suitable setting for a satisfying meal at a tolerable cost within the context of the resort's generally elevated prices."

"It appears that I fail to comprehend the essence of this establishment, as my experience was characterized by a profound lack of distinction in all aspects, including the culinary offerings, customer service, and pricing. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the Kiki burger, which regrettably conformed to the prevailing norm of mediocrity, with certain bites exhibiting an unbalanced sweetness, yet partially redeemed by the savory presence of mushrooms. Furthermore, my order of garlic fries proved to be a disappointment, as the scant portion size belied the deceptive impression of abundance, thereby eliciting a sense of dissatisfaction. Moreover, the hostesses demonstrated a remarkable propensity for accommodating patrons in close proximity to our table, which engendered considerable annoyance, prompting nearby diners to request relocation twice during the course of our meal. In light of these circumstances, I must aver that any future visit would be highly unlikely, as the dearth of exceptional qualities renders this dining establishment unworthy of further consideration."

You should come here to revel in the ambiance and to partake in the phenomenon that has captivated the attention of many. Order a frozen hot chocolate and you shall have indulged in an experience comparable to the one offered by its counterpart in NY, albeit the latter being a humble shack. Be aware, however, that this frozen delight is excessively sweet, and even when shared with another individual, you will likely consume only half of it, leaving behind a substantial amount of whipped cream. 

Their culinary offerings are unremarkable and typical of establishments serving standard American fare, such as TGIF. The loaded potato skins, priced at $11, are not worth the expense, and the chicken dijon pizza, at $14, is arid and unappetizing. It is advisable to opt for store-bought frozen pizza instead and cook it in the comfort of your own home. 

People flock to this establishment for the experience alone, which warrants three stars. The ambiance possesses an ineffable quality that makes women feel pampered and special. :))

I've been to the Bank twice and I'm not sure if I'd go back. I think my first trip was an anamoly. The club was poppin with amazaaaaaazing music. I wish I could have got that mix! The club was packed and since the Bank is kinda tiny, it felt like a house party. Everyone was dancing and having a great time, you could really feel the positive energy. We met some cool people and hung at their table majority of the night so it made the night more enjoyable. You never realize how much you value being able to sit down when you want to LOL! I didn't want to leave the club because I was having so much fun, but I had an early flight so I had too :(

The 2nd trip, 6 months later on Christmas Day was less thrilling. I was on the guestlist so we walked right in at like 11. It was DOA and as time went by the club filled up the crowd looked very unattractive. I can't even blame the lameness on the fact that it was a holiday so it may have been so an off night because we left and went to XS and it was packed with better looking people *shrug*. 

Overall I'm thinking that on my first trip to the Bank either I got really lucky or maybe Christmas night  just so happend to be a wrong place/wrong time bust? Maybe the third time will be the charm??

"The quality of the cuisine is reliably satisfactory, conforming to the high standards that are inherent in the reputation of this establishment, despite its affiliation with a large corporate entity, which, admittedly, may engender a certain degree of skepticism on the part of those who prefer independently-owned dining establishments. Nonetheless, it would be remiss to dismiss the exceptional nature of their chambord margarita, which distinguishes itself from the ordinary and mundane offerings typically associated with chain restaurants."

This was our maiden visit to Tandoori Times; thus, we were eager to sample their culinary offerings and assess the ambiance. Upon entering the establishment, we were immediately struck by the warm and welcoming atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the subtle lighting and tasteful decor. Although we anticipated a larger crowd, the restaurant was surprisingly uncrowded, which allowed us to savor our dining experience without the distraction of boisterous patrons.  
The culinary offerings at Tandoori Times were indeed impressive. We opted for the goat curry, which was their Friday special, and it did not disappoint. The flavors were rich and well-balanced, with none of the spices overpowering the others. Additionally, the tender chunks of goat meat were cooked to perfection, literally melting in our mouths. Our better half, who is typically not enamored with curries, was pleasantly surprised by the tandoori chicken. The marinade added depth to the dish without overwhelming the natural flavors of the poultry. The pesto naan was an excellent accompaniment to our meals, providing a delightful contrast in texture and taste. In short, we had no criticisms regarding the cuisine whatsoever.  
Unfortunately, the same cannot be said about the service we received. Our server, although polite and affable during his sparse appearances, failed to attend to our needs in a timely manner. After presenting us with menus, he vanished for an interminable period, leaving us to wonder if we needed to summon him via smoke signals or Morse code. When he finally reappeared, he took our order expeditiously but neglected to inquire about our beverage preferences. As a result, we were forced to solicit the attention of another server to procure our drinks. Moreover, the prolonged delay in delivering our food made us question whether the kitchen staff was engaged in an epic battle of Jenga or merely relishing a leisurely game of cricket. In either case, the wait was unacceptable and detracted significantly from our dining experience.  
Lastly, there was the unsightly spectacle of the belly dancing. While the novelty of the performance was initially entertaining, the cacophony generated by the dancer's zealous finger cymbals and the abrupt surges in music volume quickly became grating on our nerves. The constant din precluded any semblance of conversation between my husband and myself, reducing our interaction to a series of strained shouts. Although the dancing itself was engaging at first, its repetition grew tiresome after several minutes, transforming what should have been a captivating diversion into an annoyance that rivaled the persistently ringing cymbals.  
In conclusion, Tandoori Times presents a mixed bag of delights and drawbacks. Despite the culinary excellence and agreeable prices, the service leaves much to be desired. Nonetheless, we might revisit this establishment in the future, hoping that the kinks in their service will be ironed out by then.

My one pet peeve about some "shi shi" restaurants are snooty patooty hosts and hostesses.  Our party did not feel welcomed at all by the hostess (who said we'd have to pay $7 per plate for a surprise birthday cake we tried to bring in) and who looked at us like we were paupers.

Once we got past Cruella DeVil, I ordered a Lycheetini from the bar.  Loved it and would've ordered more but wanted to save room for the food.

We were escorted into an elevator which took us up to the restaurant.  I was impressed by the modern Asian decor.  Our waiter and bussers was very attentive and never was a sake glass empty.  I ordered their special California roll, freshwater eel roll, and adobo chicken roll.  The food was good, but the atmosphere and ambiance is what you pay for.

Based on the lumpia, pancit, and adobo on the menu, I assume the chef is Filipino.  One of the staff asked if I was related to the chef.  Didn't know all Filipinos were related.  


The restaurant lives up to its name.  The Social House is the perfect place to spend time with friends, enjoy some authentic sushi, and get tipsy on good sake.  If they would only get rid of the snotty hostesses.

For such a thin pizza, it's really overpriced. I ordered extra cheese as a topping, and it was barely any cheese on the pizza. 
The pizza is much different from what I am usually used to. 

They have only a few items to choose from on the menu, like salad and pizza choices only. 

If it gets cold it pretty much has to be thrown out because it gets really hard even when heated up. 

Great thing about this place is that they use a coal oven. That's really good, it always makes pizza better. 

The pizza was decent, but just not my type.

The only reason I visit this Dunkin' Donuts a lot is because the one near me closes early.  If I have a late night craving for iced coffee, I have to go to Sam's Town.  Fine.  I love DD's, but this location is just so-so.  Depending on who makes the drink, the coffee is very inconsistent.  Every time, I get the same thing... and every time, it's like I'm getting a very different product.  At my normal DD's, the coffee tastes exactly the same each time.  Here, my fianc\u00e9 and I have learned to order our drinks a certain way based on who is making them, and even then, we sometimes end up with a Frankenstein drink.  Also, the workers are usually friendly.  However, there is one young girl who is often there late at night who seems to get really angry whenever a customer walks in.  I really wish she would get an attitude adjustment, because it makes ordering something really uncomfortable.

OK so today someone in my office brought me a sandwich from City Market Deli. It was the Santa Fe Club. Oven Gold Turkey, Bacon, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato, Alfalfa Sprouts, Chipotle Mayo served on Our Toasted Multi-Grain Bread.\n\nThe bread is very good and the sandwich has a good amount of flavorful turkey. The chipotle mayo has just the right amount of heat. Overall a very tasty sandwich!

"Let me initiate my remarks by emphasizing that the culinary offerings themselves were undoubtedly a 5; my companion and I opted to share yakitori and onigiri, and I had the pleasure of consuming a pork rice bowl, albeit with an excessive amount of fat, but the portion I did eat was indeed delectable; my companion, on the other hand, decided on a tuna and salmon salad special from the wall. Additionally, we took advantage of the wine specials available on the wall, which were offered at the remarkably affordable price of $4 per glass - truly remarkable! The pricing overall was quite reasonable. We made a concerted effort to consume as much as we possibly could. However, there were certain aspects that left something to be desired:\n\nWe elected to be seated at the bar, yet unfortunately, the temperature was so elevated that it significantly impaired our appetites. Although the service was generally satisfactory, it must be noted that it was more of a collective endeavor rather than the responsibility of a single server. Furthermore, the food was presented in a somewhat haphazard manner, with no discernible pattern regarding the order in which the dishes were served; while this did not pose a problem for us personally, it is possible that some individuals may not be entirely comfortable with such an arrangement. Lastly, the establishment's dimensions were rather diminutive, and we were compelled to wait for approximately two minutes before being seated, which, although tolerable, resulted in a moderately lengthy queue upon our departure."

During our return journey from Las Vegas, we decided to make a brief halt at this establishment, and sample their culinary offerings. My gastronomical inclinations were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the edibles, particularly the dipping sauces, which I found to be more delectable than those proffered by Boiling Crab (LA). However, our server's inability to elucidate the varying degrees of piquancy, coupled with her unfortunate tendency to downplay the fiery nature of certain menu items, somewhat tempered my enthusiasm for indulging in an extensive array of dishes. Specifically, she cautioned against the Cajun fries, characterizing them as excessively fiery, while simultaneously recommending the mild sauce as a safer alternative, despite my explicit expression of preference for pungent flavors. Consequently, I opted for a less ambitious order, forgoing both the Cajun fries and the medium sauce, which, in hindsight, I might have relished had I been adequately informed. Furthermore, an unfortunate mix-up with one of my companion's orders resulted in the substitution of chicken wings for fried shrimp, followed by an interminable delay in rectifying the error and presenting us with an incorrect bill. Despite these drawbacks, I might consider revisiting the restaurant, provided they address their service-related shortcomings.

It's a flat odd coloured mess, I can't wait to go back. I had the Dic Ann cheeseburger and sauce, which is a flat cheeseburger with meat sauce, and they give you a popsicle stick to lift it out of the cardboard basket. And the flattest hot dog with all the fixins, I can't really explain it, but it was squashed and tasty. Think White Castle but with Wolverine-like origins, from the Wilds of the Canadian wilderness, Montreal.

"While not my customary Goodwill drop-off site, this particular location is considerable in size, boasting an expansive layout that has assimilated the former standalone structure adjacent to it, with the Hannaford supermarket now cohabiting the premises, albeit with a diminished capacity to accommodate the arrival of Goodwill, thereby necessitating a slight detour through the loading dock zone for efficient unloading, ultimately providing a serviceable and convenient drop-off point."

"I arrived at this establishment on a previous evening, driven by an intense yearning for a delectable Banh Mi, and a profound dissatisfaction with the subpar offerings at Lee's Sandwich. Following a perusal of favorable assessments regarding Mr. Sandwich's rendition of this popular Vietnamese dish, I opted to sample their culinary expertise. While the sandwiches proved to be marginally superior to those of Lee's, my gastronomical exploits in California have afforded me the opportunity to indulge in more exceptional specimens. Thus, my quest for the ideal Banh Mi continues unabated. Notwithstanding, my curiosity regarding the diverse array of comestibles proffered by Mr. Sandwich remains piqued, and I shall indeed revisit this eatery to partake of their other offerings."

Staff is great. The restaurant is clean, yet the food is missing something in comparison to Chipotle. Location is awesome (across from Wells Fargo)!

My boyfriend loves this place(only one like it that offers buffalo chicken), but despite multiple attempts I never finish it. 

Normally I love the bowl, yet I've tried the burrito too. I want to love this place. 

Favorite item is chips and cheese dip. They've never let me down there.

Experienced my first spring training game on St. Patty's Day with a matchup of the A's Vs. the Giants.  Half my family was in A's gear and the other half in Giants.  First the good.  I really liked the size and feel of the ballpark, felt like there was no bad seat in the stadium.  Parking was inexpensive and plenty of it.  Concessions were good and they had extra people out with buckets of beer and water.  Now the bad.  We had seats in the outfields and the bleacher benches were built for 8 year olds, not someone over 6 ft tall.  Also, there was no grass areas in the outfield.  Overall, I really enjoyed the game, Giants won, and we all had a good time.  I look forward to going to Scottsdale stadium.

"It appears to be a competition to determine who can consume the largest quantity of flesh in the shortest period of time. The culinary offerings at this establishment were satisfactory, albeit it took an extended duration for the various meats to arrive, resulting in a limited sample size of each selection. Additionally, the venue's diminutive size and cramped atmosphere, coupled with an underwhelming array of side dishes and exorbitant beverages, contributed to an overall sense of disenchantment. Even with prior reservations, the prolonged delay only served to amplify my disappointment, rendering any potential enthusiasm for a future visit nonexistent."

"Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance that permeated the atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the pleasant temperature that facilitated my comfort and enjoyment of the culinary offerings available. Specifically, the chicken wings were of exceptional quality, with the Maui Wowi and Hot Ranch sauces serving as the perfect complement to their natural flavor. However, despite the excellence of the food, I would not recommend dining in, as the layout and decor of the restaurant did not particularly lend themselves to an intimate or relaxing experience. Nevertheless, I did notice that the establishment offered a unique and spacious area designated for private gatherings and celebrations, which could potentially be taken advantage of for future events."

5 Star service, this place is very homely and hidden on the side of Wynn road.  It must compete with Dai jung gum (korean place) and Pho.  I think that their dishes are very homestyle:  The Panang and Veggie green curries are reminiscent of that from a can that I can make at home.  Their soup that comes with the lunch special however, is spectacular- No MSG and sweet from overloading of chicken and veggies.  \n\nI had the Sliced beef noodle soup, Thai style. I was anticipating something spicy sour and sweet, but instead it's just beefy broth and thin pho-like noodles...  Not quite the kind they have in texas
Not sure what's going on, slow service many of their own beers out of stock on a slow Sunday evening.\nFood was so slow I cancelled my entr\u00e9e and left.

Doc and Eddy's offers an acceptable dining experience, albeit unremarkable and unexceptional. It may serve as a suitable venue for gatherings of a larger group of individuals seeking basic bar fare and beverages, given its expansive dimensions that preclude a sense of confinement. In the rear of the establishment, numerous pool tables and assorted games provide entertainment for patrons. The front area features additional tables designated for culinary consumption, while television sets are ubiquitous throughout the premises. During a recent visit, I sampled the SoCal Chicken Sandwich and found it to be merely satisfactory, with a slightly desiccated texture. However, I did appreciate the seasoning applied to my fries. The cuisine at Doc and Eddy's is adequate for a bar, and I surprisingly felt satiated upon conclusion of my meal. Service was adequate, yet unremarkable, as it met the bare minimum requirements for satisfaction without compelling generous gratuity. Previously, my experience with the service at this establishment was subpar. Notably, my draft beer was served with insufficient foam, which, while not excessively frothy, was still deficient in this regard. Given its proximity to my residence, I envision revisiting Doc and Eddy's on occasion, although its unexceptional offerings do not particularly entice me.

very elegant but after  our bad day we decided to eat here and this was our last day so we enter it was clean only few people by the bar I order the fagioli soup  it was good, and veal piccata I did like the flavor but vegetables to plain of flavor, hubby order lasagna he didn't like it  and the bread they serve it really good also the vinaigrette they serve I really love he flavor so it was good for the prize we pay

"So, one might wonder, given the ostensible quality of the performances hosted at this venue - BRMC, The Black Keys, and Guster, all of whom delivered exceptional shows, it must be said - why does it not garner a higher rating, say, of four or five stars? Well, my dear reader, let me elucidate. Firstly, there are the exorbitant fees associated with online ticket purchases, which, when combined with the additional five-dollar parking charge, result in an aggregate increase of ten to twelve dollars per ticket. Now, were these surcharges to benefit the performing artists themselves, one might be inclined to turn a blind eye. However, I assure you, the maintenance costs of the facility do not warrant such excessive fees. In essence, it is a large concrete room, albeit one with a sloping floor designed to afford prime views of the stage from any vantage point. Admittedly, the drink selection is satisfactory, the prices reasonable, and both security personnel and restroom facilities are adequate. Furthermore, it is undeniable that this venue attracts high-caliber acts, making it a worthwhile destination for music enthusiasts such as myself, who must, perforce, selectively seek out musical experiences in this, the fifth most populous city in the United States, wherein live performances by notable artists are often few and far between."

Jollibee has been my preferred fast-food establishment since my early childhood days, as it holds sentimental value to me, having frequented it with my mother on numerous occasions, particularly on my birthdays, thereby creating an indelible mark on my culinary experiences. The Las Vegas branch of Jollibee was the first that I had the pleasure of visiting outside of the Philippines, which dates back a few years, and I have made it a point to visit it at least twice annually since then. My gastronomical inclinations lean towards their delectable Chicken Joy, accompanied by a side of spaghetti, and the delightful Peach Mango Pie, although I find their other offerings to be satisfactory as well.

My parents Like to come here, so I often meet them for lunch.
This means free food for me, so the price is awesome.
Service is always friendly, and the food is pretty darn good.
I love a cold beer and some fried zucchini, and they have it, so that's pretty sweet.
They could expand on their beer selection, that would be OK by me.

Convenient location, cold beer, tasty BBQ.  Even if I did have to pay I think I would come here.

Just stopped in there this afternoon for the fall pumpkin pretzel.  The space is pretty bare, and they could do a little more with the decor to entice customers.  The service was OK, not rude but also not friendly or welcoming.  The choices are limited to 5 flavors plus the special of the day which happened to be pumpkin.  I thought the pumpkin pretzel could have had more pumpkin flavor to it.  It tasted like a cinnamon sugar pretzel.  It was tasty though, so I won't knock them too much for that.  I'll probably be back, if they offer some more interesting flavors.

"Despite my numerous sojourns at the Palazzo, a review of this esteemed establishment has yet to materialize on my part, an oversight that remains shrouded in mystery, much like the city's ubiquitous mantra that 'what happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas.' Be that as it may, allow me to extol the virtues of this distinguished hotel, boasting an enviable location, spacious accommodations, and a thoughtful layout that delineates the sleeping and living quarters. Alas, my fervent criticism revolves around the bathroom's inadequate illumination, which makes applying cosmetics an arduous task, thereby detracting from the overall experience and compelling me to seek alternative lodgings."

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, specifically during those nocturnal hours when the ambiance is at its most vibrant and the clientele is at its most diverse. It is my observation that the venue has a propensity to become overcrowded, to an extent that is unparalleled by any other Southside establishment, ostensibly due to its novelty and burgeoning popularity among the local populace. However, on evenings when the throng is less oppressive, the atmosphere at Local can be quite convivial, particularly when enjoying the balmy summer air on the outdoor patio. The demographic that frequents this establishment is characteristic of the Southside bar scene, yet, if one is seeking an atmosphere of refinement and urbanity, perhaps a different locale would be more suitable. Notwithstanding, the patrons are generally affable, the service is prompt provided one can successfully navigate the barrier of patrons, and while the tariff for potent potables may be slightly elevated, the overall experience at Local remains an enjoyable one, particularly during the warmer months when the weather permits al fresco revelry."

Standard overall. Came to look at a PS3 and some games, but realized that Black Friday would produce better deals. Ended up looking around the store for CDs and DVDs. The selection is not too impressive since everything can be streamed, purchased, or downloaded now-a-days. \n\nMore than anything, Best Buy is around for nostalgia. This store does have friendly staff which are helpful in searching for items though.

Got a cotton candy sorbet on top of vanilla custard with sprinkles. It was absolutely delish and not overly sweet. The custard was so nice and thick that I was afraid the plastic spoon they gave me would snap. The servers could be a little friendlier and less monotonous. They were helpful but gave me the impression that they just didn't want to be there. The store gives the ambience of a darker Baskin Robbins. For a nicer experience, my advice is to get your stuff to go and eat it at the nearby park.

It's a decently good sized store with lots of cheap stuff that is almost fashionable.  There were lots of people in the store and people buying quite a bit of clothes.  Not certain why I ended up dropping dough but somehow I felt like I just needed to have something new to carry around and bring home I guess.

We possess acquaintances who effusively praise the culinary offerings of mu shu, whereas our sentiments towards this particular dish are somewhat more tepid, despite our proximity to the establishment in question; specifically, we reside merely a few blocks distant. Our assessment of the price-to-quality ratio is predicated upon the unit of measurement denominated in pounds. Notwithstanding the cordial demeanor of the staff, the overall quality of the comestibles served is tantamount to that typically associated with cafeterias.

Through all our trips to Arizona, we kept driving by Nielsen's Frozen Custard when we went to and from our hotel to our daughter's home.  Each time, I would say to myself that we had to give it a try.  However, many times we would drive by it when it was closed.  Well...this trip (our final one to visit our daughter who has now moved), we got here!

Upon entering, we were surprised to find that in addition, to frozen custard, they also served meals (burgers, sandwiches, salads, etc.).  We were there strictly for the frozen custard.

We were greeted by a very friendly young lady who worked behind the counter.  She was patient with us as we perused the massive topping menu---so much choice!  In the end, I chose a small cup of vanilla with sprinkles and my husband had a small cup of unadorned chocolate custard.  After ordering, we were given a number to put on our table then the young lady brought out our order quickly.

We both agreed that the frozen custard had a nice, creamy consistency.  However, we found that it didn't have much flavor.  Neither the vanilla nor the chocolate had a strong enough flavor---and that was disappointing.  We were expecting much better.

Yet, we don't regret giving it a try.  Had we not done so, it would have been one of those things that would have nagged at me.  I would have always wondered if we had missed out on something excellent.

Clean moderately priced hotel. Came in during CES week and paid about 160$ a night for 4 nights. Got a smoking room, you can hear plumbing next door, stains in the bath and toilet from cigg burns, sitting chair had white stains on it. It costs 5$ for hot water! It seems it's always the expensive hotels that don't have a microwave, coffeemaker, fridge, and charge an arm and a leg for stuff like hot water, and wifi.  Anyhow I got smart and just heated up my water with a glass cup and the iron. PH you think you can work me, but no no no.. LOL.

It's a Grassmarket pub of reasonable size, with a reasonable selection of beers and spirits and a reasonable decor. There are some hidden treats though: be sure to seek out the back garden on a summer's evening, or head upstairs to the quiet and reserved dining area. There's also a healthy festival pedigree - a small room even further upstairs finds itself converted into a snug and cosy performance space for comedy acts of the surreal and experimental end of the spectrum (in my experience).\n\nWell done Beehive: you're there when we need you.

We tend to visit this particular establishment when we are not particularly inclined to venture forth on an extensive excursion, or alternatively, when we happen to be within the confines of the shopping plaza and are in dire need of sustenance for our reptilian companions in the form of feeder crickets. However, it has been our experience that securing assistance from an employee can be a rather arduous task, even after soliciting the aid of multiple individuals, numbering up to four. Notwithstanding this, the cashiers have consistently displayed a cordial demeanor towards us, and on occasion, have even extended generous discounts to us as compensation for enduring prolonged waiting periods while they endeavored to facilitate the processing of a customer's transaction. Despite these factors, we shall continue to patronize this business for the same reasons that initially drew us to it, although it does not hold the distinction of being our premier choice among establishments specializing in the sale of items related to the care and well-being of pets.

this Frys has come a long way,  there selection of better quality and variety , decent selection of avalible produce organic as well as non and  breads,i can usually find a decent selection of meats, lamb seems to be hit and miss same with fish I dont under stand why they buy farm raised color added salmon ...oh and from the east coast except maybe for the price aspect hey fish buyer for frys the nw is alot closer and offers better quality  salmon but my biggest pet peive w/this store is the service at the deli there slow and incompetent i dont know how many times i have waited way to long to be waited on and ended up just walking away or avoiding the deli all together knowing the outcome .......

I'm not sure why they call themselves barcelona, not very authetic spanish cooking. but the tapas are good. they could have a bigger selection of tapas. service was excelant. check them out on half price night!!! And try the Sangrias, free samples are available...

I don't get the 2+ hour wait? 

The hostess isn't very nice. Had two encounters with her and she's just snobby.

Anyways, the food... Shared a bunch of stuff. The pork belly tacos, bone marrow, tzatziki dip, skewers with chimichurri, a sushi roll. All were okay but nothing super amazing. The skewers were a little bland. 

Had the pistachio ice cream which was good but super melted when it came out.

Again, don't understand the hype. It was okay but don't think I'll be back anytime soon.

Stopped in for Sushi. Trendy atmosphere. Loud club music playing to pump you up as you eat. Classic Bruce Lee flick projected on wall is good for a few laughs. Sushi is fresh. Stuck with some of the more basic Maki rolls (Spicy Tuna, California). Both were on par with what you would expect from most Sushi restraunts. \n\nThe Sapporo Beer in 22oz can has an interesting steel shaped design to it.

This small place is not easy to find.  They have a good menu, I ordered the fried beef flat noodle to go.  It was just okay.  \nThe owner speaks Cantonese and I was able to chat with them a bit.  I think I need to order something else next time just so I can provide a better review for this place.  But the first dish didn't pass my test. \nI will go back to try other things.

"My personal opinion regarding Rito's is that the prices they charge are somewhat excessive in relation to the quantity and quality of the food provided. Specifically, the burritos appear large due to the employment of an oversized tortilla, which, upon closer inspection, reveals a relatively meager amount of meat, resulting in a disproportionate ratio of tortilla to filling. In the case of the green chile burrito I had the pleasure of sampling, if the portion size of the meat had been more generous, perhaps the price point of $8 would have been more palatable. However, I must admit that the beans were of superior quality and the salsa, albeit available at an additional cost of 25 cents for a mere two tablespoons, was truly exceptional. Despite these positive aspects, my overall dining experience at Rito's failed to meet my expectations, as the flavors and presentation of the dishes did not differ significantly from those I have enjoyed in the past, prompting a nostalgic desire to embrace my mother.":

I would like to try Richardson's again. I went on a date here and we were going to order a couple things off the menu, but the manager said, "Let me take care of you- you're going to love this". We looked at each other (date and I) and were like, "Ok, I guess".

The manager sent out a garlic plate. It wasn't the worst thing for a date, since roasted garlic isn't stinky, but it was a cheesy heavy gross mess for me. I'm not into that kind of food at all and would have much preferred to choose something different. It was huge as well, we couldn't even finish it and didn't have any room to try any entrees on the menu. 

So, well, next time I know better and will stick to my own palate preferences rather than be persuaded by  a stranger that thinks first date food should be the size and style of a fancy superbowl platter. The dish wasn't gross, but it was incredibly heavy for 2 people. i might order that as an app if I was with a party of 4 or larger.

Overall, the place is beautiful and it's a great date spot. Call ahead and make a reservation though. I hope one day I can go again and try something that I like better.

"This drinking establishment, characterized by its pronounced horizontal orientation and staffed by diminutive individuals, constitutes merely one aspect of the venue's multifaceted nature. The ambiance of Giligin's, reminiscent of a tawdry yet entertaining relative, permeates every detail, from the viscous floor surface to the capricious pendulum suspended in the bar area, the chilled display cases behind the counter resembling a spirits emporium, and the nightly promotional schemes such as the aforementioned goldfish races. Although a menu is available, I must confess that apprehension prevents me from partaking in their culinary offerings. My previous visit to this establishment, which coincided with the fervor surrounding the Super Bowl festivities hosted by FBR, proved to be an exhilarating experience, complete with $1 jello shot specials and an opportunity to capture photographic memories with the Captain Morgan mascot. Subsequently, I found myself meandering within the premises, brandishing a large Coors Light container, while engaging in a spirited game of beanbag toss with a visiting female participant from Wisconsin, ultimately resulting in my defeat."

If I had the opportunity to consume the delectable pepper jack mac and cheese on a daily basis, I would unquestionably take advantage of it. In point of fact, I make it a point to order it each and every time I visit the establishment, as it is an integral component of my culinary experience. Furthermore, I must say that the sandwiches they offer are quite satisfactory as well, boasting an impressive array of flavors and textures that complement the main attraction remarkably well. Additionally, the ambiance of the establishment exudes a welcoming and relaxed vibe, allowing patrons to indulge in a selection of high-quality bar fare while enjoying a couple of cold beverages.

CVS is known as a great Pharmaceutical chain that also offers everyday grocery items.  This store located off the 215 and Valley Verede is a great addition to this wonderful chain.\n\nThe savings and weekly specials are very hard to beat at CVS.  I have always enjoyed the service and 24 hour drive through Pharmacy at almost every location.  Awesome store!!!
Chicken parm was just average. Field greens salad was great. Wait staff was great. The seating is right under the blue sky and in front of a large fountain in the Forum Shops.

"If this putative golf club is indeed an establishment dedicated to the pursuit of golfing activities, then I must be the legendary yeti, for it appears that no golf balls are being struck with any degree of proficiency within these premises, which ostensibly purport to offer a tranquil ambiance conducive to the enjoyment of a round of golf, but in reality seem to be lacking in the essential elements necessary to facilitate such a sporting endeavor."

"Although my affection for the concept of Sidebar remains intact, my fondness for the venue itself is somewhat mitigated by my underwhelming experiences there. While the beverages they offer are certainly passable, I have found the atmosphere to be less than enjoyable on multiple occasions. Specifically, I have visited the establishment twice, with vastly differing results. During my initial visit, I had the pleasure of being served by a charismatic and knowledgeable bartender who hailed from San Francisco, and I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed his company and the overall experience. However, my subsequent visit proved to be a stark contrast, as the bartender who attended to me was not only unfriendly but also displayed an air of superiority when addressing queries from patrons, which I found particularly vexing and ultimately detracted from my enjoyment of the outing. Suffice it to say, I have not returned to Sidebar since then."

This is a fairly new place.  It's charming and homey.  The restaurant has been very clean both times we visited.  Both times there we sat at the bar, and drinks were made well, however we did not eat.  They do not have beer on tap and carry no craft beers, although one of the owners days that will change soon.  They have a nice bar, however the bar top is not as wife as the foot step on the bottom of the bar, making sitting at the bar rather uncomfortable.  They do have a game room in the back with pool tables, foosball and darts.  They also have a back patio with corn hole and horseshoes.  Being new, the service is a little slow and they don't seen to have enough staff, but maybe that was the time of day we went there each time.  We will definitely go back and try their barbeque.

Whenever I'm in Vegas, I always like to eat at a nice restaurant. This was my choice one year. \nWe had ordered for appetizers was the bone marrow and maple glazed pork belly. These were amazing. Melt-in-your-mouth goodness!!!! \nAnd for our entrees, I had ordered the 8 oz. filet mignon/American Wagyu while my bf ordered the \"A tasting of New York sirloin\". We both requested med-rare as how our steak should be cooked. As for the sides, we had the wild field mushrooms, creamed spinach and broccoli-rapini. And of course, a bottle of red wine(I don't remember what it was). When our steaks and sides arrived, I was excited to cut into the steak and taste the wonderfully crusted meat but to my surprise, I was disappointed and didn't like my steak at all. I like my steak crusted but not burnt!!! I didn't touch my steak for the rest of my meal but I did enjoy the wine and the sides we had ordered. I can honestly say that I will not be returning. That's only based on my steak alone bc the service was impeccable.

Parking SUCKS.
Everything is over priced. 

It took me 25 minutes to get a cup of coffee, and I wouldn't have minded the wait if someone had acknowledged my presence and given the polite "I'll be with you as soon as possible" report. Clearly, that was too much to ask for.

But if you happen to go when it's not busy (i'm not sure when this is...) I'm fairly certain the ambiance would be delightful. It's an interesting concept. Also, the spaces are WAY too tight for the type of traffic they have in there.

The gelato on the South side of the building is really bland and boring. I'd rather eat store brand ice cream. Their Pizza is really awesome, though.

Great idea - mediocre execution.

Ladies, please be careful especially on a Saturday night. I was here last night (Saturday) with a couple girlfriends seated on the patio. We ordered drinks from the server who brought them from the inside bar so we could not see them being poured or who had access to them before delivering to our table. After just one Cosmopolitan I was barely able to walk and got very sick later than night. This has never happened to me before and I'm concerned something was slipped in my drink. Not necessarily by staff but possibly a patron at or near the bar before our drinks came to us. Thank god my girlfriends were there to get me home safely. Just a lesson learned to always keep an eye on your drinks from the moment they are poured... No matter where you're at!

"A certain individual within this establishment appears to be nonchalant towards their responsibilities, which is an anomaly among the diligent staff members I have had the pleasure of interacting with during my numerous visits to Bookman's over the years. Perhaps it can be attributed to advanced age or a particularly trying day, but this employee failed to display even a cursory interest in the assortment of items I was presenting for trade, dismissing them outright without so much as a fleeting glance. This lackadaisical attitude is unprecedented, as I have consistently experienced courteous and efficient service at this very store, save for this singular instance. Notwithstanding, I opted to peruse the premises in search of alternative treasures, and indeed discovered two coveted items that had long eluded my grasp. However, in light of the aforementioned disagreeable encounter, I chose to reconsider my purchase and relinquish said items back unto the shelves."

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment during the luncheon hour, and my initial visit proved to be a thoroughly enjoyable experience, primarily due to the welcoming ambiance and exceptional customer service. The personnel were incredibly friendly, accommodating, and helpful, which greatly enhanced my dining experience. The booths were also noteworthy, offering an impressive level of comfort and luxury. 

In terms of the cuisine, my companion and I opted to share two dishes â?the Mushroom and Sausage Pizza, as well as the Chicken Chopped Salad. The pizza crust, mushrooms, and sausage were undoubtedly the highlights of the meal, boasting remarkable quality and flavor. However, I must admit that the red sauce accompanying the pizza left something to be desired, as it appeared to be somewhat underdeveloped and lacking in depth, with a taste reminiscent of tomato paste straight from the can. 

Regarding the salad, the grilled chicken was expertly prepared and presented in manageable, bite-sized portions. Unfortunately, the dressing did not quite live up to expectations, as it seemed rather diluted and lacking in distinct flavor. 

Despite these minor shortcomings, I remain convinced that Nook possesses considerable potential and warrants further exploration. The exceptional service I received certainly played a significant role in fostering this sentiment, and I would unquestionably consider revisiting this establishment in the future."

"Underwhelming encounter with too much repetition."
