My Girl hated her steak it was dry the sauces they offered where nasty, My beef wellington was good but not great, the mac and cheese is hella dry ,,,, why?????? overall more hype... u pay for the environment and the way they serve the food. Will not return but will try Burgar next  time.

Located in close proximity to the renowned Rio All-Suite Hotel and Casino, the Flamingo hotel boasts an unparalleled position, rendering it easily accessible by foot for those who relish a leisurely stroll along the Las Vegas Strip. However, it is worth noting that the pedestrian route traverses an overhead bridge above the highway, which may not be the most scenic or enjoyable trek. Despite its unpretentious nature, this establishment offers exceptional value for money, with tariffs that are considerably reasonable compared to neighboring luxury resorts. As a subsidiary of Coast Properties, this hotel benefits from an abundance of on-site facilities, effectively rendering it self-sufficient and obviating the need for guests to venture beyond its confines in search of dining or entertainment options. Thus, for travelers seeking a relaxed ambiance and economical accommodations, this venue is certainly worthy of consideration, allowing them to experience the vibrant spirit of Las Vegas without breaking the bank.

Didn't come here to eat just drink but can't really go wrong with 2.50 coronas this is definitely is a college bar and a bit noisy what's wierd is there Oregon duck fans and not ASU fans? Great place for day drinking though

"A typical shopping mall, characterized by an assortment of retail establishments catering predominantly to the needs and preferences of tourists, with prices that are considerably higher than those found at local venues. Despite its reputation as a 'tourist trap,' this mall does feature a select number of unique specialty stores and occasional sales events, rendering it a worthwhile destination for visitors seeking a distinctive shopping experience. Additionally, the mall boasts an exceptional coffee establishment, as well as complimentary yoga classes offered at Lululemon on Sundays, further enhancing its appeal to patrons."
Popped in for a few tacos today... The carne asada was lacking in flavor, no marinade, and pretty bland. The carnitas were very good and I'd eat a dozen at one sitting :)

"A pleasant regional venue offering delectable cuisine and an expansive outdoor area ideal for leisurely summer gatherings. While the interior ambiance may be somewhat dim, the culinary offerings more than compensate for this minor shortcoming. However, the placement and size of the televisions could be improved to enhance the overall viewing experience for patrons. Locating this establishment may prove somewhat challenging for the uninitiated, but once arrived, visitors can enjoy a welcoming, well-maintained, and secure environment."

This is your average Chinese restaurant. Cheap but average food. They have a really cheap lunch menu, for only $5.95 you get an entree and a drink.
Their customer service is very good. They checked on us on a regular basis and refilled our drinks in a timely matter. 
The food is just ok, but again you get what you pay for.
I found it kind of strange that they do not believe in plates.  The food is delivered on styrofoam and no serving spoon, which makes the food look even less appealing. 
Overall, the restaurant is just ok if you are looking for a cheap and quick meal.

I've frequented this location a couple times & I've never had an issue with them, service or food wise. I just enjoyed a peanut buster parfait & it was just like the picture, how many restaurants can say that!, lol  when I'm in the mood for DQ & I'm in the area I'll stop in here for a bite

After having such a horrible experience at Babystacks (see prior review), my friend and I drove over to Lulu's. I don't know if it was the contrast to the poor service we just experienced but it was so nice to have such good service.  Although  you order at the counter, you can sit in the Metro pizza area which is easier with kids. Also, they brought out drinks over to us, which again helps with kids. They didn't bat an eye when my friend sent her egg back because she forgot to ask for it to be over hard instead of over easy as it normally comes. The manager is always nice and has gone out of her way to make us feel welcome before. 

 I had the Herman breakfast sandwich, a little pricey (about $8 if I remember correctly), but I love that it comes on a pretzel bun and it is surprisingly filling for just being a sandwich. It is just the sandwich with egg, sausage, cheese and a stone ground mustard. 

I have had the chocolate croissant before and it was okay - but of course I am a chocolate croissant aficionado (aka snob) and really only like the traditional french chocolate croissant (as served at Patisserie Manon and the Baguette Cafe). The lemon tart is really good and reminds me of a sour cream lemon pie my hubby makes which is phenomenal. They usually have cookie and muffin samples out which is nice.

Read the reviews on Yelp while I was visiting Phoenix.  I am a Doo-Nut fiend, so was looking for a place.  Lamar's was middle of the road.  I am a classic glazed donut kind of guy and I love them even more when they are hot and fresh.  I think had I been there when the donuts were hot and fresh I would've enjoyed them more.  Yet, it wasn't bad.

Specialty food should be special. There should be a reason why you pay a bit extra for a few morsels of goodness. Reid's has a lock on these specialty foods with a nice looking meat department, array of choice cheeses and impressive wine selection. Let's break down this location a bit, shall we?

The Good: As mentioned, it's a great spot to grab a quick bite, snag a bottle of wine, some tasty snacks and get on your merry way. The service is pretty spectacular - whether your seeking said bottle of wine or dining on a sandwich during lunch. Many of the sandwiches and salads I saw coming around looked fresh and delicious. Also, there's a decent sized wine bar next to the wine vault/selection area that could kick your feet up while you taste away. 

The Meh: The parking is pretty much horrendous. Unless you're stealing parking from business across the street, you better be comfortable walking a ways. The sandwich I ate here was underwhelming - the grilled pimento cheese was gut busting-ly greasy (granted, it's grilled pimento cheese) and also missed the zing I was looking for. I barely got through half of the sloppy mess and had to put it down for fear that I may have a heart attack in the shop. 

If I'm walkin' around Selwyn and need to score a few snacks before heading home, Reid's is a fine choice, yet they definitely have plenty of competition in the area if we're talking tasty sandwiches and wine tasting!

The sweet crepes are great. From classic simple lemon juice to the Nutella bananas . But the savory crepes are quite run of the mill, uninspired. But the coffee and the relaxed coffee shop vibe is welcoming. But the service is uneven, and a fly bothered us on the last two visits.\n\nWas undecided between four stars or three, until I ate crepes today in San Jose, CA. Smoked salmon, and fast friendly service. A good reference point, so overall it really is a three star place. But come in for coffee with friends and share a sweet crepe? Then maybe five stars!

It's a bar.  You walk in, mechanical bull, TONS of guys, loud, huge beers, and GREAT lettuce wraps (They really did have great food)!!  \n\nI don't really have much to compare it to because this was my first place to visit in while in Arizona, but it was a fun place to start the night off at and have a few beers.

"I have been frequenting this establishment for approximately a decade, and while I have had a strong affinity for their culinary offerings in the past, recent experiences have left me feeling somewhat disillusioned and disappointed. The issues that have been raised by other patrons, such as the limited quantity of meat on the sandwiches, the high prices, and the sluggish service, have unfortunately become increasingly apparent. Furthermore, I must express my dismay at the lack of environmental consciousness displayed by the restaurant, as evidenced by their refusal to reuse punch cards and instead opting to discard and replace them, resulting in unnecessary waste. Despite these criticisms, I may still continue to visit, albeit with reduced frequency."

"The advantages of this establishment include an affordable menu featuring fresh culinary offerings, delectable milkshakes, a pristine dining environment, affable and welcoming staff members, and a unique pepper bar. However, the drawbacks consist of an uninspired and lackluster dining area, an awkward layout within the dining room, unoriginal menu selections, and pre-made salad dressings. While it may be suitable for a rapid burger craving, in my view, alternative burger venues in the locality are preferable."

"This establishment undoubtedly offers an excellent venue for procuring delectable and affordable sushi for a hasty luncheon, thereby catering to individuals seeking a quick and satisfying repast. Nonetheless, it is essential to note that this eatery does not possess the optimal ambiance for a leisurely dining experience, as the seating arrangements are limited and the table settings consist of disposable utensils and Styrofoam cups. Furthermore, the waitstaff may exhibit a certain degree of inattention to detail, as evidenced by the delay in preparing the sushi rolls and the absence of sugar for the tea. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the rainbow roll and green tea offered by this restaurant are indeed exceptional, thereby rendering it a suitable destination for those seeking a satisfying and expedient meal. However, it is not recommended for dates or dinner due to the aforementioned limitations."

Nice seafood place away from the casinos.

Food: 7.5/10 - Nice menu selections. Well prepared.  The flavors will not wow you but they are a solid meal.  

Service: 8/10 - No problems. Nothing spectacular either.

Cleanliness: 8/10 - No visible issues.

Decor: 8.5 / 10 - Sat outside on a beautiful night.  Was very nice.  Inside looked nice as well.

Restrooms: 7/10 - no problems.

Parking: 9/10 - Tons of parking.  

Overall: 7/10 - A nice place to eat.  I personally like the Texas de Brazil located right next door MUCH better.

Walked in and the SeaHawkers club had just left.  The place was a wreck and they were scrambling to get the tables cleaned and the restaurant back in order.\n\nGood service, good food and cold drinks.  Use the 4Square app and unlock an additional dollar off your drinks, even during happy hour.

"A hospitable ambiance and proficient service are hallmarks of this establishment, rendering it an ideal setting for patrons seeking respite from exorbitant prices associated with mediocre beverages. Although the selection of draft beers may not boast an extensive array of options, the bartenders demonstrate a commendable level of attentiveness and helpfulness, ensuring that each patron's experience is optimized. Instances of inadvertently dispensed extra beverages are met with considerate explanations, fostering an atmosphere of transparency and customer satisfaction. As a frequent visitor, I have had the pleasure of witnessing such exceptional service on multiple occasions, leaving me with a favorable impression of this business and motivating me to continue offering my patronage."

I accorded it a three-star rating due to the fact that, overall, the hotel was merely satisfactory; I had anticipated a superior experience. My first visit to the Trump hotel was marred by the discovery of moldy food in the refrigerator! The customer service was subpar...The housekeeping staff took an inordinate amount of time to clean my room, despite my having made a timely request for their services early in the morning; however, they did not complete their task until approximately 3 pm. The hotel's location, remote from the strip, necessitated our reliance on taxis to travel to and from Caesars Palace, despite the availability of a shuttle service, as we were compelled to wait a minimum of twenty-five minutes for the shuttle, which ceased operating at midnight, thereby limiting our ability to fully enjoy ourselves and creating anxiety regarding the impending cessation of the shuttle service, prompting us to opt for taxis that charged us $20, inclusive of tips and taxes, and the taxi drivers, dissatisfied with a mere $1 gratuity, sought larger sums...It is preferable to stay on the strip to avoid the inconvenience and expense of taxi and shuttle rides! \nPros: Quiet, luxurious, odorless, well-appointed kitchen in the suites, sumptuous bathroom\nCons: A few relatively minor drawbacks. The shuttles cease operation too early and experience considerable delays in pickup. The hotel's distance from the strip makes walking an unfeasible option. There is a dearth of activities and amenities at the hotel, rendering it a rather basic establishment, despite its pool and gym facilities.

"Gastronomical indulgences of unparalleled quality, even when forgoing the limitless spaghetti option. Enjoyed an arugula and white bean salad, accompanied by a pair of penne pasta dishes, both of which demonstrated culinary proficiency. Ambient surroundings, reasonable tariffs, and attentive servers further enhanced the overall dining experience."

We have frequented this venerable establishment, which boasts an eclectic array of culinary delights, gaming facilities, and artisanal brews, on several occasions, and we must confess that the experience has been nothing short of delightful. The breakfast menu, in particular, offers an unparalleled combination of quality and affordability, with the steak and eggs option being a personal favorite, available for the remarkably reasonable price of $3.99. It is worth noting that this eatery also houses a brewery, which produces an impressive selection of craft beers, including an exceptional root beer that is not to be missed. While this may not be the most luxurious or high-end destination, it undoubtedly provides an excellent value for the money spent, and we would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience without breaking the bank. On a previous visit, we had the pleasure of enjoying a promotional offer, which allowed us to indulge in an unlimited number of Corona beers for a full hour, sans any obligation to make a purchase, and we were able to sample an impressive total of 22 Coronas, an experience that we found to be truly remarkable.

"Our dining experience was marred by an overwhelmed server who appeared flustered by the numerous tables she was attending to, and we felt somewhat inconvenient when requesting a replenishment of celery sticks, which were scantily provided alongside the delectable buffalo wings that boasted an impressive quality, albeit with varying degrees of spiciness; specifically, the mango-spicy variety was quite piquant, while the garlic Asian version was noticeably milder, and the jerk chicken offering was surprisingly bland, thus rendering the overall enjoyment of the meal somewhat inconsistent; furthermore, we were taken aback by the unexpected charge for additional celery refills, which amounted to $1.20, a sum we deemed disproportionate considering the minimal cost of a single celery stalk."

"The disparity between the quality of experience offered by the Napa Valley establishment and that of Las Vegas is palpable. Specifically, the culinary offerings and hospitality encountered at the bar fell short of expectations, with our server/bartender displaying forgetfulness on multiple occasions, necessitating repeated orders, and engaging in unprofessional conduct by openly attributing blame to the chef for errors in food preparation, which detracted from the overall quality of the dining experience, already found lacking in comparison to previous visits to the region."

"I must confess an unwavering fondness for Trader Joe's; may I be so bold as to express my enthusiasm for this establishment? The prices and quality of their nuts (encompassing almonds, pecans, walnuts, et al.) and nut-based products (including almond butter, and so forth) are, in my humble opinion, unparalleled. Furthermore, their produce is of exceptional quality, and they offer an array of unique items that are simply unattainable elsewhere. Allow me to emphasize my unequivocal endorsement of Joe Joe's; indeed, it is nothing short of magnificent! 

However, I must deduct two stars from my rating due to the following factors:

1. The quest for a parking spot during peak hours (specifically between 12 pm and 1 pm from Monday to Friday) borders on the impossible. Accept the challenge at your own peril, dear reader! 

2. Lamentably, the store's dimensions are rather diminutive, leaving me with an inescapable feeling of disappointment. In spite of these drawbacks, I maintain that Trader Joe's is an outstanding retailer."

"Ah, Treasure Island, a veritable haven for buccaneers and swashbucklers of yore, wherefore art thou? Aye, welcome to TI, a bastion of piracy, where scantily clad maidens dance with abandon, a spectacle most titillating, no doubt. Situated across the street from the opulent Venetian and Palazzo resorts, TI, alas, hath seen better days, its rooms, casino, and culinary offerings leaving much to be desired. Yet, for those seeking to economize and bask in the lively ambiance of the Strip's lower end, TI remaineth a viable option, though be prepared to endure the raucous pirate performance each eve."

You know, after going back to the convention for a second year and eating at the Golden Palace Buffet again, I have to say that ordering off of the menu provided a significant improvement over the buffet.\n\nThe food wasn't nearly as greasy and was actually quite flavorful.  I was pleased with my meal and I'm sure my friends were, too.  My friend, who was wearing a giant costume, was treated with courtesy.

Nice and firm please, that is how I like it, not soft and squishy.

Unfortunately the tofu here is the latter. I ordered the yellow curry tofu, and the tofu was just chunks of softer tofu cut up into my curry. It was not fried or prepared in any other way first.  The curry was rich and had a good spice to it, there was also an ample amount of vegetables. The presentation with the rice moulded to a small cone was a nice touch. 

There is a lunch menu full of the usual Thai suspects, curries, pad Thai etc. 

The business it self is located in a odd small strip mall, the inside consists of high top tables by the window and normal tables in the inside.  It was pretty empty when we went for lunch on a weekday.

Stopped by this Subway on the drive back home to Vegas from Phoenix.  It is conveniently located on the right side of the road heading to Vegas.

I ordered a 6" BMT w/Jalapeno Cheddar Bread & had it toasted.  I added Tomatoes, Lettuce, Green Peppers, Pepperoncinis, Mustard, Mayo, Oil, Vinegar, Salt, Pepper.  They made it quickly and I was eating in no time.

The ingredients were very fresh and the Sandwich tasted great.  A nice snack for the ride home.

A bonus is the clean restrooms....a quick tip is to stop here to use the restroom instead of a nasty gas station....every gas station in Wickenberg was busy with travelers using the restrooms.

Will I return?  Next time I drive to/from Phoenix, I will.

The last time my friends and I stayed in Vegas, we ended up at Treasure Island because we got a really good deal.  When we checked in, we noticed there was a Pho Restaurant and thought it was so random.  We scoffed at the patrons dining inside who had paid the exorbitant prices to eat Vietnamese food we were certain was mediocre at best. Little did we know we'd be there the following afternoon as well as the next slurping up the noodle soup to cure our pounding heads from our mad hangovers.\n\nBottom line: Prices are steep but it is Vegas after all and it's definitely not the best Pho I've ever had but if you happen to be staying at Treasure Island, check this place out because nothing cures a hangover better than some noodle soup.

I don't know what it is about mainland L&Ls...but the food just doesn't have the same taste as L&Ls back home in Hawaii.  The food is edible and very bland.  Beware when paying, though.  The prices on the menu board say one thing, but check your receipt...you may have been charged more.  I brought this to the attention of the worker who was ringing up my purchase, and his response was \"I can't do anything...that's what it says on the computer.\"  Really?  Businesses need to realize they can't advertise their price publicly, and then charge more at the register.  Very bad business practice!

Had dinner with a large group. We had a superb wine, but I'm sure it was not cheap and was chosen by the host of the dinner. The food? Well...the chopped salad was pretty mediocre, and too filling with all the red kidney beans it it. The table breads and muffins were too dry, kind of inedible.

Duck pancake...like someone had poured half a bottle of cheap, sweet syrup on it so who knows what the duck tasted like.

The porterhouse lamb chops - very good. This was by far the best thing I had. The lamb was perfectly grilled, and the sauce was inoffensive so you could enjoy the meat. 

Dessert - that warm, pudding-like cake that I can't remember. It was good, and chocolate. Like many restaurants they served the dessert and then came around asking for coffee as kind of an afterthought. The coffee service took so long that it was tough to wait on eating the cake. Dang, I like coffee WITH dessert. But, most restaurants haven't figured out how to serve both at around the same time.

The restaurant is a nice spot in Caesars so I don't want to dissuade people from going. But, I'd make the grilled meat the centerpiece of what you order and not get too high on hope for the rest, based on what I experienced. And get a nice bottle of wine to go with it!

It is a Wal-Mart store location that has recently opened its doors to the public, and my initial thoughts were that perhaps it might possess a distinct ambiance, a departure from the conventional Wal-Mart experience to which I had grown accustomed. However, upon entering the premises, I was quickly disabused of such notion, as it became apparent that this establishment adhered to the standard template associated with the Wal-Mart brand, complete with an array of unremarkable products offered at prices designed to appeal to budget-conscious consumers. Furthermore, the clientele that frequents this store appears to be drawn from the same demographic that has come to be synonymous with the Wal-Mart shopping experience, as depicted on websites such as peopleofwalmart.com, characterized by an atmosphere in which children vociferously proclaim their knowledge of numerals, while adults engage in behaviors that impede the progress of others, all within an environment that seems tailored to accommodate the preferences of senior citizens who prefer a leisurely pace when navigating the various aisles.

This is a 'Superstore' and the biggest close by supermarket for Leith / Shore residents. 

It has 2 entrances one at the Tesco Car park at the back and the back entrance on Duke Street. 

It is a Tesco supermarket and they do what supermarkets do. In addition to that they have also clothes and electricals available.

For a so-called Superstore it is a little small. but it supplies what is needed and it is open from 06:00 till Midnight. 

Be aware that the law of baying alcohol before 10am  and after 10pm also counts for supermarkets.. Some Leith residents tend to 'forget' that rule and get into a discussion a the till. - happened a few times. 

They have a section dedicated to self-service tills and 2 fast lane basket only cashiers. 

They are not as frequently visited by me, certainly after the whole Horse meat scandal. But they are a handy go to for packaged products. Whiskies, spirits, wine and chocolates. - that's about it. 

Not the worst of shops, but not the best either

"Based on the copious acclaim this establishment had received, I was anticipating an exceptional experience, but unfortunately, it fell short of my expectations. Notwithstanding, I must commend the ambiance and aesthetic appeal of the venue, which were undeniably impressive. My beverage of choice, a nonfat chai latte, was somewhat unremarkable and lacking in distinctiveness, which may have contributed to my underwhelming experience. However, I must emphasize that the company was pleasant, the atmosphere was agreeable, and the interior design was indeed captivating. If I were to revisit, I would perhaps reconsider my beverage selection and opt for their coffee offerings instead, in the hopes of a more satisfactory encounter."

Not bad. Better than other fast food joints in Scotland. Actually WAY better than the fast food joints in Scotland. \n\nI kinda expected more, but was won over by the rootbeer float. That was definitely worth going. OMG, you have not experienced American fast food/diner fare til you've had a rootbeer float. Brought me back to the days of Dairy Queen and the likes. Yet the burger wasn't all that. It was ok but it just felt like there was something missing, to make it a home run. Also, I probably should've ordered the cajun fries. I ordered the onion rings. They were good but clearly frozen. So now I'm on a mission to find fresh made onion rings, any rec's?

well i wanted a place at center strip. would i have gone for the flamingo for a little more money, knowing what i know now? yes.

but... hey, can't complain. it was a little shoddy, a little dirty, and totally just fine. we had a balcony! which my sister's suite at the mirage did NOT! so there.

the buffet was fine. nothing to write home about, but so far no food-borne illness, which i'm all about.

so yes, it may not be much of a step up from the motel 6, but it is a step. a good deal at center strip. and if you're spending too much time in your room you're doing something wrong anyway!

"I had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment last evening, and I must say that the culinary experience was nothing short of exceptional. The three-course meal, complemented by a glass of wine, struck me as an excellent value proposition, particularly given the quality of the fare and the attentive service provided by both the greeter and our waitress. My sardine starter and hake main course, accompanied by a side of spinach, were both exquisitely prepared and presented, showcasing the chef's evident dedication to their craft. While I would have liked to award an additional half star for the superlative dining experience, I regretfully deducted a full star due to a few minor shortcomings. Specifically, the cheese board, while adequate, could have benefited from a greater variety of accompaniments, such as oatcakes, and perhaps a fresher slice of brie. Moreover, the cheese knife, though functional, appeared somewhat worn and tired, detracting slightly from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Notwithstanding these minor criticisms, I must commend the restaurant on its well-appointed interior, which, despite its former identity as a Harry Ramsden's, remains tastefully designed and bathed in natural light. Suffice it to say, I am eagerly anticipating my next visit to this gastronomic gem."

"Utopian haven for hipsters. Bring on the 1920s era boots with dungarees that are a perfect match. 

Exquisite ambiance. A magnificent, vintage roaster is showcased and utilized extensively. 

Evidently, there is a scarcity of artisanal coffee in my hometown. A queue extended nearly to the entrance. 

I managed to acquire an espresso. It was presented promptly and proficiently. In my modest opinion, the coffee was satisfactory...not exceptional. An excess of fruitiness/acidity. Insufficient rich, velvety texture reminiscent of chocolate. However, that's merely my taste. Not necessarily everyone else's preference.

Nonetheless, my companion ordered a pour-over. And, pour-overs require a considerable amount of time. Following ten minutes of waiting, we inquired. Oh! We neglected your pour-over coffee! Wait an additional ten minutes. Derrrr...I'm unwilling to wait another ten minutes, but I suppose I must since my girlfriend and I both have an addiction to caffeine and cannot function adequately without it. 

Fortunately, I had the opportunity to sample my companion's brew, and it was delightful. 

In summary, they possess a successful formula, but minor adjustments are necessary. I would certainly revisit."

We partook of a culinary experience at this establishment in the company of our kin, and we must say, the ambiance was quite pleasant, albeit a tad tranquil for a Sunday afternoon. Upon entering the realm of the all-you-can-eat extravaganza, we were struck by an unpleasant olfactory sensation akin to that of a sewage system, which momentarily deterred us from indulging in the gastronomical offerings. However, our ardent fondness for sushi (a staggering fifteen times per mensem, no less!) impelled us to persevere and sample the wares presented. Alas, our expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the sushi failed to meet the standards of a top-tier establishment, eliciting comparisons to the pedestrian offerings found at your run-of-the-mill grocery store. Notwithstanding, the diversity of options available on the buffet table was quite impressive, and it would have been even more satisfactory had the taste lived up to the price point.

We saw this place on Bar Rescue and wanted to check it out. My wife and I showed up about 9:30 PM. I was starving and planned on eating here. Unfortunately the bartender said the kitchen was closed because they had a slow night. I had one beer and left only because I couldn't keep drinking without getting some kind if food in my belly. Next time in Vegas I will definitely give this place another shot. And maybe more stars. The locals were extremely friendly and greeted us as soon as we walked in. The bartender was also very friendly. Wish I could have experienced the food.

"I thoroughly relished the culinary offerings, specifically the chicken fried steak, which was served with an ample portion of mashed potatoes and a savory gravy that complemented the dish perfectly. Additionally, a side of green beans and a preliminary salad preceded the main course, contributing to an overall satisfying gastronomical experience. However, upon entering the establishment, we encountered a degree of perplexity due to the absence of a clear greeting protocol. Despite the cozy ambiance, it is crucial for the staff to maintain a vigilant attitude towards welcoming patrons and clarifying the waiting process, which currently seems to rely on an informal 'first-come, first-served' basis. Notwithstanding this drawback, my evaluation of the restaurant remains neutral, augmented by my appreciation for its family-owned nature and the palatable fare."

Food and service were okay. Among the dishes I ate were sweet & sour soup and tofu with baby bok choy.\n\nThe decor seemed fancy. I liked the jellyfish lights near the entrance and the wood-covered menus.

Very nice bar and the prices are very reasonable, if they put 2 (diamond) tables in there instead of 1 bar table and 1 build at home type pool table it would make this bar a very awesome place to hang out at and take pool league teams all week 24/7.
Average American restaurant, good food, but nothing special. Safe choice restaurant.   Bar area is loud, a bit difficult to talk and hear.

Pros: Nicely laid out store with a wide variety of vintage merchandise.\nCons:  Booths are not individually signed with percentage off discounts for store sales which makes things rather confusing.  Employees are hard to identify as they don't wear aprons, badges, etc.  Your purchase will be wrapped in used newspaper instead of clean wrapping paper.  All things that can be improved upon for a better shopping experience.

I liked this place.  The ambiance is nice and the service is superb.  The mojito was delicious and so was the waffles.  My daughter was excited by the red velvet pancakes.  The down side was price - SO EXPENSIVE!  An order of pancakes was $13!  I can't afford to frequent this place very often.

A good place to eat, trendy. You can't call ahead or make reservations so expect to wait about 20-30 minutes for a table. The food is good, but when I went there I got an Eggs Benedict and it was more of a hard boiled egg, though it was well-seasoned. \n\nI'll be giving it another try, but I was much more excited about this place before I tried it.

We halted our perambulation at this establishment for the purpose of partaking in a midday repast, as we were experiencing fatigue and an absence of inclination to continue our pedestrian journey. Both of us opted for the creamy potato and leek soup, which proved to be a delectable choice. My companion had the tuna sandwich accompanied by a side of fries, while I selected the unembellished green salad, also with a side of fries. I was dismayed to discover that my salad contained several leaves that were not as fresh as they could have been, yet the waitress, Dana, did not include them in the calculation of our bill. The fries were served hot and crispy, their flavor being enhanced by the addition of aromatic herbs. While the culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, they did not possess any exceptional qualities that would render them memorable. Nonetheless, Dana's hospitable demeanor and attentive service left a favorable impression upon us.

Quite disappointing when I expected the same flavor and price when I was in LA. 

Don't get me wrong, the waiters/waitress were super friendly. We ordered bulgogi and ribs. The food was flavorful but average. No refills for the side dishes when you are grilling at the grill-your-own-bbq table. 

Extra: went with a groupon deal but still ended up paying way more than expected and received less food. 

TL;DR: ok place for food, clean, but does not justify the price.

Upstream is probably thought of as one of the best restaurants in Charlotte.  I am from Philadelphia where there are excellent restaurants with iron chefs so my viewpoint may be a bit skewed.   The food was good but not great or amazing.  Every dish (except the house salad) was over salted.  My husband had the tuna and I had the seabass. They were both very good but as I said before not great.  We would go there again but for sushi/raw items not necessarily the cooked menu items.  The salad was was the highlight for me (house salad) and the crab bisque was pretty tasty too.   Overall the service was very good but slow.  Our waiter was one of the most knowledgeable wait staff we have encountered since moving from PA.

After Harlow's down the road was so packed we couldn't park, we decided to give this new breakfast cafe a try.  The portions are extremely generous and overall the food was really good.  The prices are a little high I think, but not so much that I wouldn't return.  I knocked down a star because the ham I received was \"off\" and tasted like it was past it's shelf life, and the oj was just so-so.  They do give complimentary chocolate covered strawberries that are epic!

It's BBQ at an airport.  If you're in the mood for BBQ while in the airport, well friend, you have pretty darn limited options.  This place is affordable for an airport, and decent.  Great BBQ it is not, but it's serviceable, and quite a bit better than your options to the left and right.

I went with the three meat platter.  The brisket was 1/2 fat; I'm pretty sure I got the end chunk.  The pulled pork was decent, and the turkey had a good smoke but was pretty dry.  They have one sauce option...yes or no.  Definitely not mustard-based, but recommended as it's not overbearing.  

For healthy sides...well, you're at a BBQ joint, so good luck with that.

....and boy are my arms tired!

Comedy clubs are easy to review when focusing on the club itself, and not the talent.  You could be in the perfect comedy club and see a horrible act, just as you could see something amazing at a dive bar's open mic night.  

This "club" is really  a conference room that has been converted into a comedy club.  The staff sets up chairs around the room for the patrons the night of the show, adding seats when needed.  There are a few VIP couches, but since this intimate setting is quite quaint, there really is no reason to pay the high price for them.

There are two waitresses who run around frantically trying to fill all the patrons' orders, but be ready to wait for your beverage.  Walking up to the bar in the room is usually a better way to go.  

I saw the late (9pm) show on a Saturday night.  Seating starts at 8:30, so get there early if you want to sit in the front.  Really, there isn't a horrible seat in the house though.  

I saw Todd Paul the night I went in, and laughed my A$$ off.  He was charismatic and hilarious.  His act was a mix of magic, stunts, and comedy.  He did an amazing job of making fun of Las Vegas shows, specifically magic shows.  I would definitely return for another fun night.

We ate here a few weeks ago per a recommendation from the hotel we were staying at.  While I do not eat steak a few of my friends do and they said they liked it.  I ordered the Chicken Peppered Penne which was delicious.  I asked them to make it extra spicy which they did.  The pasta was cooked perfectly, the sauce was creamy, and the dish had a great flavor.  The service was good and the prices were reasonable.

This is the best Pho I've had in Scottsdale!  Now, as far as Pho goes, it's mediocre. The broth is good, but the quantity is small and price high!  It's seems as if they are scared to give you a good sized portion of noodles and meat. I get irked when I sped over $8 for Pho and I'm not stuffed. I think they do try hard here, but get away with the poor sizing and simple taste because they can!  \n\nThe staff is attentive ms friendly. Overall, give it a shot and order extra noodles and meatballs to get full!

Nice pub, very touristy. In the upstairs part, the food is very good, but the ambiance not even remotely comparable to downstairs.\n\nDownstairs the selection of real ales is awesome. Why does leaving your business card get you sparkly wine? Why not one of these awesome beers or whiskies? I found it pretty cool that they count how many hand pumped ales they pump every week. The week before I was there: 1987. Cool.
Not a big fan but Tax free yeah!  Off base has more selection and you can find deals. Unless your buying a high price item i would shop elsewhere. The lines get bad so don't be in a rush.

"Alright, the embellishments within this establishment are rather kitsch and over-the-top, yet they seem to be an integral aspect of the overall experience, perhaps even intentionally so, as if to convey a sense of steadfastness and tradition amidst an ever-changing landscape; furthermore, the wait staff's attire, while aesthetically displeasing, seems to be a deliberate choice, evocative of the utilitarian and somewhat oppressive nature of workplace attire, as seen in films such as Office Space; we visited this venue for breakfast, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the divergence from the typical buffet-style fare found in nearby Disney-fied Las Vegas strip locales was palpable."

"Although the beer did not possess any extraordinary qualities, it was still palatable. It is worth mentioning that the establishment boasted an agreeable ambiance. However, it appeared that their primary emphasis lay in offering beverages with a sweeter flavor profile. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that they had depleted their stock of lighter brews, including the blonde variety. Consequently, we shall endeavor to sample their wares at a later time and reassess our initial evaluation."

I would not endorse this airline if you are embarking on a journey with minors, as it offers only basic amenities and lacks entertainment facilities, particularly on lengthy flights; there was no television on our five-hour voyage from New York, which resulted in the children on board becoming restless and irritable due to the lack of diversions; the seating was also quite confined and diminutive, which further exacerbated the discomfort; additionally, the aircraft appeared to be somewhat antiquated. Instead, I would suggest opting for Delta Airlines, which offers a more comprehensive range of services and amenities tailored to accommodate families with young children.

Decent place, good food, great  atmosphere to watch a game. Thank god the karaoke was not there tonight. Service could be better, mainly faster. The servers are spread too thin, as there seem to never be enough top handle the crowd. Otherwise a decent pace too have a drink, grab a bite and watch sports.

This place is open 24 hours and is located outside in the Paris Hotel Casino. It very nice and the Ambiance is really nice and classy. Food is actually OK, but nothing special. The dessert are great though and actually cheap for the amount you get. I got the banana split and share it with two other people and we didn't finish it. Cost like $10 bucks or something. The Sugar Factory store however is over price. Mints and such are like $5-$8 for a small tin. It one of those place you should try once. It a fun place and has outside seating. Dessert and Drinks is what they known for.

"Gastronomical assessment on a scale of one to ten, based on a singular visitation:
Eight for comestibles
Five starred beverages
Eight for hospitality
Eight for ambiance
Seven for value

Personally, I found the culinary offerings to be relatively satisfactory. Particularly noteworthy was the manner in which the yolk of the eggs rested atop the dish, a hallmark of New Mexico's gastronomical tradition. The blue corn tortillas accompanying my enchiladas were substantial and possessed an appreciable texture. Regrettably, the margaritas failed to meet expectations, exhibiting an unpleasant sweet and sour taste, devoid of any discernible bite or depth. Furthermore, the machine-made quality of their production was evident, detracting from the overall experience. Lastly, the serving of salsa, while possessing a commendable level of piquancy, lacked distinction in terms of flavor profile."

While at Fiesta Mall with my son who was getting his hair cut we decided to eat. We wondered around the food court and was approached by an employee of Sarku Japan offering free samples of their teriaki chicken. After trying it my son just had to order from there.  The staff was friendly and the price was reasonable.  He ordered the teriaki chicken & shrimp. The amount of food that he got was way more than expected and he was happy it tasted like what it was suppose to. \nA definate place we'll visit in again and highly recommend!!

Maria...host, rolled her eyes and seemed to have a attitude problem\nKyahl?  Sounds like Kyle. was actually pretty good, he answered my mother in law's questions to the best of his abilities.\nThe food is always kind of hit or miss...the veal parm was good but the macaroni rosa was very bland and the broccoli in it weren't cooked and the pasta was a more al dente than we are use too...there was still a crunch

I've been here a few times and its decent food. There is nothing special about this place that makes me want to specifically go back. Although, if someone is holding a party or special occasion here I doubt I would avoid this place.

I've never been here just for lunch or dinner, so that may effect my review. Although, I've eaten this food on multiple occasions for events at the restaurant. Its good Indian food, and you can never say no to good Indian food. It just wasn't spectacular. I would give most Indian food places 5-stars if the quality of the meat they used was better and if the quality of everything they use is just better. The salads weren't green, the meat in the korma and tikka was very small. It just felt like they were cheaping out on us.

Desserts weren't really special either. If you give me gulab jamun or some jelebi, I am a sucker for that stuff. Theirs was decent, but there wasn't much of it available. However, there really isn't much better stuff in AZ in this vicinity. I'd say India Gate is a little better, maybe try that place out first.

"Oh my goodness, what a disappointment! I have penned a review of their Pecos and Washington site, which I adore and yearn for during the summer months when hankering for seafood. Nonetheless, this particular establishment seemed to be lacking in a certain je ne sais quoi. I requested the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos, and unfortunately, they failed to impress me with their flavors. The ceviche had an overpowering fishy taste, necessitating copious amounts of lemon and salt, while the tacos were uninspiring and lackluster. \n\nThe eatery's ambiance was pleasant, and the server was friendly and attentive. However, the overall experience fell short of expectations. My dining companions concurred, having experienced the exceptional quality of the other location. I shall not be returning to this site, particularly given the elevated prices, although the cost would be warranted if the "Islitas" experience were replicated here. Unfortunately, that was not the case. Instead, I recommend visiting their north Las Vegas location, despite their steep pricing, as they possess the potential for improvement. Thus, I award them three stars, or else I would have given them two."

"I placed an order for the white pizza, featuring a delectable combination of tomato, onion, and Kalamata olives, and upon consuming this culinary masterpiece, I must say it was quite flavorful. However, I must note that the cooking time was somewhat excessive, resulting in a crust that was marginally overcooked, leading to an unfortunate texture that was slightly too crunchy for my liking. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the establishment appeared to be well-staffed, and the interior ambiance was passable. Nonetheless, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy, as I perceived it to be somewhat steep and lacking in value. Therefore, I am unlikely to return, especially considering the distance between my location and the restaurant, and the abundance of alternative dining options that are more likely to receive my patronage."

"This establishment did not conform to my preconceived notions. Rather, it constituted a vast expanse of unencumbered space, with a sizable bar situated in the centralmost location. The culinary offerings, while admittedly delectable, were notably elevated in comparison to those typically found at traditional sports-oriented drinking establishments. Furthermore, the absence of a diverse selection of draft beers was conspicuous, with only a few pedestrian options available. The abundance of flat-screen televisions, while certainly appropriate for a venue of this nature, failed to compensate for the overall lack of individuality and distinctiveness that permeated the atmosphere. Ultimately, this establishment's overt commercialism proved distasteful to my refined sensibilities."

Nothing really special about this hotel within the hotel besides maybe shorter check in lines which is nice and asain themed room. Basically this just seems like they tried to do something special with some old space and while its nice its not really 5 star worthy.   The problem is Caesars palace is old and has horrible customer service.  Everything is slow and understaffed.   Wynn, Bellegio and Venetian are all better places to stay.

Joe's has been the recipient of our patronage on multiple occasions, and we have consistently savored the culinary offerings presented by this esteemed establishment. Unfortunately, the quality of the service we have received during these visits has been subpar, bordering on the unacceptable. Despite this drawback, we would still advocate for a visit to Joe's, as the ambiance is convivial, and the fare is delectable. However, it is crucial to cultivate an attitude of patience, as the tardiness of the staff can be exasperating. By doing so, you can optimize your dining experience and ensure that your evening is free from undue stress and annoyance.
Great selection of beer. Plenty of it! The food is so-so. Typical bar-food. Very nice wait-staff and bar tenders. Large enough place to accommodate a busy night. Worth the stop.

I went here for dinner with my guy last night and I completely agree with the other reviews, the patio is fantastic. It has a great view and its surprisingly quiet and secluded while being right above Indian School road. The wine and beer selection is impressive. I really like all of the local choices. \nThe food however was underwhelming. I started with the fries which had rosemary and parmesan and a dipping sauce similar to a thousand island on the side. It was good, but not great. For our entrees we had the sausage and mushroom pizza, and the penne ragu. The pizza was tasty, it had caramelized onions three types of mushrooms and Italian sausage, the crust was just the way I like it not too crispy and not too soft, but definitely a fork and knife needed pizza. The ragu was interesting; it reminded me of everything that would be inside a shredded beef burrito but instead of a tortilla it's in a bowl with penne pasta underneath. It wasn't bad just unexpected. I wish we would have tried desert they all looked delicious, perhaps next time. \nAll in all I think this is a great place for appetizers and drinks especially on their wonderful patio.
Good coffee ... i'm not eating doughnuts or bagels at the moment, so it's hard to rate their signature foods. Ask me again in 40 pounds.

I came here with some friends yesterday and we shared a number of items. As I walked in, I noticed how lovely it smelled and was excited to try their waffles.
 
We sat and perused the menu for a while and I was a little disappointed that no one really checked on us or even asked if we wanted waters or more menus than just the one for our group of three. We finally figured out what we wanted and went up to the counter to order.

The lady behind he counter kept interrupting my dining companion as he started to order by yelling behind to another person who worked there. I thought that was a little rude, so that definitely put me off.

Our food took a while to come, but it looked really pretty. 

What we ordered:
-red velvet wafflenut 
-Nutella and almond wafflenut 
-The Fat Elvis waffle
-Strawberry and chocolate waffle
-Vegas churro waffle with honey, cinnamon, sugar and vanilla ice cream

Everything was solid. The consensus was that the churro waffle was the favorite and I personally enjoyed the strawberry waffle, minus the chocolate sauce. 

Service needs work and the location is awkward, so I don't see myself making much effort to come back to this place in the future.

Service was fast, but the burger, hotdog, and fries were overrated for the expensive price.\nInn n Out  is still my favorite fast food burger and Bachi Burger is my favorite gourmet burger place in Vegas!

"It is a location frequently visited by travelers seeking leisure activities, and it is not uncommon for the delay in securing a table to be utterly abysmal. Thus, it is imperative to be cognizant of this fact beforehand. The dish consisting of noodles topped with a crispy duck confit is, without a doubt, utterly sublime. However, its cost relative to its quantity is somewhat disproportionate, as the serving size falls short of expectations considering the premium price point. This, in essence, constitutes my primary criticism of LOS. Either the portion sizes should be more generous given the tariff or the culinary offerings should exhibit flawless execution. Unfortunately, this disparity between quality and price resulted in the deduction of two stars from my overall rating."

My wife dragged me in here after she tried their surf n turf and raved about it. I can't comment on that yet.
We sat at the bar and played poker for awhile. Not a big deal but they make you play max bet for a 2nd drink. They were nice enough to warn me about that and still comped my 2nd drink. Might be a reason why we were about the only ones playing.
We ordered food and then sat at a table and brought our drinks with. The portions were big for the sandwiches (philly is great) and very good BUT wait till you get the bill. Yes, we saw the prices but by the time we got done with food and tip it was almost $40 for 2 sandwiches and we didn't have any drinks to pay for. 
It was good but I just don't see the attraction for a sandwich place and their prices.

We indulged in an intimate dining experience at this establishment for our engagement celebration with our dearest family members. The ambiance was vibrant and bustling on a Wednesday evening, with a scarcity of parking spaces that proved to be a minor inconvenience. Our party of thirteen was accommodated in a cozy corner proximate to the entrance, where the influx of chilly air and pungent cigarette odors occasionally permeated the atmosphere. Fortunately, my siblings possess diminutive statures, which enabled them to occupy the seats adjacent to the wall without any significant discomfort. However, it is worth noting that the seating arrangement was somewhat cramped and would have posed a challenge for individuals of average build.

The culinary offerings were diverse and included traditional Chinese delicacies such as lobster, red trout, fried flounder, chicken, beef, and an assortment of vegetables. While the fare was satisfactory, it did not exceed my expectations, and a minor mistake in one of the children's orders slightly marred the dining experience. Nevertheless, my grandmother appeared to enjoy the meal, and her satisfaction was of paramount importance to me. In conclusion, although I prefer other establishments, I would not object to revisiting this venue in the future, provided that I am not subjected to the discomfort of sitting beside the entrance during inclement weather.

Paul Martin's possesses numerous attributes that render it an appealing dining establishment, regrettably, the peripheral aspects are subpar. Paul Martin's exudes an air of refinement, reminiscent of upscale steakhouses in the nation's capital, with its dim yet pleasing illumination, vibrant but unobtrusive musical ambiance, and welcoming atmosphere.

The culinary offerings at Paul Martin's are generally satisfactory, with the Sunday special, comprising a salad, prime rib, and ice cream, priced at $25, being a notable example. The salad boasts a diverse array of flavors without becoming overpowering, while the prime rib is tender and benefits from an exceptional spice rub that elevates it to a higher level. Unfortunately, the interior of the prime rib is somewhat lacking in quality, resembling a vast expanse of mediocre meat. The dessert option fails to impress, as the absence of lactose-free selections renders it inaccessible to patrons with dietary restrictions, which is both disappointing and perplexing, given the high standards that Paul Martin's purports to uphold.

The service at Paul Martin's falls short of expectations, as the server appears overwhelmed on occasion, exemplified by their response to our query regarding lactose intolerance, where they erroneously inform us that the ice cream is gluten-free. Furthermore, the staff's handling of gift cards sold by the establishment borders on offensive, as paying customers are made to feel awkward and guilty for utilizing them.

In conclusion, Paul Martin's cuisine warrants a rating of four stars, whereas its service only manages to achieve two stars. Thus, a rating of three stars seems appropriate.

"The personnel at this establishment generally exhibit a high level of cordiality and assistance, refraining from an excessive display of authority while maintaining a clean and organized environment. However, it is my observation that this particular location suffers from a noticeable dearth of diversity and options in terms of size..."

"Consequently, it is our considered opinion that Uncle Bears constitutes an ideal venue for social gatherings and casual dining experiences, facilitating as it does, an agreeable ambiance conducive to conviviality and relaxation. Although the menu may not boast an extensive array of culinary delights, it does feature a selection of delectable offerings, specifically including the slider variety, which consistently impresses with its satisfying flavor profile. Furthermore, the chicken fajitas merit high praise for their palatable quality, refuting as they do, unfounded claims of rubbery texture. 
  A most appreciable aspect of this establishment lies in its impressive beer selection, featuring an assortment of locally brewed Four Peaks varieties alongside an array of nationally recognized microbrews. The interior design and motif, characterized by elements reminiscent of canine companions, contributes further to the welcoming atmosphere, prompting patrons to ponder, albeit bemusedly, the curious absence of images showcasing their own cherished canines. Ultimately, Uncle Bears qualifies as a quintessential neighborhood tavern, offering a hospitable setting suitable for casual dining, socializing, and indulging in a diverse range of beverages."

D'Arcy McGee's serves up a mix of various cuisines that can be best summed up as Anglo-Saxon origin.  Ranging from dishes such as Irish boxty, corned beef and cabbage, Scotch eggs, Canadian poutine, and British Yorkshire pudding, portions are hearty and service is cheerful and pleasant.  The food quality itself is just OK, but it's a nice change of pace from your standard wings, pizza, or sandwiches that you find at other bar-type restaurants.
Pho is good but its not best pho or egg rolls (they don't even serve it with the lettuce and herbs) you can get in Pittsburgh. On the flip side though, their owner is super friendly

This Marble Slab Creamery is situated in the Stonecrest Shopping Center, precisely towards the forefront of the development, in close proximity to an array of establishments such as JoJo's, Miro, Dean & DeLuca, et al. It embodies a conventional ice cream shop, offering a diverse selection of flavors, along with a unique assortment of "Ice Cream Cupcakes" that caught my attention for the first time. Additionally, whole ice cream cakes in varying dimensions are prominently displayed within a stand-up freezer. Although a limited number of chairs and tables are dispersed throughout the interior, this location is conveniently positioned near an expansive outdoor plaza, replete with ample seating options adjacent to a magnificent fountain, providing an idyllic setting for patrons to relish their frozen treats during favorable weather conditions.

 On my visit, I opted to sample one of the aforementioned ice cream cupcakes at a later time, which proved to be satisfactory. Furthermore, I purchased a Birthday Cake milkshake, which, unfortunately, was not blended with the utmost care, resulting in an uneven consistency. The initial sips consisted solely of sweet milk, succeeded by occasional clumps of ice cream. While not exceptional, it remained adequate. The staff members exhibited kindness and hospitality, contributing to a pleasant experience. Ultimately, my expectations were not exceedingly high, and this establishment met them with its unremarkable yet acceptable offerings.

This particular venue boasts a proximate location in close vicinity to an outlet mall, thereby rendering it easily accessible to patrons. Within the establishment's premises, staff members proffer packing tape to customers upon request, a convenience notably absent at certain alternative locations where purchase is mandatory. Furthermore, the personnel assigned to customer service duties exhibit a demeanor characterized by kindness and helpfulness, a stark contrast to the demeanor displayed by certain individuals employed by the United States Postal Service.

My spouse and I decided to make a brief visit to this establishment prior to attending a cinematic production. As we had already partaken in our evening meal, we opted to solely indulge in alcoholic beverages and sweet treats.

Upon entering the premises, we elected to sit on the outdoor patio, which offered a pleasant atmosphere. Despite being the lone patrons occupying the patio, we were concerned that our presence might be overlooked by the staff. However, our concerns were quickly assuaged, as the service we received was quite satisfactory.

My companion opted for a bottled beverage, specifically a beer, while I chose to sample their frozen strawberry margarita. Unfortunately, the margarita lacked the intensity of flavor that I had anticipated, with the strawberry essence being somewhat diluted. My spouse, on the other hand, was pleasantly surprised by the taste of his beer, a brew named Victoria, which he found to be quite palatable. In addition, I requested a serving of frozen ice cream, selecting the vanilla variety. The visual presentation of the dessert was quite appealing, and I thoroughly enjoyed the crispy, deep-fried ice cream.

Prior to departing for the cinema, I took advantage of the facilities, specifically the women's restroom. I was favorably impressed by the spaciousness and cleanliness of the bathroom, which featured a large, full-length mirror. Additionally, the handicapped/nursing facility was exceptionally roomy and well-appointed.

In conclusion, our brief excursion to this eatery proved to be an enjoyable experience, and we may consider returning for a future dinner date.

Rented a twenty-five footlong recreational vehicle that encountered thrice electrical malfunctions during a ten-day excursion. Fortunately, the rental company's customer support staff proficiently arranged for a field technician to visit us at distant national parks to diagnose and rectify the issues. Regrettably, the motorhome had been inadequately maintained prior to our rental, resulting in persistent problems. Despite this setback, we enjoyed our journey after resolving the battery-related difficulties. I would consider renting from them again, but I would insist on a more recent model with lower mileage and thoroughly inspect the vehicle before embarking on my trip.

We went to Fairview Grill for dinner and drinks one night. We expected an evening of pub food, draft beer, and an unpretentious atmosphere, and that's exactly what we got.  

We had a coupon for a free entree, so to us the prices were VERY reasonable.  Generally entrees (mostly sandwiches and burgers) are about $8, which is an excellent value considering the quantity of food you get. We both had burgers, and we were both very pleased. My husband had fries, which he enjoyed, and I got onion rings (of course), and they were above average. The waitress got our order correct (even the "hold the X, extra Y" order we placed) without writing it down.  She was very attentive, and kept the beer and water flowing.  

The atmosphere is one of a relaxed pub--everyone was very friendly there too, including two guys who waved at us upon entering and asked how we were doing.  

Because we are right down the street from Fairview Grill, we will definitely be returning.  Might even shoot a game or two of pool. I don't know if it stands out among pubs in town, but it was an enjoyable evening overall.

"The lodging establishment and its personnel are exceptional. I have a predilection for Hilton hotels and, in terms of accommodations, this particular venue is satisfactory. However, the location is not optimal due to the necessity of utilizing taxi services to reach destinations beyond walking distance; nevertheless, the guestroom and overall structure are quite pleasant. 

It is advisable to avoid participating in a timeshare sales presentation if feasible. The reduced tariff for the hotel stay was not worth the unpleasant sensation lingering in my mouth after enduring a prolonged sales pitch lasting two and a half hours. 

In the event that you already possess ownership and have dedicated yourself to taking vacations, then indeed, this would be a suitable place to lodge. 

In the event that you resemble the majority of individuals and are unable to tolerate aggressive sales tactics, I would refrain from accepting any offers that may appear appealing in exchange for attending a sales presentation, as it is unequivocally not worthwhile. I would willingly return in time and compensate someone to avoid reliving that experience once more."

I am fond of the concept of this establishment, as it offers the opportunity to partake in live musical performances while enjoying a meal before proceeding to witness a comedic act in the adjacent venue. The culinary offerings were indeed delectable. However, my sole grievance pertains to the sluggish pace of the service, as it required an excessive duration of time to receive our initial course of fried potato slices. Despite their flavorfulness, the prolonged wait was unacceptable. Nevertheless, the assortment of beverages available on tap was impressive. It is my hope that the efficiency of the service will improve with the passage of time.

I expected more...Overall, the food was very good (thus, the three stars), but the experience overall was a big let down.  My entree came before I was finished with my appetizer and the dessert was a disappointment.  I expected impeccable service and a long leisurely dinner.    Instead, I felt rushed and let down.  Not worth the money.

It's a decent paper with great access to their writers. Plus, I really like the location! (They are located directly next to my office, so whenever I need something...I just walk over) \n\nIt also makes a great filler in my fire pit! Lol

Overall spent a fun evening in this buzzing,pseudo loungy Portuguese.
The Pros: nice atmosphere where you can watch the kitchen if you're into that kind of thing. You can rub elbows with a hip very well to do Montreal crowd. The food is very good and the menu extensive.
Cons: this place is quite expensive for what you get and  you can easily spend more than $150 per person if you go with a variety of tapas,mains, dessert drinks and wine.
Lots of sea food and fish items but at nearly $40 a plate it's almost at the ripoff price point. Conclusion if you got money to burn by all means go.  If you don't skip it or beware.

"On this particular occasion, it so happens that this specific Hampton Inn establishment represents my inaugural visitation. The layout and overall design of the premises seem to conform to the standardized template typically associated with Hampton Inn properties. Nonetheless, the personnel here have demonstrated a remarkable level of cordiality and assistance, which unfortunately cannot be said for all locations I have had the privilege of visiting. My arrival took place prior to the hours of 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and the receptionist was able to facilitate my check-in process without any undue delay or complications. The state of the room was satisfactory, with no visible signs of disarray or neglect. Subsequently, I decided to pay a visit to the on-site Fitness Center during the late afternoon hours, only to be confronted with a rather unexpected revelation. The designated 'Fitness Center' was, in reality, a minuscule storage space that housed a paltry assortment of three exercise machines and a handful of exercise balls. This cramped space, regrettably, lacked the capacity to accommodate more than four individuals at any given moment, thus leading to an unfortunate sense of disappointment on my part."

was, okay.

I had the lamb entree, nothing exceptional.  could use more fresh veggie on the plate versus just legumes.

lamb cooked well but was not memorable at all. (no rosemary or other good taste)--was SOO PLAIN as if i was eating british food.

service:

waitor was nice
one server came with our dishes and we had to move things on our table to make space.  we are used to services being experienced enough to prep our table or manage the dishes they are carrying.

department stores are always awful spaces to be in, BUT, there IS something that changes a bit during the madness of the holiday rush, like the mania of our commodity/consumer culture reveals itself in a particularly fascinating way... the emphasis on the DISPLAY takes on new urgency and obsession during december. I had kind of a great time just people watching as i tagged along behind my brother who was looking for a necklace for his gf. Call it a sick fascination, but i actually like being in the thick of the spectacle for the holidays... so, even though i bought nothing, i did have kind of a fun 25 minutes skulking around the multi-level store.\n\nI will also add, that this particular Bay has the most enormous and endless perfume section I've even experienced... each of the aisles in the near-infinite procession of stocked smells is equally attended by some charming model-esque figure who is only too eager to spritz some Cher-endorsed stink in your face... hellish yet hypnotic!

those that know me know i like to have a good time. 

i usually do.

went with a group of around 30, so yeah it was crazy.

for some strange reason, i just wasnt feeling this place. yeah the usual things youd find at a strip club are here..  cute to a few HOTT ladies walking around preying on drunk folks. random ass femalecustomer getting it on with a group of said ladies.... hella expensive ass drinks......

but strip clubs are like masturbation.... in the begining it all seems like a great idea, youre all excited and during, youre having a great time..... but after a few minutes after, you realized, damn i just fucked myself.
 
+1 star for that cute stripper that actually seemed like she was enjoying chatting and took me over to an abandoned area not being used that night just to chat about random ass shit and not to clean me out of all my money.

Bonne nourriture, ambiance et d\u00e9cor.\nPar contre, service tr\u00e8s in\u00e9gal et boiteux.\nProbl\u00e8me \u00e9vident de gestion du service \u00e0 la client\u00e8le. Soyez pr\u00eats \u00e0 attendre tr\u00e8s longtemps.

I was excited to come here last Saturday to see Billy Gardell.  I knew I was going to get royally screwed out of tons of money by this place so I was semi-prepared.


Pros:
* Great acts
* Very intimate setting = every seat is a good seat with a good view of the stage
* Reasonable ticket prices
* Parking validation
* Decent food at reasonable prices for good portions
* Friendly service that is relatively fast and efficient

Cons:
* They cram you in like sardines
* Their drink prices are ridiculous and they make you buy two of them
* If you order food you still have to buy 2 wicked overpriced drinks.  The price of your food does NOT count towards some stupid minimum.
* They add a mandatory tip % to your bill


The bottom line is that I won't be back to this place until they fix how much they rape you or there is a comic that I really really really want to see.  I realize that they are in biz to make money and are probably raking it in, but they can go fuk themselves for being greedy and making me hate comedy theaters.

My companions hold this establishment in high regard, yet my personal assessment is somewhat tepid. It is contingent upon one's penchant for a particular type of pizza, as individual preferences vary greatly in this regard. I do not partake in pizza that is heavily reliant on bread, as the sauce is the paramount component that determines its quality. Unfortunately, the pies served here are rather parsimonious with their sauce and cheese, which does not align with my predilections. Those who appreciate a superior crust may find this place appealing, but it does not suit my tastes. Being a native of Chicago, I have been exposed to an abundance of exceptional pizza venues, which has elevated my standards. While Phoenicians may recommend various establishments, my experiences have led me to conclude that they are merely mediocre in comparison to the renowned Lou Malnattis or Giordano's in Chicago.

It's Carowinds. Some good rides. Most surrounded by stuff you won't ride or games you won't waste money on. The kids will have fun, no doubt. The people are nice enough. The group hospitality is very good with great brisket and chicken. They make you feel welcome. Just enjoy it.

"We visited this establishment as part of the 'Buffet of Buffets' 24-hour pass experience, and while it may not compare to the opulent spread offered at the Wynn, we believe that it warrants more than the numerous one and two-star reviews it has received. Although the variety of dishes may be restricted, the quality of the cuisine is certainly not subpar. The ambiance of the interior is quite welcoming, but the queue can be quite lengthy, unless, of course, you possess diamond or platinum membership status, which grants you expedited access."

"I require a half-star button, as three and a half stars seem insufficient to express my ambivalence towards this dining experience. Following an unsuccessful attempt to procure a strawberry honey tea, I reluctantly opted for a raspberry tea, which, much to my dismay, lacked the characteristic sweetness that its moniker would suggest. My culinary excursion also included a tamale chx salad, comprised of an assortment of ingredients such as grapes, celery, green onion, and almonds, all finely sliced to prevent any singular component from dominating the palate. While the salad was indeed satisfactory, the tamale itself was somewhat disappointing, as it failed to exhibit the moisture and flavor that I have come to expect from such a dish. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the meal was priced at a reasonable eight dollars, which, in conjunction with the friendly and expedient service, almost persuades me to consider a future visit solely for the purpose of sampling the aforementioned strawberry honey tea that has garnered such fervent endorsements from patrons."

We arrived too late to be seated and were quickly told as much the second we walked through the door.

But we were hungry and so very pleased to find out they would let us order take out. 

The food was prepared fast and tasted good. It was my first time eating at this chain so I'm not sure how it normally tastes. I really liked the garlic aioli that came with my pasta. The salad was tasty.

The manager Adam Wilcox, accommodated some of our party's particular requests.

They have gluten-free options - make sure you order them specifically even if you are ordering off the gluten-free menu.

I had a great burger here the night--it was a no-frills deal, like something you're mom would've made if she were in a rush. But it was tasty. Coupled with a few beers (and the P-stone has a TON), it was a great little meal. \n\nThe P-stone's a cool little place, although it doesn't look like much from the street. In fact, it really doesn't look like anything at all, really. Groovy, mellow crowd hangs here, so it's not a real rowdy scene if that's what you're looking for. Very familiar feel--like a mom and pop deal, if that makes sense. It seems like a cook place to hang out with a bunch of friends on a random, quiet night.

Came here a little while back to see Fu Manchu - the stoner rock band, that is, not the movie. This little dive on the southeast corner of Hayden and Roosevelt in a little strip mall used to be called Chaser's. Saw a few local bands there a few times back in the day - Zen Lunatics, One Foot In The Grave. One Foot In The Grave was sort of a Sun City novelty punk band about 2 decades ago when all members being over 50 was actually a novelty. Now that most punk bands from the first wave or even the hardcore years are all past 50 that novelty has long worn off. :) So the bar pretty much looks the same as it did during the Chaser's years and place had a good sized crowd - you had to squeeze your way through to get from point A to point B. Men's bathroom didn't even have a door but at least it had working toilets - no peeing in coffee cans here. Had one gin and tonic - tasted a little watery so I didn't get any more. Headliners were super loud. Like holy crap I forgot my earplugs loud. Like stop by the bookstore tomorrow and get the Sign Language For Dummies LOUD! It's ok for shows but I wouldn't come here again unless I  REALLY REALLY want to see whatever band is playing here.

"An assessment of this establishment can be encapsulated in the adage 'you get what you pay for.' While it may not have been a luxurious or opulent venue, it offered a satisfactory and economical lodging experience. My expectations were adequately met, as the facilities were well-maintained, the staff was attentive, and the amenities, including transportation to and from the Las Vegas Strip and McCarran International Airport, were convenient. In conclusion, a reasonable and contented stay was had, particularly considering the elevated prices customary in Las Vegas."

"Individuals with a propensity for cordiality and an inclination towards the procurement of unconventional goods have consistently provided me with a satisfactory experience, characterized by the offering of high-quality wares and an abundance of fresh produce, further complemented by an impressive array of dehydrated fruits and nuts."

Positives:  muddled cocktail is sublime.  Service was friendly and attentive.  A variety of menu items at different price points.  A great environment & stylish moderndecor.\n\nNegatives:  the food.  It's nothing special.  Lots of highly stylized menu choices, where the title outdoes the reality.

We were excited to try Julian Serrano because of their ceviche and array of tapa menus! I ordered the mixed seafood ceviche- it was meh okay.  Nothing special.  Also the steamed the mussels that were pretty good.  The other girls ordered the spare ribs and mushroom risotto - nothing specatuclar :-(

It is entirely acceptable and within the realm of possibility that one may find themselves in a state of contentment and satisfaction, having consumed a culinary creation such as a chicken pita sandwich, which, by virtue of its inherent qualities, including the savory flavors imbued within the pita bread and the generous portioning of succulent chicken, constitutes a veritable feast for the taste buds, thereby rendering it an optimal choice for those seeking satiation and nourishment. However, it is equally conceivable that certain individuals may harbor a desire for something additional, some je ne sais quoi that would elevate their dining experience to a higher plane of existence, thereby warranting a rating of four or five stars. Furthermore, it is important to note that a plethora of alternative establishments and culinary options exist, readily available for those who do not have a preference for chicken pita sandwiches or seek a different gastronomical experience altogether.

The modified text is: "CAUTIONARY NOTE: IT HAS COME TO OUR ATTENTION THAT THE ESTABLISHMENT IN QUESTION UTILIZES LEAN MEAT IN THEIR CULINARY PREPARATIONS. WHILE WE ACKNOWLEDGE THE HEALTH BENEFITS OF SUCH AN APPROACH, WE MUST ALSO CONSIDER THE IMPACT ON THE TASTE AND TEXTURE OF THE FOOD. UPON PERUSING THE MENU, WE NOTICED THAT THE BURGER OPTION APPEARED TO BE A VIABLE CHOICE, AND WE DECIDED TO PROCEED WITH TWO ORDERS OF SAID ITEM.
