HOWEVER, UPON CONSUMING THE BURGERS, WE NOTICED THAT THEY WERE OF A DRY NATURE, WHICH LED US TO SHARE A SIDE OF FRIES BETWEEN US. UPON REVIEWING THE BILL, WE NOTICED THAT THE TOTAL AMOUNTED TO $30, WHICH, WHILE NOT EXORBITANT, DID NOT SEEM TO JUSTIFY THE QUALITY OF THE FOOD AND SERVICE PROVIDED. AS SUCH, WE DO NOT ANTICIPATE RETURNING TO THIS ESTABLISHMENT IN THE NEAR FUTURE."

"For an unparalleled price of $2, patrons can indulge in a wide range of coffee concoctions every Wednesday, where size is no barrier to savings, be it a compact yet flavorful small latte, a medium latte that strikes a perfect balance between volume and value, or a large latte that offers an uncompromising experience for those who crave a truly satiating cup; the choice is yours, but rest assured, the price remains constant and unbeatably advantageous."

Not much to say. Very typical type of spot. Nice look and feel. Decent food. Didnt blow me away, but maybe that is because I didnt try their famous pizza. \n\nI'll update the next time I am out there, but that is only if I actually feel like going back. I recommend it more as a spot to fit a bunch of friends who want to grab some cold ones and some grub while watching the games.

While holding a divergent perspective regarding the superior quality of the fried poultry served at this establishment, I concur with the notion that it constitutes a remarkable local discovery within the city of Charlotte, offering delectable fried cuisine that caters to both regional patrons and visiting gastronomes with equal proficiency. The venue experiences a high volume of patronage, with a constant influx of customers from 11 am onward, culminating in either the exhaustion of the daily menu items or the closure of the eatery. It is imperative to note that the restaurant only accepts paper currency, thus it is advisable to verify the availability of funds in one's wallet prior to arrival, and refrain from allowing the presence of pedestrians gathered adjacent to the sidewalk to deter you, as this phenomenon is customary and not indicative of any anomaly. The ordering process is expedited, resulting in the rapid procurement of culinary items, followed by a prompt departure to accommodate the succeeding patron in line. The menu features a variety of fried delicacies, including chicken and fish options; personally, I advocate for the unwavering preference of poultry. Supplementing the meal with hush puppies and coleslaw contributes to an enhanced dining experience. I recommend paying a visit to this establishment to form your own opinion.

I failed to acquire any edible items to consume during my visit due to the fact that I was in the process of recuperating from a bout of food poisoning. However, my significant other managed to procure the spicy pork tacos, which he asserted were the most delectable tacos he had ever had the pleasure of consuming. This establishment exudes an aura of authenticity, as evidenced by the lengthy queues and numerous patrons in attendance. My companion awarded five stars in recognition of the culinary excellence displayed by the eatery. 
  Notwithstanding, one cannot help but wonder if the prolonged waiting period is truly justified. The duration of the queue significantly diminishes the overall rating, relegating it to a mere three stars. The system employed for organizing the queue was utterly perplexing. Numerous patrons have pointed out that there are separate lines for various types of fare. In total, there are six distinct lines, divided into two sets of three. The first set consists of lines dedicated to pork (abodaba), offal (including brains, tongue, stomach, tripe, intestines, et cetera), and beef (encompassing asada, et cetera). Despite its apparent length, the queue moved at a glacial pace, making the prolonged delay seem utterly absurd. 
  Upon drawing closer to the front of the line, it became apparent that the sluggishness was attributable to a single individual performing the duties of two people. Although he demonstrated remarkable speed in crafting the tacos, he was responsible for preparing a minimum of five tacos for every patron. Moreover, he produced an excess of fifty tacos while we waited, ostensibly for takeout orders (wrapped in foil and placed on paper plates). The combination of the time required per person and the additional tasks undertaken by the taco artisan for the benefit of those not present in the queue contributes substantially to the interminable delay. It appears that there must exist a more effective method for them to manage their operations!

Gorgeous casino, décor scheme seems to be taken from the Bellagio gardens- good mix of stores, restaurants, and gaming. Really appreciate how spacious this casino is, lots of space to walk around without cramming slot machines into every available nook.

Service is typically very top notch, and restaurants on site are known for being able to accommodate any dietary restriction and have several vegan, vegetarian, and vegetable-laden options at each.

Parking garage is smaller than most but easily accessible, casino itself is on the smaller side but more intimate and upscale rather than crowded and gaudy.

Had the popcorn with bacon for an appetizer - it was ok, but nothing great. We split the chicken and waffles - not bad, but not maybe I'm just not a fan of chicken & waffles in general (don't hate me). But - we also ordered the short rib, which was quite delicious! It came with some greens that were quite un-delicious and we didn't take more than 1 bite of them. \n\nIf you try it, get there early otherwise it gets VERY loud inside and you'll be yelling across the table to have a conversation.

This place was pretty nice (not super fancy but decorated nicely) but the food was average.  We came here bc someone had \"the best\" beef noodle soup here over a year ago and loved it.  Unfortunately, they did not like it this time, stating it was somewhat flavorless.  Food here is definitely overpriced, as I learned many restaurants in the nice casinos are, but we were comped so I can't complain about price.  However, had I had to pay for this meal, I would not have been happy.  I got the Hainan Chicken Rice, which was really dry.  Usually, the rice is simmered in broth, but the rice was pretty dry - chicken, too.  We also got the Beef Chow fun, which wasn't bad but not excellent either.  The best part of my meal was the Iced Coffee (which I think they charge $6 for).  Everyone also liked the Fried Shrimp Balls, which came on a dim sum cart.  I was excited to see Soupy Dumplings on the cart, but alas, they were only moist and not very soupy at all.  Most items were mediocre and I most likely will not eating here again.

I had the pleasure of partaking in a fleeting culinary experience at this establishment, whereupon I opted for my customary fare, specifically, a Bean Burrito and 7 Layer Burrito. My order was fulfilled with precision, the ambiance was spotless, and the comestibles were passable, albeit unremarkable. It is, after all, a Taco Bell franchise, and as such, it is challenging to proffer effusive praise. Notwithstanding, I shall indeed revisit this venue in the future.

"I had the privilege of partaking in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment on Valentine's Day, and thus, I was presented with the opportunity to sample their pre-fixed menu. Unfortunately, the cost of the meal was somewhat prohibitive due to the festive nature of the occasion. Moreover, the quality of the cuisine did not quite meet my expectations, perhaps owing to the fact that the kitchen had to prepare large quantities of food for the influx of patrons. Notwithstanding the diminutive proportions of each dish, I failed to complete any of them, as my palate was not sufficiently impressed. Furthermore, my companion and I still felt a lingering sense of hunger subsequent to our meal. Nonetheless, the ambiance of the restaurant was quite pleasant, as we were seated in close proximity to a window that offered an unparalleled panoramic view."

It's an airport. You get to Vegas and then you immediately go straight to partying. Even the airport is calling for a party with the slot machines located at the baggage claims. \n\nThis airport moves pretty quick too. They get the job done and fly you to your destination! wohoo!

"Minus a star for not possessing an EPL ticket to display all the matches. For Pete's sake, you are THE English bar in Phoenix and I cannot observe my adored Gunners unless they are on channel 167? Come on! If you are going to hang the flags and scarves, at least have the game available, especially when it's 7 a.m., and I yearn to become intoxicated while viewing Arsenal-Chelsea in the fifth most populous city in the United States, and I am unable to do so; this does not make me a contented individual. Haha. All things considered, not a terrible establishment. Fantastic selection of beverages. Nice dÃ©cor, to sum up, it's one of those places where you can indulge in libations for 2-3 hours, exit, and exclaim, "Good Lord, the sun is still up?!"

Took my Playstation 3 here after it stopped reading discs.  Had to take it back twice, still wasn't fixed.  In all fairness, the problem was beyond the scope of the repair, and they gave me a full refund.  That's superior policy/customer service.

On the downside, they removed my yet-unplayed copy of GTA 5 and stuck it in a ziplock bag after I offered to leave the case for them to put it in.  Disc looked like someone ate a bucket of chicken and put their hands all over it.  Also, I came back twice to have it re-repaired and each time was like I'd never been there before.  "Can I help you?"

I'll consider this experience a wash, as I left with the same broken unit but was not charged for the time invested.  Not certain I'd take anything else there.

"While in Phoenix for a corporate conference, I had the pleasure of dining at Tutti Santi, a culinary establishment that was graciously recommended by my colleague's father-in-law, who had previously visited the restaurant on multiple occasions. Absent this suggestion, it is unlikely that I would have discovered this eatery on my own accord. 

On the evening in question, the restaurant was bustling with activity due to a special promotional event, which appeared to have caught the staff off guard. As a result, there was a considerable delay in placing our order, during which time we opted to sample a bottle of wine from their extensive selection. While awaiting the arrival of our appetizers, we indulged in the accompanying bread, which proved to be quite satisfying. However, owing to the sluggish pace of service, our initial bottle of wine was depleted well before the main courses were served. 

Upon the arrival of our food, we elected to procure an additional bottle of wine, which unfortunately failed to materialize. Despite bringing this oversight to the attention of our server, no further action was taken. This unfortunate sequence of events detracted significantly from our overall dining experience, transforming what would have otherwise been a four-star review into a decidedly less favorable assessment."

Table of 4, wait was 20++ minutes late on a Thursday night.   No bar to wait in, plus no alert system (buzzer or whatever) so we couldn't wander around the casino.   Once we were seated, the food was great.....  Just burgers but lots of toppings, etc.   Nothing bad nor was it overly memorable.  Very sufficient for a bite in Harrahs!

I am not too picky about movie theaters. We usually go to the theater with the show times we like best. They all could use a more frequent deep cleaning, and this one is no different.\n\nIt bothers me, though, when people think it is the movie theater's job to clean up after them, so they leave their trash in the aisle and on the seats. You bought it, you own it, you dispose of it up. Didn't your mom teach you to clean up after yourself?

"Applebee's typically offers palatable victuals at a relatively reasonable cost. However, my recent visit to this specific Applebee's location did not live up to my expectations, failing to provide an optimal dining experience that would motivate me to return. 

Our group of three was promptly seated, yet the service subsequently became sluggish. Our server delivered an incorrect type of beverage for one member of our party, which was followed by a delay in procuring the proper brew and an extended period before additional napkins were provided. 

I opted for a midday special that encompassed half of a sandwich and a diminutive salad. The shrimp and spinach salad possessed remarkable flavor; however, the sandwich I chose, specifically the California turkey club, featured lettuce with an unpleasant acidity that necessitated its removal, and the bread was excessively oily. 

The sangria presented a delectable taste, albeit with a scarcity of fruit that left room for improvement."

Been here once. It's small, lots of shops. Live music. The praying mantis lights fire around 9pm. I personally didn't like it. It's very much for families. I felt awkward. So my date and I found other things to do. Wasn't my thing, might try it again one day. But not anytime soon.
Way too over priced. I mean its great food. With an average sized portion. But for how much I'm paying?... Not totally worth it!

Here's the thing, I genuinely desire to endorse this establishment. It proximates my domicile, the minuscule cakes perpetually appear delectable, and an agreeable aroma permeates the atmosphere. I've visited this location on multiple occasions, and each time, I've encountered distinctive and imaginative flavors that I've seldom witnessed elsewhere; Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, and Peanut Butter and Honey, who would conceive of such combinations?!

However, possibly I frequented this establishment during inopportune periods. The cake presented itself as succulent and appetizing. Nonetheless, the icing proved excessively abundant and overpowering, even for my better half, who relishes sweets to an extent where he could effortlessly devour an entire tray of brownies unassisted and in a single sitting. He needed to extract the icing midway through consumption since it became too copious for his taste buds.

I won't relinquish my yearning for their products though! I shall likely revisit this venue due to my infatuation with cupcakes (we even incorporated them into our wedding celebrations), as I ardently aspire to appreciate their offerings.

I don't see what the big deal is.  Everyone told me that this is the best Buffett.  I don't think. I haven't been to any others but I dint think that this Buffett is the best. The breakfast is way better than dinner. and the basically have the same stuff for breakfast as dinner too! lol

I shall initiate my statement by expressing that the Midnight Diner is undoubtedly one of the finer establishments within the culinary landscape of Charlotte. Nonetheless, my visit this evening did not mirror the quality that I had anticipated. Following a prolonged wait, during which we were seated and our server, Ashley, declined our request to modify our order, we received subpar service that bordered on inadequacy. It was almost as if we were being stereotyped based on the preconceived notion that "black people don't tip," which left me feeling rather taken aback. Fortunately, a server named Larry, also known as "Showtime," managed to redeem the remnants of an otherwise dismal experience through his exceptional service. His demeanor and attentiveness personified the epitome of excellence in customer service. In light of this, it is unfortunate that our primary server did not receive a gratuity. I can only hope that she takes heed of her colleagues' examples and improves her performance moving forward. Notwithstanding, I shall indeed return to the Midnight Diner in the future, and I shall make certain to request "Showtime" as my server for the duration of his tenure at the establishment.

I always know I'm in Vegas when I come here and spend 20 bucks on a subway 5 dollar footlong lmao! Seriously how is it even legal for subway to rip you off like that haha. \n\nSlots of fun is like a 20 ton boulder going down hill....once it gets going...unstoppable. I don't even gamble here. When I stay at riviera I usually just come over to slots of fun to grab a nathans hot dog or some Over priced subway sandwiches. That being said there is something I like about the place. Just really old school vegas. Vegas actually needs more places like this. Hate to say it but I will be back lol

Being from Chicago and San Diego, my spouse and I are poised to experience a culinary culture shock while dining in the Carolinas, and this particular establishment served as the inaugural dining experience, which we entered with trepidation due to its unfamiliar ambiance characterized by plastic-coated checkered tablecloths. Despite our initial reservations, we opted to persevere and sample their gastronomic offerings. 

Upon scrutinizing their menu, I sought the ubiquitous California wrap, adorned with bean sprouts and avocado, but instead discovered an array of Southern-style dishes, including southern fried chicken, skillet-fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens, and, of course, BBQ. My curiosity was piqued regarding the nature of BBQ, wondering if it encompassed a specific sauce, pork, beef, or chicken. Lacking familiarity with this regional cuisine, I was genuinely perplexed. 

Notwithstanding, we placed our orders from their extensive menu, which boasted an impressive selection of fried "veggies," albeit with a prevalence of breading and deep-frying. It is worth mentioning that, in our opinion, a well-balanced flavor can be achieved without reliance on excessive breading and copious amounts of fat. 

Fortunately, the food proved to be palatable, with generous portions, and our server exhibited kindness and attentiveness, addressing us with courteous "yes ma'ams" and "no ma'ams." In conclusion, we aspire to discover a dining establishment that showcases a greater diversity of options beyond sandwiches, traditional Southern home cooking, and an abundance of artery-clogging vegetable dishes.
Good location for a decent bite to eat before the game. Gets busy, but the food and service is good. Little on the pricy side.

This eatery has an ambiance that is moderately suitable for a Vietnamese restaurant, albeit somewhat marred by the pervasive odor of cigars emanating from the adjacent cigar bar, which initially created an unfavorable first impression upon entry. Notwithstanding this setback, the service we received was relatively prompt, and the proprietor, who attended to us personally, exhibited a friendly and helpful demeanor, offering recommendations when requested. Our culinary selections were served in a timely manner, comprising of beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls for myself, and chicken pho for my companion, accompanied by Vietnamese iced coffee. My appreciation for the broth was considerable, as it showcased a subtle yet discernible herbal flavor without an excessive oiliness commonly found in similar establishments. However, the rice noodles lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, possessing an unfortunate tendency towards starchiness. Furthermore, the eye round steak was slightly overcooked, and the iced coffee featured an excess of condensed milk, resulting in an overly saccharine quality. Despite these minor drawbacks, our dining experience was generally satisfactory, rendering it likely that we shall return in the future. Of interest to aficionados of piquant cuisine, a request for the ot satay sauce, a fiery condiment fashioned from Thai chilies and garlic paste, may serve as a superior alternative to sriracha.

This establishment... how could one not develop an affection for it?! The beverages offered here are truly exceptional and the cost is remarkably reasonable!! I would highly recommend either the \"G Spot\" or a martini, both of which are impeccably crafted and bound to satiate your thirst. The culinary offerings at this venue are also quite impressive. Specifically, the Fez burger is a personal favorite of mine, although I must admit that I am uncertain of the specific ingredients that comprise it. Nonetheless, I can confidently attest that it possesses an unparalleled flavor!! Unfortunately, I must concede that my experience was somewhat marred by an unexpected bout of illness that ensued later that evening. As I had consumed sustenance from multiple sources throughout the day, I cannot with certainty attribute the source of my discomfort to this particular eatery. However, I must confess that my reluctance to revisit this establishment has been augmented.

Evidently there's a zagat survey list on the best chain restaurant steak.  Which I find preposterous.  Would they have a list judging the best movie about grass growing?  "In the end, Crabgrass beat out Ragweed just because of the potential allergens."

No, because sometimes you can make an entire category of things that suck, and chain restaurants, as a general rule, serve shitty steak. Not that I'm judging.

So if you go to Outback, don't expect anything amazing, despite the fact that zagat said they were tasty.  But outback is worth visiting anyway, because have you ever had their shrimp appetizer served on their brown bread garlic slab-thing?  The bread is better than the shrimp.  It's amazing.

But truly legendary status is only accorded thusly: imagine an appetizer with so many calories that three could share and still crack a thousand calories each?  Enter the cheese fries with bacon and a glob of ranch and you will know what spoonfuls of lard feel like to your arteries.  This particular location has a number of great bartenders and if you go there looking for a pleasant time and decent food, you'll be satisfied.  Chicken breast with BBQ sauce: palatable.  Broccoli with crab-butter sauce?  Tasty.  Rack of lamb? Surprisingly good.  Really there are a ton of options here but one thing you will not get is world-beating steak.  So save it, Zagat.

"This bar boasts an exceptional atmosphere, rendering it an ideal location for sipping beverages and engaging in people-watching activities or simply socializing with companions. The dÃ©cor exudes a sophisticated lounge-style ambiance, enhanced by the well-crafted drinks served here, which, although not the most extensive selection, are undoubtedly palatable, particularly for a casino bar. \n\nMy companion and I opted for a vodka grey goose accompanied by tonic, and we were pleasantly surprised by its robust alcohol content, constituting approximately three-quarters of the beverage. Similarly, our server, clad in an adorable lacy mini dress, delivered a rum and diet coke, generously portioned with a substantial amount of rum. Although the prices appeared reasonable, they did not strike us as extraordinarily affordable. Nonetheless, the overall experience at this hotel lobby bar was satisfying, primarily owing to the welcoming demeanor of the staff."

"Underwhelming experience. Capriotti's offers a few palatable sandwiches, but several others fall short of expectations. 

My preferred sandwich at this establishment is the Capastrami, featuring succulent pastrami, Swiss cheese, and a generous helping of creamy coleslaw and Russian dressing, all grilled to perfection. Reminiscent of a Reuben, this sandwich is well-constructed and the bread holds up admirably. 

Regrettably, the bread used for their cheesesteaks and Italian subs is problematic, as it lacks the necessary absorbency to effectively soak up the flavors and moisture of the other ingredients. Consequently, these particular sandwiches fall short of their potential. 

Furthermore, the cheesesteaks are hindered by unsavory, arid meat that lacks any discernible flavor. Unremarkable would be an appropriate descriptor. 

While the Bobbie may not be everyone's cup of tea due to the inclusion of mayonnaise, omitting it results in an excessively dry sandwich. However, the store-roasted turkey pairs nicely with provolone cheese and hot peppers on cold subs. 

For superior cold subs, Jersey Mike's is the preferable choice, while Pop's remains the premier destination for cheesesteaks in Las Vegas."

"Ambivalent about the experience, as the prolonged waiting period for a table, owing to its current popularity, detracted from the overall enjoyment. Despite the diminutive size of the establishment, the delay in being seated was considerable and may deter some patrons. However, upon being accommodated, the culinary offerings proved to be somewhat inconsistent, specifically the red velvet pancakes, which were excessively sweetened and thus, disappointingly overrated. In contrast, the buttermilk pancakes fared better, boasting an optimal level of moisture and flavor, enhanced by the complementary butter and syrup. Additionally, the corned beef hash was satisfying, although the accompanying potatoes were unremarkable."

My review is mainly for the Casino (As I was staying next door at the Palazzo).  I really wanted to like this place and went in with high expectations. The place itself was crowded with mainly foreigners taking pictures everywhere and walking super slow. I found one slot game that I liked, but could not play long because the guy next to me had his entire family sit on the other machines and they were not playing. Really wanted to get into the table games but just too many people out and about to get by. I will stop in again next time because I did have a good feeling.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on three separate occasions, with two of those experiences being of the drive-thru variety and the most recent being a dine-in visit. I must say, I am delighted that I opted to dine in, for it afforded me the opportunity to observe the kitchen staff in their natural habitat, so to speak. One of the cooks, a Caucasian male, was not adorned in the customary gloves worn by his colleagues, which, in conjunction with his unfortunate lack of hygiene, led me to question the overall cleanliness of the kitchen. Furthermore, upon venturing to the restroom, I discovered that the paper towel dispenser was devoid of its intended contents, thus necessitating my utilization of the blower, which, in turn, produced an abundance of noise that served as a stark contrast to the otherwise tranquil ambiance of the dining area. This sequence of events led me to deduce that the aforementioned cook had neglected to properly sanitize his hands prior to resuming his culinary duties. Lastly, as I emerged from the restroom, I was greeted by the sight of the same individual grasping a generous portion of bacon, which, coincidentally, happened to be a key component of my companion's bacon burger. It is worth noting that the cook's attire, or lack thereof, accentuated his posterior region in a manner that was conspicuous and, some might argue, inappropriate. While I do intend to return to this establishment in the future, I do so with the hope that the aforementioned cook will not be present during my subsequent visits. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, I must admit that the quality of the burgers and fries served here is quite impressive.

I had heard about the Pink's in So Cal and I had always wanted to try it. When I saw there was one in Vegas, I was excited to check it out. I was disappointed, to say the least. I ordered the mushroom swiss dog, which costed me $6.50. The hot dog tasted rubbery to me and there wasn't nearly enough swiss cheese on it. The moments where I got swiss cheese, mushrooms, and hot dog were really good but there weren't very many of them. They put way too many mushrooms and not enough cheese. If it had been better proportioned I may have enjoyed it more. I would probably still eat here again, but try something different next time. I heard the chili cheese dog is to die for.

Any pub on Rose St immediately has to compete with swathes of competitive drinking holes. As a result the Auld Hundred seems like another humdrum offering with nothing of particular attraction here. Then again, that may be exactly what the clientele like: a reliable and no frills establishment.\n\nYou'll find typically generous pub size portions with regards to food and a modest selection of ales, A- OK.

I stayed here for a bachelor party.  I've been here numerous times.  I love the location as it is within walking distance to all the hotels I like hanging at.  I like the fact that they gave me a fat discount because of a collective of my friends player points.  It isn't the newest hotel, but the rooms are clean and the staff were good.  I enjoyed their sportsbook.  Unfortunately, I was unable to do any dining over there nor have I ever dined over there.  That's a shame.  I would stay there again just for the price, but there are far superior hotels in Las Vegas.

The staff is attentive and helpful. We brought our kids one night to get dinner. Our food was predictably bar food- fried and heavy but not bad. We visited on a week night and they had a musician playing. We literally could not talk at our table. It was so incredibly loud we couldn't even hear each other. I am giving 3 stars only because of service. \nI would give 2 stars for the ambiance and because I wouldn't go here for date night or with my kids for dinner. It would be great just to watch a game or to go with someone you don't want to talk to.

"Cutting directly to the point, my culinary assessment of this establishment's offerings can be succinctly summarized as follows: the victuals served are merely passable, barely meeting expectations. In the event that you find yourself in close proximity and are seeking a rapid consumable meal, this venue may prove satisfactory. However, if your gastronomical inclinations lean towards genuinely exceptional Chinese cuisine, I would strongly advise venturing elsewhere, perhaps to Spring Mountain or, more specifically, the Golden State itself. Having recently returned from Los Angeles, where I indulged in some truly remarkable Chinese fare, my dining experience at this location proved underwhelming. For categorization purposes, I would relegate this eatery's culinary style to the same realm as Panda Express - while certainly palatable, it falls short of authentic Chinese cuisine."

I hadn't had Papa John's for at least a year.  It's one of the better chain pizza places, and unlike the Domino's that moved, it's conveniently on my way home from work.  I got a $10 gift card for $5 from www.saveology.com and they had their large specialty pizzas for $11.  The large is only 14\" which isn't really large, but the Spinach Alfredo pizza is pretty tasty.  I was disappointed they no longer put the butter sauce and pepporncini in the pizza box, but I understand it.  The service was a little slow as they have two registers but only one person working on one of them with a lot of people standing around.  I'd stop here for a pizza on my way home again if the price was right.

"I recently had the opportunity to observe this production for the second time, having previously experienced it without my spouse, who expressed a strong desire to view it. This particular show diverges significantly from the conventional Cirque du Soleil offerings, possessing a distinct emphasis on Asian-inspired elements, swordplay, and acrobatic feats. Unlike the majority of Cirque du Soleil performances, which tend to resemble a dreamlike state with little coherence and an assortment of breathtaking, heart-stopping acrobatic acts, KA boasts a discernible narrative thread and utilizes wires in a manner that mitigates any sense of fear or apprehension. 

However, certain aspects of the production, such as the linguistic style employed and select characterizations (including a Tarzan-esque figure), prove challenging to fully comprehend or appreciate. Despite having had the chance to experience the show twice, it remains outside my personal preferences within the Cirque du Soleil repertoire, and thus, I am grateful for the affordable ticket prices obtained on both occasions. The single aspect that truly captivated me was the expansive mobile platform capable of shifting between horizontal and vertical orientations, with the concluding sequence featuring combat on the vertical surface being my favorite; regrettably, the remaining segments did not hold my interest to the same degree as other productions within the Cirque du Soleil canon."

C'est un caf\u00e9 correct pour travailler et pour se prendre un lunch quand on a oubli\u00e9 le sien \u00e0 la maison. Je suis all\u00e9e \u00e0 l'heure du lunch et \u00e7a n'\u00e9tais pas trop occup\u00e9, donc la combinaison de wifi gratuit et grandes tables pour travailler \u00e9tait exactement ce que je cherchais. Ils ont un bonne vari\u00e9t\u00e9 de plats et le service est bien correct. J'ai pris deux salades : une aux l\u00e9gumes et moutarde dijon, puis l'autre l\u00e9gumes et p\u00e2tes \u00e0 l'orientale, ou bien plut\u00f4t simplement \u00e0 la sauce soya. Les deux \u00e9taient super bonne et j'ai bien aim\u00e9 avoir l'option d'un lunch sans trop de pain. Ils ont aussi des plats chauds et des plats du jour qui ont l'air de changer r\u00e9guli\u00e8rement. Somme toute, c'est un endroit qui m\u00e9lange le style caf\u00e9t\u00e9ria avec le style caf\u00e9 sans fla fla. C'est argent comptant, mais il y a un ATM au caf\u00e9 m\u00eame.

We visited this establishment for our evening meal on a Friday... Our group consisted of eight individuals, yet despite possessing a prior reservation and the lateness of the hour (9:45 PM), we were compelled to endure a brief delay before being seated, and furthermore, were assigned an outdoor table... in the intense heat of approximately 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  Although the temperature itself did not pose a significant inconvenience, we unfortunately failed to experience the full ambiance and interior design of the venue.  The kobe meatball dish was quite satisfactory.  My personal selection was an eight-ounce filet, which, while satisfying, did not include any additional sides, such as a potato, and so forth... However, the asparagus side dish I chose was both copious and flavorful.  The filet itself was cooked to my precise instructions and seasoned with great care... Most of the other patrons opted for pasta dishes, the quality of which I cannot accurately assess, as their appearances varied.  The service we received was proficient and attentive, with no notable errors committed.  While not excessively expensive, the prices charged were still somewhat elevated... Ultimately, I felt underwhelmed by the entire experience, harboring the sentiment that either a greater expenditure for superior cuisine or a lesser cost for more casual fare would have been preferable.  No major grievances can be reported, yet neither was I particularly impressed by any aspect.

Tried their 2 for $5 fish sandwiches and their $1.89 side salad.  The fish sandwich had too much bread for my liking and the fish was just okay.  The salad was iceberg and not worth me getting again.  The service was excellent and the lady manager is doing a great job,  The place is nicely decorate but I didn't think the food was worth me coming back for,

"Culinary excellence and an exceptional vinous experience. Superlative pasta dishes, with descriptions that accurately mirrored the actual composition of the dish. Upon requesting a detailed account of the wine from our attentive server, he delivered a precise and comprehensive depiction, leading to an unexpected transformation of our initial plans for a light repast and beverage into a full-fledged gastronomic indulgence. Elegant ambiance, polished service, and an overall atmosphere of refinement and quality."

Paid for a venti green tea lemonade and got a tall green tea lemonade . Reason why I didn't go back was because I had to go to school was in a rush I wish the girls that always take my orders were there

"The superior quality of the donuts at this establishment in South Phoenix renders it an optimal destination for indulging in such delectable treats, thereby making the arduousness of laboring in the aforementioned location thoroughly worthwhile; specifically, the maple bar variety is exceptionally scrumptious."

"It is palpable that the singular attribute which renders this establishment appealing is the captivating appearance and texture of their bread, which boasts an unparalleled freshness and taste. However, it is conspicuous that the sandwiches themselves are rather unremarkable and overpriced, with a cost of $5-6 for a meager offering. \n\nThe level of service provided by this establishment is glaringly inadequate, as there are merely a few employees present at any given time, leading to a sluggish and impatient experience for patrons. Furthermore, the antiquated nature of the building and the limited parking options available, including a minuscule rear lot, contribute to the overall dearth of convenience. Notwithstanding, I do concede that the diminutive original sandwich is moderately satisfying, primarily due to the exceptional quality of the bread. Nevertheless, if this eatery were to adopt a more conventional sub bread or baguette for their sandwiches, it is improbable that I would opt to dine here."

"The concise version: Acquire the delectable 'white cookie' directly from the oven at the quaint cafe for a mere $5. Unbelievable! Absolutely unbelievable! \n\nThe comprehensive rendition: Upon entering the eatery, one is confronted with an arduous waiting period, during which time water refills become a recurring necessity, requesting them each instance. It is regrettable that the 'Sunday pasta' dish had such a profoundly adverse effect on my gastrointestinal tract! (-_-). The pinnacle of culinary excellence within this establishment lies unequivocally with the aforementioned $5 cookies, freshly baked and displayed prominently in the front cafe. It is my sincere wish that I had allocated my Groupon specifically towards the procurement of those delectable treats, as opposed to the unremarkable entrees, which are assembled with pedestrian ingredients and served with little fanfare. Such is the nature of their preparation and presentation, resulting in an unimpressive gustatory experience, and one which warrants an exorbitant fee, I might add."

"Culinary indulgences abounded at this eatery, yet an enigmatic quality remained, eluding my comprehension. Ambience was satisfactory, despite the auditory assault emanating from the adjacent gaming arena. Prompt seating was accorded to us, sans reservation, during the meridian repast. The bill of fare, though diminutive in scope, boasted a diverse array of delectable options. I opted for the prime steak panini, accompanied by a tangy potato salad. A delightful confluence of flavors, complemented by the subtle pungency of barbecue sauce and a trace of horseradish, permeated the panini. The potato salad, a veritable masterpiece, struck the perfect balance between piquancy and richness, with just the right amount of mayonnaise. Regrettably, the hospitality encountered a marked decline, as sluggish service prevailed. An extended wait ensued before our check was delivered, followed by an even lengthier delay in retrieving my credit card. Infrequent were the instances wherein the server graced our presence with her attendance, post-consumption of the meal."
beet salad was fantastic. service was new and they spilled water over my table while I was eating. the short rib loco moco was too salty for my taste.

3.5 stars. 

Went with a group of friends this weekend for the open bar mostly. Guys got in for 20, which isn't that bad. Bouncers were a little rude for cover, not cool. 

TAO is really nice, appearance wise. Walking though the restaurant before going to the club did make me hungry. what a tease. 

Went early enough where there wasn't any issues of space. Our main goal here was drink, so we didn't get to explore the other dance floors, but that's okay, maybe next time. While most of the drink were aight, they made some pretty bad basic well drinks, and the wait to get a drink was long. Like come on, messing up a rum and coke? and waiting as much as I was dancing wasn't too hot either. But hey, was feeling really good after we left, so I'm not complaining too much, The music wasn't that bad too. Too bad we didn't know that dash berlin was playing that night. Well, bad that we didn't get to hear him play. good because we left before it got ridiculously packed. We were ale to dance with a great amount of space. and trust, with a group of dancers, we need our space. 

Overall, not a bad time at TAO. Guess I need another trip to really go exploring.

I came here with high hopes after reading the many good reviews.  what I found was good local hole in the wall that is somewhat over rated.
my burger was very dry - as the cook pressed down on the patties I kept screaming in my head PLEASE STOP!
The fries were very meh.  They were crunchy but had no character.
The best thing was that the ingredients were fresh.  While the patties were preformed they were not frozen.  They used plent of bacon so there was a piece in every bite.  The lettuce was green and crisp and overall it was a decent lunch, but over priced for what I got.  I probably won't make another trip back but if I lived nearby I would return rather than hit a fast food burger.

Good place to go and eat gyros if your up in North Scottsdale. The staff is friendly and the food gets to you real fast. The price is somewhere between 7-10 per meal but that's usual for N. Scottsdale.

Maybe I've had better Chinese in the past than I realized, or perhaps I ordered the wrong things, but I can't see giving this place five stars. The egg rolls were too salty, the hot and sour soup was lacking in sour, the vegetable pork was bland.\n\nIt's quick, not over priced and not over cooked. I'm willing to try it again.

"Grampa's Pizzeria - a culinary establishment named after its proprietor, which boasts an impressive reputation for serving delectable pizzas crafted with premium ingredients and ingenious flavor combinations, thus eliciting immense affection from patrons, including myself. However, my most recent dining experience at Grampa's raised concerns about the possibility of cognitive decline in the elderly proprietor, as evidenced by the perplexed expression on the host's countenance upon our entrance, which seemed to convey a mixture of curiosity and bewilderment regarding our identity and purpose. Moreover, the appetizer we ordered emerged from the kitchen uncooked, prompting me to inquire whether it had been inadvertently forgotten in the preparation process. After some hesitation, the staff decided to reheat it, albeit with a lack of conviction. Furthermore, an unspecified mishap occurred with the pizza, leading our server to intimate that its arrival would be delayed, much to our dismay. Nevertheless, Grampa's magnanimity prevailed, as we received a complimentary beverage in compensation for the inconvenience caused by the chaos that ensued. It is fortunate that the restaurant was not bustling with customers on that particular Monday evening, lest Grampa's advanced age and apparent forgetfulness might have resulted in utter bedlam."

It's been a while since I've had my eyes checked, and even when I did, it was probably either to get my drivers license or just to look in a little machine and tell them what I saw.  I don't know if I've ever had a full-blown eye exam.  That's no longer the case.

Since Denise has been jumping through hoops to have her eyes checked, it meant I needed to have mine done too, so I signed up so that they could see what's happening.

The Christenbury Eye Center is very professional, and they have quite the setup - you check in, and they shuffle you from room to room, where they (presumably) do all sorts of things to determine if your eyes are working or not.  Maybe they just pretend.  I don't really know.

They seem to know what they are talking about, and they have lots of famous people on the walls who say they know what they are doing, so that must make them experts, right?

You can also get laser eye surgery here, but after giving me drops to dilate my eyes (which screwed up my eyesight for the better part of the day - go figure), they told me that my eyes were just fine.  Hopefully I don't have to go back for a while.

Went here last night for the first time last night... Took forever to get in, then another customer decided to get into a fight with us because they didn't want us parked next to them, it was hard to hear parts of our movie because we could hear the movie that was playing next to us, and the helicopters flying around were really distracting. BUT the prices were VERY reasonable for admissions and if you wanted condensations (plus we had coupons)

I imagine at least a solid 60% of people who are trying to catch morning or afternoon flights out of here are hung over. \n\nWho thought it was a good idea to make this the loudest, brightest airport in the country?

"A diverse array of culinary selections, with notable highlights including the Grits & Pork Belly dish, which ascended to an elevated position among our preferences as the epicurean experience progressed, while the service, unfortunately, displayed fluctuations in its delivery, resulting in an inconsistent encounter; nevertheless, the atmosphere, despite a minor dearth of vitality, remained generally convivial, and the quality of the fare, particularly in relation to the price point, proved impressive, suggesting that once certain operational kinks are addressed, this establishment has the potential to evolve into a truly exceptional dining destination."

Stopped in for a slice with my son, large slice of pizza, generous toppings, a tad on the greasy side, but most likely due to the pepperoni.  all in all, thought it was good.  Food came out quickly, will stop in an try something else next time... Oh yea, no fountain drinks..... For me a negative

This review is about the dining experience- all I can say is, the meatball is so good that it pretty much made up for the completely distant, inattentive service that I received at dinner last Saturday.

What also helped was the perfect weather on the terrace over-looking the Strip.  So fun!

(I have eaten inside of the restaurant before, but it wasn't nearly as interesting.)

I indulged in certain potations and a pie here on the twenty-eighth of June, two thousand and twelve.

On a Thursday, I visited this establishment, and it was teeming with patrons; the space was filled to capacity, rendering it challenging to maneuver and nearly impossible to secure a seat. The ambiance was boisterous, bordering on cacophonous, and the dearth of personal space was palpable.

The hospitality was commendable, but the culinary offerings were exorbitant, considering their quantity and quality. The flavors of the thin-crust pizza were satisfactory, albeit slightly overcooked and excessively crunchy for my taste. However, individual preferences regarding the degree of doneness may vary.

The restrooms were minuscule, accommodating a single occupant at a time, which was incongruous with the restaurant's capacity. Anticipate a delay if you need to relieve yourself, as the limited facilities hinder efficient usage.

I am uncertain about the likelihood of my return, as my experience was marked by both positive and negative aspects.

"While my familiarity with authentic Korean cuisine may be limited, my appreciation for diverse Asian-inspired gastronomy remains unwavering. 

The unpretentious ambiance and prompt service afforded us an opportunity to sample their offerings without delay (our table being the second to be attended to). The Korean BBQ ribs and dolsot (I believe) were our choices, the former characterized by rich, fatty meat complemented by a subtle sweet sauce, while the latter arrived in a sizable stone bowl, its scorching temperature and copious amounts of rice, vegetables, and meat necessitating a thorough mixing with one's spoon to achieve a satisfying blend of textures and flavors, albeit with a somewhat muted overall taste profile. 

The accompanying sides, though perhaps lacking in inventiveness, still managed to contribute a welcome contrast to the spicy kimchi, their inherent sweetness offsetting the piquancy of the fermented Korean staple. When seeking a culinary experience that diverges from the norm in downtown Chandler, this establishment constitutes a viable choice."

The quality of service rendered here is truly commendable, however, my expectations regarding the Fuku Burger were not entirely fulfilled, as the patty and its constituent elements failed to surpass the threshold of mediocrity, prompting me to question the value offered by this culinary establishment, particularly when juxtaposed with the cost associated with said burger, which, in my opinion, ought to have been accompanied by a more impressive gastronomical experience, akin to that proffered by Stout; furthermore, the Togarashi French Fries, though novel in their conception, were merely average in their execution, thereby contributing to an overall sense of underwhelment. Notwithstanding these criticisms, it must be acknowledged that the eatery boasts an enviable location within a trendy food court, fostering a dynamic ambiance conducive to social gatherings and casual dining.

Well the service was five stars. The bread with the olive paste really good. Ehhhh I think that is where it stops. The calamari was bland and too salty the sauce was spicy and decent. I ordered the pesto gnocchi it was mediocre like chef boyardi with green sauce. My partner had the steak and it just had way too too much pepper and the Alfredo sauce for the pasta well let's just say it made Olive Garden look like Ruth Chris steakhouse. The dessert was good. So dessert and bread yes, but food heck no. The portions were also very large just wished I likes my food.

Went there yesterday to observe a postseason game with other Yelpers.  As far as observing televisions went, there wasn't a poor vantage point in the entire establishment.  For those that detest smoke, there exists a non-smoking entrance in the rear of the edifice which leads to the bar side; however, if one desires to engage in recreational activities such as playing billiards or utilizing the Men's restroom, one must still traverse the smoking patio.  Speaking of the Men's restroom, I have witnessed inferior maintenance practices, but this particular lavatory could benefit from a thorough cleaning, as my feet adhered to the floor adjacent to the urinal. 

They possessed an ample assortment of superior quality draught beers.  I intended to consume a hamburger, but the plethora of delectable alternatives arriving at our table diverted my attention away from the initial objective.  The nachos were adequate.  I typically refrain from consuming hot wings due to their fiery temperature; however, these particular specimens were grilled, leaving a subtle aftertaste and were surprisingly palatable.  In addition, I devoured an onion ring, a potato skin, and a cheese stick.  Satisfactory bar cuisine without being extraordinary.  Service vacillated between proficient and indifferent, occasionally disappearing without a trace.  They were out of various items such as iced tea, certain types of brownies, and select beverages.  As a collective, we purchased sufficient libations where those who opted to combine their beverages with water were not subjected to scrutiny. 

In conclusion, a respectable neighborhood tavern.

"Adequate,

Pizza delivered to my lodging establishment.  Verify.
Opened up the box and the circular flatbread appeared delectable. Check.
Pizza contained ingredients as requested. Check.
Pizza cut in squares, reminiscent of a traditional Chicago-style pie. Check
Pizza cut all the way through the dough. EPIC FAIL.

My goodness me.  When you grasp a portion (Chizona's cuts the pie in squares) you aspire to lift a segment with all of the additives situated on top of the slice.  Three of us (two who had never encountered a Chicago-style thin crust) and not a single slice was cut completely through.  In a hotel room, devoid of utensils, we attempted our utmost to maintain the additives on top of each slice, but pulling apart slices that were not cut generated a regrettable disarray.  We concluded with numerous hand-pulled unoccupied slices and endeavored our best to position the additives on each slice.  We relinquished the effort.

If you are unable to cut a pie, which is so fundamental to Pizza 101, then you generate a subpar encounter for your clientele.  

3 stars for the fresh ingredients, excellent sauce, and the proprietor adding some Giardiniera (extremely fresh and flavorful). Subtract 2 stars for the chaos produced by the pizza not being cut entirely through.

I harbored significantly higher expectations."

"My recent visit to this establishment served as a stark reminder of the transient nature of culinary experiences, as my expectations, cultivated by a previous visit several years prior, were drastically diminished by a subpar dining experience. The ambiance, while undeniably opulent, failed to compensate for the underwhelming array of dishes presented at the buffet, which, regrettably, did not live up to its promised extensiveness. Moreover, the prolonged waiting period, amounting to a full hour on a Sunday evening, only exacerbated my disappointment. In conclusion, I would advise potential patrons to exercise caution in their expectations, as the experience, though ostensibly luxurious, does not necessarily warrant the lengthy queue."

"The culinary conundrum my spouse and I frequently encounter while on holiday is exemplified by our experience at Lemongrass, where we encountered a considerable delay for no apparent reason, coupled with uninspired Thai cuisine that failed to impress. Our repast consisted of deep-fried spring rolls that lacked any semblance of flavor and were unpleasantly soggy, accompanied by a pho that was overpowered by an excess of cinnamon, and a stir-fry of rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onions, bean sprouts, bell peppers, eggs, and curry powder that, while quite piquant, did not compensate for the shortcomings of the previous dishes. The subpar fare and sluggish service we experienced at Lemongrass led us to conclude that it would be judicious to explore alternative dining options."

"I am taken aback by the dearth of reviews pertaining to Betty Lou, given our thoroughly enjoyable experience aboard the Monona brunch cruise. While the overall experience was indeed pleasant, there are several areas in which improvements could be made. Specifically, the value proposition relative to the cost, the limited selection of seating options on the vessel, and the sporadic availability of crew members and service staff are aspects that warrant attention. On the other hand, the gastronomical offerings were undoubtedly impressive, with both the quantity and quality of the fare receiving high marks. The ambiance of the boat and the surrounding environment contributed to an overall agreeable experience. However, upon embarkation, we encountered an unexpected and unfortunate situation involving a group of boisterous youths who managed to secure prime seating at the expense of those who had arrived earlier. To avoid such confusion, it would be wise for management to implement a more structured approach to boarding, such as calling groups in the order in which they were reserved. The culinary offerings were truly exceptional, with each course expertly presented and paced throughout the meal. Unfortunately, the mimosas, while flavorful, lacked potency, and attempts to procure additional drinks proved challenging due to the scarcity of bartenders and servers attending to the sizable crowd. Furthermore, our table was not released for the initial round of food, adding to the confusion. Despite these issues, the panoramic views afforded by the boat's route were undeniably breathtaking, and the captain's obliging gesture of executing a photo-op spin at the conclusion of the voyage was greatly appreciated."

As much as I thoroughly enjoy this establishment, I must admit that I am somewhat disillusioned by the fact that I am only twenty years old and yet, I find myself frequenting a venue that appears to cater to an older demographic. Notwithstanding, I possess an ardent affection for the musical genres showcased here, and I would venture to say that my knowledge of said genres is relatively extensive. However, I find myself perplexed by the paradoxical nature of my presence in this setting, unable to discern whether my youthful inclination towards authentic music is an anomaly or if, conversely, it is symptomatic of a broader generational trend.  

My most recent visit to this esteemed establishment occurred on a Friday evening, a night when the talented ensemble known as Baddness takes center stage. Their repertoire, comprised of selections from Earth, Wind & Fire, The Gap Band, Maze, et al., was an eclectic mix of funk and soul, devoid of any blues influences. My admiration for this group was further amplified by their sartorial splendor, as each member donned vibrant red attire, culminating in a resplendent, sequined coat adorning the lead vocalist. Such an aesthetic, reminiscent of the retro flair often associated with the films of Jim Jarmusch, such as Mystery Train, left me utterly captivated. In terms of both musical prowess and stylistic panache, I would unhesitatingly confer upon Baddness a grade of A+.  

While I cannot deny the allure of this venue, I must concede that its designation as a blues house is somewhat dubious. In contrast, the Rhythm Room, with its reputation as a legitimate platform for touring artists, aligns more closely with my tastes. The ambiance of this particular establishment, however, strikes me as more akin to a dive bar or lounge, catering to aficionados of the genre. Despite my eagerness to return, I feel compelled to postpone future visits until a later time, allowing me to mature and better align with the demographic that populates this environs.

I must confess that my experience at this establishment was merely average, and I must attribute this to my own lack of sophistication in regards to genuine Asian cuisine, as my brother and I both failed to consume the entirety of our meals, perhaps due to a lack of hunger. However, I must acknowledge that the proprietor of this establishment exhibited an extraordinary level of hospitality, bordering on the absurd, which was quite perplexing, yet simultaneously endearing. Furthermore, he presented us with a pictorial menu, which was considerate given our unfamiliarity with the culinary offerings. Despite these positive aspects, I would not necessarily recommend this restaurant, unless one happens to be in close proximity and accompanied by a fellow patron who expresses a desire to dine there.

Whenever I past by this restaurant, it always give me this homey feeling to it and thought to myself that one day I'll make some time to go. And I did. When I went there, I was promptly seated planned to be unbiased throughout the whole meal. Service was good.. Unfortunately, their food was just mediocre for the price I've paid. The menu is what I call, \"tourist price\". (Over priced) Tofu Hut serve similar things there for a less expensive price. If their food was as good as the place looks, I would've give them another star but eh, food was alright.
The food is tasty, but so much MSG!  I'm usually not very sensitive to MSG, but man you can really feel it after you eat here!

"Why the hell does everyone have stuffed animals?! Apparently, they gift you a stuffed animal post placing your order, so when you're seated, they know which table to deliver the cuisine to. I thought it was a pleasant gesture, so I said, 'No thanks' to the filthy stuffed animal. Then I pondered why the food never arrived. Chuy's reminds me of the surf n' turf taco shops by the beach. I enjoy the meat and seafood options and, in particular, the aroma of grilled cuisine, but the flavor could benefit from significantly more spice. The menu was extensive and provided a multitude of options. Too many to catalog, and I believe they even offer fried chicken? Strange. 

I ordered the Broiled Whitefish Taco Platter ($6) with a side of Shrimp Skewers ($4). The shrimp skewer was superb; I sprinkled some lemon juice on it, along with some hot sauce, and that alone was a superior meal to my taco platter. The fish did not taste 'fresh," and I am still uncertain about what whitefish is. The rice and beans were average. The cabbage salad required assistance. It consisted of chopped cabbage with a vinaigrette. 

I was not impressed by Chuy's, but I could return there. It's a secure alternative; perhaps next time, I should sample their $2 margaritas, which they serve all day, every day. Now that's a thought!"

Amidst my utter disbelief at having neglected to evaluate this establishment, I must confess that my recent visit on July 3rd, during an unseasonably sweltering mid-day, proved to be a rather underwhelming experience. Despite the allure of Serendipity's al fresco dining area, the oppressive heat rendered it uninhabitable, leading to a regrettable twenty-to-twenty-five minute wait to be seated. Upon being escorted to our table, I opted to sample their renowned "Strip Steak Sandwich," only to discover that the portion size, while generous, did not quite meet my expectations regarding the quality of the cut of meat. Notwithstanding this minor shortcoming, the culinary offerings generally met my approval, save for a perceived slight overpricing.

Unfortunately, the unfavorable meteorological conditions coupled with my satiation precluded me from indulging in their delectable desserts and enjoying the outdoor seating. However, I did return the following day, opting to avail myself of their convenient walk-up, to-go window, whereupon I sampled both the traditional frozen hot chocolate and its Oreo-infused counterpart. While neither variant disappointed, the latter boasted a richer, more complex flavor profile, which I found vastly superior. Moreover, I noticed that the portion sizes of these drinks seemed smaller than those served within the restaurant proper, a phenomenon I could not readily explain. In conclusion, I shall endeavor to patronize Serendipity's New York location in the near future, thereby enabling me to compare and contrast the two establishments.

Underwear for $1 and bras for $10?!?! Yes, please!*














*Disclaimer: Only in the sale section, and only if you can locate your correct size.

They proffer the unpretentious "street" style tacos that I relish. My culinary exploits encompassed one al pastor and one asada, both of which were scrumptious. Notably, the former boasted an agreeable piquancy. Alas, my gustatory excursion was not without its drawbacks, as the green tamale I sampled was quite unsatisfactory. The dearth of verdant chile and cheese within the masa rendered it rather insipid. Regrettably, my quest for a delectable tamale has yet to be fulfilled in this vicinity. Furthermore, my beverage of choice, jamaica, was disappointingly diluted and tart, prompting me to ponder whether I should have opted for the horchata I initially coveted instead. In essence, the eatery's redeeming quality lies in its tacos; thus, it is advisable to restrict one's order to these delectable morsels and forgo any additional items.

Please note that the output may contain some minor variations in wording or punctuation compared to the original text, but the overall meaning and content should remain the same. Also, please ensure that the modified text does not exceed 512 tokens.

I go to Vegas a couple times a year  and I stay at different casinos .  This last time in September I stayed at the Excalibur.  We have stayed here before.  We always enjoy this casino, the rooms are clean and comfortable and the price is reasonable.  This last time we left a tip for the maid who was cleaning our room. She left us a thank you note, which I thought was very thoughtful of her.  It is the first time anyone has written us a thank you note for a tip. Her name was Clementine and she did a wonderful job.

"This particular Costco establishment does not rank among the most exceptional I have had the privilege of visiting. Several aspects of the experience leave room for improvement, in my opinion. Firstly, the parking situation can become quite congested, although this is a common issue among Costcos and, therefore, tolerable. My primary concerns revolve around the sampling services. Specifically, the pace of distribution is sluggish, leading to frequent depletion of samples, followed by an inefficient replenishment process. This results in a prolonged waiting period, which can be frustrating, especially given the significance I attach to sampling as an integral aspect of my Costco excursions. In fact, I have visited other Costco locations where the sampling process operates with greater efficiency, characterized by a steady supply of offerings and a more seamless experience.  

Another drawback of this Costco lies in its car wash facilities. While the exterior cleaning function performs admirably, the interior remains unattended, lacking essential vacuuming amenities. Notably, this absence of vacuum services distinguishes this car wash from others that typically provide such features.  

Despite these shortcomings, I still derive pleasure from procuring beverages, such as beer and wine, at this Costco. Their extensive selection of alcoholic beverages, including sizable vodka bottles, holds appeal for me. Additionally, I recently became aware of their discounted restaurant cards, which offer welcome savings.  

In summary, while this Costco presents some limitations, I shall persist in visiting, albeit with a slight scowl during the prolonged sample intervals."

Three stars for taste and unique style pizza. But for a quick lunch, fogettabout it. Slow......Come on guys, your customer base in the industrial area have to be in and out in 20 minutes to get back to work. Here is a clue....SLICES! And while you are at it, a \"slice and a drink\" lunch special  please. Most pizza joints have this, right? I would enjoy your great pizza more often, if in a reasonably time and price......

We happened upon this culinary establishment by sheer serendipity and opted to partake in a tardy midday repast. Our order consisted of the delectable hummus and crispy potato slices, accompanied by an assortment of golden onion rings and crispy fries. Upon consuming these delights, we found that they were skillfully prepared and offered an explosion of flavors on our taste buds. However, our dining experience was slightly marred by the lackadaisical attitude displayed by the servers, as their attentiveness waned noticeably as the patronage dwindled, leaving us waiting interminably for even the most basic acknowledgment or assistance. Despite my concerted efforts to capture someone's attention, it became apparent that they had adopted a deliberate policy of avoidance or feigned obliviousness.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, accompanied by a group of acquaintances, and opted to sample their evening fare, despite having previously indulged in their midday offerings. I elected to share the 'Big Boy Platter' with my significant other, which showcased an assortment of barbecued delights. While the poultry component of the platter was somewhat lacking in moisture, the remaining items, specifically the pulled pork, exhibited satisfactory tenderness. The ambiance of the venue, though slightly outdated, maintained a welcoming and casual atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the hospitable demeanor of the staff. Notwithstanding, it is crucial to acknowledge that numerous exceptional barbecue establishments exist within the city, making it effortless to overlook this particular locale. Ultimately, my experience at this eatery did not particularly distinguish itself from others of its ilk."

On the weird chance that someday I'd get to meet the inventor of the soft serve ice-cream machine, this is how our conversation would go;

"So..how did the idea of a soft serve machine come to you?"

"Well, I was taking my dog Toots for a walk one day when all of a sudden, he decides to shit all over Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.
I was horrified. 
Ed's an attorney and he warned me about Toots shitting on his front lawn one more time...how he'd come after us both.
He did. 
There Toots is, happily shitting away...a huge creamy brown dump slowly oozing its way out , when Ed comes flying out of the house with a broom.
Toots freaks, and hauls ass without even pinching it off. 
And that was my inspiration.
I thought, if I ever invented an ice-cream machine, I'd want it to cleanly pinch-off, unlike Toots who left a dashed trail across Ed and Dolores's lawn.
So I guess we can thank Toots for the idea."

Many thanks Toots.
I used to love frozen yogurt...when someone else was serving it up.
Now that I have to serve it up,  all I can think about is how this machine was designed by some lunatic who managed to create a replica of his dog, shitting on Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.

I would unlikely revisit Galaxy if I still resided in Las Vegas, given the peculiar behavior of the employees regarding customer service. During my two visits within a week's span, the staff demonstrated a lack of coordination and synchronization in their work, leading me to conclude that a return visit would not be worthwhile. 
  While the breakfast sandwiches are satisfactory, their prices are somewhat steep considering the quality of ingredients utilized. However, I must acknowledge that the sustenance provided was adequate for my journey to Los Angeles, thus rendering my complaints somewhat moot. 
  The coffee offerings at Galaxy are unremarkable, yet they do possess a unique aspect in the form of almond syrup, a flavor enhancer that I find challenging to procure. Consequently, I shall grant them additional credit for this particular feature. 
  Although the ambiance is rendered fascinating by the incorporation of Star Wars and other niche-themed embellishments, I cannot overlook the deficiency in staff training and overall efficiency, thereby making it improbable for me to actively seek out such an establishment.

Stopped in for lunch.  They have nice specials which include: Miso soup, salad and sashimi with rice.  Staff is very friendly.  Here's the thing: Miso was great. Salad was wilted and with bell peppers?  Never had Asian salad with Bell peppers..chilis yes, but bell peppers? Yuck.  The rice did not come out with my meal.  I had 4 people come over all confused about who was doing what. They had the right heart, but..service was disorganized, but friendly.  When asked if everything was okay..I made the statement about the salad..it was old and wilted and... I wasn't offered a replacement.  When the rice finally got to me it was a HUGH softball size and so dry and nasty and tasteless that  I didn't eat it.  The Tuna sashimi though...was EXCELLENT,  the wasabi was powerful and they serve white ginger, but it was dry.  So...they need improvement--period. It was a $12 lunch plus tip.

We order our food from their carside service.  We found the food to be great, but patience trying to get your food from the carside pickup!!  (over 15 minutes past the time promised and ignored until the manager brought it out!!)

"The eatery in question has been rebranded as 'Las Americas', offering an authentic Colombian culinary experience, albeit unremarkable in its overall presentation, despite the pleasant demeanor of its staff."

You know what I like best about this place?

I love going to places where I am the youngest customer by a considerable margin.

And I'm old enough to have spent the first half of my years so far using phones that were attached to walls and stuff. You know, the ones where you had to turn this twisty thing to make a call and you didn't know who was calling you before you answered?

Anyway, the older generation seems to like good deals on veggies and other produce, because they usually have them here. Sometimes you can get in and out without being overcome by the feeling that the zombie apocalypse is upon us, and they are all on walkers.

In more-or-less typical Basha's practice, some of the items are weirdly overpriced. Stick with the loss-leaders and you might make out ok.

Oh, and also: The parking spaces are nice and wide. Wide enough to fully swing open the door of your Buick Park Avenue.

This place was pretty good! My husband and I got a take out order and were very happy with it. That was probably one of the best chili rellenos I've had. I was disappointed with the veggie salad, however, as it was mostly just lettuce. The black beans were pretty spicy and salty, so plan on having something to mix them with like rice or an extra tortilla. I probably wouldn't dine in if I could help it, the dining room isn't very comfy, (free wifi while you wait for your order is nice, though) but I will definitely be getting more take out! \n\nOh, and: a snickerdoodle with every order! A good one, too!

Never knew how big the place was. Seems like an awesome place for sporting events. I didn't get any drinks, but the specials appear good. It was freaking dead in there, but I want to try and go on a busy night for further review.

Looking around town for Jin's chicken and fish which wasn't in its normal Francis location we found this spot. Fulfilling after bar chicken/fish sandwiches. Would never go here for a meal but it's a perfect after bar spot. I got a chicken sandwich which was basically two chicken fingers drenched in Franks Red Hot, mayo, tiny lettuce piece on a thin hamburger bun. Did the trick for what I wanted.

"A selection of relatively healthy options are available on the menu, with breakfast items being served until 10:30 am, which would be vastly improved if offered throughout the day, as I unfortunately arrived at 11 am. I opted for the grilled chicken beer bread, a dish comprising a grilled chicken fillet enveloped within a wrap, accompanied by a side of either fries or salad. Naturally, I chose the fries, yearning for a fish and chip dish, yet attempting to exercise restraint. Unfortunately, this proved to be an error, as the chicken was heavily processed and smothered in melted cheese, which I carefully removed and set aside, as it was far more beneficial to discard it than to consume it. Despite these drawbacks, I endeavored to savor the meal by extracting the palatable components. However, due to the wrap's fragmented state, it was impossible to lift it and consume it neatly, and its texture was too soggy to slice. Furthermore, upon surveying my surroundings, I observed the peculiar combination of a dance music soundtrack, which seemed incongruous and added to the overall feeling of unease. In the event that I were compelled to return, I would likely opt for the fish and chips or a burger."

The ground chicken was the best thing I tried at this restaurant. There was plenty of delicious flavors with each bite. Unfortunately, the boneless chunks of chicken that came with the chicken soltani ($17.99) weren't nearly as good. The beef kabob ($16.99) looked better than it tasted due to a lack of seasoning and its course texture. 

On the plus side, both entrees came with some amazingly fluffy and delicious Basmati rice. Portion sizes were huge, with each entree big enough for two people. At the moderately high prices they charge, it would have been best for us to split one of them. 

The hummus was decent and the yogurt and cucumber dip was too heavy on the dill.

It's a sit-down restaurant with a large open interior with two lit up trees stationed in the center.  If you want a more casual spot to eat (meaning cheaper) you're probably better off elsewhere.

I can't believe I forgot to write a review for Ceres. I remember every single detail the day I went here for brunch with a group of Yelpers. It was life-changing! From who I sat with, me ending up paying for 2 people, the food, the music...everything. It really helps not getting drunk for brunch!

Located inside JW Marriott, the parking situation was a bit of a mess. Some jerk almost ran me over...that was my first memory of him. From that moment on I just knew...

Buffet-style brunch was good. There was a waffle station and an omelet station. I stood a long time waiting for my omelet since they gave mine to some old grumpy lady. They have the usual breakfast fare: eggs, hashbrowns, sausages, bacon, Danishes, bread, potatoes, etc. So, for $20+ brunch x 2...this place was just ok.

Ok. 

So this place is NEVER busy! and its open real late.
So already I like it because its open late, however the food well the food is alright.

The meat that they use have too much fat, especially the slices of beef, however for the price its a good deal.

The service is pretty good, and they pay attention to you, mostly because its never busy, or at least its never been busy when I go there, which is quite late most of the time..

So if its late, everything is closed, use this as a plan B most definitely. However it is a good plan B

"It was a cursory visit, to say the least, as I opted to partake in a brief excursion to the nearby Chipotle establishment, which was conveniently positioned within close proximity to my location. My infrequent patronage of this particular fast-food chain was, in fact, the impetus behind my decision to indulge in their culinary offerings on this particular occasion. Furthermore, the dearth of clientele within the premises at the time of my visit served as an added incentive, as I was able to enjoy a tranquil dining experience unencumbered by the presence of throngs of people. The staff members, cognizant of my limited auditory abilities, graciously accommodated my request for repetition when placing my order, thereby ensuring that I comprehended the details of my meal without any confusion. The gastronomical delight that ensued was indeed satisfying, particularly the warm burrito that provided a welcome respite from the inclement weather conditions outside. Suffice it to say, I shall not hesitate to revisit this establishment in the future, albeit with a preference for a less piquant sauce, as the existing quantity proved to be somewhat overwhelming for my taste buds."

I have been here quite a while. Had the best experience all these time untill the last two.. i have always came here during  the day which i may say it was awesome  the staff kept up with everything(food, drinks, refill) always checking  in on us. Each time  we always  hit the  bar after words. Till i went during  the evening place was pack and had a group  of 9. -.- lets start  by saying the server  didn't  show up to often. We all order food at once  so we wouldn't confuse  him. He had a smile  on his face but knew something  was wrong. Only 3 plates  showed  up when good came and when wr ask him where the rest was he replied  by saying he forgot. An average  drink took about 15 min.  And we had to hunt our server down for our  tab. At the end we still think its a awesome  place but will not go at night, it sucks.!
