I will start out with the good - The food.  I had a burger and tots and they were great. I tried my boyfriends catfish Po'boy and it was amazing. The mac and cheese is very good. Onion rings were just okay.

We went to watch the Pather's game and they turned the sound on. It wasnt very packed and the service was pretty good. 

The bad part - there beer selection needs some help. They only have a few taps but where are all the great local beers?

Also, a palmeto bug kept flying around us while we were eating. Hard to prevent but still not very fun.

"The accommodations themselves were diminutive in stature, with minuscule bathing facilities that exuded an antiquated ambiance. However, the notion that one's financial expenditure directly correlates with the quality of lodgings was not entirely applicable in this case, as the rooms were meticulously maintained and presented a modernized, albeit somewhat retro, aesthetic. The temperature of the shower fluctuated between extreme cold and intense heat, which may be attributed to the aged infrastructure of the establishment. Furthermore, a $20 resort fee was charged for internet access that proved unreliable, raising questions regarding the necessity of such a fee, particularly in light of the absence of any pool or other amenities typically associated with the term'resort.' Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the value offered by the hotel remained reasonable considering its affordability. Incidentally, the Fremont Street Experience, a popular entertainment district, was situated immediately outside the room, which may have been perceived as a hindrance for those seeking a more tranquil environment, but would unlikely pose a concern for individuals who intended to engage in nocturnal revelry."

Good food, laid back, good beer choices... great place if you're looking for a sit back place to enjoy time with friends or family and want good food but don't need stellar foodie meal. The mix match 6 - pack of beer is good deal if you want something to go and keeps you from making that extra trip to liquor store. Only negative we've had here is the service can be slow. It seems they assign tables in rotation order instead of zones so wait staff is all over the place and can't attend to tables as quickly.

"Upon partaking in a culinary excursion at this establishment, our gastronomical experience was generally satisfactory, with the exception of a few financial discrepancies. Specifically, upon perusing the menu, we noticed that the cost of certain beverages was inconsistent with the prices advertised on the chalkboard exterior to the restaurant. Furthermore, upon querying our server regarding this disparity, he appeared perplexed by our inquiry, leading us to hastily settle the bill to avoid any further inconvenience. However, we cannot help but feel that an injustice was done, particularly in light of the fact that we were overcharged by twelve dollars for the Bloody Mary's consumed by our party. Therefore, we shall remain vigilant in our pursuit of a resolution to this matter, lest we be compelled to reconsider our patronage of this establishment in the future."

"My previous reluctance to visit this establishment has been alleviated by the revelation that they have revamped their menu to incorporate exceptional organic ciabatta rolls and have eliminated high fructose corn syrup from all items. Furthermore, they have taken the initiative to eradicate trans fat from every dish, a pioneering move in the culinary industry. The Royal with light mustard is particularly delectable, and I often opt to substitute the meat with turkey or ham if the toppings align with my preferences. Notably, the quality of the food has significantly improved, prompting me to frequent the restaurant more often. Additionally, I came across a review mentioning that customers can receive soft-serve ice cream with any meal, an enticing perk that I was previously unaware of. While I would enthusiastically award them an additional star, I must refrain from doing so due to the presence of a slender lesbian employee, although I jest about that fact."

After partaking of the delectable ice cream cookie sandwich from the adjacent establishment, I surmised that a supplementary indulgence would be requisite to satiate my craving for something sweet and tart; thus, I opted for a 'like it', an icy confection with a subtle sweetness and a hint of tartness, though regrettably, it fell short of my expectations, as it lacked the distinctive flavor profile of the genuine article. Nonetheless, the hospitality exhibited by the staff within these premises was truly commendable, as three affable and obliging gentlemen, exuding an unwavering enthusiasm to assist, attended to my needs with alacrity, providing a refreshing contrast to the customary diffidence displayed by their contemporaries stationed behind the counter. Undoubtedly, the prospect of returning to this establishment holds considerable allure for me.

We have had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on a solitary occasion, and we must say that the poultry appendages and fried potatoes were quite delectable.
The menu boasts an array of delectable items such as subs (including options with fried fish, Philly or chicken cheesesteaks, accompanied by either cold or hot vegetables...), wraps, burger platters, fish plates, chicken plates, and an assortment of other culinary delights.
Upon discovering this eatery, we experienced a profound sense of satisfaction, as it brought to mind memories of similar carry-out establishments from our past. Having resided in the Charlotte area for a period of seven years, this marks the initial instance in which we have encountered a venue of this nature.
Due to its location in a relatively small corner, we advise patrons to maintain a vigilant gaze while seeking out this hidden gem.

"I recently arrived at this establishment for the purpose of undergoing a smog inspection, which typically carries a cost of $19.95; however, due to my possession of a special promotional mailing, I was able to avail myself of a reduced rate of $14.95, a savings of $5 that I found quite satisfactory given the straightforward nature of the service provided, which involved a brief and efficient process of inspection and maintenance that did not necessitate an extensive period of time or excessive monetary expenditure, thereby rendering the overall experience relatively unremarkable, yet pleasingly convenient and economical in comparison to other establishments offering comparable services, such as Jiffy Smog."

This venue was teeming with an abundance of patrons during my visit, rendering the dance floor minuscule in comparison to the vast multitude of individuals seeking to partake in the festivities. It appeared that every conceivable location within the establishment had been designated for the purpose of accommodating bottle service, thereby creating a predicament for those who did not possess the privilege of such provisions. Fortunately, I possessed certain inherent attributes which enabled me to successfully manipulate the circumstances in my favor, thereby securing both a Grey Goose cranberry and a seat. However, I could not help but sympathize with the male contingent, who were not as fortunate in their endeavors to gain entry. Notwithstanding the aforementioned obstacles, I chose to award two additional stars in light of the fact that our queue was of considerable length, yet we managed to bypass the majority of it and gain admittance to the club with relative ease.

"Expeditious'strip-mall' Chinese cuisine, conforming to preconceived notions. Ideal for a hasty, post-work acquisition of a convenient family takeout meal, yet, temper expectations regarding gastronomic refinement. Recently sampled the beef with broccoli, kung pao chicken, and sweet and sour chicken, all fabricated from discerning diner-friendly components and appreciated by younger palates. Noteworthily, staff members are of Chinese descent, and a few words uttered in Mandarin by patrons elicit a positive response. In conclusion, while unremarkable, a reasonable value for a mid-week home-cooked meal."

"The establishment boasts an impressive grilling station, proffering an array of delectable cuts of meat, specifically catering to those with an unrelenting hankering for juicy steaks. Their offerings include the quintessential ham and roast beef varieties, which, in conjunction with the reasonable tariff and the boundless appetites of my adolescent progeny, rendered the dining experience decidedly satisfactory."

Decided not to come back because last time I was very disappointed with the super expensive honey toast ( cant remember the name all I know is $12.99) and it wasn't that good but had to come back because we couldnt find anywhere else to play card. At least this place has a better service than tea station tho. Overall is not that bad just a little bit pricey.

The culinary offerings were of an exceptionally high quality, boasting an unparalleled freshness and authenticity that was undoubtedly palpable; however, the prices were exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous, which made it challenging for this patron to justify the cost, despite the proprietor's amicable demeanor and the hospitable nature of the young woman manning the counter, thus rendering the prospect of a future visit uncertain, contingent upon a reevaluation of the menu items' pricing, particularly when considering the supplementary charges for beverages and desserts, which tended to inflate the total cost beyond what could be deemed reasonable or appropriate.

Smart and stylish, The West Room has an enticing cocktail menu, but I'm not sure the food was good enough to merit a repeat visit.\n\nOverall, we said: \"the West Room is smart and appealing, but I'm not convinced it's all it could be or wants to be. Their menu doesn't quite compel you towards the dishes it wants to serve you, so could use a little trimming to focus it better. It likes to market itself as the west end's \"hidden gem\". Certainly, if you stumble upon it on your travels, I think you'll be impressed, but impressed enough for regular repeat visits? I'm not so sure of that, as things stand.

My family from Korea came to visit and on our trip to Vegas, they were desperately craving something familiar.  My plan was to take them to Grand Lux but on the way, my grandma began looking pale.  So, we saw signs for this restaurant and detoured over to Imperial Palace.  Up the elevator we went to the deserted 5th floor dining plaza where we were welcomed by a familiar Korean greeting.  My grandma smiled and immediately announced that she felt better already.  

Their menu included Korean, Japanese, and Chinese dishes but we opted for solely Korean.  We had the duk mandoo gook (rice cake dumpling soup), dolsot bibimbap (mixture of rice, veggies, fried egg served in a hot stone bowl/pot), soft tofu soup, and bulgogi (marinated meat).  Everything was just whatever but watching my grandma grasp her bowl of rice with both hands and eat like her life depended on it made the meal more enjoyable.  

Pretty expensive for mediocre Korean food in Vegas (like $90 total plus tax and tip .. just for lunch!) but the staff was accommodating and friendly.  

I personally wouldn't come back but I appreciated the service and convenience.

We stumbled in off the plane and had a tasty lunch. For 2 people - calamari a la plancha, xato salad, scallops in romesco sauce, white ceviche and raspberry tuna skewers - it was all good and beautifully presented. No drinks. $80 for a light lunch felt a bit steep.

I went to CUT w/ some friends.  The portion is great (considering the $ I am paying =)  ).  I love their bread sticks.  I was kind of disappointed because the steak was a bit blackened and overcooked.  Taste was okay.  For the price given, the food was more on the average, there were many staff compared to the # of guests, which is good.  I am not sure if it's me or what, it seemed to me the staff's services were a bit "fake" and not too friendly.

Maybe people like the lighting?  but to me it was a bit too dark.  You can barely see the food.  

I might try it a gain if given the chance.

We only ever get the Louisiana Chicken pasta or cheesecake any more.  I think the menu is so big that it is hard for them to have any specialties (other than cheesecake).  The last 5 dishes I've had have been nothing special at all, and one I even sent back because it was so bad (and I NEVER do that).

My boyfriend and I just had dinner here. I have to say, I'm very underwhelmed by the food here. I was pretty stoked to get a tastey but simple sandwich and fresh made soup. Regretfully, I had the grilled cheese and it was quite lacking in flavor. The red pepper lobster bisque, though a tad \"clumpy\" was quite tasty. I will give Cafe Zupas another shot, but I'm hoping my next choice in sandwich will turn it around for me.

Maybe I was just super hyper up and expected way too much but the Blue Man Group wasn't all that.  Don't get me wrong, there were some really cool parts but there were also some boring parts.  I wanted to fall asleep a couple of times.  My husband's review would be even more critical.  He thought almost the whole show was boring.  For the price of the tickets, I don't think it's worth it.  Maybe if the tickets were $20-30 cheaper, it would be a better bang for your buck.  Some parts were very funny, some parts were neat, and some parts were just like okay-can-this-be-over-already.  Overall, it just gets three stars from me.

I really like this place.  The food, drinks, and wine are always delicious.  The service is great,  but I can't get over how loud they play the live music on Friday and Saturday nights.  The music itself is fun and provides a great feeling, but don't plan on being able to have a conversation if you're in the main room while they pump it in on a speaker.

"I was seeking an activity suitable for engaging with my in-laws, and this particular attraction appeared to align with their interests. However, upon further inspection, it became apparent that it was a quintessential tourist trap, replete with an array of commercialized souvenirs and services that came at an additional cost. Despite the overtly exploitative nature of the establishment, I must admit that the experience was moderately enjoyable, as I had the opportunity to capture some remarkable photographs and gain insight into the local lore. Nonetheless, I do not envision revisiting this destination in the future, as a single visit proved sufficient to satiate my curiosity."

There's so much else to see and do in Vegas that I wouldn't bother spending my time here unless its absolutely freezing cold or scorching hot outside and you're just looking to spend some time indoors and not have to hop from hotel to hotel. It is a pretty nice mall though with one of the bigger indoor food courts I've seen anywhere.\n\nIf you've got lots of money to spend, then this is a good spot to go shopping. Otherwise I'd check out one of the various outlet malls in the area around Vegas where you'll find much better deals on stuff.
Went here with some friends and was not familiar with the menu.  The order counter seemed confusing to me too. Got a turkey sandwich,  but think they used miracle whip not mayo.  Not a fan though.

I saw these reviews and decided to try this place. The Pellini is an Italian burrito. You get to pick you meat (chicken, steak, italian sausage, shrimp), sauces (tomato and white), and topping (cheese, veggies). There are lots of choices so you can really have fun and personalize it. 
I had the chicken and Italian sausage and I thought that it was ok. Not great. I didn't think it had a lot a taste but maybe it how I put the Pellini together. 
My wife had the chicken and shrimp and the shrimp really brought out the taste. Her Pellini tasted really good.
The decor was up to date and clean. It thought the the service was pretty good. They were very helpful and friendly. 
Not to sure if I will return but my wife enjoyed it, so we'll see.

"Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar offers an extraordinary experience, garnering an overall rating of 3.75. Patrons can revel in the exceptional musical prowess of the pianists, who possess an unparalleled repertoire of songs spanning diverse genres, including classic rock and heavy metal. The ambiance is characterized by a vibrant and lively atmosphere, fostering an environment conducive to socializing, dancing, and merriment. Entrance is complimentary, negating the need for an admission fee or minimum drink purchase, thereby allowing patrons to enjoy the entertainment stress-free. While the audience primarily consists of individuals aged 40 and above, the venue's unique concept and appeal have the potential to captivate a broader demographic. By offering a system of song requests accompanied by tips, patrons can actively engage with the performers and enhance their experience. Embrace the joy of dueling pianos and create unforgettable memories at Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar."

I was here for lunch a few days ago.  Nice ambiance - and cosy and warm inside while it blew a storm outside.  I had good service, but wasn't overwhelmed by the food.  An halloumi sandwich with ciabatta and salad.   I enjoyed the salad, and the halloumi, but frankly the ciabatta didn't do it for me - and didn't bring out the best in the halloumi (even with the chilli jelly).   For dessert I had carrot cake - which was rather dry.  Much better carrot cake to be had in town.\n\nI'll be back though - apparently they do a good eggs benedict.

I like this place because it's cheap.

The food isn't outstanding, but it's tasty enough.

We go fairly regularly because it's easy.

I'd recommend it.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of Spinato's on three separate occasions, with two instances involving takeout and one wherein I indulged in the dining room experience. Upon reflection, I have formulated three distinct musings regarding my experiences at this establishment:  

Firstly, the pizza served at Spinato's is undoubtedly of satisfactory quality, boasting flavors and textures that are bound to satiate even the most discerning of palates.  

Secondly, it is my opinion that the pricing of said pizza is somewhat elevated, perhaps to an extent that may deter potential patrons who are seeking a more affordable dining option.  

Lastly, and unfortunately, the service I received during my visits was subpar, bordering on unacceptable. On one occasion, I was mistakenly served a different pizza than the one I had ordered, and I was forced to wait an additional ten minutes before receiving my correct order. Moreover, no discount or compensation was offered for the inconvenience caused. Similarly, during my third visit, I was told that my takeout order would be ready within 30-35 minutes; however, I waited a full 57 minutes before finally receiving my food. When I brought this issue to the attention of the takeout staff, I was met with a dismissive and unapologetic demeanor, further compounding my frustration.  

In light of these experiences, I am inclined to seek alternative dining options, such as Grimaldi's, where I can enjoy high-quality pizza without breaking the bank.

"If you're seeking a nocturnal excursion replete with alcoholic indulgences and a brief respite from the impending bedlam, Caramel presents itself as a viable option. While it may not be an establishment worthy of extensive correspondence, it did elicit a sense of contentment within me, albeit for a singular reason: seating. On our third evening of unbridled revelry, my priorities had been simplified to a considerable degree; specifically, I craved a chair. Upon entering the venue following a convivial dinner and encountering a group of acquaintances, we were promptly accosted by a cocktail server who offered us a table designated for reserved seating. This was a veritable symphony to my auricular senses (as well as my fatigued pedal extremities!). Although the lounge itself was somewhat diminutive in stature, the assemblage comprised an eclectic mix of patrons. The ambiance, while not particularly noteworthy, was supplemented by a satisfactory musical selection and the possibility of sampling artisanal infusions of vodka. However, it is important to note that prolonged stays exceeding thirty minutes are not recommended, as the locale fails to offer sufficient diversions to warrant extended periods of time."
Not my cup of tea. I did not like my tuna entree, despite it being somewhere around $35. \n\nI do enjoy their cocktails, and like to come to the bar for happy hour.

I absolutely LOVE Cirque shows, having seen a couple before (Ovo & Zumanity), so I was really excited when my boyfriend was offered comp tickets for his birthday in Las Vegas. Our seats were perfect, right in the middle about 6 rows up from the stage. I was extremely impressed with the set, as it was beautiful, and the water acts were gorgeous. Unfortunately, I was slightly underwhelmed. I don't know if it was just me, but I found the comedy to be lacking...the clown humour wasn't funny and I actually found it to be pretty boring. I was expecting to see more \"AMAZING\" acrobatics, but aside from the beautiful diving (that takes talent) and a couple other acts (fire dancers, jumpers) I was really unimpressed. I didn't understand the story they were trying to tell, and some of the scenes were downright confusing. What was with the guy holding the 1-800 sign? Not to mention, I felt creeped out by it, like it was a weird acid trip. Those guys in the red coats are what nightmares are made out of. I love Cirque du Soleil and \"O\" was a nice way to spend an evening, but overall I'm glad we didn't pay for the tickets. We found ourselves yawning towards the end and unfortunately, we were glad when it ended. Next time, I will see Ka or Mystere!

"Although it's a rather extravagant Las Vegas interpretation of a traditional public house, this establishment can still provide a satisfactory experience for those seeking a casual drink, despite the fact that the cost of a single pint may be slightly elevated compared to what one might consider reasonable. However, based on my recent visit, I would not wholeheartedly recommend dining here, as the ambiance and quality of service did not entirely align with my expectations, despite the delectability of my initial course, which consisted of thin slices of pork belly atop a rich, egg-based bread, complemented by a sweet maple glaze and crowned with a poached egg. Specifically, while the bartenders were quite affable, the table staff exhibited a subtle yet perceptible air of indifference, and my primary dish, consisting of fish and chips, failed to impress me as much as I had hoped, given the premium pricing. Nonetheless, if you find yourself on the Strip and are in pursuit of a respectable beer, it may still be worth paying a visit to this establishment."

Love me some Famous Dave's catfish! Another unique quality of Famous Dave's are the sauces that are at your dispense on each table. Be sure to try the Georgia Mustard-goes well on just about everything. The reason for the 3 stars is because the most consistent factor here is the careless service.  I recently had a server not only talk to us for over 10 minutes about his name before he took our order,but also had the nerve to solicit help and funds for his charity.  I was appalled that he continued on and that the manager did not put a stop to it.  i think I was more irritated because if he spent as much time on assisting our table as he did talking about himself, our order would not have been screwed up so bad!

Who likes the DMV? Nobody. Then why do I give it a 3 star? For the self-service kiosks, where you can be in and out in less than 10 minutes. It's the best thing they could have done to help keep people moving. Now the only time I dread going is when I have to actually see a human to get done what I need. Visit the website to see what you can get done at the kiosk. And they have kiosks in other businesses (AAA's, grocery stores, etc) around Las Vegas, so check that out.

I thought the food was pretty good. I have done alot of really good Tapas and this was just pretty good. These guys pack it in like sardines and a young good looking crowd it is. Too busy for me on the weekends I would go back but there are many other fish in the sea so it won't be soon.

The service and ambiance were very good. Small and intimate. Tables were a little close together in our section, and the heater was blowing directly underneath our feet, so it got a little uncomfortable as the night went on. Used a living social deal, which made the meal an excellent value. Ordered the escargot appetizer and the french onion soup, which were both delicious. Unfortunately, several appetizer and entree menu items were unavailable, including the frog legs, which I was interested in trying. I ordered the steak and frites (ribeye). The steak just wasn't good. The meat seemed very bland and I had to chew through some very tough and rubbery bits. Even though I  enjoyed the soup and appetizer, I left a bit unsatisfied due to the less than stellar ribeye. I do intent to come back and try something else on the menu in the future.

"Refrain from purchasing the bananas, as they have been subjected to refrigeration, which will cause them to undergo an accelerated ripening process, resulting in an unpleasant browning effect by the end of the day. It is advisable to avoid acquiring bananas from Dole, as their quality is inferior compared to other brands."

"It is my conviction that this location formerly possessed a more optimal state of affairs, characterized by a heightened level of proficiency and effectiveness in addressing the needs of its clientele, as well as a greater abundance of insightful and useful information. Alas, it appears that I have had the misfortune of encountering an unfortunate concatenation of circumstances, resulting in an experience that falls short of my expectations. Notwithstanding this disappointment, I must acknowledge that the prices offered here remain competitive and the selection of goods and services available is indeed impressive. Furthermore, I find myself in need of seating arrangements conducive to leisurely perusal and contemplation."

"Subpar, and the notion of 'bring your own wine' has been rendered overhyped. Opting for the fillet mignon, my expectations were unfulfilled. In juxtaposition to the plethora of exceptional eateries within the historic district, this establishment falls short. Perhaps my carnivorous inclinations preclude me from fully appreciating an adequate steak. The reality is, I can effortlessly prepare a superior cut at home for a fraction of the cost, sans the cacophonous ambiance. This venue may be suitable for a corporate gathering on a weeknight, provided it is not too busy, expensive, or utterly deplorable."

"Although the culinary quality of the establishment's primary menu item, specifically the burger, leaves much to be desired, the supplementary offering of fries, when considered in isolation, does possess a certain je ne sais quoi that elevates it to a level worthy of appreciation and enjoyment. However, it is unfortunate that the overall gastronomical experience at this venue falls short of expectations due to the subpar quality of the aforementioned burger, which, if improved even slightly, would undoubtedly enhance the overall dining experience and potentially increase patronage."

This establishment proved to be merely adequate, prompting me to categorize it as "old timey" in both atmosphere and patronage demographics. My visit transpired during a business luncheon, which appeared to be a popular choice among the mature male populace of Phoenix. It is worth mentioning that the interior design was utterly unremarkable, resembling a dining hall affiliated with a mid-range hotel chain.

As for the culinary offerings, my craving for prime rib led me to select it from the menu. Although the cooking process was accurate in achieving a medium rare consistency, the meat itself was somewhat disappointing in terms of flavor and tenderness. The au jus accompanying the dish was also underwhelming. In contrast, my dining companion opted for the filet, which they reported to be quite satisfactory.

In light of these factors, I cannot in good conscience bestow an overwhelmingly positive review upon Stockyards. Furthermore, the prices charged for the fare provided seemed slightly elevated considering its overall quality. My feelings toward this establishment are largely indifferent, and I believe that life is indeed too brief to indulge in uninspired cuisine.

"My sentiments towards this establishment are somewhat ambivalent, as I have been a patron of their services on multiple occasions, yet have recently encountered certain operational aspects that detract from the overall experience. Specifically, during my most recent visits, I have noticed that the salon has adopted a practice of simultaneously performing gel manicures and pedicures, which I find to be excessively stressful and detrimental to the otherwise therapeutic nature of the treatment. While I acknowledge that this may be a result of my own failure to communicate my preferences effectively or perhaps due to unforeseen circumstances, I cannot help but feel that such an approach diminishes the enjoyment that I would normally derive from the process. Notwithstanding this criticism, I must admit that the salon does offer one of the more satisfactory pedicure experiences available in Las Vegas, particularly the hot stone variety, which I highly recommend."

It was 10:45 on a Saturday morning, and I was craving a cup of coffee, which led me to embark on a quest to find a suitable establishment where I could indulge in this beverage. Unfortunately, the first cafe I encountered was closed, much to my dismay. Undeterred, I continued my search, seeking a venue that offered a tranquil atmosphere where I could enjoy my coffee and peruse the latest edition of The New York Times. My initial intention was to visit a nearby cafe, but upon arriving, I found the ambiance to be too modern for my liking. I was in a peculiar mood and desired a more traditional coffee experience, devoid of any frills or pretenses. As fate would have it, I chanced upon an elderly gentleman who was enthusiastically promoting a restaurant, touting the "Best lunch in town!" with great vigor. His infectious energy convinced me to give the eatery a try. Thus, I discovered MacAlpines, a quaint establishment that had just opened its doors. I was immediately drawn to the cozy atmosphere and settled into a seat at the counter. Two cups of rich, diner coffee later, I realized my hunger and opted for a delectable stuffed tomato, replete with fresh vegetables. The charming decor and lively jukebox further enhanced my dining experience. Although it took some time for the staff to warm up and display their hospitality, I am eager to revisit MacAlpines with companions and assess its quality once more.

Not as good as their flagship out on Sahara, but this one's right on the strip, although with the renovation you have to wade thru some dust and scaffolding to get here. The portions were just as monstrously large though, and this time we split 2 dishes among the three of us lightweights, and we left full having not even finished either of them. I'd have picked the chicken and waffles for sure but democracy won out. Here we tried the chorizo skillet and the Tractor Driver Combo. The chorizo skillet was good, although the one tortilla it comes with is inadequate for the amount of filling it comes with. The tractor driver combo we upgraded to a banana pancake which was well worth the extra dollar. Service was excellent. \n\nThe experience at their standalone restaurant on Sahara was better in terms of the atmosphere, the food, and the overall experience, but this was still fine.

I was here for my 21st birthday. It was a lot of fun, but it was rather small. It felt like they were double their max capacity. The dj was awesome, but again the dance floor was too small and crowded :(

The food was good, portions huge, and there was a good variety on the menu.  However it took us an hour and 12 minutes from arrival to getting our food, even though the place wasn't full.  So worth it for the food quality and portions, but be prepared for a long wait to get it.

"Although initially dubious about the authenticity of Hawaiian cuisine in Las Vegas, my expectations were pleasantly surpassed by Island Flavor's offerings, with the exception of a few minor drawbacks. The portions were generously sized, with a single plate sufficient to satisfy three individuals had we been aware of their magnitude. The Kahlua pork, while somewhat lacking in saltiness, was tender and flavorful, while the sweet and sour pork ribs, though slightly overseasoned with salt, remained palatable. The Furikake chicken, enhanced by the addition of Sriracha, was particularly impressive. However, my primary criticisms pertain to the rice dishes. The brown rice, prepared with an excessive amount of water, resulted in a pair of soggy, unappealing scoops. In contrast, the fried rice, characterized by its predominantly white rice composition, Lapcherng, and vegetables immersed in soy sauce, fell short of my expectations for a traditional fried rice dish. Notwithstanding these issues, the COCO PUFFS, adorned with a mysterious yet delectable buttery yellow topping complementing the chocolate cream puff, earned high praise. Similarly, the mud pie, enhanced by the inclusion of chocolate cacao or coffee nibs in the kona coffee ice cream, was well-received, despite the unnecessary flavored syrups accompanying it. The staff maintained a friendly and accommodating demeanor, despite their hectic workload. Lastly, the Spam musubi, reminiscent of those enjoyed in Hawaii, rounded off the meal satisfactorily."

I love a good massage. My husband purchased a gift card for couples massage and gifted it to me for Christmas. Scheduling the massage was very easy. This location is very clean and the waiting room was very therapeutic. The massage room was ok. It was barely decorated and in kind of a weird layout. Our massage therapists were very friendly and professional. I can't say that I will be back after I use the rest of the money on my gift card, though. The massage was ok, but I've had much better ones. They really try to sell you on becoming a member when you are checking out, which I do not like.

"I was taken aback by the fact that the jerk fried rice did not possess the same level of piquancy as it had during my initial visit. Moreover, the portion size appeared diminutive in comparison to previous experiences, barely filling the circular aluminum receptacle. Despite these observations, the culinary offerings remained flavorsome and gratifying. I would advocate for the black beans over the refried variety, as they exhibit a more pronounced gustatory profile. The service was commendable, with the staff displaying promptness and amiability in their interactions with us. Notwithstanding, the ordering process proved somewhat perplexing, necessitating the guidance of the staff for novice patrons to fully comprehend the intricacies of the menu."

I was at the Starbucks in the Trails Village Center and needed to stop at the ATM at Wells Fargo.  There wasn't a single car in any of the three lanes even the one with the ATM.  That's almost 4 stars without thinking.

This is an OK place, but it's not in my neighborhood and it's a bit of a pain getting in and out with the traffic coming in and out of the Trails Center.

I have lived here over a decade and this is my first check in here says something.

My review of Fin is pretty much the same as all of the other Yelpers. I found Fin to be a bit pricey for Chinese food, and the staff is very overly incredibly attentive. If you take a sip of water, someone is there to refill it for you. 

The food is good, though, there's no doubt about it. I ordered the stir-fry chicken and was very satisfied. They also follow up your meal with a delicious house made fortune cookie and shot of Baileys. 

The ambiance is fantastic if you sit toward the back and can block out the chachings of the nearby slot machines. 

Highly recommended for a nice dinner as long as you're aware of the price and overly attentie service staff.

I suppose its well stocked and closer for me than Tesco but it just doesnt have that friendly neighbourhood shop vibe. 
Twice in the last couple of weeks Ive been short changed and instead of a 'are you sure' or a 'lets see' the dude looked at me as if I just declared an interest in his wife.
Both times they were out by a pound or so. we aint talking 2p here man!


 They are on to me though. Last week I was overcharged for a coke and so I said 'I paid less last week'. He replied 'oh we undercharged you by mistake'...Good move that one...


 Finally, dont try and haggle. I haggled them for 20p off some Snapple but the only one who sanctions haggled goods is the Old Man. The other staff were taken by surprise and looked a little scared as I tried the haggling.

"= = = = = = DAILY LUNCH BUFFET!  = = = = = = 

Monica O. orchestrated an unforgettable culinary excursion at a local Thai restaurant, enticing 15 fellow Yelp enthusiasts to partake in a sumptuous buffet showcasing an array of delectable Thai delights, fostering camaraderie and conviviality among the group. (Kudos to Monica!)  The bountiful spread boasted 15 diverse offerings, including two soups, a vegetarian option featuring egg and tofu, and a coconut-based delight with chicken; plain and flavored rice complemented the assortment, accompanied by an assortment of savory hot dishes encompassing chicken, beef, and fish, along with numerous vegetable combinations, totaling an impressive 19 items. 

The culinary experience was generally satisfying, and considering the scarcity of Thai buffets in the area, the establishment's presence is indeed a welcome addition.     :-)

Although the dining ambiance was pleasant, and the table service was adequate, several minor drawbacks marred the experience:

*  A preponderance of poultry dominated the meat selections.

*  Desserts were conspicuously absent from the menu.

*  The eatery enforced a restrictive policy, permitting a single credit or debit card payment per table, which proved problematic for our group, as only one member had sufficient cash on hand.  This particular stipulation seemed inconvenient and counterproductive, prioritizing corporate interests over customer satisfaction.  

                                                                                          `

Lunch Buffet Schedule and Prices:

Tuesday through Friday: $9.99, available from 11:30 AM.
Sunday: $10.99, served from 12 noon."

I had the fish and tofu tacos for lunch. They use corn tortillas, which I respect. The fish was good and the tofu mixture was interesting, but the tacos were not particularly great.  The location seems good though. The bar has a lot of space around it, and I assume the patio is quite nice.

Quirky interior, clearly popular and possibly the best priced pot of tea in town.


 Could maybe do with opening past 18:00.

"The price point was appropriate. However, my predilection for the culinary offerings of Five Guys surpasses my affection for this establishment. Although the ambiance and gastronomical experience provided by What A Burger may be considered antiquated, it remains my preferred purveyor of burgers. Notwithstanding the crowded atmosphere, the staff at In-N-Out Burger exhibited commendable hospitality, yet the quality of their burgers pales in comparison to that of their competitors, thereby precipitating a deficiency in the overall satisfaction of my dining experience."

I'm pretty sure most of these new reviews are from employees and their families. 

Refused to honor my Groupon (prepaid of course).
This is exactly the same place as before. Their sign even still says Greek Grill & Fry Co. and it's run by the same people. 
The server was polite and made good suggestions,  but failed to alert me that they would not honor the 50% off Groupon before we ate, but instead offering a 20% discount. I always mention any deals on the way in for this reason.

The food was good,  not a huge selection but it was hot and made to order. We seemed to be the only customers that whole day. The Uncle/Grandpa of the family was in the dining area watching TV and talking on his phone. It's a very casual place.

There are some tables and a lot of slot machines. If you live in the area, it could be a good place to go and hang out. I would never recommend a drive from the strip to gamble here, but not bad for a locals hang out. With dollar beer and hot dogs, how can you go wrong!?

Its americanized, but pretty tasty! I love the fried rice and usually just get that. We were getting takeout once and waited at the bar, and the bartender gave us free tastes of the lychee cocktail while we waited! And that was tasty too!

Its also never crowded, its quiet and the service is consistently not bad. 

All that being said though, there isn't really anything special about this place. Its just kind of...eh... Best as take out.

I don't know about the lounge part everyone else has reviewed, but I had dinner there and was like meh about it. The portions are extremely small for the prices. Even the sake was a bit overpriced, I felt. The waitstaff, as much as I appreciate attentiveness, was maybe a little too overeager to get us the hell out of there. My husband's plate was actually cleared before he was even done eating. We eventually had to tell them to leave the plates until we were finished. While the ambiance is very cool and romantic, I don't think I'd drop another buck in there in the future.

This is not the same restaurant of past years.  Been eating at the Golden Steer since the early 1970's and the service and food was outstanding.  Going down hill since the 2000's.  Will not eat there any more.  Not worth the value.  Staff was very friendly and they decor has not changed.  I ordered a NY Strip steak and they butterflied it and took all the flavor out it.  We used to brag about his place to all we know who were traveling to Las Vegas, no more.

"Although my culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, I do appreciate the expansive outdoor seating area, which presents an ideal setting for indulging in a mixed beverage, such as a refreshing cocktail or a glass of wine, at any time."

"Concurring with the prevailing sentiment, I must aver that this excursion does not qualify as a hike in the classical sense, owing to the presence of artificial stairs and an absence of any genuine ruggedness or challenge. Rather, it constitutes a leisurely stroll with a picturesque view of the surrounding landscape, conveniently located in close proximity to the local zoological garden. While it may serve as a charming diversion for a couple seeking a lighthearted adventure, it falls short of the rigorous criteria typically associated with hiking. Notwithstanding, I did appreciate the opportunity to showcase my stylish attire, replete with fashionable footwear, as I effortlessly ascended the hill."

I had arrived at this establishment prior to the purported culmination of the world, and it appeared that everyone else had already partaken in the festivities, as evidenced by their jubilant demeanor. My significant other had received a suggestion from her promoter that enabled us to gain admittance without incurring any financial obligations, and we were also presented with complimentary beverages shortly before the stroke of midnight, which contributed to the overall enjoyment of our visit. It is worth mentioning that Blush is rather diminutive in size when compared to XS and Surrender, lacking a designated area for dancing and instead featuring narrow pathways between the tables. Patrons may attempt to engage in dance within these confines, but such efforts are likely to result in an appearance of awkwardness due to the restricted nature of the space. The musical offerings within Blush seemed to be predominantly mainstream, with a reduced emphasis on hip-hop, prompting us to vacate the premises after a mere half hour and rejoin our companions who had been unable to gain entry.
Chef cooking in the open facility. Mostly noodles. Pad Thai noodles, beef. A most desirable appetite for the hungry man. Couldn't take this to heart.

"Today, I partook in a leisurely hike with a group of acquaintances, followed by a midday repast at a local eatery.  Upon entering the establishment, we were greeted by a welcoming ambiance and an agreeable hostess who promptly seated us.  Our server, an affable young woman, presented us with menus and offered suggestions from the extensive bill of fare.  I opted for a delectable sandwich, which was served steaming hot and overflowing with fresh ingredients.  Unfortunately, my side dish of mixed greens appeared somewhat limp and lackluster, leading me to surmise that it may have been sitting for an extended period.  One of my fellow diners selected a traditional morning meal, which he proclaimed to be both flavorful and plentiful.  Another member of our party chose a breakfast burrito, which he described as'very good.'  However, my own salad proved to be the weakest component of the meal, prompting me to speculate that perhaps it was not the freshest offering on the menu.  Despite this minor shortcoming, the quality of service we received was quite satisfactory, as our server remained attentive and personable throughout our visit.  Additionally, the restaurant provided complimentary carafes of coffee, iced tea, and soda, allowing us to refill our glasses at our discretion.  In conclusion, while the cost of the meal was reasonable, I might recommend avoiding the salad option during lunch hours, but would certainly consider returning to sample other items from their diverse culinary offerings."

we ate here for our last day in vegas. everyone was hung over and we needed some soup to make us feel better. i ordered the fire chicken wings which weren't spicy at all. but it wasn't bad. the dim sum was yummy because they had a good amount of shrimp inside. the duck noodle soup thing was ok. the duck was good. hot and sour soup- a bit spicy, too much pepper. and the chrysanthemum iced tea was delish.

This particular site was in close proximity to Arizona State University. It was devoid of patrons on a festive day. Our attendant was exceptional. The culinary offerings were prepared flawlessly. Furthermore, they offered a designated area for scholastic pursuits, which I believed to be an inspired notion. The sole recommendation proffered by my dining companion was that the server should inform patrons of any supplementary charges beforehand, rather than taking them by surprise on their bill. Although the menu did contain a reference to this practice, it did not explicitly state that an additional two dollars would be added to the cost of eggs upon requesting a slice of cheese.

The prices were great, but they were out of stout...

I was a bit crowded and that left the staff super spread out... Our table faced the kitchen door and it was obvious they only had two cooks in the kitchen, I wonder how the dining room got so croweded?  But for the price I don't mind having to wait for our food, beg for water and the check.

I will say the people watching was priceless!  It looked like perhaps a convention of middle-aged mid-west salesmen had hit the place hard just before we were seated! Hilarious :)

We got a room for $35/night, a Motel-6 price for a better-than-Motel-6 room with much-better-than-Motel-6 amenities.  The pools are awesome.  You get a free drink pass.  Gym is pretty nice, too.  I approve.

Finally, an individual exhibited intelligence and elected to establish a Metro Pizza in Henderson, thereby alleviating the necessity for me to engage in a conflict with UNLV students during their lunch break in order to secure a pleasant booth and a delicious pizza. The novel location, in my opinion, surpasses the original in quality. It features a complete bar section, a private dining area for celebrations, and a customary dining room. Additionally, there is a distinct wing designated for carry-out orders, thereby eliminating the need for me to traverse the entire restaurant while attired in my pajamas and slippers. While the pizza is undoubtedly delectable on its own, the nuclear fries are truly exceptional, possessing a subtle spice and a slight kick that complements a pie perfectly. Furthermore, they offer an assortment of beers on tap, which pair magnificently with pizza. However, it is advisable to avoid visiting during weekend evenings, as the excitement surrounding the new establishment remains prominent, resulting in overcrowding. Instead, opt for the lunch period, when the atmosphere remains relatively peaceful.  
Recommended pizza: Margherita  
Recommended beer: Hefeweizen accompanied by a few lemons.

This is the cheapest option if you are in Paris, which isn't saying much. We'll actually there's a place two doors down that had sandwiches in a display case but for an extra dollar or two we got a much more appetizing sandwich here. \n\nI definitely would not go out of your way for this place. However, if it is 2pm, you just got in from your flight and don't want another airport refrigerated sandwich, then just maybe this is the place for you too.

First and foremost, I don't mind spending money on good coffee.  I do have to say that the ambiance has definitely changed quite a bit in the last 6 months.   I used to walk in and see my favorite baristas and we'd chit chat a little but now they all seem to be gone.  I'm going to assume that's because of the new location?  I'm not sure.  Regardless the coffee now seems to taste less satisfying :(.  It's saddening because we really adored this place but now go elsewhere.  If anything it's a testament to the difference people can make in that sort of environment.

this is a review for flaverz the buffet inside harrah's. whenever i go out to vegas i always try to eat at this place. its one of those places that is not so cheap but they have a great selection of food. they have mexican, italian, sea food, fresh foods, chinese, and deserts. everything is great and all the times that ive been there is always some new item on the list. its great. i think that it is like $20 per person. however if you do the timeshare stuff then you can get 2 for 1. however having gone this week we discovered that you have to be 28+ to do the time share :( im just 24 but a few months ago i was able to do it :) oh the time share thing is at the entrance to the casino, just walk around and they will get you specially if you are a couple or look like one.

Last week, my spouse and I opted to partake in a midday repast at a local eatery, whereupon we encountered a somewhat underwhelming culinary experience due to the mediocre quality of the fare and the sluggishness of the server. Despite these drawbacks, our meals did come accompanied by several complimentary items such as a bowl of broth, a crispy cylindrical pastry, and a trio of deep-fried dumplings. However, the soup did not conform to my expectations of a traditional Thai soup, the spring roll was excessively oily, and the wontons lacked discernible flavor. My partner chose the yellow curry, while I selected the Panang variant; furthermore, I requested that my dish be prepared at the Thai spicy level, yet it was merely moderately piquant. In light of this experience, we have decided to explore alternative Thai dining options in the future, specifically the Thai Cafe, which lies approximately a mile distant from our current location.

"The fruit and vegetables procured from this establishment may not consistently possess optimal quality, as I have previously purchased a bag of plums from this location at a discounted price, only to discover upon consumption that they had deteriorated in freshness. However, I was able to successfully slow cook them, resulting in an unexpectedly delectable culinary experience. It is essential to exercise caution when acquiring items at a significantly reduced cost or those that are out of season, as there exists a heightened risk of compromised quality. Nonetheless, it is crucial to emphasize that a plethora of satisfactory products can be found among the offerings, thereby rendering it judicious to maintain vigilance in the face of potential disappointment."

I'll start with the food. It was good. My husband enjoyed the steak and I got the halibut. Both really tasty. Baked potato was stellar and they have a 'wine of the month' which you can get for $20 or if you have the hotel coupon book, free.

Service. Was very attentive in some ways, non-existent in others. Served us drinks/wine right away. Never brought bread and we had to ask for our entree after being there about 75 minutes and then rush to make our show. Not a huge deal EXCEPT the server was super defensive about it and made excuses, which I thought was weird as we weren't irritable when we mentioned it, just asked because we needed to get out of there.

Seemed super pricey for South Point too, but if you want a special occasion and are staying there - I'd say try it. It was good.

"It is patently evident that securing a reservation at this establishment during the festive Christmas season is an absolute imperative, particularly for parties comprising more than two individuals. The dearth of vacant tables during our visit underscored the pressing need for a prior appointment, as we were compelled to occupy seats at the bar owing to the absence of availability. The prices charged for the culinary offerings were considerable, with a modest soup costing a tenner and a special combination of soup and pasta setting patrons back by nineteen dollars. Notwithstanding the elevated tariffs, the gastronomic experience was merely passable, as one of my colleagues was obliged to return the special due to the uncooked state of the meat. However, the eatery's personnel demonstrated commendable alacrity in recognizing and addressing the issue, which merited a generous gratuity."

I really like Lavo (as a nightclub)! Have yet to have a meal here though, so this review is for the nightclub only. Space-wise it can get pretty cramped because it's a bit on the smaller side, but nowhere near as uncomfortably packed as Tao. Dance floor is pretty tiny, but honestly, I didn't notice it until the place had mostly cleared out and I got a good look around. They play hip-hop and a lot of old songs, but old in a way that makes you go "oh man, I haven't heard this song in a while, but  it's still awesome," which I think is a nice change of pace from all the clubs that play almost exclusively house music.

Lavo is probably a 3.5 in my book, though I have to admit, part of the reason for that is because we had open bar, courtesy of our wonderful promoter (who also got our guys in for free!) There's a main bar area, but we got all our drinks from the side bar, which was super crowded and only had one bartender working there. But he was a really adorable and sweet bartender, so no complaints.

tl;dr: Everyone in my group had a fairly fun time. Would definitely come back-- especially if we're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo!

"Although certain aspects of this establishment were satisfactory, such as its proximity to the Town & Country shopping center and the ample parking facilities, other elements, including the meager amount of meat and toppings on the sandwiches, left much to be desired. Furthermore, the preponderance of bread in these sandwiches made them seem unbalanced and lacking in substance. While the chocolate milkshake was a notable highlight, it was not enough to compensate for the overall mediocrity of the dining experience. In light of these factors, it is difficult to wholeheartedly recommend this venue, especially when compared to more affordable options such as Subway, where one can expect a greater quantity and variety of ingredients."

I would give this a 3.5. I would expect the pizza to be a lot better just because it is a Pie place. It was good but I've had a lot better. The thing this has is great ambiance. I love how low the lighting is. Dark tables that are turned perfectly so you don't feel like you are apart of other people's dinners. Great fire from the oven and open area bar. Had a good solid wine. We got the cheese board which was good. We both got pizza but like I said it was good just nothing special.

I rarely frequent Fresh and Easy due to the lack of visual appeal of their stores, with the exception of a few select items that pique my interest, primarily snacks such as peanut butter filled salted pretzel nubs, some satisfactory salted kettle chips, and a passable trail mix suitable for hiking excursions. My brief visit to the store yesterday served as a testament to my unfamiliarity with its layout, as I aimlessly wandered the aisles in search of my desired products, not unlike a zombie driven by an unyielding determination to acquire the items on my list. Following a swift checkout process, during which I presented only two items for purchase, I proceeded to venture across the street to Albertsons, whereupon I conducted a more extensive and deliberate shopping expedition.

Really great salsa bar, tacos, quesadillas and burros.  This is 'authentic' mexican; not Macayos.  \nA few downsides though, it is really small & not really built for families or large groups; plus, I wouldn't park in the neighboring streets.  I got yelled at by one homeowner saying if they saw my vehicle again they're having it TOWED!.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by the consumption of these burgers, at a price point that can only be described as eminently reasonable, is nothing short of exceptional, particularly when considered in conjunction with the ambiance fostered by the establishment's unique setting, which serves to facilitate convivial dialogue among patrons; however, it must be noted that certain aspects of the menu, specifically the dearth of diversity in the realm of beer offerings, as well as the rather unremarkable quality of the fries served as an accompaniment to the main course, do detract somewhat from the overall enjoyment of the dining experience."

"Culinary delights are undeniably delectable, yet the quality of customer service leaves much to be desired. Despite this establishment being a personal favorite, the experience at this particular venue falls short of expectations. A prolonged waiting period of 15 minutes ensued, during which time the dining area was largely unoccupied, for a bean burrito to be prepared for takeout. It is truly disconcerting that such an esteemed eatery would fail to meet the standards of efficiency and promptness, especially during a relatively slow period."
Good flavor, good service, long wait and under done pepperonis. Gotta go to Grimaldis in Brooklyn to compare the two. Nothing special.

This is for the Sunday night concert series. If you like families and dogs and strollers and people running around your blanket and trains blaring their horns and lousy sound systems and parking from hell, the Sunday night concert series should be on your radar. My chunky date and myself found a decent location away from the stage, but still experienced most everything previously mentioned. None of it really bothered us too much, so if you can endure all of that or actually somebody with multiple dogs and kids, then this is your piece of cake. The Scottsdale douchebag factor was not in effect, but you will have to arrive early to get a spot across the street. Now, it might have been more crowded due to holiday weekend, but who knows unless I go again which I doubt.
Went on a night that they had a live band on the patio.....was a nice atmosphere. Drinks were good but food was just okay. May go back if other places are too busy.

"Aesthetically pleasing accommodations, albeit briefly inhabited, rendered an additional tariff of $50 for early ingress. Contrasted with the alternative of slumbering within the confines of our minuscule Honda Insight alongside my spouse, infant, and mother-in-law, this arrangement proved preferable. Notwithstanding, the availability of power outlets for our diverse assortment of mobile devices necessitated a systematic rotation and judicious utilization of the facilities' electrical infrastructure. Lamentably, the queue for registration extended interminably, attended by an insufficient number of personnel to facilitate its expeditious progression... Lamentably, the process of settling our financial obligations similarly degenerated into chaos, as the throngs of patrons vying to vacate the premises swelled to unmanageable proportions during the terminal phase of our sojourn. Gratuities notwithstanding, the absence of a coffee brewing apparatus within our quarters occasioned mild disappointment. Furthermore, the egress protocol struck us as somewhat bizarre, advocating instead for a simplified, hassle-free procedure involving the placement of the invoice beneath the entrance to our abode, followed by a swift and unencumbered departure, devoid of any unnecessary delays or complications. Ultimately, despite some minor shortcomings, our stay at the TI proved satisfactory, yet, given the tariff, we might opt to seek alternative lodgings in the future."

Last evening, we opted to partake of a culinary excursion to the esteemed eatery known as Mert's, whereupon we indulged in their delectable Fried Catfish and Beef Rib Combo. Alas, our gastronomical experience was not without its drawbacks, as the whole fried catfish presented some difficulties in navigating the bony terrain, ultimately yielding a meager amount of succulent fish. Furthermore, "The Beef Rib" dish was found to be somewhat lacking in quantity, with the meat being chopped into small pieces and intermingled with an abundance of bones. However, we must commend the kitchen staff for their proficiency in preparing the sides, particularly the Mac and Cheese, which boasted a satisfying crust on its surface, and the Corn Bread, whose texture and flavor were both pleasing, although a minor quibble could be raised regarding the slightly overcooked nature of the piece my spouse received, resulting in a somewhat dry and unfortunate conclusion to an otherwise enjoyable repast. In summary, while not without its flaws, our visit to Mert's proved to be a generally satisfactory dining experience.

"My affection for cinematic endeavors directed by John Hughes notwithstanding, this particular establishment purporting to serve breakfast items under the moniker 'The Breakfast Club' fell short of my expectations, which, admittedly, were predicated on the eponymous film. The eggs, while adequate in terms of their culinary execution, unfortunately lacked that je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the realm of true gastronomical excellence; the potatoes, referred to as 'O'Brian' in an apparent attempt at novelty, were unremarkable in both texture and flavor, with an unfortunate tendency towards oiliness and an inconsistent distribution of pepper; the jalapeno biscuits, whose conceptual appeal had initially piqued my interest, regrettably failed to deliver upon their promised premise, manifesting instead as somewhat tough and flavorless disk-shaped entities infused with jalapenos; the heuvos rancheros, while perhaps visually unappealing to some due to their resemblance to a feline hairball, were declared palatable by my dining companion. \n\nIn conclusion, my experience at this establishment was, overall, disappointing, primarily due to an excessive greasiness that permeated the menu offerings, as well as an outdoor seating area that, while pleasant in theory, proved to be a mixed blessing given its proximity to a heavily trafficked thoroughfare. However, it must be acknowledged that the quality of service provided by the waitstaff was, for the most part, satisfactory, despite certain unsettling mannerisms reminiscent of the Stepford Wives that were observable in some of the servers."
Overall it's a nice place the reason for only 3 stars is this: $5 to park,$35.99 entrance, $8 small locker, $3 water and only 5 working slides, a wave pool and lazy river. Make up your own minds ...

Fairly typical Chinese food with a Sushi menu and nice restaurant seating area.  I wasn't as wow'd as I was hoping after reading all the rave reviews here on Yelp, but it is a pretty decent offering.

I tried the egg drop soup, which was a good value, the pork dumplings, which were meh - I think the sauce was overly sweet, the kung pao chicken, which was pretty good, and the chicken lo mein noodles, which were meh (but aren't all lo mein noodles pretty meh?).

Overall I would come back and get some take out because it does lie somewhere in between your PFChangs and your strip mall cheap Chinese take out place.  However, I don't believe it's that great of a value offering.  The prices are a bit high for cheap Chinese, and the quality is only just a bit higher.  Doesn't feel like you're getting a great deal.

The decor here is adorable. It made me want to sit and stay a while. I had my first macaroon, well two, mixed berry and raspberry. People always rave about them (not necessarily from here, but in general) so I decided to indulge. I didn't love or hate them. I'll definitely be back to try other options.

"Although Footlocker may not excite one's senses, it does offer an array of prominent shoe brands, including Reebok, Nike, Adidas, and an abundance of basketball sneakers that could be deemed superfluous. Prices range from moderate to expensive, yet periodic sales provide customers with the opportunity to acquire desirable footwear at a reduced cost. However, these sales often feature aesthetically unappealing shoes that may not be in high demand. As Footlocker appears to cater primarily to male clientele, its inventory is comprised predominantly of men's shoes, leaving a limited selection for women. Thus, while I may visit the store to peruse its offerings, I frequently find myself seeking alternatives that better align with my preferences."

My fiance said I should write a review.    I replied that the restaurant didn't strike me as good or bad.  It was pretty middle of the road.

2.5 stars for me.

Service was fine.   No real complaints or compliments there.

Food.  During happy hour, you get 2 tacos for $3 Chef's choice of tacos.  And I delighted in eating the salmon taco.   

I was expecting grand things from the guacamole and was disappointed.   The dried cranberries were an interesting addition.  But I much prefer good ol' Trader Joe's guacamole.

Food was rico.   Rico means "rich" in Spanish and usually a compliment.   I just found the food rico in terms of calories.

I wouldn't mind going back but neither am I itching to return either.

This isn't a movie theater that I frequent regularly since I live in NLV, but the "renovations" since Rave owned the place seems favorable. They've added extended armrests between each seat with a heavier duty cup holder than you're used to but has pros and cons; while it makes sharing drinks and snacks easier, it also makes the armrest stationary. 

PRO:
New armrests are larger.
Snack bar seems to be larger than most.

CON:
The movie (White House Down) started about 20 minutes late, apparently nobody was in the operating room.
There were only like 30 M&Ms in the package I purchased at the snack bar.

"Indubitably, 'Ja... perfectly fine.' However, there seems to be a certain je ne sais quoi missing from 'Jawohl. I rather enjoy that.' Perhaps it's the lack of a tangible element, such as a location with a similar ambiance to a fast-food chain, but with a more refined and sophisticated atmosphere, akin to a restaurant rather than a bar. Perchance, the concept of offering a build-your-own menu, where customers can curate their own dishes from a selection of premium ingredients, might help to establish a more coherent and well-rounded culinary experience. It's worth mentioning that the service has been consistently friendly and attentive, without being overbearing or intrusive. While the location itself is not necessarily problematic, the overall concept and pricing strategy may benefit from further refinement to fully realize its potential. At present, it appears to be a fusion of a trendy Berlin-Mitte scene restaurant and the currently popular Munich 'Currywurst bars,' resulting in a unique yet somewhat disjointed dining experience. Notwithstanding, the establishment boasts a commendable gender diversity among its staff."

A coterie of individuals, including myself, elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to the fact that we had been informed that their burgers were of superior quality. Upon arriving at the venue, we discovered that the comestibles were indeed delectable, yet somewhat greasy and arid. However, it was the unfortunate occurrence of poor hospitality that truly marred our dining experience. Specifically, Olivia, our server, displayed an acrimonious demeanor throughout the duration of our visit, seemingly without provocation. When we requested a container for transporting our food, she carelessly flung it onto the table, an action we perceived as discourteous. Furthermore, we were compelled to request the replenishment of our water vessels thrice before she eventually attended to our needs. Considering the elevated prices charged by this restaurant, a certain level of decorum and attentive service would have been anticipated. In conclusion, while the edibles were undoubtedly savory, the subpar service we received left much to be desired. If one values a satisfying dining experience, they may wish to consider patronizing this establishment with the hope that they will encounter a more competent and affable server.

"I decided to indulge in an afternoon delight, opting for a frozen yogurt treat from Golden Spoon. With an array of delectable flavors to choose from, I settled on Irish creme, adorned with almond roca topping. Initially, I relished every bite, savoring the richness of the frozen confection. However, as I progressed through my treat, my thoughts became increasingly preoccupied with the unmistakable zest of Twangy Tart. The tangy, fruity essence of this flavor captivated my taste buds, leaving me in a state of utter fascination. It was as if the Ice Tango had performed a tantalizing dance on my tongue, leaving an indelible impression. From that moment forward, I found myself irreversibly enamored with the Twang, and no other frozen yogurt establishment could compare. Golden Spoon, once my go-to destination for frozen delights, had suddenly become secondary. My taste buds had been forever transformed by the magical touch of Ice Tango, and nothing would ever be the same again."

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment are undoubtedly palatable, they fail to justify the cost associated with their consumption. My recent visit afforded me the opportunity to sample their allegedly piquant poultry dish, which, I must admit, lived up to its billing in terms of its fiery demeanor. However, my gratification was somewhat tempered by the exorbitant tariff levied for the meal, specifically $11 for a midday repast that, in my estimation, did not warrant such an extravagant expenditure. Notwithstanding, I would still confer upon the victuals a rating of four stars out of five, cognizant of the fact that my reservations pertain primarily to the pricing and not necessarily the quality or flavor of the fare itself."

I only ordered pho there and wasn't impressed at all but I saw some other dishes other people were eating looked pretty good.  It gave me the feeling that it's a more Americanized joint comparing to the ones on spring mtn. I'm willing to try again.

"This shopping center formerly enjoyed a preeminent status among its peers within the locality. However, with the advent of Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace, it appears that a significant proportion of patrons residing in Chandler, Tempe, and Gilbert have migrated their allegiance to these newer retail establishments. Despite this shift, a plethora of quality stores continue to operate within Fiesta, mirroring an array of identical retailers found at the aforementioned competitors. Notably, during peak sales periods and holidays, the mall's diminished foot traffic translates into a more comfortable and convenient shopping experience for patrons. Additionally, Fiesta boasts a unique covered parking area, which distinguishes it from its rivals and offers a welcome respite from the sweltering heat during the summer months."

"It is patently evident that the medical establishment in question, despite their professed commitment to excellence in patient care, has elected to adopt a decidedly parsimonious approach when it comes to the fiscal aspects of their operations. Specifically, the recent invoice we received for services rendered, which was delivered in a wholly unremarkable envelope devoid of any semblance of aesthetic appeal or functional utility, serves as a stark reminder of the disparity between the lofty standards they purport to uphold and the rather more pedestrian reality of their business practices. Not only did the invoice lack any semblance of a tear-off portion or return envelope (the latter of which, it must be acknowledged, would have been an unreasonable expectation given the paltry sums involved), but it was also printed on a machine that could charitably be described as 'economical,' thereby imbuing the entire document with an air of unmistakable thriftiness. This begs the question: if such scant regard is given to the presentation and delivery of financial documents, might it not be reasonable to surmise that similar corner-cutting measures are being taken in other, perhaps more critical, aspects of the medical facility's operations? Furthermore, it seems axiomatic that even a modest investment in pre-printed invoices with detachable return portions and, at the very least, a complimentary return envelope, would serve to enhance the overall experience for patients, thereby fostering a more positive perception of the institution and, by extension, its reputation."

Awesome location, cool place....the Chopped Salad is by far the most amazing salad I have ever had in my life (but way...and I mean way to small)...If it were double the portion for the price I would probably visit more. I had a flight when I was there...it took forever (as I know flights are supposed to)...but this was ridiculous...the buffalo meat is so gross...it reminds me of when a stray dog visits my lawn...

The BBQ sauce is good....the staff is just OK. Nothing mind blowing. I think staff in a place with a pricey menu should spoil the guests a bit...Give away a free desert when you know the service and meal is just OK...this may bring your customer base back to visit just because you redeemed yourself at the end.

Overall its a cool place. It fits with the downtown Scottsdale lifestyle. But stay away from the buffalo, because it will give doggy bag a whole new meaning....

"The culinary offerings at this establishment were of considerable quality, possessing both substantial quantity and delectable flavor. However, when juxtaposed with alternative taco establishments or Mexican cuisine, it becomes apparent that the fare offered here is merely mediocre. As an ardent devotee of Mexican cuisine, I find myself yearning for the genuine authenticity that other eateries provide, which is conspicuously lacking in this particular venue, perhaps due to its location within a casino. \nMy primary grievance pertains to the exorbitant pricing, wherein a meal for two individuals amounted to a staggering $54. Although the quality of the food was satisfactory and benefited from a discount for gamblers, I would be utterly dismayed if I were compelled to expend in excess of $50 for a dining experience of comparable caliber. Therefore, while I encourage potential patrons to sample the culinary delights available here, they should be cognizant of the fact that the cost does not justify the quality provided."

Decent food for the price however I've been to better sushi places for the similar price(and sometimes its worth pay extra for better food). Their makis are often sloppy and unfinished looking and certain fish(fresh tuna or yellow tail for example) are not the freshest. I guess it's good for quick lunch once in a while but not for a fancy dinner.

"Encountered an individual at this location, with the intention of engaging in a recreational activity on the tennis courts.  To our astonishment, the facilities were in a state of good repair, despite the absence of net straps, which did not deter us from participating in the sport.  Generally speaking, this complex possesses a certain appeal... However, my singular grievance would be the convoluted design of the parking area, replete with numerous curved pathways, thereby creating numerous blind spots for drivers who must reverse their vehicles.  Although this layout may contribute to the aesthetic appeal of the surroundings, it would undoubtedly pose a formidable challenge for maintenance personnel, as the absence of straightforward trajectories necessitates additional effort in upkeep. \n\nObserved that the residential units appeared sturdy and well-constructed, employing brick as the primary building material... Nevertheless, the proximity of the highway resulted in significant noise pollution, permeating the atmosphere and rendering it audible even from the tennis court.  Did not venture inside a specific dwelling, yet the auditory level was considerable, even from a distance."

"Applebee's, a ubiquitous chain restaurant, fails to impress me with its unremarkable offerings. Despite my predilection for certain franchises, Applebee's does not rank among my favorites. The cuisine is merely adequate, neither exceptional nor deplorable, but rather mediocre. My recent visit, prompted by a group decision, proved to be an underwhelming experience, save for a few notable exceptions. The Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger, a welcome surprise, boasted a satisfying combination of flavors and spices that elicited a pleasurable response from my taste buds. However, the remaining dishes, including the 3 cheese penne and chicken entrÃ©e, did not garner much enthusiasm from either myself or my fellow diners. Notably, my 18-month-old daughter, notorious for her finicky palate, surprised me by consuming half of her grilled cheese sandwich, the bread of which was reminiscent of a sweet, eggy brioche. The service at Applebee's was commendable, as our server was attentive and proactive in addressing our needs. In summary, while the food and service were satisfactory, the establishment's overall ambiance left me uninspired. Given the choice, I would opt for Chili's over Applebee's, but this particular location managed to incrementally enhance my impression of the franchise."

This was my second trip to this location and I noticed their salad bar had fewer items from before.  It was still very good but am disappointed that they seemed to have eliminated some items.
