I am not a big meat eater and came for the salad bar so I noticed these things. It was still really really good however.

I enjoyed my meal at Spago, but wasn't as impressed as my companions. The wedge salad is good but not notable, however the heirloom tomato and burrata salad special was outstanding - the best overall dish of the night.  

We ended up splitting 3 pizzas - I have to say, I found the crust to be disappointing on all of them. Not much flavor at all - more of just a vehicle for the toppings.  As for the specific pies:
-Margherita - crust was a bit undercooked, and overall I would call this a pretty average Margherita pizza
-Proscuitto - this was the best of the 3 - the Proscuitto and Fromage blanc worked perfectly together.  With a great crust this pizza would have mind blowing potential.
-Lamb Chorizo - a very nice pie overall - enjoyed the chorizo, and the toppings all worked well together. 

Service was excellent.

This establishment offers an exceptional value proposition, boasting a prime location, adequate amenities, and satisfactory service, all at a relatively affordable price point. We have had the pleasure of staying here on multiple occasions, and each experience has been characterized by clean and comfortable accommodations, a diverse array of dining options, and a convenient proximity to various entertainment venues and shopping centers. While the casino floor may be somewhat diminutive and smoky, it serves its purpose for those seeking a low-key gaming experience. Additionally, the on-site spa offers reasonably priced treatments. Some minor drawbacks we have encountered include high-pressure showers that may not align with everyone's preferences and occasional technical issues with in-room televisions, though the latter did not warrant our attention during our most recent visit. In contrast to other establishments in the area that offer a greater degree of luxury and prestige, this hotel provides an excellent balance of quality and affordability, allowing guests to allocate their financial savings towards indulging in the city's vibrant culinary scene, entertainment options, and nightlife.

Kind of tucked away and hard to notice, especially being next to the really glammed out Ella's Deli. But worth a visit if you're looking for a good gyro or kebab. :]

The donuts are alright too. They have a wide variety! Myself, I really rather like their cookies. They also offer homemade baklava.

Really though I can reccomend their sandwiches with a side of the seasoned fries. Quite yummy! Vegetarian options also available such as potato kahbi or falafel sandwiches. And they had a lot of beverages to choose from too.

Although the location is not ideal, it's worth a stop if you're in that part of town. :]

when this place first opened it was really good, back then I would have given it 5 stars. Now it is just ok. My dad likes to go there, that is why we went. 
We started with the grilled artichoke. Usually this is pretty good. Not so much this time. Maybe artichokes are out of season?. It was hard and not very flavorful. The aioli that accompanied it was tasty. 
The prime rib was ok, the portions get smaller each time I go. Very tender, good flavor. Nothing outstanding. We all had the same cut. Same side of baked potato. No dessert. 
Probably will go again as my dad loves this place.

Barneys is a multifaceted drinking establishment that offers a unique experience for patrons seeking a more relaxed atmosphere than the typical bars in the vicinity. For individuals desiring an unpretentious environment where they can enjoy themselves without the necessity of dressing up or paying covers, Barneys may be the ideal destination.

The second floor of the bar particularly stood out to me as a preferred spot, owing to the hospitable demeanor of the bartender and their promptness in refilling drinks. Although the rooftop area has the potential to be an attractive spot during warmer weather, the presence of smoking therein serves as a deterrent for some.

One notable aspect of Barneys is its innovative method of pouring beer from the bottom up, creating a distinctive and entertaining experience for customers. Moreover, for those who have had a few too many drinks, the bar features an amusing arcade game involving a lobster claw, reminiscent of the classic claw machine found at carnivals and arcades.

Overall, Barneys earns a rating of 3.5 stars for its distinctive ambiance and diverse offerings that cater to various preferences.

My wife went there recently during the week with a few friends. It was a Monday afternoon. She said it was not what she expected. It was a neat experience but not as many animals as she thought. 10 bucks to get in for locals and that seemed kinda steep after she got in and realized how minimal the park was.  Also it was over 100 degrees and there was not a drop of water to be had. Every water fountain she stopped at....it said out of order.  This is very dangerous for visitors. They should have water available st all times.

"As an individual enrolled at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, this eatery presents an extraordinary value, offering five tacos, two sides, and a beverage for a mere $5; the tacos, though diminutive in stature, are abundant in terms of protein, thereby obviating any concern of being shortchanged; it is an ideal venue for socializing with companions, indulging in a pail of fermented beverages, and engaging in lively conversation; the protocol involves ordering at the counter, with the staff summoning one's attention via a vocal announcement when the culinary items are prepared; reportedly, the establishment occasionally features live musical performances or a disc jockey, typically showcasing a Latin-inspired theme, which, while unsurprising given the restaurant's heritage, may strike some patrons as unexpected."

I am very torn about First Friday. I absolutely love community events. Especially art walks, and more creative culture, but this is very lacking. I want to love it because it's in my back yard, too! 

However, First Friday leaves me with a sense of empty feeling. Located in the arts district downtown should be plenty of reason why this event should boast art, but it doesn't. 

The art galleries are lacking, and the street vendors that sell art are more there to just get a buck than they are about art. 

Then there's the riff raff of downtown trying to join in, and so many kids everywhere! I guess police try to crack down on curfew, but there's always so many grungy kids that are up to no good running around. 

The food stalls are nice during summer hours, winter many vendors decide to stay home. 

I'll probably end up going back in the summer, but I'll go early before it gets dark, and the crazy kids (literally kids) come out at night.

I loved the environment, and the staff was incredible.  

the food wasn't amazing.. just .. good.
and the cost didn't justify what was on my plate.

"I recently had the occasion to partake in a culinary excursion to TMI for an evening repast. While the gastronomical experience was not without its merits, it failed to surpass my expectations in terms of overall satisfaction. Upon initiating the meal, we opted to sample the TMI toast, which, despite some reservations regarding the texture of the bread, proved to be a satisfying commencement to the delectation process. However, my subsequent selection, the Mac & Cheese, unfortunately did not live up to my gustatory standards, as it was noticeably oleaginous and lacking in flavor. It is worth mentioning that I have historically been able to establish a rapport with nearly any iteration of Mac & Cheese, yet the version proffered by TMI unfortunately did not conform to this trend. The remaining members of my dining party opted for sandwiches and salads, the quality of which, according to their accounts, ranged from satisfactory to palatable. Aesthetically, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain je ne sais quoi, while the degree of auditory intensity rendered conversation somewhat challenging. Furthermore, the temperature within the premises was uncomfortably elevated. In conclusion, while TMI may possess certain attributes that could potentially appeal to certain gastronomes, my own experience did not warrant an overly enthusiastic endorsement, thereby rendering my return in the proximate future unlikely."

I was surprised to find that had a TON of brand new irrigation supplies. As a gardener, I am always fiddling with the irrigation, and am in constant need of emitters, hose, and connectors to support my filthy habit. They have it all (at least when I went), and at a fraction of what the hardware store charges.

It's a fun place to go. I love sharing my food family style so this place is great for me. The dishes we chose were hit and miss, though. An eggplant and goat cheese dish had the eggplant so thin, it was overwhelmed by the 90% cheese portion. An egg/potato/something else dish was very... potatoey, though what was I expecting from it huh? Filet mignon and Thai beef salad were delicious though. Glad I tried it, but probably wouldn't return.

So we hadn't been since this place used to be Cafe Del Sol (yes, a few years ago). We used the Groupon we had purchased about a month ago. It was kind of awkward because there's the main dining room and a separate red-headed step child dining room around the corner, not really attached at all to the main dining room and probably all the excitement. We got there right at the end of happy hour and wifey ordered a glass of Sangria, I had a glass of Tempranillo (that totally blew by the way).  I ended up ordering another glass of wine (don't remember the name) and it was pretty good. I got the cola and pineapple braised short ribs, jalapeno cream corn a chile corn casserole. The sides were good, although the corn casserole was a tad dry. The shorts ribs were great, they didn't have that cheap pot roast taste that some braised short ribs can have. The sauce was a bit thick for my taste, but not a huge deal. Wifey had the grilled shrimp appetizer with avocado and mango sauce appetizer and the empanadas. She loved her food. I wasn't a fan of the empanadas. but the shrimp were pretty good. Overall, I think it's a pretty good place and it's nice to have another option in the area. Would I choose to go back? no, probably not, but I know the wife will make me go back at some point.

"A refreshing submergence into an atmospheric drinking establishment, offering a brief respite from the conventional Las Vegas landscape. We entered the premises on a Friday evening, subsequent to receiving complimentary beverage vouchers on Fremont Street. The ambiance was relatively desolate for a weekend night, which rendered the decibel levels of the bartenders' megaphones marginally excessive and potentially annoying. Nonetheless, the experience was enjoyable, albeit tainted by the realization that the bartenders employed a subtle ploy to coerce patrons into purchasing potations for both themselves and the staff, resulting in an unexpected escalation of our tab."

I have stayed at the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas numerous times, and I'm ready to move on to other hotels.  Its outdated, the food at the main cafe and buffet are so-so, however the rates were pretty fantastic.  Compared to the other hotels, especially the newest arrivals, it shows its age.  

However, I do like it that the concierge will put hotel guests on the VIP list to get into Haze, and other nightclubs in the vicinity.  That was a cool feature we appreciate, and at no cost to the concierge for to get in.  

If its deals you are looking for, and "decent" rooms, it is worth looking into.

"I have had the pleasure of patronizing the establishment located in Henderson on Sunset and the one situated on South Rainbow on multiple occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been thoroughly enjoyable, particularly when it comes to their breakfast offerings, specifically the steak and eggs, which have been cooked to perfection and served with a smile by the friendly staff. Additionally, I have taken advantage of their happy hour promotion at the South Rainbow location, which boasts an impressive selection of $2 draft beers and 1/2 price appetizers, making for a truly exceptional value. However, I must express my disappointment regarding their recently revamped reward card program, which has undergone significant changes to the earning levels, effectively rendering it nearly impossible for me to accrue sufficient credits to redeem a $10 credit within a reasonable time frame, thereby warranting a subpar grade. Consequently, taking into account the substantial disparity between my previous experiences and my current dissatisfaction with their loyalty program, I would assign an overall rating of three stars, which falls midway between an 'A' and an 'F', respectively."

It was ok.... the ordering system was a little confusing, but I am a smart girl and I figured it out. I was looking for a good burger and I found one just the way I wanted it, and the onion rings were good. Its just missing a little personality....?

This was a customary resort eatery where the culinary offerings were moderately aspirational, and the prices were correspondingly elevated. I opted for the poultry dish, as the vast majority of the other entrees were excessively steep, with an unwavering emphasis on high-quality beef. Notwithstanding, the fare was relatively palatable, and the hospitality was of a superior quality. Regrettably, the adjacent table ignited their cigarettes, resulting in a pervasive haze, but we had already concluded our meal and elected to sit alfresco, thus I cannot hold it against them. Ultimately, the cost was slightly exorbitant for the quality of the cuisine, although it was a luxury resort, and I would not anticipate anything else. I probably will not return, but our server was quite pleasant, which is the sole reason I feel a twinge of guilt about awarding this establishment three stars. Apart from that, it was a generally satisfactory experience.

It's amazing what a few blocks can do, in this case... not much if you're heading further East. I love me some Lao Laan... never really had Lao prior to moving to Madison. But I just don't get the same attentive service, sweet menu recommendations and authentic experience I so often found on Willy. What gives? The menu is more compact but the dining room is bigger, so it's perfect if you need room to groove, but other than the size, I think Willy is probably you're best bet if you're looking for curry east of the capitol.

"Although the culinary experience at this establishment was satisfactory, the cost of the meal was considerably high in relation to the quantity and quality of the food provided, thereby rendering it a relatively expensive dining option. Furthermore, my attempt to partake in a midday repast was thwarted by the restaurant's limited operating hours, which did not include luncheon service. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the personnel were quite hospitable and the service was adequate, yet the absence of a lunch menu precludes the possibility of future visits."

Nice but the menu it is stil the same  for the past 6 years...we are in Montreal 

Anyways, the best dish for me is the radish oyster  cannot get enough of the stuff. 12CAD$ for 4 oysters is well worth it

the rest to my taste was quite ordinary, not worth the money

I came in to pick up a new laptop charger and get the upgrade to Lion OSX.

Getting the charger was easy enough, but because I'm on Leopard and not Snow Leopard, I have to buy *two* OS upgrades to get to Lion. Ok, that's fine and all, but the stores don't carry the upgrade from Leopard to Snow Leopard. Excuse me?

My only options were to find a Best Buy that may or may not have the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade disc in stock, or order it online and wait several days for it to arrive. They can't keep a few discs in stock at the Apple store? Absurd.

Other than that total stupidity, the location was fine, store was clean (albeit busy at an odd time), and employee that checked me out was nice enough.

"Culinary experiences that are reasonably priced and of sufficient quality. Enter with the expectation of a restaurant providing typical diner fare and you shall be gratified. The hospitality is adequate, the cuisine is passable, and the cost (particularly considering its proximity to the Las Vegas Strip) is quite favorable."

"Satisfactory... I had the 'Sin City' burger, and I must say, it was quite palatable. My spouse had a classic, but I didn't particularly care for it, although I'm uncertain of the specific ingredients she had added to it. Nonetheless, she seemed to enjoy it, which, in the end, is what truly matters. The sweet potato fries were not particularly impressive, primarily due to their seasoning, which did not align with my personal preferences. However, the regular fries were adequate. In conclusion, while not exceptional, the dining experience was generally satisfying, surpassing the quality of the typical fast food burger by a noticeable margin."
Pretty good for kids, average to below average for adults.  Friendly staff, good price.  Not the best tasting, but you can tolerate a slice or 2.  Limited dessert and salad options.

"If you have an inclination towards indulging in a delectable dessert, specifically one that incorporates rich, velvety chocolate or perhaps a colossal sundae, then this establishment is bound to satiate your craving. Conveniently situated within the historic district, this charming ice cream parlor exudes a nostalgic ambiance, reminiscent of a bygone era, through its preserved retro aesthetic and interior design. Upon entering, my companion and I opted to indulge in the extravagant Buster Brownie Sundae, and while the sweetness was undoubtedly intense, the experience was unquestionably worthwhile. Although Sugar Bowl offers culinary options beyond their renowned frozen treats, we were oblivious to this fact and ultimately chose not to sample them. Notwithstanding, the service we received was warm and welcoming."

"I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment on multiple occasions, both in-house and via delivery, and while the initial excitement has subsided, the quality of the food remains unwavering. The prevalence of five-star reviews may lead one to assume an air of infallibility, but in reality, the restaurant's excellence lies in its ability to deliver a fresh, flavorful wing experience, augmented by the 'awesome sauce' that has become a staple of their menu. My personal preference tends towards the Golden BBQ and Order, though I have also sampled the Citrus Chipotle, Jamaican Jerk, and Sweet Chili options, each boasting a distinct and satisfying flavor profile. The boneless wings, comparable in size to chicken tenders, maintain their appeal, and the delivery process is both expedient and reliable. However, the quality of service varies, with some experiences falling short of expectations, despite the frequency of my visits. Of note, the waffle fries, which I opted to upgrade, were cooked to a crispy perfection, transcending the realm of traditional potatoes and entering the realm of potato chips. In conclusion, while the inflated reviews may be misleading, the restaurant's strengths lie in its diverse array of sauces and consistently satisfying wing experience."

So, I have this weird affliction that makes me feel really uncomfortable when someone puts a HUGE plate of food in front of me. I wanted the chile rellenos, but not the supersized plate! Alas, such is the state of dining in most restaurants these days, but seriously, if I would have known the portions were this big I would have shared my dinner with my friend.\n\nStill, for Vegas we got a table on a Friday night with no wait and no reservation, the service was very attentive, and the bill was reasonable. My mojito was quite tasty also. So go, share, and enjoy!

A Charlotte staple in need of a makeover. Generally solid food but sometimes inconsistent - biggest challenge is the atmosphere which is stale and hasn't kept up with the rest of the Charlotte restaurant scene. You can't go wrong by a visit to PC - especially if the weather is nice and you get to sit on the excellent patio. Salads are great here.

"Halted by this establishment to acquire a potable beverage prior to partaking in an evening meal elsewhere. The atmosphere within was boisterous, verging on cacophonous, owing to the vociferous patrons gathered around the numerous screens displaying some form of athletic competition involving gentlemen gliding across ice surfaces; raucous birthday celebrations manifesting themselves in various areas throughout the premises; and an audio system emitting sonorous melodies at an intensity that bordered on the excessive. Despite its primary focus on gin, the venue's beverage list proved unremarkable in terms of its beer offerings, yet the selection of gin-based concoctions piqued my interest. Following the recommendation of our hospitable server, we opted to sample a particular mixture featuring Ungava gin from Quebec and maple syrup, which, despite my limited affinity for gin, proved quite palatable (it is worth mentioning that any beverage fortified with maple syrup is likely to elicit my approval). A cursory examination of the menu revealed prices that could be described as moderately elevated, with a single beer and cocktail combination costing $20, exclusive of taxes and gratuities, which, I must confess, struck me as somewhat steep. Notwithstanding this, the quality of the service we received was commendable, as our server, despite being occupied with attendance to the multiple large gatherings scattered throughout the establishment, managed to tend to our needs in a timely and attentive manner. All things considered, I am pleased that we decided to visit this locale, as it has been on our list of potential destinations ever since our relocation to this vicinity."

This is easy to confuse with Central Library, but this is hwere they keep the special books - all the special books.  Central Library is just a normal library.

To come read these books you will have to apply at the registration desk for a pass (with ID) that will last for either a few days or about 3 months.

If there is a secific old book here you want to see then you should definitely come here to see it, but if not then this is a lot of fuss over reading a book and you'll be better going elsewhere.

Good sports bar/restaurant--if that's your thing.

Went here when visiting with my dad who suggested it as "one of those new fun places."

The stuffed portabella mushroom appetizer was delicious, though ridiculously decadent.  The carnitas libre pizza was also pretty good, but also extremely rich--i.e. you can taste your arteries clogging.  The pollotate pizza was bland and dry--potatos on pizza is fun in theory, but I'm not convinced.  However, the cook forgot the onions on it, which actually might make a substantial, positive difference.  We okayed the oversight (they've only been open for two months) and they comped our bill a bit, so that was nice.  The service was pretty great, actually.

There's a ton of TVs here and a well-stocked bar with loads of beers on tap.  So if that's your thing, it's probably one of the better sports bar/restaurants out there.  For me, if I'm going to waste the kinds of calories that are packed into these dishes, it had better be for something extra special, which this place just isn't.

Popped in for lunch after a little AM yoga sesh today.  Had been by after my initial trip to Union on opening day - they weren't open when I was there then.  Weirdly, at 11:45 today half the stores in Union were open, half weren't.  Anyway, TDP is super cute.  Love the tables, love the outdoor seating and the small bar.  The staff was super friendly and helpful with our orders.  I could really taste the olive oil on my sandwich and the bread was nice. 

Overall, the food was good, but not great and definitely overpriced. $9 for a Caprese sandwich is ridiculous - and the tomato on this one wasn't ripe.    The meatball sandwich needed more sauce.  The chicken salad sandwich looked great, but again, for such small sandwiches I would expect fruit or salad or something.

I think next time I'll just enjoy the free smells, and buy a bottle of delicious olive oil from their store across the way.

Jersey Mike's didn't make me weak in the knees but it is clean, efficient and friendly.  The menu is a little difficult to read for a first timer, so the zig zag lane where you order your food made me feel a little rushed. I went at lunch time and it was packed.
The mini sub is what should really be called a regular.  The regular is quite large and the other size is enough for three people.
The club had plenty of meat on it.
It was difficult to tell the difference between the white and wheat sub rolls, but they were not bad.
The most interesting thing was the cups the drinks come in.  There are several different cups with the stories of various Jersey Mike's that have done fund raising for feel good causes. I want to believe this is true because we all like to think we are patronizing do-gooder companies.
It may just be branding, I haven't had a chance to really check it out yet.
I would go back, but I want to try something spicier next time.

Los 7 Compadres has a variety (20) of combination platters for about 7 bucks.  Between my wife and I we had 7 items on our combination platters, which we shared.  7 has been a recurring number for us starting with the OYE at Malee's.  Including the rice and beans, the sour cream and the guacamole this gave us an astounding number of possible combinations for each bite.  

A bite of chicken enchilada.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice.
A bite of chicken enchilada with beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice, beans and guacamole.

Play this out again with the burrito, cheese enchilada, tamale, beef enchilada, bean enchilada, etcetera.  All of the food was good.  Portions were generally large.  I found the tamales to be the least satisfying item.  They were a bit dry and the dominant flavor was just the spice of jalapeno.

Note-even the mild here has a real bite.  Overall I'd give them 3.5 stars.  Good enough for a return trip.

"It is utterly perplexing that this establishment appears to take great pride in not only permitting but also possibly encouraging patrons to engage in the noxious habit of smoking, which is particularly baffling given the otherwise impressive array of beverages available and the superior quality of the culinary offerings, including an assortment of pizzas, sandwiches, and appetizers; however, it is profoundly unsettling to consider the prospect of departing the premises with the lingering stench of a foul ashtray clinging to one's person, and it would be truly advantageous if the management were to reconsider their stance on this issue and join the rest of society in embracing the modern era."

Well...I'm super excited that there is finally, finally some V-food in downtown Phoenix.  The more ethnic cuisine around the better.  It is in a convenient location on 1st and Adams.  The kitchen area is open to the public (a first I think I've ever seen).  I ordered take out and everything I needed was in there.  The plus, fast service.  The minus, I felt like things were not quite as tasty as some of my other standbyes.  The prices also reflect the snazzy downtown locale, a dinner for two came out to be closer to 30 bucks (which is still a bargain) but I'm used to about 15-20 at the divier joints.  I'm still going to support them when I'm in a pinch for takeout or lunch downtown, but if I'm craving the authentic and frenetic pace of a Vietnamese eatery I'll have to head out to the avenue's for some of the more established dives.\nDidn't have the bahn mi (they were out).  Had a standard buhn dice which was nice but i'm used to the nom plah a little sweeter with more garlic.  The egg rolls are good, (not filled with just veggies).  The spring rolls are missing my favorite, shrimp!  The omlette dish is an acquired taste, and I'll leave it at that :)

Chinatown in Montreal is small (1 - no matter where in the world we go, my mom ALWAYS has to have rice at least once a day 2- they have the fruits my family travels to Canada for) and this is a reliable resource for good, cheap roast pork/duck over rice. Their beef pan fried noodles are not great (as in, not something I would order again). Their wonton noodle soup is pretty good: I got it both times we came here. General Tso'c chicken was pretty good: again, something my family ordered both times we came.\n\nOverall, nothing crazy and nothing that's a must see in Montreal. The service is OK (if you get a waiter that speaks English well, then the service is good, if not, the inability to effectively communicate causes some frustration. The food comes out fast, so if you're starving, this is a good place to go. Their bubble tea is alright: stops a craving, but it's not great. They do get brownie points for giving baby bochoy with everything and for the HUGE food portions.

Dropping down to three stars ... On a recent visit, I saw TWO roaches on the main floor of the restaurant. No one seemed to care, so I got up and stepped on one.  I pointed out the other, and one of the staff killed it, but they didn't seem surprised.  I know that roaches are hard to control, but having two of them wandering about in a busy restaurant just isn't a good thing. 

Also, our waiter was an overly chatty guy who seems to think we are interested in his voice.  They had some good staff in the past, but I suspect the owner, who likes to get drunk and hang out on the patio, gives me the impression of a guy who would be difficult to work for! 

The food is still decent and better than anything else I've found, but I'm looking for alternatives ...

While $29.99, $32.42 with tax, proved to be too much for this feast.  While there was a lot offered at good quality, it wasn't worth the price as compared to some of the finer hotels.

I was there at 10:15am on a Saturday.  Mimosas are served, and I had two (delicious).  They had a good amount of breakfast and lunch items,  and I had a little of each.  Yes, lunch is already served.  Brunch.

Nothing was outstanding, but all was good.  It isn't an enormously large buffet, but ample nonetheless.

I think I would go back if 1) I was drunk, 2) I had a hankering for AYCE, 3) I was stuck without my car, 4) held hostage, 5) I was drunk.  Oh I said that.  Well, if the price was less...I would go.

"I possess an affinity for both Mexican and Chinese cuisine, thus, it logically follows that I would appreciate a culinary establishment that combines these two distinct gastronomical traditions. The menu, indeed, piques my interest, particularly due to the presence of the Jade Red Chicken, which, I must say, rivals any Orange or General Tso's dish I have had the pleasure of sampling. Moreover, I appreciate the diverse array of options available. The fare, undoubtedly, impresses, especially for those who relish spicy flavors. \n\nHowever, I must express some dissatisfaction with the state of the restaurant's cleanliness. Upon entering, I could not help but notice the unpretentious decor and ambiance, which, while not necessarily unpleasant, does convey a sense of frugality. Furthermore, the seating appears somewhat worn and uncomfortable, and the ceiling exhibits visible signs of wear and tear. Yet, these shortcomings, while unfortunate, pale in comparison to the unsanitary conditions that permeate the restrooms and dining area. The lavatories, in particular, present a scene akin to a truck stop restroom that has suffered a catastrophic event. The doors and walls, regrettably, bear an unsettling resemblance to a neglected state highway facility, marred by numerous handprints and streaks. Additionally, the majority of the trash receptacles overflow with waste, while the tables remain uncleaned. To my knowledge, no staff members appeared to be attending to these issues. Therefore, I must advise that a modicum of investment in maintenance and upkeep would greatly enhance the overall experience. Perhaps the acquisition of newer, more aesthetically pleasing furniture might also contribute to a more satisfactory ambiance. Under the condition that the proprietors address these concerns, I would consider awarding four stars."

Just quickly ran in and grabbed some stuff for dinner. Never been inside of this store until today. It's okay. I don't think the fruits and vegetables are the best but they'll do in a time crunch (because the store is located near the house) but I would prefer Safeway for fruits, vegetables and possibly meats. Prices are average - specials on some things but nothing out there that makes this store stand out.

My first visit was decent, but didn't quite live up to my expectations.

I food just wasn't that good for a steakhouse. Neither my wife and I cared for our appetizer. We got the Fire-Grilled Fresh Artichoke. They say it is a popular choice, but I didn't like it at all. My burger was very plain and lacked good taste. It made me wish I had gone to Five Guys instead. My wife got the steak and thought it was OK, but later she ended up getting sick. She ordered off the gluten-free menu as she has sensitivities, so this place may have issues with cross-contamination.

One positive was our friendly server. Cassie was excellent and we were very pleased because we rarely get good service when we go out. She kept up with refills and offered to replace anything we didn't like. I also wrote about my visit and explained how I didn't like the food. The manager said he would send us a coupon, so I can appreciate that they are reaching out to their customers.

I got good vibes from sitting at the restaurant. I like their tables and seats. I think I will give it a second chance, but the food has to be better if they want to win me over as a customer.

We were the sole patrons present within the establishment during a Sunday afternoon, which I found rather peculiar subsequent to my acquaintance's effusive praise of this venue. Our culinary selections were served with such haste that it would have been impossible for the staff to prepare them via microwaving and plating, leading me to surmise that all dishes were pre-prepared. While the flavors were passable, the chicken contained an excessive amount of osseous material, and the deep-fried pork was so rigid that it nearly caused me to chip my tooth enamel. I pondered whether this manner of preparation was customary among Cuban cuisine enthusiasts.

Parking facilities are situated at the rear of the building. It is imperative that you secure your vehicle and refrain from traversing the surrounding area unaccompanied.

I would consider revisiting the establishment, but I would endeavor to select an item from the menu that they might prepare fresh, without resorting to pre-cooking or reheating. I awarded them three stars due to their hospitable demeanor, proficiency in both English and Spanish, and their success in avoiding the induction of gastrointestinal discomfort.

"Is this venue currently closed, or merely undergoing revitalization efforts? I have visited this establishment on multiple occasions for lunch, and my culinary experiences have led me to the conclusion that the barbacoa torta is, without a doubt, the most exceptional item on the menu. While I have sampled other offerings, such as the breakfast burrito, I must admit that the balance of potato to chorizo was somewhat lacking, particularly given the cost and dimensions of the dish."

"Culinary offerings at this establishment were inventive and flavorsome, with appetizer portions being reasonable in terms of both price and quality. However, main courses fell short in terms of portion size, with prices ranging from $6-10 higher than expected. Notwithstanding, the bread provided was dry, albeit suitable as a light accompaniment to the meal. The wine selection boasted an impressive variety, catering to diverse tastes. While not exceptional compared to eateries in prominent food cities like Portland, this restaurant serves as a valuable addition to the local dining scene in Chandler and Sun Lakes. Although not particularly busy on a Friday evening, it remains uncertain whether patrons perceive the dinner options as overpriced, warranting further assessment for long-term success. Despite its unconventional strip mall location, the ambiance remained pleasant."

Some of the best cocktails in town. Only downside is some bartenders make them better than others. Love the mojitos! Reasonable prices. Nice decor. Nice crowd. Nice music. I went for brunch and had a lobster omelette.. I found it had a bit too many different flavors for my taste, but I'm sure others would love it, as I'm kind of picky. The guava mimosa wasn't too good though.

I'm upgrading to 3 stars because the service is awesome.  Of course, there was about a 1:1 ratio server to guests so....

This place is not doing very well so I do feel bad, however, there are some obvious reasons.  The prices are very high and the portions are not very big.  So for the amount of food you get, the items are very overpriced.  Burgers, skewers, sandwiches and salads are all around 10, pizzas between 10-15.  Everything is a la carte and you get about 3 appetizer size skewers for the entrees.  Appetizers are about 10 as well, and desserts are 7 even with the option to add ice cream for 1.  

I will say the burgers are better than the Grind - they actually stay together!  (the bun falls apart easily at the Grind and makes eating hard after a couple bites).  The fries were good ($5).  The pork skewers were passable but nothing special.  The Dorito potato skins were nothing special - just had a wedge of cheesy chip stuck in the middle of it.  The cupcake was good, but the chocolate was a little grainy.  Very small portion for that one..

All in all, I probably won't go back for anything but happy hour - for the burgers.

What a little surprise in the heart of Verdun..

We heard of this place through a friend, and having had authentic spectacular Persian food before, I was quite skeptical. However, Parisa did not disappoint!

Their house soup was really something special (minus the random noodles that seemed out of place).

We had the sauteed mushrooms to start - I expected them to be sweeter, but they were quite good!

We then had the lamb (AMAZING) and the chicken drumsticks (not bad) as our main dish.

The service was great, the host was super friendly, and the atmosphere was nice and quiet. 

For a BYOW place, it's definitely a nice place to go. Try it, and definitely do not miss out on the soup! Super good!

After perusing the menu at this establishment on multiple occasions, I decided to partake in their culinary offerings, primarily due to the copious amount of laudatory reviews I had encountered. Upon consuming my meal, I found the flavors to be quite satisfactory, however, my companion did not share my enthusiasm. It is worth mentioning that this restaurant does not possess an air conditioning system, which resulted in a rather uncomfortable dining experience for me, as I was perspiring profusely throughout my visit.

"Although this establishment may not exude an extravagant ambiance, it nevertheless possesses an acceptable level of quality. Upon arriving with a group of twelve, we had the foresight to reserve a table in advance, thereby avoiding any unnecessary delays. Our server, a consummate professional, exhibited remarkable proficiency in catering to our diverse needs, deftly navigating the numerous requests and preferences expressed by various members of our party. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to the high standards set by the exceptional service. Specifically, my potatoes were overcooked to an unfortunate degree, while the flavor profile of the sausage deviated somewhat from the expected norm. Additionally, my omelette displayed a peculiar texture that could be described as rubbery. Thus, while the service we received was truly commendable, the food itself fell short of our expectations."

Decent bar, nice patio though it can be loud on E-Wash.  Good place to relax with a nice beer however I was disappointed they did not have more Belgians after being places like Brasserie V.  It would fit well with the decent bars on Willy street, but has the bonus of being porn-shop adjacent.

"The ambiance of this establishment is truly captivating. The interior design exudes an aura of elegance and sophistication, with subtle lighting that creates an atmosphere of refined intimacy. The seating arrangements are ergonomically designed to provide maximum comfort, allowing patrons to unwind and relax in style. The musical selection presented by the disc jockey on the evening in question was diverse and engaging, albeit the volume level was slightly excessive for a venue of this nature, thereby creating a slight hindrance to effective communication between patrons seated at a distance from one another. However, the outdoor seating area provided a tranquil respite from the sonic intensity within, offering ample opportunities for observation and appreciation of the surrounding environment."

I often stop in this place when Im at Tempe Marketplace to get a drink and relax.  They usually have some decent drink specials and they have a nice big bar.  The bartenders usually take a little effort to order from, not really sure why that is, maybe I just have bad luck.

Hmmm I am American and I grew up in the NYC area, so I am fairly confident that I know good Italian food when I taste it.  I am not saying that the food isn't good, but it definitely did not blow me away.  We came here because it was listed as a Top 10 Best Restaurant in Edinburgh, according to The Guardian and I definitely would not rate this in my top 10.

However, with that being said, the service was fantastic.  Our servers were all very friendly and attentive.  The portions here are enormous and we did feel that they mislead us into ordering more food than we needed because we did ask if the starters were big enough to shared and they recommended that we order two.  Both plates were huge and we certainly could have just shared one between the two of us.  Not to mention the entrees were enough for 2-3 people to share.  So come hungry!

Ambiance has a little bit of a corny feel but also reminded me a lot of any Italian spot in suburban New York / New Jersey, in the sense that there was Frank Sinatra playing in the background the entire time and the servers were a little over the top trying to prove their Italian-ness (actual, and not the macho mobster Guido kind we see over here in the States).

"In the previous fortnight, I have visited this establishment on two separate occasions, seeking medical attention for distinct health concerns. Initially, I sustained a fracture of my coccyx (tail bone), owing to my own foolhardy actions. Following a brief waiting period, I received prompt and comprehensive care. Dr. Guy demonstrated proficiency in managing my situation, requesting an immediate radiograph and subsequently discussing my results, available options, and methods of pain relief. One's appreciation for a particular bodily component is often realized only when it becomes injured, leaving one utterly debilitated and experiencing excruciating pain.  

On a separate occasion, I experienced intense, sporadic abdominal pain. Due to its proximity to my residence, I opted to visit this clinic, necessitating urgent medical attention. Presenting with visible signs of distress, including pallor, trembling, and uncontrollable sobbing, I was surprised by the facility's inability to accommodate me due to an excessive patient load. Considering the gravity of my symptoms, it would have been more appropriate for a physician to tend to my needs temporarily, offering some measure of pain alleviation as I awaited transfer to the emergency department.  

Despite the subpar nature of my most recent encounter, I shall continue to seek medical assistance at this location when necessary. However, the aforementioned experience has illuminated the fact that, in extraordinary situations involving a person's health and well-being, this clinic may not be willing to adapt their policies."

I don't hate it. 
I don't love it. 
I'm very blah about it.


Initially wanted to come here after seeing pictures on Instagram. I was super excited as I was hoping for snow like that from Hawaii snow places, like Snow Factory or Frost City.

My friends and I had #3, #4, #5 respectively. I don't like the "popping pearls" in my #5 so, I replaced it with butterfinger.

I'd like to say it was similar in texture being kind of creamy but, they need to improve on their flavors. I got to samps the taro, green tea, and "kuma snow" (whatever flavor that it) and it was whatever......it quenched my thirst in this heat we're having.
I'd like to see more variety ---- I'm thinking of the variety that Snow Ono food/shave ice truck had --- I miss horchata flavor, I guess.

I loved how the decor is all bright and cute. Tryna get the whole Asian-kawaii market. I mean, that's what got me.....very Instagram worthy pics outta here.

Overall, I'll be back. Businesses tend to get better in time ***cross fingers*** 
I wanna bring more people so we can "samps" more things; this way I don't base this review on just 3 flavors.

"It is my understanding that this establishment has garnered a certain level of notoriety, and thus, I felt compelled to partake in a visitation to said venue.  My attendance was precipitated by a philanthropic endeavor in support of a local elementary educational institution.  Upon entering the premises, I couldn't help but notice the stark similarity between this skating rink and those that I frequented during my own childhood in the 1980s.  It remains unclear whether any substantive improvements have been effectuated since that time period.  During the evening of my visit, the ambient temperature within the facility seemed to be rather elevated, almost unbearably so, and was further exacerbated by an unmistakable odor reminiscent of a gymnasium locker room.  However, I must admit that the prices charged at the concession stand were quite reasonable, the musical selections being played were contemporary and engaging, and all of the patrons, spanning multiple generations, appeared to be thoroughly enjoying themselves.  Additionally, it is worth noting that this establishment accommodates individuals who prefer the use of roller blades featuring a single row of wheels, and offers a modest discount for such patrons.  Thus, if one is seeking an authentic, nostalgia-inducing skating experience, devoid of modernistic updates, then perhaps a visit to this venue would be worth considering."

"An establishment that offered a satisfactory ambiance, with a culinary experience that met our expectations. Upon entering, we were greeted by an atmosphere that exuded cleanliness and warmth. Our meal began with the clear egg rolls accompanied by a delectable peanut sauce, a staple dish that we often indulge in when partaking in Vietnamese cuisine. The flavors were adequately represented, without surpassing our expectations. Subsequently, we opted for the combo pho soup, which presented generous proportions and a commendable execution. Although the broth lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it was reminiscent of fish sauce, mint, and other indispensable components. One might argue that the soup catered to American palates, with a subtle spiciness that left room for personal adjustments. However, for those seeking a more genuine experience, a more robust foundation would be necessary. The menu, though limited, helped avoid the paradox of choice, but we couldn't help but feel that certain Vietnamese delicacies were absent. The staff provided friendly and efficient service, contributing to an overall positive experience. We may consider revisiting this establishment in the future, curious to witness its evolution."

We organized a farewell celebration for a departing colleague at this establishment, and I must admit that the service we received was quite satisfactory, particularly considering the size of our group, which consisted of 16 individuals and one minor. The avocado-based dip, commonly known as guacamole, was quite palatable, and I was particularly fond of the spicy salsa that they offer upon request. However, the fruit-based alcoholic beverage known as sangria was excessively sweetened, although the house margarita served on the rocks was somewhat more agreeable. The culinary offerings were rather unremarkable; I consumed some uninspired chicken enchiladas that, while not necessarily unpalatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Nonetheless, my most enjoyable experience of the evening was visiting the Trader Joe's store located within the same retail complex after our meal.

The view is amazing for 360 degrees... The ambiance is quite chill and the DJ on Friday night is decent. Mostly top 40 and EDM infused mixes playing through the speakers. 

The late happy hour is only for food and the reason this place gets a couple of stars knocked out of the sky is because of the service and the food that is served. The buns on the sliders were hard enough to break a window on impact and the calamari was soggy (probably microwaved for happy hour). It also took forever for the waitress to make her way around to us. I could have taken the stairs to level 0, walk to the liquor store and walk back up the stairs to Level 107 before she came back with our order. 

This place has a lot of potential, it just needs a facelift in a few places. The view is main reason this gets 3 stars.

The people here are super friendly and nice. Yhe reason I gave only three stars is one their liquid flavors was missing somethin.  I think if they remixed a few  flavors it would be a little better. And the second reason is that their liquid is pricey. Like 21 bucks for one bottle.

Heard A LOT of good things about this place but somehow I don't seem what all the good rants about this place where. I came with high expectations due to the fact that friends and colleagues have fervently extolled its virtues, yet ultimately, it failed to meet my elevated standards in Las Vegas. We arrived at approximately 1 pm, thereby falling within the parameters of brunch time. The menu primarily consisted of breakfast fare, complemented by a smattering of salads and other lunch options. However, what truly piqued my interest was their delectable chicken wings, savory saian chow mein, and crispy fried rice, the rich alfredo pasta, and the flavorful calamari skewer. Unfortunately, everything else paled in comparison to my gastronomic inclinations. As a self-proclaimed dessert aficionado, I eagerly indulged in the dessert bar, but found only a select few offerings aesthetically pleasing and gustatorily satisfying. The chocolate-dipped strawberries, creamy cheesecake, and velvety Thai ice cream were my standout favorites from the entire assortment! THE THAI TEA ICE CREAM IS THE ONLY REASON WHY I GAVE THEM AN EXTRA STAR! It is an absolute must-try for all my fellow Thai tea enthusiasts out there! In conclusion, a run-of-the-mill buffet for roughly $30 per person, with a merely passable culinary experience, redeemed only by the exceptional Thai tea ice cream.
= = = = = =  CLOSED  = = = = = =\n\nSorry to see Him's JL close.  I liked the place.     :-(

"A pleasant and hygienic smorgasbord, proffering an abundance of accommodations for patrons. Although I did not object to the tariff of thirteen dollars per individual, my satisfaction was somewhat diminished upon discovering that an extensive array of porcine delicacies constituted a significant portion of the offerings. As I am not particularly enamored with swinish cuisine, I might opt to expend my resources elsewhere in the future, perhaps at Buffet@asia, where a greater diversity of options, including an increased emphasis on seafood and Mongolian barbecue, is available."

My wife and I were roaming the industrial and business park area of Phoenix looking for a decent bite to eat, preferably Mexican food. We finally stumbled upon a set of about five Mexican eateries. We decided on Salsitas, which seems to be a chain in the Valley of The Sun.

I wished that the woman had done a better job of speaking and understanding English. The food order was correct, and plentiful, not to mention cheap, but we had specifically asked for forks and were not given any. I had to go to our hotel's front deck and beg the clerk for a couple of plastic forks. 

The burrito was huge and very tasty. I had a couple of Grilled Chicken mini-tacos, and while they were pretty good, they were nothing special and I even found a few pieces of gristle. My wife had a chicken burrito and said it was huge and very good. She could not finish it. They also gave us some hot carrots so that scored well with her.

Ten bucks for all of that, including four salsas and sour cream. Not bad, but I'd like to try more.

Its an ok place... I wouldnt reeeeeeeally go here if we weren't invited with a table. The place is very small which would be great if there wouldn't be 200 people cramped on 2squaremeters. I felt like I was in China or subway in NYC. At least the people smelled good, unlike NYC subway. A lot of fake plastic chickerias running around there. Hard to guess their age so I felt comftable, being only 27 myself of course.
The drinks are EXPENSIVE!! I got us 3 shots since I didnt feel like some metrosexual spikedhairguy buying me drinks, and I can afford my own. Well... it was 36$, yes you read right, for 3!! shots. I asked where the diamonds are cause I couldnt find them in there.
I wrote on the slip too that " I aint no rich bitch " under gratidue. SORRY bartender dude. But with these prices you should get the novel price.
Oh well, its still fun. Make sure you PRE BOOZE heavily or bring a dude along that has a platinum credit card.

This is your perfect place to bring someone after going out.
Instead of going to macdonald or some fast food joint this place is cheaper,healthier and quicker than any fast food store.
Plus you can grab something for breakfast the next day.
No matter what time i go i always see people baking fresh bagel.
I'm more of a conservative guy so i usually take sesame bagel or butter bagel.
Hope this help,

Cheers,

Eric Van Nguyen

As Demetria so astutely observed, this establishment tends to be somewhat inconsistent in the quality of its offerings, with a tendency towards both excellence and disappointment. For optimal culinary experiences, it is advisable to arrive promptly, as the most delectable items often disappear rapidly. The fried chicken, when cooked to perfection, is undoubtedly a highlight, although it occasionally suffers from overcooking or dryness. The six-cheese spaghetti is also a commendable option, but its quality can vary depending on the preparation method. The abundance of sides offers numerous choices, including mac-n-cheese, which, much like the aforementioned chicken and spaghetti, may occasionally be overcooked, resulting in a less than satisfactory dining experience. However, the blackeyed peas and cornbread consistently impress, and their lemonade, arguably the finest in Charlotte, has garnered high praise. A word of caution regarding the volunteers who handle beverage refills: they are renowned for their warmth and generosity, and a adept diner may even secure an additional portion of mac-n-cheese through skillful banter. It is essential to display gratitude via a gratuity at the register. Fare thee well, my friend.

"Cautionary statement: This evaluation is predominantly grounded on the parameters of service and informational proficiency, rather than culinary offerings. We visited this establishment during happy hour and, while intending to confer four stars, a deduction of one star was necessitated due to the absence of communication regarding seating arrangements for said happy hour. Specifically, we were not apprised of the fact that happy hour seating was exclusive to the bar and adjacent bench. Furthermore, our ignorance was not alleviated by inquiring about the protocol, as we were informed to occupy any vacant seat of our preference. Notably, by the time of our departure, a sole couple remained, and they too were oblivious to the proper seating arrangement, thereby resulting in their failure to capitalize on the discounted prices.  

Our culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, with a few notable exceptions. The red sangria was unremarkable, while the lamb, though flavorsome, was diminutive and overpriced. The croquettes were uninspired, whereas the Patatas Bravas, essentially roasted potatoes enrobed in a tomato-based sauce, was straightforward yet gratifying. The total cost of our repast, excluding gratuity, approximated $60, with an additional $20 expended unnecessarily due to our unawareness of the happy hour stipulations. A comprehensive examination of the menu revealed that several items we ordered were available at a reduced rate had we been seated at the bar."

This interior setting exudes an aesthetic appeal that is quintessentially modern, and I must say, I was thoroughly entertained by the metamorphosis that the proprietors undertook to transform this architectural gem into a space that can accommodate a diverse array of patrons. 
  My experience at the alternative venue was somewhat diminished by the presence of a rowdy clientele, but I must admit that the ambiance was quite captivating. Notwithstanding the challenges posed by the limited parking options, the valet service was quite efficient. 
  Upon arriving at the establishment on a Friday afternoon, I was eager to commemorate a friend's birthday. We indulged in several appetizers, specifically The Trifecta, Double Down, and Crabmeat and Artichoke Dip, which were delectable, to say the least. Our server was attentive, ensuring that our needs were met and even keeping us informed about the happy hour specials. 
  As the clock approached 5 pm, the atmosphere within the establishment became increasingly lively, with a large contingent of middle-aged gentlemen converging upon the premises, fresh from a golf outing. Despite the influx of patrons, the ambiance remained laid-back and welcoming, with a healthy mix of mature and youthful clientele. 
  The abundance of televisions scattered throughout the venue ensured that there was always something engaging to observe. Although the enclosed patio area was slightly more boisterous, our group was vociferous regardless, and there was ample space to move around without feeling confined or inconveniencing fellow patrons. Thus far, I have had the pleasure of partaking in a single happy hour visit; however, I eagerly anticipate experiencing the culinary delights offered during dinner hours.

I would assign The Green Owl a rating of 4 to 5 stars in relation to the culinary aspect of their offerings, but regrettably, their service falls short, leading to a decrease in their overall evaluation. In conjunction with my romantic partner, I had the pleasure of dining at this establishment last week. Following our seating, it required some time to hail the attention of our server, thus impeding our ability to place our order in a timely manner. We opted to share an order of crabby cakes, while my companion selected a bowl of chili complemented by sour cream and cornbread, and I chose the "meatball" sub, accompanied by kale chips as a side dish. The crabby cakes were served promptly, enveloped in a delectable creamy sauce, which we devoured instantaneously. Noteworthily, my companion, who habitually consumes meat and eschews tofu, relished these dishes. Our server informed us that our main courses would arrive shortly after presenting the crabby cakes. However, our food did not materialize for an additional 40 minutes, during which our server failed to provide any updates or explanations for the delay. Despite this setback, the quality of the food remained impressive. My sandwich was delivered scorching hot, with a crunchy bread roll and flavorful eggplant meatballs that maintained their texture within the sandwich. Unfortunately, the price point of $6 for an average-sized portion proved too prohibitive for me to indulge in a dessert. Notwithstanding the deficiencies in service, I harbor the intention of revisiting the Green Owl, as my curiosity lingers regarding numerous menu items that pique my interest.

the food was alright but definitely cost more than it should.  we went for a quick lunch and the service was alright too but the food was not up to par with your typical vegas food.  btw don't get the kim chee, not good.

Came here because Oregano's was packed on a Saturday night.  I wonder how many of their customers are in the same boat.  I was initially craving Mexican food anyway, so I didn't care.  

The service is awesome, the beer was so cold it was almost icy (read: awesome) and the salsa is yummy yummy.  I ordered the specialty chimichanga and my mom got rolled tacos.  The plates were hu-hu-hu-huge.  And can I just say that cream cheese makes everything better, especially chimichangas.  YUM.  

Not the best Mexican joint I have ever been to, but definitely decent enough to visit again (for the locals).
I went on a hip hop night and not  much hip hop was played. However, it was still a good time there.

This sushi restaurant has fresh fish and is the best I've found for a reasonable price in the valley (This coming from an east coast foodie who LOVES sushi.) However, the service is bad more often than it is good and NEVER go here in a hurry. I've never made it out of there in less than an hour. Once I went in there and asked for an itemized check, it took them 25 minutes to bring the check back AND it still wasnt itemized. In fact, I still don't know what it was. I love their sushi but its about time for me to find a new sushi restaurant after how many times I've had waitresses be rude and even ignore me. \n\nTheir redeeming quality that kept me coming back so long was their happy hour prices Sunday-Thursday. Its a lot of sushi for a small cost. So if you have plenty of time and don't mind a bad waiter or two check it out!

Decent store with knowledgeable staff but the prices are a bit higher than other stores. One employee recommended a collar that really helped with our dog that was a puller.

Everyone is friendly. There is a huge selection of many things for many pets. The prices are not bad but a touch high.

But Banfield. Don't do it. Avoid them. My aunt had awful experiences with "the plan" for their old dog. She was pressured into expensive treatments, they would sometimes not do ones she wanted, and it wasn't exactly cheap. Our experience was the same. We bought 1 year to try it, and canceling took a few tries. They pressured us to do more than we normally would have. And the "savings" included hundreds of dollars in services that most people would not buy.

Come here to get your pet some exercise in the summer. Get food, litter, check sale prices, visit the partnered pet rescue people, maybe grab a treat or toy for your pet. But Banfield felt even higher pressure than our last car purchase.

-Note* Review is for casino/shops/ pool area only. 

I don't love it nor do I hate it.

Shops: They have a new renovated shops it looks great and clean.  I would probably only enter the Urban Outfitters store. 
Pool: I love the beach pool they have going on. They have the waves and sands in their pool.  I always have a great time here and it is never too packed here which I like. 
Casino: It's pretty self-explanatory. All casinos in las vegas is very similar. I do love they have these chandeliers in the ceilings, it is a very nice touch.  

Overall: The casino is clean and pretty much okay.  I don't mind coming here or passing through the casino.  They offer a lot of great restaurant and they have the house of blues. Families can have a great time here and can even check out the Shark Reef in this hotel.

"An ideal location in Las Vegas to host one's parents, offering delectable cuisine, albeit at a slightly elevated cost. However, considering the city's reputation for extravagance, it would be unwise to compromise on fiscal constraints. The menu presented an intriguing array of options, yet the dishes did not possess an exceptionally unique flavor profile. Rather, they constituted a fundamental American breakfast with subtle variations here and there. The service was efficient, and we were accommodated in a timely manner (although a notable queue began to form around the peak period for brunch)."

"While the interior may benefit from some modernization, the culinary offerings are undeniably satisfactory. However, I find it somewhat problematic to be charged for supplementary hash browns and an English muffin, particularly when the portion size has diminished, resulting in a higher cost for a relatively reduced quantity of sustenance. Notwithstanding, US Egg remains a reliable establishment, albeit one that may not necessarily warrant being showcased to others as a prime dining destination."

The Chilenita they have the best empanada in town. It's a great place to take out or sit down for lunch. The staff is friendly. The food is so good. The price is affordable. There no other place that has 13 different empanada's to choose from. I love the Chilenita.

Food is average with sandwiches being $8-$10.  Had a burger with Pork Barbecue on it and onion straws and an iced tea for about $14.  Little pricey at lunch.  Surprised there was only 1 bartender/waitress for the whole bar area, but she did a good job managing it.  There were probably 20 people at the bar.  The restaurant has a bunch of TV's on sports or trivia.  The restaurant was crowded which is probably due to its location in the USX building.

We visited Red Lobster for lunch at approximately 2:00 PM, and although the establishment was moderately occupied, we were promptly accommodated with a table.  All three of us opted for the Endless Shrimp promotion, which offered an assortment of diverse flavors.  While the dishes were undoubtedly palatable, they failed to elicit any extraordinary praise or excitement.  The service, though not characterized by excessive haste, did not hinder our dining experience.  The staff members exhibited unwavering politeness and cordiality throughout our visit.  At a cost of $57.00 for three lunch specials, the total surpassed my customary expenditure in a locality renowned for its affordable cuisine.  Nonetheless, the charge was not entirely unexpected given the restaurant's reputation for quality seafood.  Ultimately, our dining experience merited a rating of "A-OK," denoting a satisfactory and enjoyable meal.

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment are generally of superior quality, my recent dining experience was marred by a number of unfortunate incidents that detracted from my overall satisfaction. Specifically, my pork kebab contained an excessive amount of cartilaginous material, which made it difficult to consume with any degree of pleasure. Furthermore, I was forced to wait an inordinate amount of time for both my beverage and dipping sauce, which only served to exacerbate my frustration. In light of these issues, I would suggest that patrons who value a seamless dining experience may wish to consider alternative options."
The locations in phoenix have chicken we can add to our meal. This location does not. We drove an extra 10 minutes to get here  to find out they don't have chicken was not a pleasant surprise.

Food is good, service is bad.  Have been here twice...both times our order was screwed up.  The second time we received no apology.  Wait staff is reactive instead of proactive.  Food is decent but expect more for the money.  I really wanted to like this place but I have been given too many reasons to go elsewhere.

Food is unique and tasty. Try the ultimate grilled cheese.  Service is poor. Three employees hang around at a table in the bar area chatting while the cook is preparing my food,  lunch came out wonderful but the front of house staff needs to find something to do and pay attention to a the few customers that are in there. I stopped in today at 1 for lunch but they changed their hours they are not open until 3 o'clock weekdays. I feel this place is going to close down quite soon. Prices for pool during promo hours are great.

my best friends girlfriend came for a visit from austin, being an architecture major, this was a place we obviously had to go.\n\nbeing there was obviously amazing... here's my beef... a tour was between $30-$80, seriously.  there was no way we could afford this obnoxious fee so we walked around the house and checked out the gift shop. we were pleased with this, but pretty disappointed not to take the tour.

This culinary establishment constitutes one of our most cherished destinations for a brief gastronomic interlude, especially when we possess Aria resort credits that necessitate expenditure. My personal predilection at this venue formerly consisted of procuring an assortment of baked items and chocolates for my acquaintances and loved ones back home (I have always been particularly fond of the bear claw). However, I have recently opted to sample their crepes, which I find quite delectable. We devoured a savory crepe filled with ham, cheese, and sauteed mushrooms, accompanied by a side dish consisting of leafy greens and diminutive tomatoes. Our preferred dessert crepe contains a filling of vanilla custard cream, topped with a mixture of berries in the form of a rich sauce. The queues at this eatery tend to be rather lengthy whenever I visit, yet the staff manages to process the clientele with remarkable efficiency. Although the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the quality of the cuisine and the overall experience justify the cost.

Can't understand why this place is always so packed. Well actually, the sound system is probably the best out of any club on mill. So that part I liked. There is room to breathe once you make it to the pool tables, but it's a battle to get there in the first place. There is a good amount of tables. Overall, so so. But I'll visit another time for further review.
Very colorful, especially if you want to smoke weed surrounded by a bunch of weirdos playing African drums...other than that it is rather boring

After perusing an array of favorable critiques, my spouse and I elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to her inclination towards consumng Indian cuisine.  This eatery does not boast an extensive capacity, and its format is predicated upon a buffet-style service.  The Mother's Day special included a delectable mango lassi and a dolsa, which consists of a rolled-up pancake containing a lentil filling. 
  The chilled bar presented an assortment of various chutneys, a salad, some fruit, and additional sauces.  Additionally, there were three distinct types of soup available: a tomato soup with a tangy flavor profile, a lentil-based soup, and a piquant soup. 
  This restaurant showcases a diverse array of traditional Indian dishes.  The goat curry particularly stood out to my taste buds, as the meat was tender and easily detached from the bone, complemented by a richly flavored curry sauce.  Furthermore, the tandoori chicken was cooked to perfection, retaining its natural moisture and avoiding the common pitfall of dryness often associated with this dish at other establishments.  The paneer sag (a spinach and cheese dish) also demonstrated notable quality. 
  Although vegetarian options were present, my carnivorous inclinations led me to ignore them.  Ultimately, this dining experience provided me with a satisfying introduction to Indian cuisine without overwhelming my palate with excessively spicy fare, thereby solidifying this restaurant's standing as a respectable venue in my opinion.

"It is utterly perplexing to comprehend the grounds upon which numerous individuals base their expectations when patronizing establishments serving rapid culinary fare, as the quality of the consumables and the demeanor of the personnel are often subjective and variable factors; however, in this particular instance, my associates and I opted to sample the wares of this eatery, utilizing a promotional coupon to facilitate our indulgence in an array of menu items. Upon entering the premises, we encountered a hospitable staff who exhibited great alacrity in providing us with an assortment of comestibles, including the signature beverages and sundry accompaniments. Our gastronomical excursion proved to be a gratifying experience, as the lactose-based drinks were indeed remarkable, and my companions expressed unanimous approbation for the savory patties comprised of bovine flesh. Furthermore, we discovered that the cylindrical tubers, although ostensibly the most sought-after item, were surpassed in palatability by the slender, crispy fries."

UltraStar is new to the Phoenix area. It has a spacious lobby with all the warmth of a airplane hanger. Its corporate vibe is immediately apparent in every aspect of the consumer experience. One can almost sense the calculated, committee-approved decision making that dominates the theatre. \nThe concession stand and gourmet coffee bar must seem amusing to Europeans. The seating area has little ambiance and is certainly not a place I'd spend any time hanging out. Boring.\nThe theatre I viewed the film in was serviceable, but nothing outstanding comes to mind. The film started on time. The UltraStar management really would benefit from a visit to a Harkins theatre to get this whole thing 'figured out.'

"Satisfactory victuals and the customary servers are occupied but vigilant.  The greenery-based dishes are palatable, yet caution is advised regarding their preparation time, as they tend to require an equally prolonged duration, if not more, compared to other menu items to arrive at your table.  The poultry strips are delectable, and reports suggest that the wraps are exceptional. 

Beyond that, the remaining options are passable but not remarkable.  The potato-based soup is quite tasty, but avoid ordering it with excessive frequency, as it is featured as the daily special approximately 90% of the time. 

A suitable alternative when seeking a respite from fast food in the central business district or desiring something beyond a simple sandwich."

While the restaurant itself was nice and the staff was also very nice the food was nothing that I can say was truly amazing. We were expecting a very 5 star experience when it came to the food and we were surprised when the food came out just a few minutes after we ordered. Most everyone in our party thought the food was average, nothing to right home about. We have a restaurant near us called Frida Mexican Restaurant in Glendale,CA and there food is much much better. On the bright side I did order the Nachos and this seem to be the hit on the table So much so that everyone started munching away at my food \n\nSo heres the deal for me, I am always looking for amazing Mexican Food, something above and beyond what I can expect living in Los Angeles. Diego was not it for me, Great looking place, Friendly Staff, with So-So Food.

Let me start by saying that I LOVE the food and flavor combinations at Layers. Also on the fabulous list is that it's organic :). I have been a fan since this new location opened. However, (and this is why I rated only 3 stars, they used to be 5 in my book) I have been disappointed the last few visits. The baked goods remain awesome, but the \"kitchen\" food isn't as amazing these days. Last time, the pasta has far too much oil which knocked off the entire dish. This time I went for the meatloaf sandwich, The Conservative, and while the flavor combo of yummy meatloaf and carmelized onions snuggled together in a panini were a hit - the presentation was a mess. The bread was so broken and soggy that it really had no business being called a sandwich because I could not pick it up. Had to eat with a fork and knife. I've had this sandwich, or a similar one in the past (when the store opened) and had much more success in getting it from the plate to my mouth in a ladylike fashion.  Maybe the bread was different?  Possibly the chef was different?  Something has changed....\nTo clarify, I would not discourage anyone from ordering anything off the menu, but I just know that Layers can do better than I have recently experienced.  I hope that they will strive for their best because they are one of my favorites!

Surely ensure that they are cognizant of your time-sensitive predicament, provided you are indeed in a state of hastiness. It is utterly lamentable that despite my preemptive efforts to communicate explicit instructions (specifically requesting that the three dozen bialys be encased in plastic bags, as I intended to compactly store them within my luggage), an unfortunate oversight transpired, wherein the bialys were not adequately prepared, thus necessitating the taxi to await my presence, resulting in an augmented financial burden of $72 for a mere 39 bialys, inclusive of the taxi fare.

"Have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on two separate occasions, and upon conducting a cursory examination of the menu, it appeared that the options available remained relatively consistent between visits, although, I must admit, my culinary explorations were temporarily suspended due to a fleeting sense of uncertainty regarding the quality of the dishes, which, in hindsight, proved to be an unfounded concern, as the staff, who displayed an unwavering commitment to ensuring our satisfaction, greeted us with warm smiles and offered their assistance in Tagalog, regardless of our proficiency in the language, thereby creating a welcoming ambiance reminiscent of a familial gathering, and, furthermore, the delectable aroma of the pork gisantes and the flavorsome pancit left me in a state of gastronomical delight, all for the reasonable price of $7.99 per individual, and, as an added convenience, an assortment of tantalizing treats and snacks were available for purchase at the register, thus, making it an ideal destination for future family outings, with honorable mentions extending to the savory pusit and diniguan (dinardaraan), and, while the parking situation may appear somewhat peculiar, owing to the one-way entrance, I found that securing a parking spot was a straightforward process, albeit requiring a modicum of vigilance to ensure entry through the appropriate entrance."

"Upon perusing Yelp in pursuit of a novel culinary experience, I chanced upon this establishment and decided to pay it a visit. Upon entering, I was struck by the diverse array of fresh, authentic Poke available, which exceeded my expectations and piqued my interest. Furthermore, I appreciated the opportunity to sample the various options prior to making a purchase, which allowed me to make an informed decision.
