Eventually, I opted for the spicy avocado ahi, which proved to be a satisfying choice, boasting a subtle yet palpable level of spiciness that complemented the dish without overpowering it. Indeed, this meal served as the sole sustenance for my midday repast, and I must say that I was thoroughly pleased with my decision to patronize this unassuming eatery. Despite its unpretentious appearance, this venue offers a truly delightful Poke experience that is not to be missed."

After an afternoon of recreation at the nearby park, I returned home feeling famished and disinclined towards consuming the customary cuisine offered on East Boulevard; thus, I opted to venture forth to Thai Taste, a local eatery renowned for its authentic Thai culinary delights. Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the traditional Thai decor that permeated the interior space, fostering a warm and welcoming ambiance that, albeit quaint, did not feel overly cramped or congested, even during a presumably off-peak dining period. 
  The menu presented itself in a straightforward fashion, allowing patrons to select their preferred entrÃ©e and combine it with a choice of meat, thereby tailoring their dining experience according to individual preferences. In my case, I opted for the green curry, which, when prepared with chicken, promised to deliver a flavor profile characterized by a harmonious balance between the pungency of fresh green chilies and the richness of coconut milk. Unfortunately, the execution of this particular dish fell short of my expectations, as the green curry, while boasting an undeniably aromatic quality, lacked the requisite level of piquancy typically associated with such a preparation. However, in light of favorable reviews pertaining to the establishment's culinary offerings, I am inclined to attribute this shortcoming to a momentary lapse in the kitchen and intend to revisit Thai Taste in the near future, during which time I shall insist upon an extra-hot rendition of the green curry, thereby affording me the opportunity to sample the dish in its optimal form. 
  The prices charged by Thai Taste are eminently reasonable, and the attentive nature of the service afforded me a constant supply of replenished water, a considerate touch that did not go unappreciated. In a timely fashion, my meal arrived, and I relished every bite, ultimately departing the premises satiated and content. Based on my positive experience, I would unhesitatingly recommend Thai Taste to aficionados of Thai cuisine seeking a satisfying dining experience in Charlotte, and, indeed, I look forward to returning in order to sample their Pad Thai, in addition to a more fiery green curry.

"While it may appear unremarkable at first glance, a closer inspection of The House of Blues reveals a multifaceted venue that offers an immersive experience for music enthusiasts. Although primarily characterized by a predominantly standing-room layout, astute patrons can opt for the indulgence of bottle service or, alternatively, ascend to the balcony to enjoy a more exclusive vantage point. Sonically, the establishment boasts an impressive auditory infrastructure that effectively showcases the performances of both emerging and established artists, thereby ensuring an aural satisfaction that precludes any potential grievances."

Normally I wouldn't bother to write a review for a Pizza Hut. Or even check in on Yelp. Some secrets are best kept in the family. It's Pizza Hut after all. Everyone knows what they're going to get. 

So what's the motivation this time? I noticed some really bad recent reviews for the carry out location I occasionally use. The workers there, however, are consistently nice and really seem to be trying to do a good job given the limitations that Pizza Hut presents. I just wanted to give them a little "thumbs up". 

Three stars, the maximum rating allowed by law for a Pizza Hut.

I've used this restaurant for large dinner parties that were held in their private dining room and they have all been A+ experiences.   This time I made a reservation for 2 in the dining room for a happy birthday dinner.  The restaurant was full and busy and we were seated upon arrival.  Our drink orders were taken promptly but then we waited....

Our waitress took our salad and entree orders and the salad arrived pretty quickly.  She was also assigned to a 10 top table that the chef/owner was hosting so we were ignored by her for the rest of dinner.  We had to flag down the bus person for water refills, asked for additional bread while we waited for our entrees, another request for water refills and a final request for the check.  

The food was okay - I had angel hair with tomato sauce and husband had gnocchi.  Both were good portions and served steaming hot.

D'abord, le bouquet d'\u00e9pices fait acte de pr\u00e9sence. On se souvient de son bouillon, adroitement appr\u00e9ci\u00e9 de clous de girofle, de badianes, de graines de coriandre et de cardamomes. Diverses variantes sur le m\u00eame th\u00e8me. Les Classiques sont plut\u00f4t impersonnelles avec des coupes de viande plus propres et immacul\u00e9es. Les Aventuriers  se prononcent d'une anatomie bovine moins pr\u00e9venante, flancs gras et tripes croustillantes. Si le d\u00e9faut d'asepsie vous emmerde, s'abstenir de la toilette. Je soustrais  une \u00e9toile pour cette raison.
Pasta was good. wine was good. but I cant trust an ITALIAN restaurant that puts Herseys syrup on their tiramisu. Sorry.

I was impelled to visit this establishment due to the fact that I was the fortunate recipient of a complimentary voucher, courtesy of a radio station contest, and I must admit that I would not have opted to partake in this culinary experience had it not been offered gratis.

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed that there was a sampler entrÃ©e/mix grill option available for a mere $70, which included an assortment of delectable cuts, specifically filet, kobe shirt, and a New York cut. Although the Kobe shirt was undoubtedly palatable, it is worth mentioning that I have yet to encounter a less-than-satisfactory cut of Kobe beef, thus rendering its quality somewhat predictable.

Furthermore, I opted to sample their trio of mashed potatoes, which featured an array of distinct flavors, including the tantalizing truffle and lobster variety. While these potatoes were indeed quite delectable, I cannot help but feel that they fell short of exceptional.

In conclusion, taking into account the multitude of superior dining options available, I fear that I would not consider returning to this particular restaurant, despite the occasional availability of complimentary vouchers.

I love their sandwiches but they are VERY over priced AND.... they do not have whole wheat bread.  They were definitely behind the times by not having a whole wheat bread instead of WHITE bread.  Every other sandwich place I know has whole wheat..  Fire House Subs, subway, port of subs, quiznos. etc..\n\nCome on Capriotti's get some damm whole wheat french bread.

"The Mass Transit District (MTD) offers an effective solution for traversing the campus during inclement weather conditions, but it's essential to be cognizant of the fact that the buses tend to operate with a degree of tardiness, hence it's advisable to select a bus that will arrive at your desired destination a few minutes prior to the scheduled time, thereby ensuring a timely arrival. Moreover, it's worth mentioning that MTD buses are complimentary for students, which serves as an added convenience."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."  We have visited this establishment on multiple occasions, and unfortunately, our expectations have not been met.  

The appetizer platter was mediocre, with the mozzarella being the sole redeeming factor.  The bruschetta was overpowered by an excessive amount of pesto, rendering the flavor of the bread insignificant, while the calamari lacked the desired crispiness.  The chicken marsala was unimpressive, with the grilled taste overshadowing the marsala sauce.  The mashed potatoes were satisfactory, but they failed to compensate for the shortcomings of the dish.   It is evident that our preference for pasta at Carrabba's remains unwavering.  

The quality of service, however, has consistently met our expectations.

"It appears that an individual has expressed a sentiment which suggests that the English language is not necessary, and that the individual's nation can adequately function without it. Furthermore, the individual seems to be advocating for the abandonment of the English language in favor of their native tongue. This attitude towards language is not uncommon in certain parts of the world, where there is a strong emphasis on preserving cultural heritage and promoting linguistic diversity. However, it is worth considering the potential consequences of such an approach, as it may lead to communication barriers and hinder global understanding. Additionally, it is worth noting that language is not just a means of communication, but also a powerful tool for shaping one's identity and worldview. Therefore, it is important to strike a balance between preserving cultural traditions and embracing global connectivity through language."

We opted to patronize Einstein for our morning repast, despite the considerable queue that had formed outside, stretching beyond the entrance and into the street, owing to the popularity of this establishment among the local denizens. It being just shy of 9 am on a tranquil Sunday morning, we pondered the feasibility of seeking sustenance elsewhere, but ultimately elected to endure the delay, which, much to our relief, proved to be relatively brief. Following a mere thirteen minute interval, during which we placed our order and tendered payment, we were able to secure a table in the spacious dining area, whereupon our culinary selections were promptly prepared and presented to us, requiring but a scant four additional minutes of waiting. My personal preference was for the flavorful applewood bacon and cheddar cheese-adorned egg sandwich, served upon a plain bagel, which, while perhaps a tad overpriced in relation to its constituent elements, was nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying.

I went here for a meet up, we were about 20 people so I was able to sample several dishes.. some were really good some others very bad.. on the good side they offer European beers which is always good :) .\nThe food took a long time to arrive even though we RSVP weeks ahead of time, They were not prepared to serve a large group. On their defense this is a family owned business so the entire family runs the restaurant, I believe mom and dad were cooking and their son was the server. I guess is good thing that we were supporting a family  business in the Valley

"Upon venturing to this establishment for the first time, I found it to be an adequate location for satiating one's boba cravings without the necessity of traversing to Chinatown. My order of boba milk tea, enhanced by the inclusion of jelly, bore a striking resemblance in taste to volcano tea, thereby eliciting my satisfaction. However, my companion's selection of a taro smoothie yielded an unfavorable assessment from him. It is evident that the quality of the beverages served here is inconsistent and varies depending on the specific item ordered. Additionally, I deducted points due to the limited array of options available, as well as the unremarkable ambiance within the store, which features a compact, unadorned interior that does not foster a sense of leisure or relaxation. A more extensive offering of snacks would have been appreciated."

I was very excited about playing golf here since its firmly entrenched in one of the more exclusive housing areas in Summerlin called The Ridges.  I was here for a fundraiser so we played shotgun.  

The golf course is billed as Jack Nicklaus' best holes in one round.  I can definitely see the potential but this time around, I don't think the potential was actualized.  Granted it was over 100 degrees but the course was very dry and the greens spotty.  It was definitely punched recently but wasn't healing as well as it should.

Checked out the club house to see if there's anything to purchase but the guy working at the counter looked right at me then looked away.  I do not expect to be pampered but a hello would be nice.  Needless to say, I didn't buy anything.

Again, every hole has the potential to be phenomenal with great views of all the beautiful homes as well as views of he strip on a couple of holes.  Unfortunately, I think I caught it during a bad stretch.  I will be back and re-review if I find the experience to be different.

Salads are delicious there jumbo shrimps go perfect on top! There unique dressings to choose from Lime infused ranch was amazing! \n\nCons- Poor customer Service, not helpful when it comes to being undecided or asking for their recommendations

I have had the privilege of visiting the iconic city of New York, where I had the opportunity to indulge in a slice of their world-renowned pizza. Unfortunately, my experience with the pizza at this establishment fell short of my expectations, as it failed to live up to the standards set by its authentic New York-style counterpart. Despite the ambiance and quality of service being satisfactory, I regret to say that I do not foresee myself returning to this venue in the future.

I don't know that I would have gotten oil changes for a few years if it hadn't been for this place.  

One stop shopping for getting an oil change and car wash - and there's a Wendy's right next door to grab some grub while they mess with the car.  They've expanded their offerings recently and now they do things from replacing your headlights to changing out belts.  My last trip there was an oil change, new air filter and car wash for $47 after tax.  They also do a basic car wash from $3.99 and a super was from $7.99.  I've never gotten anything but the basic, and I always find things they missed so while I'm not too impressed with their quality, it's nice to have the basics all taken care of in one location. 

They have 48 hour guarantees on the washes, which is nice and when you get work done it always includes a "limited time" coupon for additional work.  Not a bad deal...

"John's watering hole possesses qualities that render it an agreeable venue for individuals seeking a casual drinking establishment within close proximity to their domicile. The interior design exudes an aura of cleanliness and aesthetic appeal, while the culinary offerings, though unremarkable in quality, provide sustenance sufficient to satiate one's appetite. Patrons have the option to peruse menus from both the esteemed Mario's Pizza and the more limited selection offered by the bar, thereby affording them a diverse array of edible options. Of particular note are the delectable sliders, available in either chicken or cheeseburger varieties, which elicit praise from this writer due to their exceptional flavor. During sporting events, numerous televisions scattered throughout the premises afford patrons an optimal viewing experience, complemented by the presence of enticing drink specials. Although service is generally satisfactory, lapses in attention occasionally occur, understandably so given the steady stream of loyal clientele drawn from surrounding neighborhoods. In summary, John's place presents itself as a welcoming and comfortable local pub, well-suited to meet the needs of those seeking a relaxed, convivial atmosphere without necessitating extensive travel."

Had a nice breakfast at Gertrude's before checking out the Chihuly exhibit at the botanical garden. My traveling companion and I like to check out the botanical gardens in the cities we visit, and it was nice to have a breakfast option right there on site.

We both had the breakfast sammies, which were good, despite the fact that I don't think anything should be called a 'sammie.' The coffee was strong, and my only complaint was that it didn't get filled very often.

We were able to eat on the patio, which was nice since we were visiting the area partially to get away from the cold. It was very comfortable and pretty.

"We recently partook in a culinary excursion to this cozy eatery, and our arrival was met with an arduous queue, which threatened to deter us from our gastronomical pursuits. However, our persistence was rewarded by the hospitable staff's proffering of a delectable tray of lechon kawali (roast pork belly), thereby rekindling our interest in savoring the establishment's offerings. The menu boasted an array of Filipino delicacies, including Filipino-style corned beef and potatoes, as well as oxtail stew (\"kare-kare\"), both of which we indulged in with great relish. The ambiance of the restaurant, nestled within a bustling Chinese plaza, exuded a sense of warmth and familiarity, reflective of the Filipino cultural value of fostering strong connections with one's neighbors, as evidenced by the name of the establishment itself, which translates to \"house-connected.\" The prices, at a reasonable $6.50 for two dishes and rice, only served to further enhance our dining experience."

"The retail establishment boasts an array of luxury items and a sufficient assortment of products, yet, in concurrence with the previous patron's remarks, the personnel would greatly benefit from fundamental instruction in clientele etiquette. Paradoxically, the more mature employees manifest a warm, polite, and accommodating demeanor, whereas their younger counterparts display discourteous conduct, engaging in boisterous personal conversations within earshot of patrons, expressing visible exasperation and impatience, and indulging in disrespectful eye movements or utterly disregarding customers. It is truly perplexing that a business that prides itself on its high-end reputation does not place greater emphasis on instilling corresponding behavioral standards among its staff."

Well, I'm sitting here while my son plays.... Music is so loud you have to shout to communicate.... I asked them to turn the volume down a bit, they did but then turned it back up..... Inappropriate songs come on and staff needs to be told to turn it.... I mean what parent wants their kid listening to a song about a$$ and twerking? Other than these issues (that can definitely be addressed), it's a great place....

There is nothing really exciting about the Boozery, which is disappointing for it's location. The bar itself is pretty small but they are able to accomodate more with outside seating. It has a nice ambiance inside but the small size of the place cramps the style a bit. They have very limited special drink menu with your average Freemont street drink prices ($7-$10).\n\nThe Boozery is just your average downtown bar. Nothing to complain about, but also nothing to brag about.

I planned an event here with some girlfriends for an early dinner. The place is easy to miss, because it's a small building so if you blink or aren't paying attention you will get lost (trust me...I know). Also, just a head's up with the place being so small parking is a bit of a pain. In fact it's pretty non-existent. There's a few spaces in the front and if you're lucky they have a few in the back...if all those are full....good luck! 

That being said, the menu is pretty simple. I think they are going for down home favorites. There are your staple dishes like meatloaf, burgers, fish and salads. But I just wasn't overly impressed with the menu. I opted for the Veggie Burger and fries. It's your typical Morning Star veggie burger so nothing to be amazed about there and the fries were just okay. 

The service was great but I'm just not sure I'd make it a priority to give them another try. Based on the reviews, their brunch might be worth another visit. We'll see!

"The decibel level within the establishment was remarkably high, rendering conversation challenging, albeit suitable for revelers seeking to partake in fermented beverages, sporting events, and grilled culinary delights. Notwithstanding, the selection of artisanal brews was truly exceptional, while the gastronomical offerings, though slightly delayed, were expertly prepared and undeniably savory. Our hospitable server and the proprietor himself extended warm welcomes, and the complementary side dishes, specifically the gravy fries and macaroni and cheese, showcased pronounced flavors. Despite my residence in Glendale, I wouldn't venture across the Valley solely to visit this venue again, however, I would unhesitatingly endorse it to acquaintances residing in close proximity who seek an exhilarating atmosphere to enjoy a football match or two alongside superior quality beverages."

(+) The lodging boasts an enviable location, nestled within close proximity to a plethora of iconic landmarks, cultural hotspots, and urban amenities, including the revered Notre Dame, the historic Old Montreal, the vibrant Chinatown, the charming Latin Quarters, and the bustling St. Catherine's, as well as an array of art museums, a convenient metro station, and a diverse selection of shopping and dining venues.

(+) The guest chamber itself is spacious, featuring a majestic high ceiling, a plush king-size bed, and a compact kitchenette, thereby providing ample space for relaxation and convenience.

(+) The hospitality of the staff is worthy of mention, as they exhibit a warm and welcoming demeanor, readily accommodating requests for additional amenities, such as the complimentary provision of a cot, graciously bestowed without any supplementary charges.

(+) The lodging offers complimentary internet access, conveniently furnishing guests with a unique code upon check-in, enabling them to seamlessly stay connected during their sojourn.

(+) A delicious continental breakfast buffet is included in the tariff, featuring an assortment of fresh pastries, crusty croissants, healthy cereals, succulent fruits, and aromatic coffee, all served in a cheerful ambiance.

(-) Unfortunately, a minor drawback was encountered, as the reservation, which specifically requested two separate beds, was inadvertently allocated a single bedroom, prompting a visit to the front desk to address the inconvenience. Although the accommodation was ultimately unable to offer an alternative room exchange, the staff graciously offered a cot at no additional cost.

(-) A slight criticism pertains to the towels, which bore an unpleasant odor, detracting from the overall comfort experience.

(-) While the daily parking fee of $22 is reasonable, the fact that it is exclusively valet-based and requires the assistance of the concierge for item retrieval may prove inconvenient for some visitors who value ease of access to their vehicles.

I know this is a rare 3 star review for this place and I will preface it by saying it is the only Las Vegas buffet I have ever been to, so I have nothing to compare it to, but enjoyed the experience.

I went here for dinner while wandering along the strip one night and I thought it was your typical buffet with a wide variety of options that weren't gourmet but still good.  I think the key is to choose the right options.  The crab legs were awesome and totally worth the $20 since I probably ate $30 of legs alone.  Other favorites included prime rib, mashed potatoes, and spicy tuna rolls.  Salad bar was just OK and so were the desserts.

This is a really good deal if you are hungry! The atmosphere is pretty tacky but it is within the Imperial Palace so that's to be expected.

I've stayed here twice, and had very different room experiences.  Only one side of the hotel is renovated and that of course makes a huge difference.  My boyfriend and I had a room with a king size bed and it was nicely updated and had a great bathroom.  I booked again with the girls and we had rooms with 2 double beds, very dated, worn furniture, old carpet.  If you're going with friends and don't plan on spending much time in the room then it's a good choice based on location and price.  The other negatives is that you have to pay to use the gym and the pool area is VERY crowded...tough to get a lounge chair.  Gambling is OK...but the drink service is a little slow.
Maybe my expectations were too high - but food was very disappointing.  It was ok - nothing spectacular or noteworthy.  Therefore it was definitely overpriced.  Wait staff was great though.

Just ordered a pizza and wings for delivery. I picked up my pizza before and I got a weird vibe from the staff. They are very unpleasant, thought if I phoned it in I would get a happy tone on the other end.... WRONG! They need to hire delightful people to work the register and take the phone calls. This will be my last time ordering from them until my free pizza coupon is valid lol! Oh and the pizza's not all that bad! Definitely better than Pizza Hut!

Hakkasan is located inside the MGM grand. I was on the GL so we went to the GL line and it was free before 1am, so we had to hurry our asses there! We made it & it was free, thank god! Anywayyys, bouncers were nice and they made our transition inside the club pretty smoothly. Once we got in, I immediately noticed how SMALL it was. The dancefloor was sooooo tiny! :( When I finally made my way over, I could barely move/dance. It was literally body to body ... and this was on a day where there's NO ONE famous dj-ing! So imagine how bad the crowd would get if Tiesto or Hardwell was up there .... I wouldn't wanna be there! \n\nBut that's all I can really say because I got super messed up and I can't remember anything else. Only that I couldn't dance at all because there was no room and the parts where it's kinda open, the security made you move :(

I have been to this particular location for eyebrow threading twice.  On both occasions I walked in without an appointment and was greeting right away.  There was no wait and the desk attendant was very professional.  The brow threading person did an excellent job.  I would recommend that she improve her customer service.  She did not ask me how I would like my brows done or even speak to me at all.  Overall, I would come back again since they did make my brows look great!

"For a smorgasbord, I surmised that this establishment offered a relatively satisfactory culinary experience, with the comestibles being genuinely representative of the authentic Indian gastronomical tradition, and the seasonings and spices being carefully prepared to evoke the distinctive flavors which I have come to associate with genuine Indian cuisine. Notwithstanding my unfamiliarity with a significant portion of the offerings, the variety of dishes available was appreciable, although I must admit that the profusion of flavors ultimately became somewhat indistinguishable from one another, leading me to speculate that in future, I might prefer to patronize a traditional Indian restaurant where I can savor a single dish, such as chicken marsala or curry, in isolation."

"Relatively pricey in comparison to the nearby Gandhi's restaurant, the culinary offerings were satisfactory yet unremarkable, while the atmosphere was somewhat more refined than the typical Indian eatery."

"It is not deceptive to admit that I relished a thoroughly enjoyable experience during my recent visit to this esteemed eatery. The interior design exudes an air of contemporary sophistication, complete with elevated platforms that double as performance areas for scantily-clad dancers to showcase their talents while patrons partake in their culinary indulgences. However, my overall satisfaction was slightly compromised due to a few minor drawbacks. Specifically, the hostesses displayed an excessively stringent demeanor, feigning ignorance of my prior reservation despite the fact that my hotel concierge had already arranged it over the phone. Furthermore, they seemed to be under the impression that they were conferring a favor upon me by accommodating my request, albeit after an extended period of time. In contrast, our server exhibited exceptional proficiency and attentiveness throughout the evening. The cuisine itself was adequate, with the Black Cod appetizer being particularly noteworthy, while the crab cake counterpart fell short of my expectations. The fried shrimp dish was also commendable, and the steak offerings adhered to the established standards associated with the Morton's brand. In conclusion, although my dining experience was generally satisfying, the abundance of exceptional eateries in Las Vegas renders it unlikely that I will return to this specific location in the future."

This is a fun place to eat, but just not my cup of tea.

The service was very good and is what gets it a passing grade.

Unfortunately, the food was very average. Everything was completely over-seasoned, so much so, that i could only eat half the food, and I was starving. Do not get the special hash and the potatoes on the same plate, they are seasoned nearly identically and would require you to drink a gallon of water to even attempt to finish it all. The quality of everything else though is fairly good though and i think this is why it is popular here. Maybe just stick with waffles and pancakes, they did look pretty good.

It is hard to say that i would recommend this place, maybe i would if I knew that person loved over seasoned food. It is a fun place though.

Once just a Panera ripoff, Atlanta Bread has since added many more of its own creations. I tried the Italian vegetable panini the other night: tasty but expensive, given the portion size. Even after finishing the pickle and kettle chips that came with it, I felt barely satiated.\n\nDecor is nice, as is the free wifi, but service is somewhat lacking. Nonetheless, this place feels like an adequate option if you're in the mood for a sandwich. (The pastas, however, are quite bland.)

In a sea of gourmet restaurants sometimes you want something ordinary.
For a cafe, it's not bad. We just wanted something "normal" for a late lunch. Alot of places weren't even open yet, many others had a limited lunch menu. It was Sunday with football games on so, alot of the bar type places were packed.
It really reminded me of Cheesecake Factory. Lots of menu choices. Staff was nice.
I got Fried Chicken with Mashed Potatoes, it wasn't greasy, but it was a bit salty, I've had better, I've had worse. The potatoes were a bit bland, but my salty chicken helped even things out. I ordered a Pear Martini and they were out of the ingredients, so I had a delicious Strawberry Martini. My husband got a Cheeseburger and fries, the fries were good, I didn't try the burger but it looked good, he devoured it, and said it was better than he expected.
I would eat here again if in a pinch, but with so many better restaurants in walking distance, it's doubtful.

This buffet can be considered satisfactory for local patrons, in my opinion. However, if I had to pay for it myself, I might have been more critical since it's merely a mid-range buffet charging over $50 for two individuals. We visited on seafood Friday, and the offerings were unremarkable, with most dishes being standard fare found at many mid-range Las Vegas buffets. Our server was friendly and attentive, though, and the hot crab legs were quite enjoyable.  

However, some aspects were disappointing. The sushi was cold and lackluster, while the cold shrimp was mushy and lacking texture. Although the salmon appeared moist, its taste was underwhelming. The hush puppies were overly salty and crunchy, and the fried catfish had an unpleasant softness due to sitting out too long, despite having a flavor reminiscent of "chicken fried" catfish. The carrot cake and chocolate fudge pieces were also subpar, with the latter feeling almost weightless.  

In summary, the crab was the highlight, and the presentation of the shellfish dishes was visually appealing and flavorful. Everything else we tried was mediocre, neither terrible nor inedible. Children would likely enjoy this establishment, as would those with sufficient funds seeking a leisurely dining experience.

HUGEEEE pasta portion. Appetizers were definitely not needed with the heft of my spaghetti. When I can't find something thrilling on the menu at an Italian restaurant, I'll often opt for the spaghetti with meatballs. It's a classic dish that, if they can't get right, bodes unwell for anything else. Fortunately, the noodles were cooked al dente and the meatballs moist. Unfortunately, we started with a selection of cured meat and flatbread pizza so I was stuffed by the time my entree arrived :(\n\nCame back later after a night of drinking, though, to have some extremely satisfying post-drinking pizza. But so did everyone else.

I reviewed this in 2009 to let people know that I got food poisoning here. I ate here again and am rating it more highly cause I ate the veg food and it was fine, but mostly because I highly approve of the quantity and quality of their rice.  Working class Asian Americans like myself love their rice and this place is super generous and the quality is very very good. Better than the entree itself in fact.

They now have vegetarian fajitas, $10, not a bad price but you don't get much tofu at all and the ones at Jack Astor's are better in every way.\n\nOver all they're not bad, but I don't think I'd order them again.

"As an aficionado of superior burgers, I must confess that it is arduous to surpass my expectations when it comes to savoring these delectable delights. Despite my penchant for culinary indulgence, I find myself frequently disappointed by the inability of establishments to prepare my burger to the precise temperature I request. This lackluster performance elicits my ire, and I yearn for a dining experience that mirrors the quality of the Outback chain, where the culinary staff unfailingly executes the cooking process with meticulous attention to detail, ensuring that each burger patty is cooked to perfection. Moreover, I implore these eateries to invest in a sufficient quantity of salt to enhance the flavor profile of their beef offerings. Lastly, I would like to highlight the importance of offering reasonable prices for beverages during happy hour, as this gesture would undoubtedly contribute to an establishment's popularity among patrons seeking a satisfying dining experience."

"Savor the delectable victuals and exceptional hospitality! Don't overlook the'sides'; I relished the creamy hummus and savory lentils, which were both scrumptious. I exhausted the pita bread but they generously provided additional portions upon my request. Additionally, the desserts are highly recommended; I indulged in an unforgettable strawberry bar (the name escapes me), which was utterly delightful. 

My culinary exploration continued with the Good Earth sandwich, boasting fresh components, yet the sauce's flavor profile didn't quite align with my palate, perhaps due to my unfamiliarity with local tastes. If I were to return, I might consider omitting the sauce or requesting it on the side. The guacamole sandwich was more to my liking, although the red sauce was excessively saccharine for my taste buds. I shared these dishes with a companion, and we concurred on our assessments. 

Furthermore, there was another vegan sandwich alternative, Tree of Life, which I ordered for my beau and his companions to share. They relished it the most, so I trust this feedback proves beneficial!"

I've been a member of Lifetime for a few months and their facilities are hands down the best. You can read the other reviews for how awesome tha facility is but I'm going to speak to some of the interesting events that take place in the men's locker room and I am not joking at all......

Apparently the men's locker room gets rather friendly after hours and when I say after hours I state that loosely as in 10-11pm.   On two occasions.....I repeat.....two occasions I had the same 55 year old man pull up to a sink next to me and blow dry his junk.  I'm not exagerrating and my friend was at the sink to his left.   He was sandwiched between us butt naked stretching his stick and blow drying his junk dry.   I ran out of the gym in fear.   A few weeks later the SAME MAN did it again except this time I was by myself.   

Another time, 2 young men in their 30's were slapping each other in behinds with towels NAKED and chasing each other around the gym.  They almost knocked me over.....Thankfully I am not homophobic but come on, there's a time and place for everything......and apparently Lifetime is where it's at.   CAUTION - BEWARE

"My expectations may have been excessively elevated, thus, allowing me to initiate an assessment of the eatery's attributes by highlighting its positive aspects. The establishment boasts a capacious parking area, modern decor, and an expansive interior design. Notably, the restaurant's personnel demonstrated proficiency in efficiently managing the front-of-house operations, despite being understaffed. Our culinary excursion encompassed orders of chicken red curry, papaya salad, BBQ chicken, pad thai, and a supplementary side dish of sweet rice. Unfortunately, the sweet rice manifested a disappointing texture, characterized by sogginess and overcooking, which was further exacerbated by its unremarkable presentation within a plastic sandwich bag. The BBQ chicken failed to meet my expectations, as it was served with a generic sweet chili sauce, rather than a genuine barbecue flavor. Moreover, the chicken itself was merely a piece of marinated chicken breast, seasoned with a dried curry rub, resulting in a pan-fried taste that did not align with my preconceptions of barbecued cuisine. The papaya salad exhibited a strong sodium presence, which overpowered the lime flavor, while the inclusion of minuscule peanut fragments seemed incongruous and culturally adapted. In contrast, the chicken red curry dish featured an appreciable assortment of bamboo shoots and customary curried vegetables; nonetheless, the curry sauce lacked a zesty quality, rendering it insipid and unimpressive. Notwithstanding, my children expressed immense fondness for the pad thai, which temporarily alleviated my gastronomical disenchantment. Given my relentless pursuit of authentic Thai cuisine in Arizona, my likelihood of revisiting this establishment remains uncertain."

"Consequently, I have decided to confer three stars upon this establishment, primarily due to the Manager's diligent efforts in addressing our bill. However, I must emphasize that this rating is not without certain reservations, as my boyfriend and I have encountered issues with the service during two separate visits. Specifically, on our first occasion, we were neglected twice regarding our request for water, and subsequently, the bill failed to materialize in a timely manner. Furthermore, during our most recent visit, an unfortunate mishap occurred where our food was mistakenly delivered to another table, resulting in a 15-minute delay before it was eventually served, albeit at a frigid temperature. Although I appreciated the Manager's gesture of offering us the meal complimentarily, I cannot help but feel that such errors are indicative of subpar service. Therefore, I must deduce that the ambiance, characterized by comfortable seating, appealing tables, and an engaging screen, does not suffice in compensating for the shortcomings in the dining experience. In light of these circumstances, I suggest that patrons consider alternative options for enjoying a film, perhaps by bringing their own provisions and relying on the cinema's atmospheric elements to enhance their viewing pleasure."
So..this place is cute!  Huge dance floor!  The whole place is huge! Geesh~  Fun decor and nice bartenders.  The guys there seem pretty lame though.  Cool place to get dressed up and dance.

it's a party on the inside, very cool decor and volcano show

better burgers than "The Burger Joint" in the same location

average food but worth the price

It's a Roberto's. I used to be in love with the food here. Over the years that has faded. I also think the overall quality of food has as well. There are several locations all over Vegas. I do think Roberto's is better than a lot of spots you can eat. But after trips to mexico and a few out of this world food truck street tacos robertos is just average. It is average that I like to eat from time to time if I am craving it. I like it, I used to love it. It's still good just not great in my books.

I have been here a couple of times. The service was great and the atmosphere is nice, casual and laid back.\n\nThe pizza is alright. I've tried a couple different pizzas here. I didn't love the sauces they used and didn't love the crust texture or taste. However, I really enjoyed the food items that were not pizza here. Their sides, salads, and soups were tasty. I'm interested in trying their other menu items. I would come back here, but not for the pizza.

Nice place, nice atmosphere, and I've always had good service here but - for me - the bread is mediocre. I'm guessing they are intending to go for a very moist, 'heavy' bread, which I'm sure some people love. I've just discovered Wildflower Bread Company and their bread is 'perfect' for me - drier, lighter, but still with moisture and 'stretch' or 'bite'.

"During my recent visit to Las Vegas, I had the opportunity to partake in the lunch buffet offered by this establishment, and I must say that the culinary offerings were quite satisfactory.  It was, in fact, a fortuitous discovery, made on the final day of our stay in the city, following a series of disappointing experiences at the Studio Cafe.  The fixed daily tariff appeared to be an exceptional value, particularly when considering the exorbitant prices typically associated with dining in Las Vegas.  However, the ambient temperature of the seating area was rather chilly for some inexplicable reason, but our server was quite attentive and accommodating, noticing our discomfort and kindly suggesting hot beverages, which she subsequently ensured were consistently replenished."

Situated in the epicenter of the commercial establishments at Palazzo, this unpretentious wine bar presents an array of adequate options at the bar, complemented by an extensive selection in the adjacent retail space.

Bottle prices are moderately elevated, commensurate with the customary Las Vegas experience.

My expectations were not entirely fulfilled in regards to the glassware, as it consisted of either the O-Line series or diminutive bowled glasses with brief stems, evocative of inferior hotel banquets. As a dedicated wine bar, I anticipated a more comprehensive selection of glassware.

Notwithstanding, the staff exhibited amicability and ensured my glass remained replenished!!

"An excellent location for recreational activities, offering ample opportunities for physical exertion and enjoyment, yet, unfortunately, hampered by inadequate maintenance and lax officiating. Specifically, the lack of a functioning speed ball arena significantly diminishes the overall experience, while the apparent reluctance of referees to oversee games properly has become increasingly problematic. However, management's willingness to provide complimentary repair services for damaged equipment and thorough cleaning procedures offers some consolation. To elevate this venue to a five-star status, a concerted effort towards revitalizing the playing fields and instituting more rigorous standards for referees would be necessary."

We had been eagerly anticipating dining at the Block & Grinder since its opening, having heard numerous accolades regarding its culinary offerings. Upon finally experiencing it for ourselves, we found the edibles to be quite satisfactory, warranting a rating of 4 to 5 stars. However, our enjoyment of the meal was somewhat mitigated by the less than stellar ambiance and service. Specifically, we were seated in a rather cramped area adjacent to a large table, and it took approximately 12 minutes before a server noticed our presence and attended to our needs. Subsequently, we received attentive care from our server, albeit at a pace that could be described as leisurely due to his responsibility for multiple sizeable tables.   Moving on to more favorable aspects of our dining experience, we began with an appetizer of pimento cheese served with crackers, which we found to be exceptionally delectable and arguably the most flavorful pimento cheese we have had the pleasure of sampling during our brief exposure to this particular delicacy. For our main course, we opted for the ribs, which proved to be a judicious decision. The meat was not only tender and lean but also ranked among the most succulent ribs we have had the pleasure of consuming.  Considering our overall satisfaction with the food, we might consider returning to the Block & Grinder, ideally during a weeknight or off-peak hours, in the hope of improving our dining experience by avoiding the crowds that may have contributed to the sluggish service we encountered. Additionally, we would be interested in sampling the establishment's cocktails.

I inhabit a proximate location in relation to Papago, thereby rendering it a frequent destination for my pedestrian excursions. However, my motivation for visiting this site does not stem from an ardent affection towards it, but rather due to its accessibility and the unchallenging nature of its trails. In fact, Papago is one of the few locations where I feel completely secure venturing out solo, owing to the absence of hazardous terrain and the minimal likelihood of encountering perilous situations, unless one mistakenly takes a misstep while ascending one of the buttes, thereby risking injury.  
The park boasts a well-maintained and pristine condition, offering picturesque vistas of Phoenix, Tempe, and Scottsdale during one's trek. On occasion, I have had the pleasure of observing avian species of interest, fluttering overhead. Given its straightforward terrain, Papago serves as an ideal venue for novice hikers and those seeking a leisurely outdoor experience with their canine companions or progeny. For those seeking to indulge in some fresh air and respite from the mundane routine, a brief sojourn to Papago during a tranquil morning or afternoon is highly recommended.

"Upon conducting an exhaustive inquiry among the indigenous populace, it became apparent that this eatery was the unanimous recommendation for gastronomical indulgence in the realm of burgers; thus, I deemed it incumbent upon myself to partake in a culinary exploration of the establishment, not once, but twice, in order to formulate a comprehensive assessment of its gustatory offerings. Unfortunately, my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated, as the fare proved to be utterly insipid, lacking even the most fundamental attributes of flavor and zest. My experiences with both the burger and steak served only to reinforce this notion, leaving me in a state of profound disillusionment."

Bed Bath & Beyond -- totally overpriced and for this particular location, also bad parking!!  Ugh.  I don't usually shop at BB&B unless I have one of those coveted 20% off coupons in my hot little hand. 

I was here recently looking for that awesome linen spray, the Egyptian Cotton-scented version. They haven't had it either time I was here. I was also looking for a new "everyday" type of pot, but they didn't have what I needed. Sure, they had Calphalon but I'm not paying THAT for a pot or pan. 

I did pick up a new shower curtain liner and a couple candles but I had to get the pot elsewhere.

"My anticipation for dining at this establishment was immense, but unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. Prior to attending a performance by Cirque du Soleil, we opted to partake in a culinary experience here. Our initial selections included the frisee salad and lobster bisque, both of which proved to be scrumptious. Notably, the frisee boasted substantial portions of bacon, which, when combined with the runny yolk, elevated the flavor profile of the dish significantly. Additionally, we indulged in a half-bottle of red wine whose quality merited its cost. However, my enthusiasm for Craftsteak ended there. I opted for the flat iron steak and sampled the surf and turf option, which featured a ribeye and lobster tail. In all honesty, I have savored superior cuts of meat in my native Texas. Disappointment also characterized my experience with the bread rolls, as their reputation preceded them, but ultimately, they failed to impress me. To put it into perspective, if you have had the pleasure of consuming a yeast roll from Hartz Chicken, then you have essentially tasted the offering from Craftsteak. My desire to elaborate further on this dining establishment is limited."

This is the only hotel I've stayed at downtown - I know, hard to believe a person from Hawaii never stayed at the California!!  But I'm really picky about what hotels I stay at and the California and every other hotel located downtown always made me feel itchy while walking through - like I said before: "Happy Faye, happy stay!"

The rooms were pretty average, but I only stayed in their standard rooms.

I've had good experiences here and never felt unsafe (while in the hotel room and casino area).  All of the employees were always nice and helpful, which is always good to have!  Their 24 hour coffee shop serves good food at reasonable prices (they even have some "Hawaii friendly" menu items!).

"In light of my personal expectations and dining experience, I would assign a rating of three and a half stars to this establishment. The ambiance and menu offerings were undoubtedly captivating, yet I couldn't help but feel that the overall atmosphere was slightly over-the-top for my taste. Perhaps this is a common trait among Las Vegas eateries? Nonetheless, I was impressed by the quality of the oxtail chili fries, which lived up to its reputation as a must-try item. Unfortunately, the Manga burger fell short of my expectations due to an excessive amount of sauce that overpowered the flavor of the patty. However, the matcha green tea milkshake provided a pleasant contrast to the savory dishes. While I acknowledge the uniqueness of Bachi Burger's offerings, I remain skeptical about its ability to hold its own against the plethora of exceptional burger joints in Los Angeles, particularly with the impending arrival of a new location on Sawtelle Boulevard. Only time will tell if Bachi Burger can successfully distinguish itself from its competitors."

Want to stay on the strip but you're a cheapskate? Sahara is the place for you.

Old + Falling Apart + Terrible Shows =  great character.

Only problem is it's a little too far away from the heart of the strip.

When I was employed at the Renaissance tower, I would frequent this establishment when I was feeling particularly indolent and opted to procure sustenance from a nearby source rather than expending the effort to traverse the street in search of a superior dining experience. This decision was motivated by the fact that, in my opinion, their pizza failed to meet even the most basic standards of culinary excellence, falling short of both greatness and goodness. However, on two separate occasions, I did partake of their breakfast muffin, which far surpassed my expectations by boasting an optimal amount of grease that effectively conveyed its quality without overwhelming the palate. Additionally, the price point was remarkably reasonable, making it an eminently affordable option for those seeking a satisfying repast without breaking the bank.

I'm not the hugest fan of Indian food but if I had to eat it this is where I would go. They also have a few other dishes besides Indian which is nice. The food tends to be spicey and pretty authentic!  A lot of what they offer is geared toward the vegetarian crowd.
I got a hair cut and loved it, however, I was not crazy about the salon. A little too modern for me.\nSeems like a good place if you like trendy hair cuts and color.

"Although I have not had the opportunity to sample a considerable number of dishes or partake in the midday buffet offered by this establishment, my culinary experiences thus far have led me to formulate the opinion that it constitutes a passable alternative for those seeking Indian cuisine. Furthermore, as an individual who adheres to a vegetarian dietary regimen, I find solace in the knowledge that there exists no possibility of animal flesh being incorporated into my meals, thereby rendering it a relatively risk-free dining destination for me."

The sushi here is not bad, but not great. Service is also up to par. Sushi rock pails in comparison, however, to nearby restaurants, that have much better quality sushi, and hover around the same price. Though I may come here again for Korean food, I will not be returning for sushi.

We take immense pleasure in frequenting this establishment with the intention of acquiring attire and travel accessories. The prices offered here are indeed competitive, and we have had the privilege of discovering remarkable bargains within these premises. Moreover, the assortment of luggage available is quite extensive, encompassing an array of styles and designs that cater to diverse preferences. It is not uncommon for us to encounter fellow shoppers in this location, particularly during peak days such as weekends. To optimize our shopping experience and avoid the throngs of people, we tend to visit during weekdays, specifically during the afternoon when the crowd has thinned out somewhat. The staff members here have consistently displayed a welcoming demeanor towards us, and we must commend their dedication to maintaining a tidy and organized environment throughout the store. Notwithstanding, we have deducted a few points from our overall satisfaction rating due to the occasional presence of lengthy queues at the checkout counters, which can be somewhat vexing. Nevertheless, we remain steadfast in our enthusiasm for patronizing this retail outlet, and we hold high hopes for our future shopping excursions to this destination. Return Factor - 60%.

These state employees don't necessarily like their job, but they did a great job of helping me out. 

I just moved to the state and required a change of residency. I have no car here yet so a drivers license wasn't a necessity, but it would have been nice to have already. Unfortunately, proof of insurance specifically for this state is necessary to do that. State ID it was then. The lady at the front (I didn't grab her name) was very  kind and accommodating for my noob questioning of changing state ID's. The line, although around the room, moved very quickly.It's a lot faster than what I'm used to from Chicago/Illinois DMV lines.

Overall, if you have all your required paper work with you,  it is a fair experience got being a thing of necessity. Props to the kind lady in the beige cardigan up front!

We had the opportunity to indulge in a four-day sojourn at this establishment during the month of August in the previous year, and while it was not an unmitigated disaster, it failed to surpass our expectations in terms of overall quality and satisfaction. It is unlikely that we will opt to return to this hotel in the future unless they offer a drastically reduced rate, as it does not compare favorably to other establishments in the vicinity. The property itself is somewhat aged, which may contribute to its relatively lower price point, but its proximity to Mandalay Bay, where our friends were celebrating their nuptials, made it a convenient choice for our group of 23 individuals. Unfortunately, the tranquility of our weekend retreat was frequently disrupted by the sounds of construction, which seemed to persist throughout the entire weekend. The pool area, though adequate in size, lacked a certain aesthetic appeal compared to other hotels in the area. However, one of the highlights of our stay was the complimentary admission to Club LAX, which offered a welcome respite from the chaos of the casino floor. Additionally, the convenience of the tram system, which allowed us to easily access both Excalibur and Mandalay Bay without excessive walking, was a welcome amenity. Our room, though sufficient for two individuals, would have been somewhat cramped for any additional occupants. Furthermore, the variety of dining options within the food court left something to be desired. In conclusion, while the value proposition of this hotel may be attractive to some budget-conscious travelers, it falls short in delivering a truly satisfying experience for those seeking a higher level of comfort and luxury.

After being seated at three different tables we decided to sit at the bar.  We then found out they were out of lager.  How the hell can a brewery be out of lager?  The food was decent, the service was below average, and the crowd was the usual here in Glendale, old white folks.

Very up-to-date hotel. Pleasant atmosphere. Make sure if you want 3G/4G access in your room that you stay on the west side. Pool has horrible hours IMHO. If you want wifi access, be prepared to spend a fortune.  Drinks at the pool are outrageously priced!  $17 for one drink (includes mandatory tip)
Food is great but service for food and even drinks takes FOREVER make sure you have No plans the rest if the night when coming here as you will spend most time waiting for service.

Went to my first Panthers' game the other day; real good time, actually, even though I couldn't care less about the Panthers. It seems I'm the only one who doesn't: the place was, to my surprise, absolutely packed with Panther's fans. Pretty good for a team that's only been around for, what, ten years?

On game day, the stadium is absolutely surrounded and consumed by tailgating fans; during the rest of the week, it stands there, right outside of downtown, quiet and lonely looking. I guess that can be said of a lot of stadiums, though. 

As for the place itself, really good facilities and pretty good crappy stadium food--hotdogs, pretzels, beers, that kinda stuff. But it actually wasn't as expensive as I'd feared. Pretty reasonable, in fact, which is a rarity. 

And the fans were well-behaved and fun. Definitely a nice, family-friendly atmosphere. And there are always tickets available, so check it out.

"I have had the privilege of dining at this esteemed establishment on two separate occasions, and, unfortunately, the culinary offerings during both visits were merely mediocre, which, in my opinion, does not align with the elevated price point. Considering the exorbitant cost, the fare should be nothing short of exceptional. While the happy hour specials are moderately appealing, and the ambiance is undeniably impressive, I fail to perceive any compelling reason to frequent this venue, unless, of course, one seeks to demonstrate their financial prosperity. In contrast, a dining experience at Ocean Club offers a far more satisfying and memorable encounter, with cuisine that is truly remarkable. In light of these factors, I must conclude that this restaurant is not worth the excessive expense, and I would only consider returning if presented with a gift certificate."

"Underwhelmed by the uninspiring ambiance and unimpressive decor, we were disinclined to indulge in a dining experience at this establishment. The cacophonous music further exacerbated our dissatisfaction, rendering an in-house meal utterly unpalatable. Thus, we opted for take-out, which, regrettably, entailed an interminable wait exceeding 10 minutes on multiple occasions, even in the absence of a queue. Despite the prolonged delay, the culinary offerings were relatively satisfying, albeit resembling grilled wraps more closely than authentic burritos, as astutely observed by a fellow reviewer. It is worth noting, however, that the restaurant's payment options were woefully limited, with only cash transactions facilitated, a decidedly antiquated practice in this era of ubiquitous digital payments. Furthermore, the parking arrangement, characterized by angled spaces requiring a precarious traversal of the sidewalk, struck us as hazardous and ill-conceived. To avoid endangering pedestrians while exiting, we advise exercising extreme caution."

Murphy's greatest attribute is its location. The downtown Chandler area has so much potential and this is a good start. Murphy's is located in a nice plaza near the heart of the city. It's an Irish pub because we don't have enough of these in the Valley, right? 

It's in a narrow suite but the bar runs almost the full length of the place. It's not very large so it gets crowded fast. The weird thing is that it dies down after 11pm. I don't know why, the people just leave. Perhaps they know something I don't. But when there are people it a mix of late 20's to young 40's crowd.

They have a lot of beers on tap, so you're sure to find something you like. The staff is friendly and they try their hardest to get to everyone. On certain nights they have live music playin in the corner. Not a lot of room, so it's usually a one or two piece band. 

I'm not worried, but I hope that this place sticks around. This area needs them.

"Beverages were exceptional, yet the demeanor of the mixologist was discourteous! Following a few libations at VBGBs, my associates and I ventured to Willies, whereupon entering, we proceeded to the bar to place an order for additional potations. Being unfamiliar with the establishment, my companion inquired as to which beverage might resemble chocolate in taste, to which the bartender retorted with a hint of sarcasm that 'chocolate tasted like chocolate.' Furthermore, when we endeavored to request the Call-a-Cab, he queried whether we enjoyed Robatussen. Although I do value being apprised of the flavor profile of a cocktail, the bartender's disposition was somewhat vexing. In contrast, during a previous visit to the Myrtle Beach location, the bartender exhibited a more hospitable demeanor, offering samples and periodically checking in on us due to our proximity to the bar. \n\nAs others have cautioned, it is ill-advised to order Call-a-Cab independently, as its potency can prove challenging. Nonetheless, every other concoction I have had the pleasure of sampling (including Shock Treatment, Chocolate Thunder, and Sour Apple) was truly delectable."

"The Saturday night smorgasbord boasts a price tag of 26.95 per individual as of this writing, which, in my opinion, would be a reasonable rate at 20, but the current cost of 27 is slightly elevated. While some delectable offerings graced the table, such as the savory steak and succulent salmon, as well as the rich yet not overwhelming peanut butter chocolate cream pie, a notable disappointment emerged in the form of the purported French onion soup. Unfortunately, this dish was fabricated with what can only be described as subpar ingredients, closely resembling the questionable ones served by McDonald's on their sandwiches, and barely palatable even for a budget-friendly buffet priced at a mere 7 dollars. In fact, a cup of Lipton instant soup would have been a superior alternative. It is worth mentioning that fresh onions are not particularly expensive, and while a truly exceptional French Onion soup does require some time and effort to prepare, it is hardly an arduous task, even for a novice culinary student. In summary, I concur with previous assessments; the quality of the buffet varies greatly, ranging from impressive to unacceptable."

"Prospective advantages encompassing the auditory indulgence in melodious tunes via radio, specifically highlighted by the artist Todd Rundgren during the evening repast, complemented by an abundance of attentive server assistance, a diverse array of draft beer options, delectable pulled pork and corn accompaniments, copious portions, and relative drawbacks including the regrettably subpar quality of hush puppies, excessively saline beef brisket, a macaroni and cheese dish characterized by a deep-fried puck with cheese sauce, minuscule quantity of vinegar sauce, and a costly total of $24 for a dual meat platter accompanied by a single beverage, aligning with the pricing standards of New York City."

here's the deal: if you come here expecting berthillon, you will be disappointed.  if you come here expecting very fine american style gelato, you'll probably leave very very happy.  \n\ni came somewhere in the middle---i recognize that i can't get a certain quality of gelato this side of the atlantic, but i was expecting a little bit more.  the choc was milk choc.  gelato ought to be made with dark choc.  i'm not sure i'd trust the fruity gelato, knowing it won't compare to france/italy.  but, i bet the nutella is great---i'll try that next time!

"Dim-sum enthusiasts seeking an early morning culinary excursion in Las Vegas may find solace in the fact that this particular establishment boasts an uncharacteristically early opening time of 10:00 am, a full hour prior to the customary commencement of operations at neighboring eateries. While the quality of the diminutive steamed dumplings, known colloquially as har gow, may fall short of expectations due to their unremarkable proportions, the flavors therein remain palatable. It is worth noting, however, that the prices charged for these delectable morsels are somewhat elevated in comparison to those offered at alternative venues, presumably as a consequence of the restaurant's location within the Rio Casino complex, which, despite its once-luxurious appointments, now exudes an air of faded splendor."

Had them cater an event - food was very good, 2 types of quiche - excellent reviews from all meeting participants.  They did forget to bring a fruit platter - luckily I had ordered enough other food that it wasn't that big of a deal, but still not the best way to make an impression.  The delivery was also quite early - about 15-20 minutes before scheduled deliver time - earlier is always better than late, however with hot food, it creates a challenge...food was nicely prepped though.  I would likely order from them again, but will certainly be double checking the order upon arrival and will stress delivery time.

So, the good:  Plaintain and black bean mash, lump crab nachos, skinny margarita, chipolte ribs

The bad:  Service is hit or miss, enchiladas are meh, greens are very plain.

Note: The grilled corn used to be fabulous when served on the cob.  Too many people complete complained about it being messy so they now strip it from the cob.  It has lost something.  Let's worry less about being "clean" and more about good food!

Last evening's experience was somewhat disillusioning, as it failed to meet the expectations established by previous visits to this establishment. Despite the ambiance of the patio, which was enhanced by the presence of heaters and a live DJ, the culinary offerings and service fell short of satisfactory. Specifically, the food, while adequate, lacked the flavor and quality anticipated, with the mozzarella and tomato panini being particularly unimpressive. Furthermore, the service was subpar, with a waitress who exhibited bizarre behavior, including sarcastic and underhanded comments, spilling water on the table, and taking an inordinate amount of time to deliver the bill and process payment. It is conceivable that the waitress was experiencing a personal difficulty, but her conduct was nonetheless unprofessional and detracted from the overall dining experience. Notwithstanding this, Bomberos remains a popular venue, and future patrons would be advised to avoid the panini and exercise caution when interacting with the waitstaff.

One of the things I love about this place is the outdoor seating in the cooler months.  I also love the Bellini, Toasted Ravioli, and Rosemary-Chicken Pizza.

There IS room for improvement, however.  The takeout "system" they are using has caused me to go somewhere else more than once.  I don't think that having certain pickup "windows" for loyal customers is a sufficient way to reward them, especially at that price point.

Oregano's, you have a LOT of good competition (especially in Central Phoenix) so you may want to rethink the way you are treating customers.  I'm going to try you out again soon so we'll see how things go from there.

"I requested the seafood trio, which was served atop a bed of risotto, and while I cannot deny that the culinary elements themselves were satisfactory, particularly the salmon and shrimp, the portion size was conspicuously diminutive in comparison to my fellow diners', and the cost was disproportionately elevated. As an aside, the calamari and spinach artichoke dip that we partook of as appetizers were indeed delectable, and the peanut butter mousse that concluded our repast was likewise enjoyable. However, taking into account the totality of the dining experience, I must confess that it fell short of being truly exceptional or memorable, eliciting neither profound animosity nor unadulterated adoration. Therefore, if an individual were to express a desire to visit this establishment, I would not actively discourage them, but I would not enthusiastically endorse it either, nor would I personally go out of my way to return."

"Pizza can be likened to sexual intercourse; even when it's subpar, it remains enjoyable. This establishment elicits a similar sentiment from me. While the pizza itself was not particularly impressive, I did appreciate the garlic-infused flavor incorporated into the crust. Unfortunately, my order was botched, and instead of the requested pepperoni and garlic combination, I received a pie adorned with pepperoni and olives. The service staff failed to express any regret or offer a discount, leaving a sour taste in my mouth. In addition, we sampled their chicken fingers, which were unremarkable but edible. It was evident that they used low-quality ingredients. Considering the cost, I might return (two medium two-topping pizzas and five chicken fingers for $15)."

"Consistent with the opinions articulated by previous patrons, this lodging option offers an affordable tariff, and it is essential to acknowledge that the quality of accommodations corresponds to the economic pricing. The advantageous aspect of this establishment is its prime location, situated directly in the center of the renowned Las Vegas Strip. Notwithstanding, even the premier penthouse failed to elicit my amazement, as I have had the pleasure of experiencing superior accommodations in the past. A unique attribute of this venue is the presence of dealer-impersonators, which provided an initial source of amusement until I noticed that the same performers were presented multiple times throughout the evening. Despite this observation, the experience remained enjoyable."

"On this particular occasion, it was my maiden visit to this establishment. I opted to place my order via the internet to facilitate a convenient and expeditious retrieval of my culinary selections. The digital ordering process was remarkably efficient and user-friendly, allowing me to complete my transaction with minimal effort and expediency. Upon arriving at the venue, I was pleased to discover that my order was being prepared at that very moment, ensuring that my meal was delivered promptly and maintained an optimal temperature. It was reassuring to note that my food was not left to linger and become stale or unpalatable.

I elected to sample their Brisket Burger, a delectable combination of a cheeseburger augmented with BBQ sauce, Brisket, and bacon. The portion of sauce accompanying my meal was appropriately proportioned, thereby preventing the bun from becoming overly saturated and compromising its structural integrity. The flavor profile of the Brisket was satisfying, although I would have preferred a more tender texture. My burger was cooked to a well-done finish, which was slightly disappointing as I generally prefer a slight pinkish hue to indicate a less thorough cooking process. In retrospect, I should have included this specification in the comment section while placing my order online.

In addition to the burger, I also requested a bowl of chicken tortilla soup as a supplementary item. This proved to be an excellent decision, as the soup was truly delicious and brimming with rich, bold flavors. The spicy kick was subtle yet discernible, and the generous helping of shredded chicken and corn elevated the dish to a superior level of culinary excellence. In fact, I found myself enjoying the soup more than the burger.

In conclusion, while the meal was not without its minor shortcomings, the overall experience was positive, and I would consider returning to sample additional menu items."

I must confess that my cinematic inclinations have been molded by my previous occupation as a projectionist during my collegiate years, which has rendered me somewhat fastidious regarding the manner in which I consume films. While I do not object to viewing motion pictures in various settings, I cannot help but feel that the quality of the presentation significantly influences the overall experience.

Unfortunately, my initial impression of this establishment was less than favorable, as it appeared to have deteriorated prematurely despite its relatively recent inception. The ambiance of the theater seemed to be tainted by an unsettling patina, akin to the effects of excessive nicotine consumption. Although the facilities boasted impressive appointments, their cleanliness left much to be desired.

My cinematic experience was merely passable, as the seats were not designed with adequate legroom, resulting in discomfort when surrounded by fellow patrons with diminutive bladders. As someone who has grown accustomed to the luxurious amenities offered by certain modern theaters, such as in-seat service of adult beverages and culinary delights, I must admit that I am unlikely to make a special effort to revisit this venue in the future.

"PROS:  
    1. The burgers possessed an impressive magnitude, their copious proportions rendering them ostensibly indulgent, although their exorbitant cost could be perceived as somewhat prohibitive.  
    2. The onion rings exhibited a remarkable crispiness, their substantial girth contributing to their overall appeal.  
    3. The Black Milk Tea boasted an unparalleled delectability, its boba manifesting an unforgettable flavor profile.  
    4. The Kimchi burger represented the epitome of culinary excellence, its sublime taste elevating it to an unrivaled position among its peers.  
    5. The staff members displayed an unwavering commitment to hospitality, their affable demeanor fostering a welcoming ambiance.  
 CONS:  
    1. My Kiki burger and Ronin burger suffered from an unfortunate similarity in taste, their initial mediocrity giving way to a faint improvement midway through consumption.  
    2. The Oxtail Chili fries, despite their promising appearance, proved forgettable and arrived belatedly, long after our burgers had been devoured.  
    3. The bar counter and tables were subjected to a questionable cleaning method, employing a cloth redolent of mildew and eliciting concerns regarding hygiene.  
    4. The limited availability of individual bathrooms resulted in an extended waiting period, further emphasizing the need for additional facilities.  
    5. The prices charged for beer were deemed excessive, bordering on extortionate."

I'd revisit this establishment to sample alternative burger offerings or perhaps simply relish in the kimchi burger's excellence once more."

I've been to Mimis a few times and I have to say that they are fairly inconsistent.  Sometimes they are good, sometimes they are bad.  It seems as though breakfast is usually pretty good, but dinner seems to be lacking most of the time.

I went this past weekend for dinner.  I got the three course steak meal for $9.99.  I know, I should have known better, but I couldn't resist.  The salad was ok.  Then came the steak with mashed potatoes.  The steak was terrible.  It definitely had fake chargrilled marks on it.  Then came the "sundae" to finish off the meal, which turned out to be a scoop of vanilla ice cream with chocolate syrup on it.  

Again, I guess you get what you pay for.

"I visited this establishment for a midday repast, and my initial impression was that it offered an extensive array of culinary options, rivalling those of other prominent hotels in the city. However, upon subsequent visits, my enthusiasm waned somewhat, as the quality of the fare failed to meet my expectations. Despite its spacious interior, the ambiance of the venue struck me as somewhat utilitarian, and the prices, while lower than those of premier establishments such as the Wynn or Bellagio, seemed incongruous with the compromised gastronomic experience. Nonetheless, for those seeking a broad variety of dishes at a relatively affordable cost, this buffet might still prove to be a suitable choice."

Picked up filled croissants for myself and the boys this morning.  
They were a little overbaked today but still tasty.
I still miss the original place that was I'm the strip mall a couple suites down.
Price has increased twice, at least, for individual croissants since it changed ownership.  Quality of croissants has not improved and if anything it seems to have gone from alright to mediocre.  Sometimes lacking filling, sometimes looking especially small -c'mon, for the price you don't want something that's a tad bigger than a grocery store cinnamon fry.
I rather they would get rid of all the new flavors they've added and simply offer a better quality product that was brought over from the original store/owner/baker(s).

Because the price of one croissant has gone up again I have opted to pick up treats to deliver to friends or a business (the staff at my vets office) from an excellent bakery that's across town.
More options and more for my money too.

"How should I rate and review this establishment without appearing judgmental? Haha, I couldn't care less!!! Away from the children yet again... Rented a car, drove to Las Vegas, arrived in 3 1/2 hours at an average speed of 80 miles per hour. Arrived at 12:35 a.m. 

Met with two other couples, coerced them away from the Baccarat tables at Caesars Palace, and joined us for a drink at OG. 

The optimal approach is to contact O.G. and reserve a table; they will dispatch a limousine to transport you from your accommodations. In this manner, you avoid paying the cover charge. Purchase a Grey Goose bottle or another type of liquor bottle, and you'll receive a complimentary "Smirnoff" bottle. The total cost, including tax and gratuity, was $415.00. Other forms of entertainment would be funded individually. Hehehehe... We enjoyed a lovely booth adorned with sheer curtains. 

Oh my goodness, oh my goodness, oh my goodness, ah my goodness... Upstairs, the women explored independently to examine the male patrons. It was relatively deserted. Only a handful of women accompanied these incredibly attractive men. Their physiques were muscular, their abdomens prominent, their biceps bulgingâyikes! I felt somewhat uneasy since they began approaching us like fresh meat. We quickly retreated downstairs. 

When my spouse inquired, "Back so soon?" I laughed out loud. 

Well, we all treated ourselves to lap dances, some of which were enjoyable, others unpleasant, some genuine, and others fabricated. Utilize your creative abilities.
