I strongly suggest visiting in pairs of couples, as it will undoubtedly provide the most enjoyable experience, given its social nature."

"Although the sizable portions of pizza at this establishment may appear generous, the overall dining experience does not particularly warrant repeated visits, despite the palatable flavors; the prices charged do not seem to align with the culinary quality offered, thereby making it an inconsequential venue for frequent pizza consumption."

"It so transpired that I found myself within the confines of a shopping mall, specifically the renowned Galleria Mall in Las Vegas, during my leisurely sojourn in that city. Feeling somewhat exhausted and financially depleted due to my relentless pursuit of retail therapy, I opted to take a respite and partake in a casual repast at a nearby eatery. My thoughts were interrupted by an insistent craving for a delectable hamburger, which prompted me to seek out a suitable establishment capable of satiating my gastronomical yearnings. As fate would have it, a Red Robin restaurant happened to be situated within close proximity, thereby rendering it an ideal choice for my culinary endeavors. Admittedly, my initial reaction was tinged with incredulity, as there existed a plethora of exceptional dining options within the city limits, yet I chose to frequent a chain restaurant that was seemingly ubiquitous. However, my desire for a straightforward, uncomplicated dining experience ultimately prevailed, leading me to select this particular venue. Upon entering the premises, I was escorted to a cozy table positioned near a window, affording me an unobstructed view of the bustling mall. Following a cursory examination of the menu, I settled upon a basic, unadorned burger, dubbed the 'Keep it Simple' option. The server, cognizant of the brief delay, offered an apology and proceeded to take my order. The ensuing wait, though perceived as somewhat prolonged, did not unduly perturb me, as I was not particularly pressed for time. Ultimately, my patience was rewarded, as the arrival of my culinary creation elicited feelings of satisfaction and contentment, owing to both its generous proportions and satisfying taste. For those who harbor a penchant for superior burgers, a visit to the Red Robin located within the Galleria Mall is certainly worth considering. Furthermore, I must admit that I am eager to explore the breadth of their menu offerings and sample alternative burgers during a future visit. In conclusion, I would assign this establishment a rating of three out of five stars, thereby acknowledging its merits while simultaneously underscoring room for improvement."
Crepes station is top notch. Seafood was okay.  Kind of worn down in the last 5 years. A deep cleaning would be great for this whole seating area. Probibly backstage too.

I have to rate this location 1 star on the whole parking situtation as well as the ease of getting in & out of the parking lot.   As Bill noted, whoever designed the layout and flow here was a total moron. 

The location gets 5 stars - it is convienent to my work and home. 

I would give the service here about 3.5 stars, because the employees are normally pretty helpful here.  And if you go at 10 minutes 'til closing time when there is a big line, sometimes the employees are down-right entertaining! 

There is almost always a line when I go here - so if you are planning a visit, just plan on having a wait if you need full service.

We have passed by this place a million times on our way to Sushi Creek and finally this morning found some time to stop.  First impression was the place was very clean and after seating ourselves we ordered, Denver omlet and some kind of breakfast bowl.  Food was good, service was very good.  Waiter made sure drinks were refilled and food was to our liking.

I haven't been to old navy in awhile so I was okay with this store. First time it was pretty messy from all the Christmas shoppers but the second time was a little cleaner. They did have good sales for all ages.

Normally I'd give this joint 5 stars bcuz almost EVERYTHING IS *AWSM*
However- just went w/my moms & ewww what a disappointment :(
She had the fried chicken & me a basic burger - burger was ehh ok at best but the chicken was bad news bears!!! The corn bread muffin was delivered warm but turned to a rock shortly after, leading me to believe they nuked it ... The batter on the chicken was nasty & the chicken itself was ALLLL FAT! Even the mixed veggies were gross!
At $14 bucks this dish is NO BUENO!
If you find yourself @ BBD - try the Cali Benedict or the sweet cream waffle & finish w/a personal pie of your liking or the diners specialty - a  big bear bear claw ;) enjoy!

We selected this hotel based on the favorable reviews we perused on Yelp, and our expectations were largely met, as the room we occupied was clean and hospitable, boasting a comfortable bed and a charming balcony. However, we encountered an issue with the complimentary Wi-Fi, which failed to function properly during our stay, rendering it unreliable for our needs. Additionally, while we appreciated the thoughtful gesture of offering free snacks, we found it impractical to venture down to the lobby each time we desired a refreshment, given the inconvenience it posed. Furthermore, the nocturnal disturbance caused by the thin walls was somewhat bothersome, albeit comprehensible considering the festive atmosphere generated by the wedding celebration taking place concurrently. In contrast, the morning meal provided was quite satisfying, exuding a cozy and lively ambiance, although our interactions with the hotel staff were limited, thus precluding us from forming an opinion regarding their service. Ultimately, while we cannot say with certainty whether we would opt to stay here again, our brief sojourn was undoubtedly pleasant.

Agree with everyone about looks, place is beautiful!  Gym is sorta small and hot, but has a ton of cardio (treadmills and Xfit).  If you are coming, be SURE to ask what is still closed.  We came looking for poolside fun, and the pool is closed for at least another MONTH! I could see happy sunbathers at Bellagio from my room splashing around...Vdara you are a cruel Mistress!!  Service friendly, but rather inefficient...tried to get burned out bulb in bathroom fixed, no luck.  Coffee in room is Kcup, two free and more in mini bar, bring your own milk, only creamer.  Also found out that on-site restaurant (Silk Road) will no longer be open for dinner.  Call before you book for amenities...I think they are having some issues.

By the time we reached here, we have so much liquid in us.  We stopped and rejuvenated ourselves with whatever soda and water we can find while walking on the strip, well u want to make sure u are amply hydrated with that 105 degree heat.\n\nBut I still wanted to taste at least 3 float samplers, but the line was too long and unruly, ppl were darting in and out like crazy, so that was enough for me.  C'mon, kids, move along...perambulating, to the M & M World.

I came here with a group for drinks before a group dinner...didn't like that you couldn't seat yourself at the bar without the hostess helping you.  We tried some drinks and french fries...all were good, albeit overpriced, but nothing to rush back for!
It's ok, it needs more fresh produce somewhere in the market. there are nice vendors there, but it needs more market types.

"It is an establishment belonging to the fast-food chain known as Burger King, and it is characterized by its lack of distinctive features or remarkable aspects worth mentioning, yet this particular location is well-maintained and provides a satisfactory level of service; furthermore, it remains open for business around the clock, which is convenient for customers who may require sustenance during unconventional hours, and it offers my preferred beverage of choice, specifically VAULT soda, which is dispensed from a tap."

So the name is like naming a place The Pizza or The Burger or The Taco. 

That said, The Sushi wins big points for the taste, but not for the portions or the price.

Inside is nice and cozy, with a basketball-arena style four-screen TV in the middle.

If price and portions were no object, this would be a five-star sushi bar as the care and taste of the sushi and sashimi can't be beat. 

The problem is the pricing is above many other sushi bars in the area. And the portions - especially when it comes to the teriyaki dishes - are more set for hamsters than people. 

The staff was cordial and offered hot tea or water to this guest waiting for a to-go order. 

All in all, a slight recommendation if price is no object and you're not THAT hungry.

"My affection for this diminutive establishment is profound. Edinburgh's commitment to preserving the traditional public houses in the city center is laudable, allowing future generations to revel in their timeless charm. The Rose St Brewery, in particular, exudes an endearing quaintness, with its upstairs lounge serving as my preferred area within the premises. The ambiance is further enhanced by carpeted floors and vintage photographs depicting the city's rich heritage adorning the walls, while a plaque proudly proclaims the pub's distinction as the Pub of The Year in 1985. \n\nUpon entering the establishment for a midday repast, I opted for a goat cheese salad, a deviation from my customary carnivorous inclinations, but one that seemed appealing due to its promised light and refreshing qualities. The dish arrived with two sizable chunks of goat cheese resting upon a bed of mixed greens and seasonal vegetables, complemented by a subtle dressing. When paired with a well-poured Guinness, the culinary experience was nothing short of perfection. While the staff's attentiveness left something to be desired, it is important to remember that, at its core, the Rose St Brewery remains a quintessential boozer, where one should not expect excessively formal service. Nonetheless, kudos are extended to the establishment for its efforts in maintaining a welcoming atmosphere, and one can only hope that it continues to thrive without succumbing to the pressures of modernity."
Seems to want to be O. But it did have good effects, music and talented artists. However, the actual story is lacking coherency and things aren't as stemless as a Cirque show.

It's hard to evaluate the merits of a coffee shop based on a french soda, but this place seems pretty good. It cost about $3 which is a bit pricey, but tasted good, and the syrups they use are good quality.\n\nI'd have to keep going here and grab a coffee to see how the place is on the whole.

"A diminutive, tranquil gaming establishment with a preference for minimal patronage and an emphasis on pristine, well-maintained equipment, complemented by an array of beverage and culinary options, thereby creating a low-traffic environment characterized by a scarcity of secondhand smoke, constitutes our optimal casino experience."
Grabbed a couple of dozen bagels and took to work.  Man they don't last long.  Bagels are good and the service is friendly.  They were real busy but make time to chat will working.

"Captivating venue with an endearing atmosphere and satisfactory culinary offerings. My significant other and I celebrated our birthdays at this establishment during the summer season. The primary motivation behind my desire to dine here was my curiosity regarding the Matilda Wong, which surpassed my expectations and left me utterly captivated. I strongly advise suspending all current activities and indulging in this delectable delight immediately. We initiated our culinary journey by sampling the Sweet Potato Ravioli complemented by a Gorgonzola Cream sauce. Although the sauce was somewhat overpowering and excessively rich for my taste, the four ravioli pieces were undeniably scrumptious. The dish was garnished with walnuts and accompanied by bread. My companion enjoyed the Hanger Steak, while I opted for the Muffuletta Pizza, excluding meat. Unfortunately, my pizza was excessively salted, likely due to the olive spread, but my partner appreciated his steak. However, nothing could compare to the sublime experience of savoring another Matilda Wong. We shared a dessert, but its name escapes me, as it was not particularly remarkable. Following this dining experience, I would consider returning to explore alternative menu options, such as the Farro Saute. The prices seemed reasonable, with $12 for ravioli, $12 for pizza, approximately $20 for steak, and less than $10 for dessert. Additionally, the mini pitchers of the Wong were priced at a very affordable $11."

24/7 Local video poker sports bar, everything you'd expect. It seems like I'm always just stopping in for a cheap breakfast, the Pt's Platter is way better than its Ihop and Denny's counterparts and the waitresses are much friendlier. Unfortunately, I always get sucked into the video poker machines and end up leaving with a full tummy and an empty wallet.

I ventured to that establishment to commemorate my spouse's successful culmination of her second year of dental education at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. The interior design boasted an aesthetic of sophisticated elegance, which was complemented by the hospitable demeanor of the hostess who greeted us upon arrival. Despite the brief delay in the serving of our meals, we opted to partake in the Steak Special designed for two individuals. Unfortunately, the waiting staff member appeared to be overwhelmed with his responsibilities, as he failed to provide adequate attention to our needs throughout the dining experience. Specifically, he neglected to replenish my water glass, compelling me to utilize my partner's water vessel and drink from it. In light of the cost and ambiance, the quality of service we received fell short of expectations.

A succinct update subsequent to my maiden commercial excursion in excess of eight months has necessitated an augmentation of concerns pertinent to my lactational responsibilities, which now involve a heightened level of scrutiny at security checkpoints. Specifically, at 5:00 AM on a Friday, which tends to be somewhat congested due to the influx of business travelers returning to the Eastern Seaboard, I encountered a peculiar scenario wherein each of my transparent containers were subjected to a meticulous examination by means of a sophisticated device designed to detect traces of explosive material. Fortunately, the TSA representative displayed remarkable courtesy and clarity in elucidating the procedure and potential consequences, thereby alleviating any apprehensions I may have harbored. Notwithstanding the substantial quantity of luggage requiring screening, the entire process was completed within a mere five minutes.

Terminal 3's Delta sector, while relatively limited in its offerings, does feature a few establishments that cater to early risers, such as Starbucks and Wendy's. However, the queues tend to be rather lengthy, particularly during peak hours.

Following the completion of renovations, locating the shuttle service for rental cars has become significantly less arduous. Furthermore, I was pleasantly surprised by the relatively brief waiting period at 12:30 AM, despite the considerable number of individuals who had arrived later than anticipated. It is worth mentioning that the shuttles themselves often exude a strong fragrance reminiscent of soap-based air fresheners, which can be somewhat overwhelming. Nevertheless, this is arguably preferable to an atmosphere tainted by unpleasant odors.

In conclusion, #Yelp365 - 169/365 serves as a testament to the unforeseen challenges and experiences that punctuate the existence of a nursing mother embarking upon commercial ventures.

If you happen to be inebriated to the extent that your cognitive faculties are significantly impaired, resulting in boisterous, rowdy, or disoriented behavior, and you are seeking a culinary establishment that can accommodate your current state, then this particular venue may be an ideal choice for satiating your gastronomical desires. It is not uncommon for patrons who have indulged in excessive alcoholic beverages to experience memorable moments within these premises, as they endeavor to regain a semblance of sobriety amidst the aromatic ambiance of freshly baked pizza, which, although palatable, may not be the most advisable option for consumption during the daylight hours due to its rich, artery-clogging characteristics, yet somehow manages to tantalize the taste buds in a manner that is particularly satisfying when consumed at an ungodly hour such as 1:45 am.

Pros: Casual, fun ambiance. Good location at Cosmopolitan. Awesome decor--lucha libre meets Las Vegas--red lamps on the ceiling, video screens with pictures flashing of Mexican artist Frida Kahlo and Chinese leader Mao, etc.\n\nCons: The menu was extensive but underwhelming. A bit over-priced for such a casual setting that basically served fried rice and tacos. It's tapas style, so expect to order several dishes for sharing. I don't think it was a fusion, but rather a menu with average Chinese and Mexican dishes.

"On the eve of Christmas Eve, pondering what to do, we opted to perambulate around Carolina Place Mall, capitalizing on its extended hours until 11 pm, and observe the frenzied shoppers seeking gifts. While not my preferred shopping venue, I acknowledge its convenience for those residing in the southside of town, particularly with the presence of an H&M, a welcome addition for those craving a diverse range of apparel options. Although not necessarily outdated, the mall exudes an old-school vibe, characterized by traditional anchor stores. Not a top choice for a shopping excursion, but a feasible alternative when proximity is a factor."

Came here for brunch before a Cardinals' game. Food was good and drinks very generous. Love that they have the bus to the games. Very nice that everyone could enjoy their time and nobody had to worry about driving.

Food was absolutely delicious,  but pricey. We were dressed in comfortable clothing (jeans/shorts/sweatshirts) and clearly did not fit in; this is a dressy crowd. We were also the youngest people there... it was mostly older adults 65+. Great views and good service.

This club is the new hit in Vegas for being so big but I didn't see anything that great about it. There's so many stairs. For a girl in heels and having to go up and down stairs all night to go back and forth between rooms is a hassle. The main room at the very top of the stairs is where they have their big shows/djs. The set up there sucks because there is a row of tables lining the front area and everyone stands up at those tables so you can't even see the performer no matter where you are standing. Always fun staring at a bunch of people's backs when a top DJ is playing and you paid money to see them. Same for the balcony in this main room. Just a row of tables right in front of the balcony so you can't see anything. Club is definitely made to try and force people to get tables. On the other hand Lights was a really awesome club. I suggest going there for shows instead.

I'd really wanted to like this place, but it just isn't happening. Family has eaten here several time and we've had excellent meals (burgers in particular), but not consistently. There is always something wrong: burger over cooked, cold food, orders not correct. If a restaurant is going to charge the higher prices, I expect consistently good food and service - not hit and miss.
I love the location, it is very \"little main street\" feeling. The food is good and priced very well. The service is slow, so i would not come here if you are in a rush.

I got great service and they totally set me up with the right bike after receiving wrong sizing from another Landis store. They definitely spent some time with me on my shoe choice. My sizing appointment went well and they answered a lot of my new road bike questions though I thought some of their techniques a bit questionable. \nHaven't used for repairs yet but have a mountain bike in rough shape to bring in so will review after that.

"The performance was ostensibly satisfactory, as the comedic individual executed merely four daredevil feats to substantiate his proficiency, while expending the majority of the time engaging in banter. The spectacle prompted curiosity regarding the methodology behind his cognizance of such information. Upon culmination of the production, he divulged the winning lottery numbers to the entire assemblage, evoking amusement and intrigue. Notwithstanding, I wouldn't attend another presentation, as I possess a predilection for novel experiences and endeavors, and thus, it is imperative for me to progress forthwith."

"I unequivocally adore this venue for breakfast, as it offers an unparalleled array of options that cater to my morning palate. I shall undoubtedly revisit this establishment when I next find myself in Las Vegas. \n\nRegarding dinner, I must express my disappointment with the menu, despite its price point of $108 for two individuals. While it boasts an impressive seafood selection, including crab, my expectations were not entirely met. In comparison, Mesa Grill, situated within Caesar Palace, provides a more satisfying dining experience for a similar cost."

"Underwhelmed experience with too much repetition."

"Not a huge fan" can be rephrased as "Underwhelmed experience" to convey a more negative connotation.
"It was okay at best" can be rephrased as "Average, nothing exceptional" to convey a more neutral tone.
"I've been to a few of these types of places around town" can be rephrased as "Familiarity with similar establishments in the local area" to sound more professional.
"This one was average" can be rephrased as "Underwhelming experience with too much repetition" to emphasize the lackluster nature of the establishment.

The modified text would be:
"Underwhelmed experience with too much repetition. Average, nothing exceptional. Familiarity with similar establishments in the local area. Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

This text uses longer and more complex sentences, as well as more professional vocabulary, while still conveying the same meaning as the original text. It also stays within the 512 token limit.

I was excited when this breakfast restaurant opened up in my neighborhood as I love to go out for breakfast almost everyday.

I have eaten there 3 times now but I only order 1 thing on the menu which I do enjoy quite a bit because their other items are a little unusual for me.

I went to eat there again yesterday and I was very sorry to see they have removed all side items off their menu. So I cannot order an omelet or 2 scrambles eggs with bacon, or a side of toast. Its one of the nine items or nothing. That does not work for me so that is why i have given this restaurant 3 stars. I hope they reconsider offering the basic breakfast items or I will probably not be back.

This was my second tapas place to visit in Las Vegas. 

The food was ok, nothing really stood out other than the paella. It was a 40 minute wait, but worth it to try at least once!

The service was top notch, from the moment you walk thru the entrance to the wait staff, manager, everyone made you feel welcome. 

The price, OH THE PRICE!   Only complaint I would say.  The entire menu is seriously over priced, even by Las Vegas Strip standards. It's the reason it will not be coming back. There are far better places to go for tapas on the Vegas strip for a better price & value. And important a better selection.

The atmosphere is great!  Plenty of light, open, not stuff. It has a bar area as well. The noise level is on the average. And the place is clean, they did a pretty good job clearing the table as you was done.  

All in all, I thought this place was OK at best.  But there are much much better places to visit.

This place is hit or miss. The service is usually subpar. Food as mentioned above is different each time. The chicken fried rice is either oily or dry. The orange chicken is very chewy which I do not enjoy. Prices are average I'd say. Overall not bad, but certainly not the best place for Chinese food in North Phoenix

A farewell lunch for a coworker landed me here.  I wasn't impressed with the popover bread they serve prior to the meal, it had a strong egg taste that almost spoiled my appetite which is hard to do.  Thankfully, my mushroom and gruyere panini was very tasty and larger than I expected, with lots of fries on the side.  Everyone enjoyed their food and they also offer a small discount for bank employees which is a plus.

I was gratified to discover this eatery within my lodging establishment, as it afforded me the convenience of not having to venture outdoors, particularly given the lateness of the hour. The bar area, however, presented a surprising spectacle, characterized by a greater number of patrons than I would have anticipated for a Monday evening. My culinary selection for the evening consisted of gnocchi, which I noticed was incorrectly spelled on the menu as "gnocci." Prior to bringing this to the attention of the waiting staff, I was struck by the peculiar manner in which the server pronounced the dish, specifically employing the phonetic rendering "knock-y." This led me to ponder whether she might also refer to her place of employment as "Bigelow Grill-e," a supposition that somewhat diminished the perception of refinement associated with my dining experience. Notwithstanding this, I found the overall atmosphere to be agreeable, with the exception of the dense cigarette smoke that permeated the bar area. Furthermore, I found myself perplexed by the enigmatic statement "Bigelow is serving innovative and imaginative interpretations of ethnic Pittsburgh classics," a phrase that piqued my curiosity and left me eager to acquire further insight from local individuals familiar with the culinary landscape of Pittsburgh.

"The early riser does not necessarily secure the prized vermiculate at Marche Atwater, particularly on a frigid winter Sunday morning when the majority of establishments remain unopened, with only a select few merchants offering their wares; however, fortune smiled upon us, enabling us to procure an assortment of delectable pastries at Boulangerie Premi\u00e8re Moisson, which served as an excellent initiation to the day's culinary pursuits. As the clock struck 8:30 a.m., a gradual influx of vendors began to populate the market, showcasing their fresh produce and artisanal goods. Marche Atwater, though smaller in scale than anticipated, still presented an array of options for those seeking gastronomical delights, although the absence of outdoor vendors during the winter season was palpable. In hindsight, a visit to Jean-Talon might have proven more fruitful."

Since my culinary predilections incline towards delectable lobster rolls, I opted to partake in this establishment's offerings during the meridian hour. In conjunction with my spouse, we elected to apportion a combination platter. The lobster roll itself was merely adequate, as the minuscule fragmentation of the meat evoked memories of canned tuna. Furthermore, my contentment was diminished by the superficial incision of the bun, which only extended partially through the bread, leading me to surmise that the restaurant was endeavoring to conserve their lobster supply. As my companion and I indulged in each bite, the lobster meat had a propensity to escape from its bread-based confines. The chowder fries, while not particularly remarkable, were palatable. However, considering the price point of over $20, I felt that the quantity of sustenance provided was insufficient to satiate my hunger, leaving me feeling underwhelmed.

"My predilection for fastidious gastronomical indulgences precipitated my visitation to this establishment, as the lyrical allusion had piqued my curiosity. Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the culinary offering, while not necessarily deplorable, did not quite meet the lofty standards I had envisioned. In fact, my palate found the patty to be somewhat akin to those proffered by Freddy's Frozen Custard, Culver's, and Steak and Shake, which, in my opinion, are superior. My initial inclination was to sample the burger in its standard configuration, which unfortunately included an excess of saccharine relish that proved to be an unfortunate choice. Consequently, I shall exercise greater discernment in my condimentary selections during future visits."

Good & decent lunch specials! However, I had to knock a couple stars because waitress came to our table at least 3 times & did not bother to fill water glasses. And we had to remind her for our roll that comes with lunch entre\u00e8! Fish was ok, not that fresh!

One of the stops on the Light Rail Bar Crawl, I felt that the Gin Mill was the most \"dive-y\" with a lot of dented chrome and scarred wood a bathroom that needed a flamethrower and some seriously loud music. I sat at the bar with my beer and watched the young-uns dancing to the DJ's tunes on the \"stage\". This vantage point gave me a great opportunity to see the bartenders in operation. Fast, efficient and friendly. Picking up abandoned empties and serving out drinks quickly. Impressive.\n\nBouncer at the door checking ID's. Taxi stand outside ready to take the wobbly folks home, but I was good. It's a very short walk to the Light Rail station that gave me time to sober up (I only had four drinks over five hours) while riding back to my parked car.

I have really enjoyed Dos Chandler for a few years now, I used to just drink their Negra Modelo and Dos X, but recently started eating the super ewey gooey chimi, which I would recommend to anyone.  Their quesadillas are awesome, they don't get much better than that.  (And I work in a New Mexican style kitchen). I feel they should offer more Mexican beers on tap, and definitely need more tequila options.  The frozen margaritas aren't anything to brag about, however.  The tables are usually sticky now whenever I sit down..and I haven't had a consistent server or bartender in a long time, there is always someone new, but they do a decent job taking care of me, but I can tell they don't have much support management-wise on the floor.  I give three stars due to dirty tables, poor beer selection on tap, and the usual generic tequila selection.  Being a Mexican restaurant they need to step up their game and clean the place up.

Ok I guess...Ate there this morning about 8:45. Sat down, was acknowledged with a nod and be with you in a minute...but was closer to 7 or 8. Ordered \"the handful\" which has 2 eggs, 2 pancakes, potatoes, and 2 bacon. Wanted to trade bacon for veggies but was told it would be $1 more even though on side items, the bacon cost more than the veggies...go figure.  Make the customer happy and he'll come back tomorrow, don't and he won't.\nIt was decent, can't complain too much, but can't give thumbs up either.

"Our August excursion culminated in our arrival at this esteemed establishment via taxi, a significantly more economical mode of transportation compared to the alternative shuttle service. Upon our arrival, the courteous Bell-Man expedited our check-in process by assuming responsibility for our luggage, thus obviating the necessity for us to endure an extended wait in the luggage claim area. The duration of our check-in process was approximately thirty to forty-five minutes on a Sunday, a time frame that we found to be quite reasonable given the influx of guests during the peak travel season. We had the pleasure of residing in the recently refurbished Grand Tower, which boasted an array of amenities designed to enhance our comfort and convenience, including a plush king-sized bed, an expensive yet functional mini refrigerator, and an impressive upgraded view that we thoroughly enjoyed during our anniversary celebration. Unfortunately, our spa experience was slightly marred by the presence of a nude female patron within the women's hot tub area, which engendered a sense of unease and discomfort due to the potential health risks associated with shared facilities. Moreover, we would like to caution prospective guests against utilizing the pool facilities, as we unfortunately contracted a persistent bacterial infection on our legs that required four weeks of antibiotic treatment to resolve."

This is the Grand Lux Cafe situated within the premises of the esteemed Venetian resort. It is worth mentioning that there exists an alternative location of the same establishment in the Palazzo, however, according to local patrons, the quality of service and culinary offerings at this particular branch are deemed superior. For the sake of comparison, it is pertinent to note that the author has had the pleasure of visiting another Grand Lux Cafe situated in the Beverly Center of Beverly Hills; and while both establishments share certain commonalities in terms of their ambiance and gastronomical offerings, this specific location boasts the unique distinction of being open for business on a twenty-four hour basis.

Upon arriving with a sizable contingent of approximately fifteen individuals, the group was able to secure seating arrangements without incident, despite the fact that it was peak dining time and no prior reservations had been made (it is customary to reserve tables at least two hours in advance).

The author and a companion opted to share a pizza pie adorned with sausage, pepperoni, and mushrooms. While the dough was somewhat overly soft and difficult to handle without the toppings breaking apart, the flavor of the crust itself was quite satisfying. As a result, the author and her companion found themselves consuming the crust of each slice, leaving behind the toppings.

It is important to note that the menu at Grand Lux Cafe features an extensive array of culinary options, which bears a striking similarity to that of Cheesecake Factory, given that the two establishments share a common affiliation. Nonetheless, it is recommended that patrons exercise caution when selecting items from the Asian-inspired section of the menu, as the authenticity of such dishes may be subject to debate.
I was a bit dubious about a cafe that advertises coffee that doesn't taste like coffee but the espresso was decent. Not awesome but better than Starbucks.

"Gastronomical excellence notwithstanding, the sluggishness and inattention exhibited by the waiting staff at this establishment significantly diminishes the overall dining experience. My previous visit, which occurred almost precisely a year ago, was marred by an analogous set of circumstances, wherein the manager demonstrated commendable attentiveness while the servers displayed an utter lack of concern towards our needs. The elapsed time between ordering and consumption stretched to an unacceptable extent, warranting my personal intervention to inquire about the delay not once, but twice. Notwithstanding these issues, the culinary offerings did indeed prove satisfying. Thus, if one prioritizes gustatory pleasure over promptness of service and the demeanor of the staff, Kona Grill may still be a suitable choice."

My Partner and I flew into Phoenix last week for the Christmas Holiday and we stopped here for lunch before heading out to the family.    I was fairly impressed with the cuisine and the ambiance.

I had a burger with all the trimmings and it was prepared perfectly.  I would have liked a few more fries with the burger, but I probably didn't need them.

I have to say the 80's hair band music videos playing were a little weird though.

If I find myself back in Phoenix, I will eat here again.

This is exactly what I was looking for in a hotel during my one night stay in Pittsburgh. Close to the city, but far enough out to get free parking and a reasonable rate (under $100).

The room was fairly small, but I was only planning on sleeping in it. It was clean so I couldn't ask for much more. The people at the front desk were very friendly too.

If I go back to Pittsburgh, I will absolutely stay here again.

"I had the pleasure of dining at Rigatonys this evening in the company of my sibling and niece, partaking in a delectable array of culinary delights. My niece and I opted to share a serving of manicotti, which, while not the most extraordinary example of its kind, was still palatable enough to warrant consumption. My sister, however, elected to sample the Mahi special, which was served with a side of asparagus and quinoa pasta. Her enthusiasm for the dish was unbridled, praising the creamy dill sauce adorning the fish and the generous helping of salami, cheeses, olives, pepperocini, and other assorted vegetables accompanying it. To conclude our repast, we indulged in a portion of spumoni, the authenticity of which was undeniable and satisfyingly sizable. Our server, Bryce, provided attentive and informed service throughout the meal, taking care to apprise us of the supplementary fee associated with splitting a plate. Additionally, a complimentary basket of bread was brought to our table, contributing further to the overall enjoyment of our dining experience. In conclusion, our visit to Rigatonys was thoroughly enjoyable, and we look forward to returning in the future."

I visited this establishment on a Saturday afternoon with the intention of partaking in their midday repast, but upon arriving, I encountered an abundance of patrons already present, thus leading me to opt for taking my sustenance with me instead. Upon eventually consuming my torta ahogada, I noticed that it had become saturated with the piquant sauce in which it was submerged, rendering it unpleasantly soggy and prone to disintegration at an accelerated rate. While I typically possess a certain degree of tolerance towards pungent culinary creations, I must admit that the overwhelming sensation of fiery heat permeated my taste buds to such an extent that it eclipsed any other discernible flavors. My companion elected to sample three fish tacos, which, regrettably, proved to be minuscule in size. Consequently, they remained unsatisfied and sought sustenance elsewhere, thereby leading to an overall experience that fell short of my expectations, given the copious favorable assessments I had previously encountered on Yelp.

Food good sometimes ,remodel nice. 
2 times there .  1 waitress had attitude over easy eggs runny did not eat nothing done.
2 attitude waitress again we were a group after bowling  some women playing. Mah jong told us to be quiet it is a restaurant we were paying they were playing for free.
Maybe we should start a poker group there and not pay then IHOP would listen to our complaints.

I've made plenty of bad decisions here.\n\nHave you ever been somewhere where it means nothing, but somehow, means everything? I like coming to Maz. They don't have a good selection of beer. Or drinks. They don't have good pool tables. There are plenty of shady things that go on here. But still I find myself here every once in a while; generally I'm in a really crappy mood, or I'm feeling to good to go home and too mashed up to go anywhere else.

The service, albeit slightly tardy, was eventually compensated by the quality of the gastronomic offerings. The sushi exhibited delectable characteristics, while the burger possessed distinctive attributes that imparted a rich and savory taste. Additionally, our indulgence in the mixed deluxe fries basket proved to be an extraordinary culinary experience. I am unequivocally inclined to revisit this establishment based on the culinary delights encountered.

"A moderate lodging facility, offering a comfortable respite in a prime location, proximal to an array of amenities, including a shopping mall, cinema, and various dining establishments, while remaining accessible to primary tourist attractions within a mere 10-15 minute distance. Additionally, this accommodation boasts a tranquil atmosphere, nestled amidst a picturesque neighborhood, replete with charming cafes and boutiques, mere steps away. Guests may enjoy the inviting ambiance of the hotel's lounge area, complete with a fireplace, ideal for relaxing with a refreshing beverage, whether alcoholic or non-alcoholic in nature. Furthermore, a comprehensive dining experience is available on-site, catering to guests' culinary needs, should they opt to forego venturing out into the city. However, it is worth noting that the rooms themselves suffer from somewhat diminutive soundproofing, resulting in an increased auditory awareness of fellow patrons' comings and goings. Moreover, the complimentary wireless internet connection, while appreciated, exhibits sluggish speeds, hindering productivity and efficiency. In summary, this establishment offers a suitable temporary abode for travelers seeking convenience and accessibility, without necessarily serving as a prolonged haven for leisurely activities."
Came in. Waiter was alright. Gave me a stair like I didn't know what I was doing. He gave mediocre service. I'm full

Qdoba is ok. Same idea as Chipotle Grill, but, in my opinion, the food just doesn't taste as good. The burritos don't have that magic ingredient that makes me want to return. And I did not dig the decorating scheme - especially the concrete floors and metal tables. It feels cold and dark, even in the summer.

I recently went to this restaurant to celebrate my coworkers birthday. I have never had any problems with Applebee's; however, this particular time, I ordered the shrimp and spinach salad and found some type of plastic in my salad. Both the manager and waitress apologized for the incident and were very quick to fix the problem. I was offered a new salad (which I took to go because my coworkers had finished their meal already) and when the food was brought out to me, the manager came back again to apologize. My meal was also free. I gave them a 3 because of how both the manager and waitress quickly fixed the problem. I don't think it was their fault but rather the fault of the cooks who were preparing the foods. My salad was also very good!

I normally come every Sunday during football season. Today was a spur of the moment decision. Sat down to my favorite Asian bartender in the US. She recommend the wings which were phenomenal. Also ordered the Kobe burger. Took it home, opened the box and found two ROTTEN tomatoes which smelled worse than organic fertilizer and just as mushy. Took it back to get a new one, where I was told it was normal for that kind of tomato to smell, look, and feel like a decomposed body. This asst manager clearly has no idea what food or customer service looks like. Luckily the GM was there to smooth things over. If it weren't for my bartender, I would never set foot back in this place again.

"Horchata, a beverage of unparalleled flavor and delight, has the propensity to elicit expressions of immense pleasure from those who partake in its consumption. Moreover, the presence of familiar countenances within the establishment contributes to an atmosphere of comfort and conviviality. Furthermore, the culinary offerings, specifically the vegetarian burrito and breakfast burrito, are of exceptional quality and generously portioned. However, it is worth noting that while the prices are reasonable, the guacamole, a crucial component of any respectable Mexican dish, falls short of expectations, thus necessitating further refinement."

I go to this facility usually 3 nights per week at about 2am and love it. Its jot crowded at all, usually having about 3-5 people in it. I can have the basketball court to myself I wanted and move freely through workout stations.

Upon initial inspection, this establishment appeared to conform to the conventional characteristics of a tourist trap, given its location within the historic district and its assortment of traditional Mexican knick-knacks. However, upon further examination, the prices were discovered to be reasonable and not exorbitant, as previously assumed. A vibrant straw sombrero was acquired for a mere $5, and various other items within the store were observed to possess price tags that were similarly fair and affordable. This store serves as a veritable treasure trove for those seeking to create an unforgettable festive experience, offering an extensive array of items tailored specifically to the celebration of Dia de Muertos, including but not limited to colorful masks, plates, cups, and even ornaments for garden decor. Unfortunately, the staff members present within the store did not exhibit a warm or welcoming demeanor; however, the overall ambiance of the store was well-maintained, ensuring a satisfying shopping experience for patrons. The vast selection of trinkets available guarantees that customers will undoubtedly depart the premises with a sense of contentment and satisfaction.

We have been going to PP for over 17 years. Dr Chiles and Dr Salek have been my children's doctors from the beginning. We have seen a lot of faces come and go. Now that PP has merged with  another very large group, it just isn't the same. I still love our doctors and that is why we stay as my children are older now and need less frequent visits. This office just doesn't have the same family friendly feel it once used to.

Patience is required as they take their sweet time and it isn't even busy. It's been 30 minutes and I don't know that they'll be done soon. I would come back because it's cheap but definitely not during 'rush' hour.

"This establishment is truly a behemoth; its gargantuan proportions are simply staggering. Attempting to navigate the vast expanse of the casino from the sidewalk entrance on the strip is an exercise in futility, as the labyrinthine layout and contradictory signage will inevitably lead to disorientation and confusion. Despite its impressive grandeur, the hotel's age is beginning to show in various aspects, with remnants of its former Wizard of Oz/Hollywood motif now conspicuous only by their absence. A pervasive verdant hue envelops everything, creating an ambiance that is both surreal and overwhelming."

Just wanted to update. Manager contacted us. Was willing to give full refund or have the top installed for free. Seems there was a communication issue. Issue was resolved, even kept the truck box cover. Did have an issue, but company did resolve in a timely manner and apologized for the miscommunication

"Although I would rate Dolce a mere 3.5 stars if given the opportunity, I must admit that the ambiance of this establishment is quite inviting and conducive to a relaxed dining experience. However, my culinary exploits at this location have been limited to a few select appetizers, specifically their delectable hummus and crispy pita chips. Yet, based on the opinions of others, I may consider elevating my assessment after partaking in their more comprehensive menu offerings. As an ardent devotee of vinous delights, I find myself drawn to this wine bar, eager to indulge in a rich, full-bodied glass of red wine while engaging in lively discourse with companions. Unfortunately, my experiences with the service staff have been somewhat mixed, with some members exhibiting a certain aloofness or reserve in their interactions. Nevertheless, such sentiments are merely anecdotal and do not detract significantly from the overall appeal of the venue. Additionally, I lament the meager selection of wines available, a sentiment shared by a previous reviewer. In light of these factors, I would still recommend paying Dolce a visit, particularly if you find yourself in close proximity to the NoDa neighborhood."

We halted our journey at this establishment for an interval of recreation and relaxation during the evening hours, as I was feeling rather indolent and it was in close proximity to my place of employment. As it transpired, they offered a satisfactory happy hour with diverse potable specials, half-priced chosen appetizers, and a select two culinary delights special that persisted from opening until closing for the modest sum of $6.99. I opted for the Tortilla soup and cheese enchiladas, which proved to be palatable and satisfying, accompanied by a side of rice and beans. Our server exhibited exceptional hospitality and I regret not committing her name to memory, but after indulging in a few of the happy hour Margaritas, my cognitive faculties were somewhat impaired.

"My culinary excursion to this establishment was predicated upon a glowing endorsement from an acquaintance who vehemently asserted that this was, without a doubt, the optimal pizza proffered within the city limits of Las Vegas. While I find such a claim to be somewhat dubious, given the city's limited reputation for exceptional pizza establishments, I decided to indulge my taste buds and form my own opinion. As a lifelong devotee of New York-style pizza, my standards are unwaveringly high, and I find it challenging to believe that any other region can surpass the culinary prowess of the Big Apple. Thus, I embarked upon this gastronomical adventure with a healthy dose of skepticism.  

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed they were offering a special promotion, wherein all pizzas were being offered at a fifty percent discount. Seizing the opportunity to sample their wares without breaking the bank, I opted for a large pie adorned with pepperoni, sausage, and black olives. Alas, my expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the pizza left something to be desired. Specifically, the crust lacked the requisite crispness that I have come to expect from a truly exceptional pizza. Furthermore, the sausage and pepperoni toppings contributed to an unfortunate sogginess that permeated the entire pie. Admittedly, the crust exhibited some promise, but it was not enough to salvage the dish from its overall mediocrity.  

In conclusion, while this establishment may lay claim to being the best pizza in Las Vegas, it falls short of the lofty standards that I have established for truly outstanding pizza. My culinary journey, regrettably, did not culminate in the discovery of a gastronomical masterpiece."

I have sat in the dining room as well as the hibachi grill on several occasions at this restaurant. I've never had a bad experience while dining at the grill. The food has always been superb and the chefs are very entertaining!

The dining room experience is less than satisfactory, however. Each time I've been there for sushi, I've had to wait 30+ minutes for my meal (the wait has always been acknowledged by the staff...last time each waiting table was given complimentary edamame). Not enough sushi chefs (only 1 person was working on each occasion) and/or wait staff.

I'd love to give this restaurant a higher rating, but until I see stellar service throughout the establishment, I have to go with ***.

Took my commuter in for an oil change and was very pleased with the cost and speed that it got done.  The location is perfect as well to just take a walk over to Costco to shop or snack while waiting.  \n\nFYI Check for coupons on their Yelp page before going it might save you some money like it did me :)

This was supposed to be Las Vegas' latest and greatest club... I thoroughly enjoyed the sound and the vibe of the House floor, but it was so crowded that you couldn't dance let alone stand anywhere without it being shoulder to shoulder. We opt to say in the Hip Hop area that was equally as crowded, but luckily we found a small corner to dance in. After a while, we got even luckier as a girl invited us to dance in her table reserve area and Warren G performed. Being West Coast girls my group knew all the songs and had a great time watching his show. We left immediately after because it was just too packed for us.\n\nDon't buy bottled water b/c the small bottle costs $9 talk about rip off.

"My initial experience at this establishment was enjoyable, and I intended to bestow a perfect rating, as the culinary offerings were satisfactory and I consumed them on consecutive days. However, upon my return, I perceived a decline in quality regarding the sandwich I ordered. Specifically, the absence of lettuce in all four Earl's club sandwiches was glaring, and an excess of bacon resulted in an overpowering saltiness. Consequently, my enthusiasm for this venue has waned, and I shall not experience cravings for its fare in the future."

A viable alternative to Pita Jungle, albeit with a tad elevated price point relative to the quantity and quality of the fare in comparison to its competitor. My personal experience has been limited to the Togo option, which, while satisfactory, may not always provide the most pleasant dining experience, particularly when taking into account the ambient atmosphere. Notwithstanding, they accommodate Hooka smoking on the patio, a feature that, although potentially bothersome to some, does not detract from the culinary enjoyment. Upon collection of my Togo order, I must steel myself against the pungent Hooka odor that permeates the outdoor seating area. Despite these minor drawbacks, the cuisine generally meets expectations, leaving room for only slight adjustments to enhance the overall dining experience.

The tacos exuded an unpleasant oiliness and lacked any semblance of flavor, leaving me utterly disillusioned with my culinary selection. Furthermore, the establishment's overall cleanliness was subpar, as evidenced by the presence of dirt on the floors, while the staff responsible for preparing the comestibles exhibited limited proficiency in the English language.

Kitty's cafe, nestled within the esteemed El Cortez Hotel and Casino, offers a dining experience reminiscent of a bygone era, replete with the warm, personalized service that has become synonymous with this venerable establishment. Patrons can indulge in traditional counter service or occupy cozy booths, all while being addressed with endearments such as "honey" or, for regulars, by their given names, courtesy of the affable servers. The menu, though unpretentious, boasts generous portions; case in point, the grilled sourdough melt, featuring turkey and ham, which, albeit unremarkable, proved satisfying. However, a novice culinary artisan helming the kitchen on the day of our visit resulted in a tardy turnaround time for dishes. Notwithstanding, Kitty's remains an optimal destination for a late-night repast, catering to those seeking sustenance following an evening of revelry within the hotel's confines or, alternatively, for individuals yearning for a modest, nocturnal dining experience. It is worth noting that the once ubiquitous "$1.99 specials" have, regrettably, become a distant memory.

This Starbucks is I guess owned by NY NY hotel so they don't use the App...sucky store!! No fare to the app users when you don't have cash on you! Good thing I had money this time and didn't loose to the slot machines here!  \n\nIt's always busy here but goes pretty fast and has a good selection of goods to eat. They open 24/7 which is a good thing. They make their coffee good. Of course, I will be back since this Starbucks is in our hotel but start using the app payment and have them work with Starbucks so we can get our points! Hahaha

Here we are at another DDD visited restaurant...

Melissa, our server, offered a bubbly good morning and 

After the customary 10 minute wait. (No wait usually means not great)

Coffee full bodied and rich, diet coke properly carbonated.

Our eggs were delivered so fast I only got three sentences of this review completed before arrival.

Our glasses were always kept full!

Nice breakfast place.

It was a convenient walk over from the FireSky hotel across the street. We started with the green pork chili. It was tasty, but not hot. We also had the lamb fondue, which is lamb rack with a squash sauce to dip them in. The squash "fondue" part was quite tasty. The lamb was cooked well.

For the main course I tried the braised short rib. It was really big. It didn't have a ton of flavour; a shame for such a tasty meat. It needed salt & pepper and the core seasoning just didn't stand out.

The food is good, but I feel it's all a bit under seasoned. Everything (except the lamb fondue) could have had some extra punch to it. Still, it wasn't so bad that you feel ripped off, so I'm going 3 stars on this.

"The gastronomical experience at this establishment was rather dichotomous, as the tapas were delectable, particularly the fungi-based risotto, while the paella exhibited an excessive sodium content. Notwithstanding, the oxtail was tender, the potatoes were delightful, and the poultry dish was savory, although I accidentally ingested a clove of garlic, which may have been problematic for vampiric individuals. Furthermore, the quality of service within the eatery was unremarkable, in contrast to the superior hospitality offered at the adjacent cafÃ©."

"Prior to attending the performance at the Luxor, our dining possibilities were restricted, and the recommendation provided by the youthful ticket agent, who was only 20 years of age, did not align with our culinary preferences. Despite his assurance that T&T was exceptional, we should have been aware that our tastes would differ. We initiated our meal with a round of mojitos, which our server claimed were of superior quality. Although I have had the opportunity to indulge in mojitos on numerous occasions and have developed a fondness for them, the ones presented to us were excessively sweet. In an attempt to counteract the sugary flavor, I requested club soda twice, but unfortunately, it failed to enhance the beverage. The mojitos were unpleasant, and we could only consume half of them. The complimentary chips and salsa were also subpar, which was unexpected since they are typically straightforward to prepare adequately. My companion and I opted for distinct dishes, with mine being tacos and hers consisting of a shrimp-based dish. Unfortunately, both were merely average in taste. Our server exhibited friendly behavior and displayed generosity by offering us free admission to the show. However, we had already procured our tickets, rendering their kind gesture unnecessary. Considering the unsatisfactory dining experience, I would not consider returning to this establishment. Instead, I would have preferred to dine at the Asian restaurant had I known their menu was impressive."

"Indubitably, the culinary experience I relished during my recent sojourn in Las Vegas with my siblings was unparalleled. Despite our intentions to maintain a thrifty budget throughout our six-day escapade, this eatery, recommended by a acquaintance of my sister, delivered an exceptional gastronomic encounter, albeit with some reservations regarding its location and ambiance. Sequestered within the confines of a food court, the venue's unassuming facade belied the delectable fare served within. Although the setting was somewhat lackluster, the quality of the cuisine more than compensated for any aesthetic shortcomings. A shared Caesar salad proved satisfying, while the filet mignon meatballs, served with spaghetti and a rich red sauce, were nothing short of mouthwatering. Furthermore, the Quattro Stagioni pizza, prepared in a wood-fired oven, showcased an exemplary balance of flavors and textures. Notwithstanding the laudable culinary offerings, the service we received left much to be desired. Our server, an individual of Italian descent with an exaggerated machismo demeanor, devoted an inordinate amount of attention to the younger female patrons dining adjacent to us, while neglecting his responsibilities towards us. Ultimately, it fell upon a busboy to retrieve our server from his distractions and attend to our needs. In conclusion, while the food at this establishment merits high praise, the service we encountered was subpar and warrants improvement."

"I thoroughly enjoyed recognizing The Dog empire during my prolonged weekend excursion to Edinburgh, as it boasted an exceptional and stylish design, accompanied by remarkable eatery concepts, including The Dog, UnderDog, SeaDog, and Amore Dog. I sincerely wished I had ample time to sample all of their delectable offerings! My flank steak salad was merely satisfactory, possessing a somewhat tough texture, yet the sweet balsamic reduction complemented the bitter arugula with precision. In contrast, my companion's mushroom risotto was exquisitely prepared and indulgent, earning it a well-deserved four stars. Unfortunately, our culinary journey concluded with a less than impressive tiramisu, which lacked the potency of espresso and featured a chilling temperature that I personally prefer for the dessert. Moreover, the dark chocolate cocoa powder overwhelmed the delicate flavor of the dish when consumed in substantial amounts, prompting us to discard the upper layer of the dessert."
Food was great and reasonably priced with restaurant.com coupon. I would've gave five stars if the waiter wasn't so cocky and direct.

Great beer selection.  But if you are looking for more consistency, it is probably not the spot (they have a rotating tap selection).  The food was actually quite wonderful. I didn't expect much for bar food, but was pleasantly surprised.  I went with a large group and we had a great time drinking and answering trivia questions from one of their board games (there is a whole table full of games for customers to enjoy, yay!). \n\nI'd say the biggest downfall for this place is the atmosphere and service... there was pretty full crowd when I went in-and only 1 server for the whole place.  Ridiculous.  He was real nice and apologetic so we took it all in stride.  But there were _long_ stretches where we didn't see him or get helped.  He did his best to keep up, but it was a noticeable problem. Sure I'd go back, but never again when hungry.  As for the atmosphere--the bar is a few steps up from a dive.  Okay to hang out for locals, but not the place to impress.  Friendly staff, good food and beer are enough to make you overlook this.

I have been a patron of this establishment for a considerable duration, and my satisfaction has been contingent upon the attendance of Dr. Finch, whose proficiency in veterinary medicine and bedside manner have engendered a sense of confidence and tranquility in me, as a concerned pet owner. It is worth mentioning that he has executed a relatively minor surgical procedure on my canine companion, Dozer, which involved the employment of a laser to excise a small growth from her eyelid, and his performance was exemplary, characterized by a commendable level of composure, erudition, and a propitious demeanor towards our cherished animal. Furthermore, it has come to my attention that he will likely be undertaking a second, considerably more complex operation on her, specifically an ACL repair, and I am entirely at ease with entrusting her care to him. Notwithstanding, I have chosen to revise my evaluation downward by a marginal extent, motivated by two primary factors. Firstly, my initial assessment may have been somewhat generous, as I was still in the process of formulating my criteria for evaluating veterinary facilities; and secondly, certain acquaintances have expressed unwavering devotion to their respective veterinarians, whereas my relationship with this establishment, although satisfactory, does not quite rise to that level of enthusiasm. Additionally, I must admit that I have periodically sought alternatives, but procrastination has led me to rely on Dr. Finch's services when Dozer has required urgent medical attention.

"Thus far, my culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the breakfast menu, specifically the corned beef and farmer's omlette. While the fare has been satisfactory, it fails to elicit any exceptional praise. However, I do appreciate the option to substitute a blueberry muffin for toast. The server has demonstrated politeness and accommodating behavior, exemplified by their willingness to provide ranch dressing with my hash browns, an unconventional yet personal preference. Additionally, this venue enjoys the distinction of being the sole dining option beyond 10 p.m. in close proximity, excluding those situated within gaming establishments, and boasts reasonable pricing. Consequently, it presents itself as a suitable setting for a relaxed meal in the company of a friend. Nonetheless, I must express my disappointment regarding the absence of dark chicken meat on the menu, as the lighter variety tends to possess an undesirable dryness."

"Although the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the prices charged for said edibles were utterly exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous. Eighteen dollars for a serving of enchiladas? Such an amount would be better suited to purchasing a meal at a high-end eatery, not a run-of-the-mill Mexican establishment. Furthermore, the cost of the accompanying chips and guacamole was equally egregious, amounting to nine dollars. While the quality of the fare was undeniable, it by no means warranted such an extravagant price tag. In light of these considerations, it is my belief that this particular dining establishment harbors an inflated sense of self-importance, as evidenced by the presence of cloth napkins and ornate paper menus, which do little to justify the excessive expense. In conclusion, due to the aforementioned factors, I shall not be inclined to return to this restaurant, as there are numerous other options available that provide comparable cuisine at a significantly lower cost."

Mert's can be characterized as an eatery that exudes a distinctly southern ambiance, which would not be out of place in a televised program featuring establishments of its ilk, such as Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. The interior design evokes a sense of quintessential southern hospitality, effectively creating a welcoming atmosphere for patrons who are not native to the area. However, it is not advisable to partake in the midday repast at this establishment, as the portions are generous and the fare is rich, rendering it imprudent to consume anything substantial during the afternoon hours. The quality of service is satisfactory, and while the cuisine may not be exceptional, it remains a passable choice for a casual dining experience.

Harrah's boasts an intelligent business model pertaining to its Carnaval Court, strategically positioned along a heavily traversed thoroughfare that effectively lures tourists into its vicinity. Surrounded by numerous kiosks offering an array of trivial knick-knacks easily accessible to inebriated patrons, even sober individuals such as myself and my companions succumbed to the allure of acquiring those novelty shirts responsive to musical rhythms. These gaudy apparel items symbolized our camaraderie, prompting us to purchase matching shirts. Upon entering the vibrant party arena adorned in our recently purchased attire, we received copious admiration and praise from fellow revelers. The expansive dance floor facilitates unrestricted movement, allowing patrons to fully indulge in their dancing desires. Located outdoors, the venue benefits from increased ventilation, thereby mitigating the potential for overheating typically associated with densely populated dance floors. The flair bartenders put on an entertaining display, complemented by their ability to craft respectable cocktails. Offering a seamless transition between merrymaking and gaming, this establishment features dedicated table games, catering to the diverse preferences of Vegas visitors. In essence, it encompasses all the essential elements sought after by patrons in the city's vibrant nightlife.

"It was gratifying to indulge in a tranquil dining experience this week, and if you seek respite from the rigors of daily life, this establishment is an ideal setting in which to do so. The panoramic view from the restaurant's vantage point is truly breathtaking, and the hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting. I opted for the Rib eye steak, which was cooked to perfection, and the accompanying Blue cheese potatoes were delectable, although the potency of the Blue Cheese slightly overshadowed the natural flavor of the potatoes. Additionally, I sampled a slice of cake for dessert, but unfortunately, the ice cream had begun to thaw, rendering it somewhat soggy, and the cake itself was slightly dry. Considering the cost, I anticipated a more fastidious attention to detail in regards to the presentation of the dessert course. Nonetheless, the ambiance and culinary offerings made for a satisfying excursion."

Dim sum, a culinary delight recommended by a friend, aroused my curiosity due to its exclusivity, as it was only available twice a year. However, upon indulging in the delectable offerings, I couldn't help but feel that the quality of the dim sum style food would have been superior if the establishment had concentrated solely on that aspect, instead of incorporating a seafood buffet. Although the dishes were savory, some were unfortunately served at room temperature. Furthermore, the absence of chili oil, a staple condiment in most Chinese eateries I frequent in San Diego, was conspicuous, yet tolerable given the sodium-rich nature of the items we consumed. Nonetheless, the non-dim sum options proved impressive, boasting fresh raw oysters, succulent crab legs, decadent lobster, and expertly crafted nigiri. My request for sushi pieces without rice was accommodated by the gracious sushi chef, albeit the generous slice thickness slightly diminished my enjoyment. A craving for octopus prompted me to explore the buffet line, whereupon I discovered a tantalizing octopus and cucumber salad, undoubtedly the highlight of the spread. An abundance of fresh fruit, including juicy mandarin oranges, tart cherries, and exotic rambutan, beckoned, but the desire to partake in a more leisurely dining experience prevailed. While the dessert bar showcased an admirable selection, it fell short of exceptional. My preference for dim sum, second only to sushi, has piqued my interest in revisiting this establishment during my forthcoming trip to San Diego.

"It's analogous to gambling. Occasionally, one experiences substantial success...while at other times, the outcome is rather meager. 

The production commenced auspiciously. Our Master of Ceremonies was engaging and hilarious, possessing an unwavering comfort in his own skin while utilizing his personal experiences as fodder for his humor, yet maintaining a keen awareness of social conventions to avoid traversing boundaries. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for the subsequent two comedians, whose performances were marred by crudeness, excessive vulgarity, and a tendency to forcefully impose their questionable humor upon the audience, regardless of conspicuous signs of discomfort. At one juncture, a female spectator felt compelled to rise and request that the comedian move on, only to be met with further exploitation of the situation as a means of continuing his set. While employing someone as the focal point of humor may be acceptable, it becomes problematic when literally no one else is participating in mirth. Fortunately, our capable MC effectively applied a makeshift solution to salvage each of these two underwhelming performances. 

The featured act, Jay Reid, significantly redeemed the entire evening...which would have otherwise been a resounding disappointment at $20 per ticket. Mr. Reid capitalized on the stage's potential, incorporating the stool and microphone stand into his routine and presenting jokes pertinent to contemporary affairs and customarily delicate or taboo subjects. His humor was tasteful, and he demonstrated great class and coolness by lingering afterward to interact with the audience."

I commemorated the milestone of my eighteenth year of existence by partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment in the company of a select group of acquaintances. It is pertinent to note that their hours of operation, specifically the period designated as "happy hour," are limited to weekdays between the hours of two and six post meridiem, thereby rendering our arrival at seven o'clock somewhat inconvenient. Notwithstanding this minor setback, I opted to sample their grilled chicken sandwich, which, while palatable, exhibited a certain pinkish hue that might have been attributable to an abbreviated cooking duration. Furthermore, the prolonged preparation time of approximately forty-five minutes, coupled with my considerable hunger, precluded me from returning said item to the kitchen for further culinary refinement. In addition, we collectively decided to partake in a shared consumption of their frozen hot chocolate beverage, which, despite its latent promise, unfortunately necessitated a significant amount of mastication upon its icy constituents throughout its duration. It is worth mentioning that the pace of service was somewhat leisurely and that the cost, while not drastically exceeding that of Cheesecake Factory, still fell within a higher price bracket. Notwithstanding these observations, I am willing to accord this eatery a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate improvement.

This isn't your Grandpa's Flamingo anymore. I would even venture to say this isn't your overweight Chain smoking uncle Larry's Flamingo we all knew and didn't love from 5-10 years ago!

Before My recent trip to The Flamingo, the thought of staying there would immediately trigger thoughts of Depressing 1980's decor, overweight fanny pack wearing gamblers & The over exuberant expressions of Donnie & Marie as they stared longingly into each others eyes trying to forget about that one night back in 77' when things went a little to far. But to the contrary I must say the Flamingo has really cleaned up its act. The new decor is nice and the casino floor is clean and 80% fanny pack clear. 

Now saying that I have yet to stay in a room, but I will say that , where as before I would've only taken a side chick I was slightly ashamed of. Now I would be ok with taking a side chick I was not ashamed of, as well as possibly a girl that I have been dating awhile, all the while  insisting "Why do we have to put labels on what we are" here without hesitation!

All in all The Flamingo is an OK place with a GREAT location that I would recommend anyone walking the strip to try out. Hey, who knows you may finally be the first person to see Donnie and Marie finally consummate 35 years of tension and frustration!

I've eaten here twice when I was staying at Treasure Island. The Pho is just okay but it'll do in a pinch. It probably smells better than it tastes.

I've tried to veggie spring rolls which were decent, but the peanut sauce is just okay - kind of coco-nutty. 

I got the Pho Tai and my friend got the Veggie Pho.  My soup was not super tasty but had lots of pieces of beef but very little noodles.  My friend enjoyed her soup - had bak choy, mushrooms and corn.  Little pricey for pho as you can get an awesome tasting bowl in LA for like 7 dollars.

Waitress was nice and the place was clean.

Not a huge fan of this Target.  It's the closest one so I find myself going there but the store is so large and it feels like everyone inside is an ASU student at times.  Which basically means it is always crowded with people and I find myself waiting in line to check out.  Otherwise, it's has a lot of good things.  Lots of parking, great staff and like I said before it's super sized so you can find anything and everything you need in one location.

"It has come to my attention that certain members of our staff are devoting an excessive amount of time engaging in non-work related conversations with one another, thereby compromising their ability to deliver optimal levels of customer service. This phenomenon is particularly prevalent when employees are positioned with their backs facing the clientele, which not only hinders their capacity to respond promptly to patrons' needs but also creates an unfavorable impression of unprofessionalism."

I just happened to be in Vegas this new year and since I saw this place in the past i decided to try it. Salad bar is ok, the meats a bit too salty and really raw (bloody) but I was surely disappointed with the service. Waitress show up only 3 times, when we first sat at the table, when she brought us the drinks and when she gave us the check!, I have to literally ask the servers to bring the meats to our table since the seem to just pas us by, I guess the just want you to eat from the salad bar :( \nIn other words, the price service/quality ratio is not good at all

We chanced upon this eatery subsequent to our inability to gain admittance to the Bacchanal due to an extensive queue. At the time of our arrival, we were experiencing considerable hunger! This cozy establishment boasts contemporary embellishments throughout its interior, creating a hip ambiance. Top 20 hits are played at a high volume, making it unsuitable for those seeking a tranquil setting conducive to conversation. \n\nThe servings here are generous, but unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not leave a lasting impression. Nothing remarkable or extraordinary was present in the dishes. I opted for a pastrami-based breakfast sandwich, which lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Had they included additional condiments or a unique sauce, it might have elevated the dish to a higher level of satisfaction. Unfortunately, the combination of pastrami, eggs, and other components did not harmonize effectively. However, it did satiate our hunger. Notwithstanding, I must admit that the tater tots were quite delectable - possessing a satisfying crunch and delightful flavor.

This is a cool spot and very educational. I loved the way that everything is divided into 4 ecosystems, I would have liked the polar/arctic room to have more though. I think that the entry fee is way too much for what you get. The gift shop is nice. You can find cool things like bags made from recycled juice boxes, insect snacks (yes REAL insects to eat) and small crystals, etc.\n\nDon't waste your time and money to take the elevator to the top of the city. You can essentially get the same view for free from the top of Mount Royal.

"It is imperative that one does not make a hasty judgment based on external appearances, as this establishment offers an array of exceptional bargains for those who are willing to invest time in their pursuit. A diverse medley of items, including apparel, artwork, and various domestic ornaments, are available for perusal and purchase. During my recent visit, it appeared that the proprietors were in the process of expanding their inventory to include an increased assortment of floor coverings and visual art pieces, which will undoubtedly be a boon for individuals seeking to revamp their domiciles. My excursion was enjoyable, and I would unhesitatingly revisit this location in quest of additional hidden gems."

"Although they have ceased to offer the delectable Chicken Strip Cheese sandwich, which was undoubtedly a culinary masterpiece, they have opted to supplant it with an uninspiring substitute that fails to elicit enthusiasm. Aside from this disappointing alteration, the establishment maintains an ambiance reminiscent of a conventional Hooters restaurant, complete with an array of novel wing flavors and the introduction of steak fries to their menu."

This lodging establishment caters to individuals who seek fundamental accommodations and are financially constrained, thereby providing a suitable venue for those seeking basic amenities at an economical price point.
