During our sojourn, we found that it fulfilled its intended function admirably and would unhesitatingly suggest it to others who do not prioritize luxurious appointments or an extensive array of services. Within close proximity, we noticed the presence of eateries such as Pizza Hut, Subway, and Fatburger, as well as a cinema, watering holes, and numerous slot machines. Our stay was primarily characterized by slumber, and we did not partake in any notable activities within the hotel's premises themselves. Furthermore, our culinary experience at Fatburger proved to be disappointing, both in terms of taste and the prolonged duration required for its preparation.

I was motivated to go here because I saw it featured on the Food Network, and I was hoping it could hold a candle to the Boiling Crab.  While to seafood was pretty good, it wasn't as spicy & flavorful as I had hoped for.  Go early as it tends to get crowded.  We went at 11am on a weekend and by the time we finished our meal, there was a line for tables.
Solid 3 star red curry tofu.\n\nNot 5 star, not 4 star...but hey!  They did great with the one classic dish I ordered...

"We arrived at approximately 8:30 PM, and upon our arrival, we observed that the queue extended beyond the entrance. Undeterred by the lengthy wait, I advocated for our participation in the line, as my craving for ice cream was unwavering. Following a 15-minute interval, we successfully placed our order; however, the delay was reasonable given the crowded atmosphere and the staff's diligent efforts to manage the influx of patrons. Notably, the employee who assisted us mistakenly provided a larger portion than requested, which they generously offered at no additional cost. It is worth mentioning that the limited seating area within the establishment was largely unoccupied, likely due to the personnel being fully engaged in fulfilling orders. Consequently, we opted for takeout. As an enthusiast of Cold Stone's unique blend of frozen delights, I have grown accustomed to enduring prolonged waits, and in my opinion, the experience merits the temporary inconvenience."

This particular venue brought to mind the ambiance of Whiskey River, albeit devoid of the boisterous individuals customarily present along the shore and characterized by a preponderance of relaxed patrons. It appeared that impromptu dance competitions were taking place on the floor, as spectators seemed to be thoroughly enjoying themselves. Additionally, there were apparent offers of 99-cent Jaeger bombshells and, upon further inquiry, I discovered the existence of 99-cent tacos or similar culinary items. A wet T-shirt contest ensued, featuring a mere trio of participants, which, while somewhat disheartening, managed to retain an element of amusement. Under the circumstances, I would consider visiting this establishment once again.

"The Grandview Saloon boasts a spectacular panorama of Pittsburgh from atop Mt. Washington, which can be savored from the establishment's expansive patio area. While the vistas from within the restaurant itself are by no means inferior, they pale in comparison to the breathtaking scenery that awaits patrons who venture outdoors. To complement the visual feast, the Saloon offers an extensive array of libations, as well as a menu that, while unremarkable in terms of culinary innovation, caters to the local palate with an assortment of familiar, comforting dishes. Unfortunately, the interior design of the restaurant fails to live up to the standards set by its picturesque surroundings, with a decidedly lackluster ambiance that detracts from the overall experience. However, with some attention directed towards refining both the aesthetic and gastronomic aspects, this venue could potentially rank among the city's most captivating destinations for dining and entertainment. In summary, while not an ideal setting for momentous occasions such as anniversaries, the Grandview Saloon remains a suitable choice for hosting first-time visitors, providing them with a unique opportunity to appreciate the splendor of Pittsburgh while indulging in a delectable beverage."

Great, friendly and attentive service. We had the Caesar salad, duck & scallops. Salad was great, duck was good & very rich. Scallops were so-so & not something I'd recommend ordering. Over all an okay meal, but not one I'd repeat.

"I have been frequenting this establishment on a regular basis during the week, and it can be challenging to determine whether it is open for business during inclement weather conditions. Despite this, there are certain aspects of the market that I thoroughly enjoy, while others leave something to be desired. The floral arrangements, for instance, are not only breathtakingly beautiful but also remarkably affordable; however, their longevity leaves much to be desired, typically lasting no more than a few days. Additionally, there are some exceptional deals on fresh produce, with some truly outstanding tomatoes and peaches available during their respective seasons. Nonetheless, it is somewhat disconcerting to note that nearly half of the merchandise on offer is not locally sourced. In fact, I found it quite vexing to locate a locally grown apple, and many of the fruits and vegetables sport SKU stickers indicating their origins in distant states such as California or Washington. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the presence of several local farmers scattered throughout the market renders it a worthwhile venture. Consequently, I shall continue to patronize this establishment with some degree of regularity."

I usually love The Coffee Bean.
Something's wrong with this one, though....  something's wrong with all the coffee inside the Venetian!!?!?!

I love a good, strong cup of coffee but it's either the water at the Venetian, or a plot to drive me insane, but all the coffee in the Venetian Hotel drives me nuts.  

But, it beats the room service coffee, and every morning. I had a cup of Joe from this place.

For the coffee -  1 star.
The way I had it brought to me every morning while in Vegas by a wonderfully  considerate hunk of a man  - - I throw in an additional 2 stars... hence, the 3-star rating.  :-)

"Adequate retail establishment offering an extensive array of merchandise that I would indeed utilize. Notably advantageous reductions on comestibles. Well-organized physical space, albeit susceptible to disarray due to the presence of numerous patrons. The sole drawback I have encountered during my visits is the considerable delay incurred while waiting to complete my purchases. A protracted queue at the checkout counter is a minor inconvenience given the substantial economies realized. Prepare to devote approximately 15 minutes or more to conclude your transaction."

It is a clean place and they have good service. The Koi pond is pretty cool. The sandwich I ordered was pretty awful, don't get the turkey because it is like packaged meat you can buy at a supermarket. The prices were on par with other delis, but you can get a much better sandwich for the same price elsewhere.

I must admit that my expectations were not entirely met by this establishment, despite the favorable reviews and endorsements featured on its website. Specifically, I had envisioned a more engaging and flavorful encounter with a grill master who would not only possess a distinctive Philadelphia accent but also demonstrate a certain level of culinary expertise. However, my experience fell short of these expectations, as the individual responsible for preparing my order appeared to be somewhat hearing-impaired and neglected to include the onions that I had specifically requested.

The cheese steak itself was not particularly impressive, lacking the rich, savory flavors that I have come to associate with this dish. Although the meat was lean and not excessively oily, it was somewhat bland and failed to leave a lasting impression on my palate. The cheese whiz and bread were satisfactory, yet the absence of onions proved to be a significant detriment to my overall enjoyment of the dish. It is worth noting that, in the aftermath of consuming the cheese steak, I experienced some gastrointestinal discomfort, which may serve as an indicator of the quality of the ingredients used in its preparation. Nevertheless, I remain open to the possibility of revisiting this establishment in the future and comparing its offerings to those of its competitors in the area.

Cabo is a very busy place- even on a Tuesday night! Luckily we were a party of 2 and were seated pretty quick. The food tasted good and fresh, but I had very high expectations based on the reputation they have in Charlotte. I was hoping for a little more flavor.

Contrary to some of the other reviews, I didn't feel rushed even though they were jammin'. I went with a friend and we were catching up for quite a while, but our waitress was friendly and didn't rush us, which I appreciated. Parking can be difficult, like most places in NoDa, so plan to cruise around a little. 

Overall I think Cabo has a fun atmosphere for grabbing drinks and something to eat, but it isn't a "go out of your way" establishment.

During our return journey from an excursion to Mexico and Cuba*, we encountered a brief layover at this airport, which proved to be quite straightforward to navigate, particularly upon entering the realm of immigration, as an abundance of signs explicitly indicated the precise directions to follow. 
  Although there was a considerable queue at immigration, it progressed at a relatively rapid pace. My significant other and I had meticulously prepared all necessary documentation pertaining to our research licenses for the Cuban segment of our travels**, but the immigration officer, with a stoic demeanor, merely scanned our passports, cast a fleeting glance in our direction, and stamped our documents, permitting us to continue our journey without delay. Following this, we retrieved our checked luggage, proceeded to customs, and after presenting our customs form, we promptly rechecked our bags. 
  Regrettably, the security screening process necessitated an extended period of time due to extensive queues. Nonetheless, I must commend the security staff for their assiduous efforts in expediting the process and maintaining a cordial demeanor throughout. 
  Had we possessed more than a mere five minutes to spare, I would have taken advantage of the opportunity to acquire some locally renowned BBQ cuisine to enjoy during our impending flight bound for San Francisco. Alas, the security line precluded such a possibility. 
  *It is worth mentioning that, unfortunately, neither Mexico nor Cuba boasts the presence of Yelp. (At least, not at present.) Thus, I shall provide a succinct summary of our experiences, which included exceptional accommodations, dining, drinking, and sightseeing ventures, all of which earned unwavering five-star ratings. 
  **It is interesting to note that Beyonce and Jay Z also followed suit. [Reuters article]

This hotel exterior is a little worn down and in need of a refurbishing. Everything about it just looks dated and tired. The rooms had obviously been updated since other parts of the hotel and they were not that bad although the tile grout looked a little dingy in my room. I did not hear the people in the room next to me as others have complained about. However, I found the food to be very good especially for a hotel. They had a decent bar with a few local brews on tap and service was friendly. The hotel location is convenient but still a 6-8 block walk to the more popular attractions downtown. We took advantage of the free shuttle service and the friendly and knowledgeable driver, Christian. Its fairly easy to get to though off I-277. For the money, it wasn't bad.

The restaurant is cozy and somewhat dark with a separate bar area and dining area. Service was quick and attentive. They have some different beers to experiment with and even let you sample some you're not familiar with before you commit. 


Food was OK but not great. I had half a turkey sandwich and salad. My turkey sandwich was a bit dry and bland and the salad was forgettable. As bars go and as bar food goes you could do much worse.

I've been wanting to try this place for awhile after hearing good things about it and reading the menu. I realize now why the website doesn't list prices-- the mission is hideously overpriced!

We ended up on the patio since they weren't seating in the main area yet (at 6:30pm? For reals?) Our waitress was nice and attentive. She noticed my water had something floating in it and replaced it quickly. My husband's water glass was dirty too. She brought us out two sample size frozen peach and strawberry margaritas which were awesome. Much better than the rocks margarita.

No complimentary chips and salsa which would be ok if they offered something else like Barrio. No happy hour either which was disappointing.

The street corn was good, but I've had much better. The butternut squash tacos were out of this world. My husband liked them better than his mahi tacos. I just can't believe they have the gall to charge $12 for 3 tiny (3 inches in diameter) tacos. They also charge $12 for guac made from 2 avocados. I'm not sure how they have survived in this economy. They must be very slow when the tourists leave for the summer.

"The positive aspects of this establishment include the provision of a magna doodle for young patrons to engage in creative expression, a courteous and attentive wait staff, a pristine dining environment owing to its recent opening, a diverse array of pasta options including whole wheat and rose sauce, the opportunity for patrons to personalize their pasta dishes with various toppings, karaoke amenities available on Friday and Saturday evenings, culinary offerings that are palatable, reasonable prices for those who refrain from adding supplementary toppings, and a distinctive dessert menu."
"However, there are several drawbacks to consider, such as the limited visibility of the children's menu, which is printed on the reverse side of the magna doodle, and the fact that kids' beverages are served in adult-sized to-go cups. Additionally, the cleanup process after a spill was quite sluggish, taking nearly 10 minutes to address my daughter's spilled milk. Furthermore, the menu selections are somewhat restricted, primarily consisting of pasta, pizza, and paninis, with limited variety in terms of entrees. Moreover, the cost of individual pasta toppings is $1.50 each, and my cannelloni dessert was disappointingly unremarkable."

We encountered an unwelcoming reception upon arriving at the entrance, whereupon the security personnel exhibited a discourteous demeanor, rendering it improbable that we would proceed any further had our celebratory companion not persistently advocated for our admittance.

"An enjoyable shopping experience awaits individuals seeking Korean cuisine-related items at this retail establishment, provided they refrain from misidentifying it as a purveyor of Japanese culinary fare, despite superficial similarities between the two cultures' gastronomical offerings."

Red 8 is a pretty good americanized chinese food. I love the Oxtail soup along with their mongolian beef and rice.. The ambiance is really nice and the service is wonderful. The dessert menu can use a bit of work but still ok. The price is a bit expensive , i think your paying for the ambiance and the fact that you are dining at the Wynn.. I don't suggest this place for chinese food. I would only go back here if i was invited, but still glad i checked this restaurant off my list.

It's getting harder to find awesome deals for meals in Vegas.  Gone are the days you can get buffets for $5 or prime rib dinners for $7.99.  Oh Sahara, how I miss you!  

Visiting family in Henderson, we headed over to Sunset Station for some dinner. They had prime rib dinner for $9.99, so I had to get it.  For a Saturday night, it was packed and we had to wait 15 minutes for a table.  

My prime rib dinner was good, but I should've ordered it medium rare, because medium well wasn't as tasty.  

Service was good and food was decent.  I just wished the prime rib dinner was little bit cheaper and then I would've given them a higher rating.  Their t-bone steak dinner special was $12.99, which I thought was a bit high for Vegas.  

Grand Cafe is way better than Denny's, so for a local 24 hour spot, I'd come back to eat.

I really want to like this place, but it was extremely disappointing. Maybe it was overhyped. The food was just okay, nothing sets it apart from other buffets. \n\nBased on other reviews, I might give it another shot next time I'm in Vegas, but I'd rather go back to the seafood buffet at Rio before dining here again.

The food is good which is the best part, I had the endless shrimp (shrimp alfredo x 2, breaded shrimp and shrimp scampi). The worst part is the wait to be seated and served. You have to wait 30 minutes to get seated and then another 15 minutes to be served. They need better service to get a higher rating from me. The food as I said above is very good and hot and once we were served, the service was decent. The cheddar biscuits that you receive after you are seated are excellent.
Good sashimi a bit high priced how ever all the fish I had was fresh and well served.  I have been three times and each time had a good experience.

"My experience at this hotel was less than satisfactory, and I would not consider staying here again. The room, while aesthetically pleasing and featuring comfortable bedding, had a subpar bathroom that appeared to be from a lower-end establishment. Moreover, the arduous trek to the back tower, which involved traversing the entire casino with one's luggage and crossing a bridge over the pool, was particularly vexing. The casino itself, however, was quite pleasant, boasting a fresh and clean atmosphere, likely due to its recent renovation. Unfortunately, the check-in process was a significant disappointment, taking an unacceptable amount of time and contributing to an overall negative experience. The pool and staff were pleasant, but the issues with check-in and the bathroom left a lasting impact on my impression of the hotel."

"The dearth of options was palpable, with a meager assortment of products available, which was further exacerbated by the cramped and cluttered nature of the store; however, the parking lot, despite its capacity, appeared to be congested, creating an incongruous juxtaposition between the exterior and interior spaces, although the staff members, who were few in number but abundant in cordiality, managed to facilitate a semblance of order amidst the chaos, and I, after conducting a thorough examination of the premises, was able to procure a set of diminutive yet aesthetically pleasing beverage receptacles for the nominal sum of sixty-nine cents, which, given the limited variety and somewhat disorganized ambiance, seemed a veritable bargain."

I recently visited this establishment during a brief sojourn at the Aria, whereupon I indulged in a delectable assortment of pastries and beverages. Prior to my visit, I had been lodging at the aforementioned hotel while attending to some business-related matters. As I was strolling towards my accommodations, I couldn't help but notice the alluring ambiance of the vicinity, which was replete with an array of vibrant colors and tantalizing aromas emanating from the nearby patisserie. My curiosity piqued, I decided to return the following morning, craving a cup of coffee and eager to sample the culinary delights offered by this esteemed establishment. Upon my arrival, I was struck by the visually stunning presentation of the multi-tiered cakes, which seemed to defy gravity with their intricate architecture. This prompted me to ponder the amount of time and effort required to create such edible masterpieces. Following a brief wait, I placed an order for two Americanos, only to observe the barista utilize a machine to efficiently dispense the beverages. While the coffee was palatable, it fell short of my expectations, considering the steep price point of $10. In light of this experience, I would not recommend this venue for coffee enthusiasts seeking a more personalized and authentic experience. Nonetheless, those seeking a variety of baked goods may find this establishment suitable for their needs.

The beer is average, but overpriced.  Save yourself $10 on a case and wait until Costco restocks.  ($30 a case at the brewery, $20 at Costco).   Perhaps I would return if they end up opening up an actual restaurant,  as the staff there were extremely friendly, but not too much of a draw at this point....

This particular establishment is one of those culinary destinations that it is imperative to visit at least once in one's lifetime, as it offers an enjoyable experience for the taste buds, with the meat consistently being of high quality, albeit it is advisable to avoid visiting during major holidays, as the level of service and gastronomic excellence may not be maintained with the same rigor and dedication.

"The pricing structure at this establishment is patently exorbitant, with minuscule, tapas-style plates of culinary fare commanding a premium price point in excess of $30, while larger, yet still diminutive entree-sized portions fetch a whopping $50 to $60. Despite my prior awareness of the menu prices, the inflated cost of my meal still managed to surpass my expectations. The ambiance of the restaurant, characterized by a color scheme dominated by red and black hues, was somewhat redeemed by the novelty of witnessing the culinary process firsthand from our perch at the bar. However, the quality of the food, though undeniably satisfactory, fails to justify the egregious markup. If the aim of this dining experience is to foster a sense of casualness, a reduction in prices by at least 25-30% would be imperative."

"Concerning the pinnacle of bagel establishments, this particular venue does not necessarily rank among the uppermost echelons, in my humble opinion. In fact, upon partaking in a 'to go' breakfast excursion with my significant other, he astutely observed that the ambiance was somewhat lacking in cleanliness, specifically referencing the conspicuously dusty vent above the bagel rack. Furthermore, the surfaces, including the counters, floors, and tables, appeared to be in dire need of a thorough sanitizing process. Despite these unfortunate observations, we elected to persevere and acquire our sustenance, albeit with a considerable delay, courtesy of an accommodating yet sluggish staff member. Upon consumption, the bagel sandwiches proved to be moderately satisfying, with the tomato basil variety being particularly palatable. Additionally, the assortment of bagel options was fairly extensive and appreciable. However, the chocolate chip muffin did not quite meet expectations, although it remained edible. Lastly, the prices, while reasonable, did not offer any remarkable value."

"Underwhelmed experience with too much repetition."
It is with profound dismay that I must convey my utter disappointment with my recent dining excursion to this establishment, which, ostensibly, specializes in "pho," a culinary delight that I, and my companion, were eager to indulge in. However, our enthusiasm was quickly extinguished when the waitstaff, in an almost perfunctory manner, divulged that they were bereft of the aforementioned "pho" at the present time. This revelation struck me as rather anomalous, given the eatery's namesake and its purported focus on Vietnamese cuisine. Had the waitress apprised us of this deficiency upon our arrival, we could have, with relative ease, sought out an alternative venue to satiate our craving for a steaming bowl of "pho." Alas, we were compelled to peruse the menu further, resulting in orders that, regrettably, failed to impress. The lone redeeming quality of this lackluster dining experience was the cordial demeanor of the staff, which, admittedly, salvaged a modicum of respectability. In light of these circumstances, I fear that my patronage of this establishment shall remain a distant memory, never to be revisited.

Though the smell of the place can really get to you, the instructors here are amazing.  Down side is the people at the front desk are extremely rude and not very friendly.  If customer service were good all around I would have continued to come to this studio. But since it's all the way on the other side of town I think I'll have to opt out for a more welcoming environment.  

Other than the downsides, they have a clean changing area with 2 showers where they provide body wash, shampoo, and conditioner so you can wash off all the nasty sweat after your classes. 

Try catching Summer and Stacy. They're both awesome in their own way.
Breakfast with Rob,  The food is good.  I had eggs, bacon and pancakes.  Not my favorite pancakes, but ok.  Love their sausage gravy however.

This establishment did not live up to our expectations, as the culinary offerings failed to impress. Specifically, my Classic Maggie pizza was satisfactory, but lacked any exceptional qualities. In contrast, my spouse's burger was severely overcooked, rendering it unpalatable. Due to the absence of our server, we opted not to request a replacement. The menu selections are reminiscent of a typical tavern, with a beer list that is neither extensive nor particularly distinctive.

Been her a couple of times now. I LOVE their beer. They ONLY serve their OWN beer. Food items are okay but not anything to write home about, nothing special. I DID NOT like their wings at all and would not recommend them. Great atmosphere and a good place to go drink. Food's a lil overpriced but it does sit in Ahwatukee. I highly recommend their \"craft brews\" that they brew there. Actually that's the ONLY beer you can get is \"Uncle Bears\" brewed beer. I'll be back but I won't make it a POINT to come here again. Just an okay place to go with friends. TV'S EVERYWHERE! Which makes it a good place to go to watch football. THEY ALLOW DOGS (on the patio and ON a leash\") If you take an 8 X 10\" picture of your dog AND FRAME it, they'll hang his/her picture up in memoriam! That's REALLY cool

Turkish Kitchen was a thoroughly decent, inexpensive meal for a group of us who hadn't booked a table in the city centre on a Friday night.

On sitting we were brought some bread and the most amazingly tasty dip ever.  I need to know what's in that dip because it was the highlight of the meal.  

Not very hungry, I opted for the Turkish ravioli which, despite not being listed on the menu, came with a side of salad and rice.  The sides were a bit awkward and somewhat wasteful, but were certainly tasty.  
The ravioli left a lot to be desired, primarily because it was so overcooked it came apart the minute it I tried to eat it.  The taste was fine though nothing compared with my other experience with Turkish ravioli, which was such a shame because I was expecting something really fantastic.  

I probably should have ordered something kebab-ey like everyone else, but I just wasn't in the mood for a meat feast.  Everyone else seemed happy with their meals, though.  

One weird thing was that when we ordered beer we got glasses which appeared all different sizes and smaller than what you would expect of either a pint or a large bottle. 

It was a really good option for a group looking for something cheap and cheerful but is, in my opinion, not Edinburgh's best Turkish by a long mile.

Great place for a Friday happy hour! The chambord marg is top notch, achiote chopped chicken salad is to die for, and the trio appetizer is great ONLY when it's half price during happy hour.  Highly recommend but only hangup is the cocky manager, useless hostests, and unattentive servers.  After two margaritas you get over the staff :)

I have no idea why there was such a huge hype, it was just a typical thin crusted pizza. Seriously!!!!! The toppings were good, pepperoni, sausage, etc... but honestly you can get a better pizza elsewhere.\n\nHowever, if you are dying for a late  night snack after Marquee it's conveniently located.

My experience here was just okay. I ordered Pho and the broth just didn't cut it for me as being good but it was just alright. My boyfriend ordered the cashew chicken for the first time and he loved it. My friend got chicken fried rice and that was good as well. The price is fairly cheap for the portions at this place which is great for college students. I would come back here for food but not for the pho. 

I'm only giving three stars because of two reasons. One of them is that I ordered the Thai iced tea for almost $3 and I expecting to have some refreshing authentic Thai iced tea, but instead it was a really small bottled one from the fridge which was pretty disappointing and not worth $3. The woman behind the cashier said "I'm too lazy to make a real one," as her excuse. My second reason is that the restaurant was way too humid and hot with the doors open on a humid rainy day. I was sweating uncomfortably while eating my hot pho and it was unpleasant. There were workers fixing the ceiling tiles or something nearby too, which I thought was unacceptable for when people are eating around them only a few feet away. 

The food was good, the atmosphere not so much. I will still be coming back for a quick Thai fix because it's so accessible and conveniently located on Green st.

We ventured to Kings on a Saturday for an early culinary excursion, coinciding with our post-Christmas shopping extravaganza. I've had the pleasure of frequenting this esteemed establishment on several occasions prior, and I must say that the sluggishness of the service has been a constant theme throughout. However, I digress. We initiated our gastronomic journey with the chilled seafood platter, a veritable cornucopia of delights, featuring four Dungeness crab legs, four oysters, four clams, and eight shrimps, all for the reasonable sum of $24.95. In my opinion, this platter ranks among the most exceptional values in Las Vegas for shellfish enthusiasts. Our entrees included grilled shrimp and scallop skewers, a kid's burger, and a combination fried platter. Unfortunately, the latter was somewhat disappointing, with an overabundance of breading and questionable texture of the shrimp and scallops, accompanied by a solitary piece of cod/haddock. In hindsight, I would adhere to my customary practice of opting for the sanddabs or a dish du jour, as the shellfish platter remains the primary draw for my patronage.

"I reside in close proximity to the Burger Factory, which is perpetually characterized by a high volume of patrons. The eatery's extensive menu boasts a diverse array of culinary options, rendering it an ideal venue for accommodating the varied gastronomical inclinations of a group of professionals. Additionally, the generous portion sizes and the establishment's reputation for serving rich, savory dishes make it an excellent choice for individuals seeking a casual dining experience that satisfies their craving for a hearty meal."

For years I have driven past Ping Pong Thai always thinking it was an adult themed Thai restaurant with ping pong shows. No shows here. They only have food. Not even one ping pong ball:(

I've tried the Panang and found it to be watery and bland. The Pad Kee Maw is consistently delicious and packs enough spice I am satisfied ordering it at Medium heat. This dish is the only reason I come here. It's certainly not for the service. 

The service is slow when dining in and good luck chasing down a refill. To Go orders are the exact opposite. Either way you choose you are still left feeling like a number. Boy do they pack the herd in at lunch.

If only they had a Ping pong table I would gladly raise the star level. Maybe the owner is a ping pong champion from Thailand. Now that would be something to get excited about.

It's so close by and the happy hour menu is a great deal, and so we keep going back. But every single time we go I get annoyed with several things. First, they only offer three beers on tap. Second, the service is always spotty. A server will be uncomfortably over-attentive at the beginning of the meal, then we have to hunt him down to get the check. I never understand this. It always seems delaying the bill is a huge liability. I wonder how many people have walked away from a meal without paying. The food can be spotty too. At this meal we got two regularly priced items and two happy hour items. One of the cheaper items, the calamari, was our favorite dish. The most expensive item, the elk meatballs, were bland, dry, and a sure never-order-again.
Wow, harsh reviews!\n\nI found the guy behind the counter helpful.  He steered me in the right direction and I got a meal I really enjoyed.   BBQ'd tilapia and Chicken Adobo were very tasty.

Close to the strip in between harrahs and ballys area in the Linq. Cool new concept, supposely all their slushies have top shelf liquor but I felt it wasn't strong enough, I believe I've gotten more drunk at fat Tuesdays slushies. They have more flavors though and we chose the patron grand mariner because it was sour.The staff is very friendly and cutely dressed, just needs more signs on the cups of drinks. The saxophone cup is seriously amazing! I think its the sexiest and bangest cup there is. ;) Ha ha

"Are you expected to be intoxicated or under the influence of controlled substances for this experience? On my second attendance of a Cirque du Soleil performance, and my initial visit to Las Vegas, I must admit that the ambiance was surreal and hallucinatory, albeit not necessarily in a euphemistic manner. The acrobatic feats performed by the actors were undoubtedly impressive, and the elaborate stage design further enhanced the overall visual spectacle. However, I must confess that certain aspects of the production, specifically the infantile laughter and the disembodied cranium, struck me as eerie and unsettling. While Cirque du Soleil consistently delivers aesthetically pleasing performances, I cannot help but feel that this particular show did not quite meet the elevated standards that I have come to expect from their productions in Las Vegas."

The modified text is: We placed an order for delivery through the online platform of http://www.youbuyandwefly.com, and we found the prices to be reasonable and the food to be delectable. Consequently, we will undoubtedly place future orders with them. However, due to the fact that we opted for delivery, we were unable to experience the ambiance of the physical establishment firsthand. Nonetheless, our meal consisted of a variety of dishes, including a flavorful hot and sour soup, succulent sweet and sour pork, savory orange chicken, and satisfying chicken chow mein, all of which met our expectations.

This place is fun because there is always a live band playing in the evening. So if you are looking do get your dance on like you are at a wedding, then this is it. In fact, if I was getting married (too late), then I would bring the whole wedding party by here and tell them to enjoy the reception. The only problem is that it is a cash bar (and credit or room charge too)! I hate those kind of weddings (not the band part but the cash bar part). 

Tables fill up fast but the room isn't closed off from the casino. You can always walk up with your own drink and enjoy the show. There are also slot machines within ear and eye shot.

I love this place because it reminds me of Old Vegas. Every casino had musical acts playing in the bars and lounges. There was no cover all Vegas wanted was you to come in and spend money on your drinks. Now every casino has mega night clubs with Lines and VIP lists, Karaoke bars, and dueling pianos. So it is nice to see some original Vegas entertainment. I've seen this town change in the last 20 years, so I appreciate this lounge.

Bring the whole group and grab a table. Get a few drinks and put on those dancing shoes. This is Vegas at it's best!!!

I started going to Spice Island when it first opened. I was in my early 20s then, which means the place is officially a Pittsburgh institution. The menu has stayed pretty much the same over the years, with the exception of adding alcohol, but why change a good thing? My favorite items on the menu are vegetarian -- the fried tofu (either sauce is delicious) and the vegetable curry trio. Pay a little extra for the coconut rice and you'll be back for the same thing again and again.

"The Mecklenburg ABC store in question boasts an array of spirituous beverages and liquid refreshments that cater to diverse tastes and preferences, albeit lacking my preferred cognac variety. Notwithstanding, the friendly demeanor exhibited by the staff members during my visit elicited a sense of cordiality, despite their seemingly scrutinizing gaze, which I chose to interpret as a harmless gesture of hospitality rather than an expression of skepticism regarding my age. It is worth mentioning that the prices charged at this establishment align with the standard rates applied at similar ABC stores, with a negligible upward deviation that barely warrants mention."

Their scones are divine and it is a nice little place with fine coffee.  I only wish they would not let dogs in.  I am allergic to them and it rather spoils my meal.  If they had a sign on the door -- no dogs, except service dogs it would be fine.  The ones brought in are not service ones.  Their scones are delicious and made daily.  Go there!

On entering this revamped place and proceeding into the great hall...OMG the detail in the pictures and paintings are visually stunning and esoterically beautiful.

A very contemporary place, quieter than museum's usually are, yes it's smaller than I'd expected from the outside but makes up for it in wow factor, well worth the £80K spent on renovation fees.

Go if you like places with a medieval feel to them, history of scotland, medicine the war and the people who recorded some of the most significant historic events.

With a very busy gift shop and full to the brim bums on seats in their eatery, this was just the place to spend a few bob and actually learn something as well. 

Go if you like Glasgow Gorbals, art of science and medicine Royal Navy, death masks of William Burke and associated criminals, migrated families to Scotland and art history. I last visited a few months ago now, but feel like going again?

But above all...just go for the cultural effect, or the cafe buzz either way you will be rewarded.

I have been frequenting this establishment since prior to my relocation to Las Vegas, and I must say that the multi-level layout, while uncommon in other eateries, is a necessity given the immense foot traffic it receives. Located at the furthest end of The Forum Shops, connected to the illustrious Caesars Palace, accessing this venue can be somewhat arduous, especially considering the considerable distance from the casino and the occasional prolonged waiting period. However, these minor inconveniences are more than compensated for by the exemplary service and delectable cuisine proffered by the knowledgeable staff. Furthermore, the proximity of this eatery to a captivating aquarium and an elaborate animatronic performance featuring both fire and water serves to mitigate any potential tedium. Thus, if you find yourself ambulating about Las Vegas and hankering for a satisfying meal from a familiar establishment, I would highly recommend giving this restaurant a try.

"Greetings Cafe Zupas, it is a pleasure to make your acquaintance! I extend a warm welcome to our community and express my hope for your establishment's longevity. The culinary creation that is your BBQ chicken salad has left an indelible mark on my palate, and I must say, the beverage bar replete with options for customization elevated my dining experience to a new echelon. My spouse, too, expressed gratification with their summer chicken salad and turkey bacon panini. And let us not forget the crowning touch that was the complimentary chocolate-covered strawberry; a sweet indulgence that capped off a thoroughly satisfying repast. I must commend your eatery for striking the perfect balance between satisfaction and portion control, offering a contemporary, health-conscious menu at an affordable price point."

Siam Terrace is one of my preferred Thai restaurants in Urbana, and it stands out as one of the few establishments where I have a singular favorite dish, specifically due to their exceptional preparation of red curry. However, this should not dissuade you from exploring other options on the menu, as the rad nar, pad thai, and diverse alternatives are equally impressive selections. My predilection for their red curry is merely an expression of my individualized preferences. While the restaurant's ambiance may feel slightly constrained when accommodating groups of four or more patrons, and the arrangement of tables appears somewhat awkward, Siam Terrace warrants a rating above four stars. Their appetizers are unremarkable yet reliable, with the standard fare being a judicious choice, while the shrimp appetizer is particularly commendable and worth recommending. Although I categorize Siam Terrace as a $$ establishment, its prices are, in reality, around $1.50, making it an economical option. Their delectable red curry dishes start at a reasonable $8.99 for vegetarian, chicken, or tofu variations, while meat entrees generally cost no more than $12, with seafood options being the priciest.

I first was introduced to this restaurant when living in Fort Worth Texas for a year. I loved this place! It's a Brazilian churrascaria  which really means it's a Brazilian cowboy barbecue. Sounds simple enough but it's better!!! \nThis is an all you can eat monster meat bonanza like nothing you have experienced before unless you've eaten here.\nIt's an all you can eat buffet but here's the twist... servers walk around with sword like skewers full of the best cuts of meat cooked to perfection. You have a little disk you flip over from red for no I'm good to green which is load me up with meat. This is the highlight of this wonderful place to eat. That isn't to take away from the salad bar which has many great items itself such as the prosciutto or the awesome cheeses. Did I also mention that yes they also have a full service bar that is spot on!

This place is a trip to morocco! Try the tea and the date shake. The bread is awesome. The owner is a gracious host and gave us a bunch of stuff to try. I love the decorations in the place too! A fun trip out

We tried a variety of tacos here (3 for $10). Tacos were all unique and tasty, but the \nSuadero Azteca (queen's special) was the standout. It was incredibly flavorful and tender and was topped with really yummy veggies. Definitely get your own of this if you are sharing. The fried fish and fried shrimp ones were tasty too. This is a great place to try inventive tacos, but can get a little pricey. I think you need to ask for chips and salsa here, as they didn't bring us any without us asking, but once brought, it was tasty :)

The name is as good as the food. You can go in and take out, you can sit down and get served, and if your close enough they will deliver. It a mom and pop Asian food place with all or your favorite taste liker teriyaki and orange chicken! worth a stop and food is always great!

Fine place for any-time beakfast (certainly a step up from Dennys or IHOP). Good omlettes and if you can take the heart-clogging properties, biscuits & gravy. Also serves sandwiches, salads and smoothies.

After hearing wonderful things about Il Pizzaiolo for years - literally years - I finally had the opportunity to try this restaurant last week with a group of co-workers. I had a wonderful time! 

First, we ordered wine. The wine list was insanely long and confusing, so we asked the waitress for her recommendation. She told us that there were three house wines, conveniently called the #1, #2, and #3. I believe they were Pinot Grigio, Pinot Noir, and Merlot. I shared two carafes of the Pinot Noir with a co-worker and thought it was very tasty.

The team shared two appetizers, Panzarotti and Fiori de Zucca. The Fiori de Zucca was fried zucchini slices that were good but not my favorite thing ever. I loved the Panzarotti. It kind of tasted like a fried risotto and mozzarella ball. So yummy. Even at the risk of potentially embarrassing myself for taking too much food, I snagged the last one. For my entree, I ordered the Ravioli alla Caprese. The entree was very simple but superbly executed.

I hope to come back to Il Pizzaiolo very soon!

DH was getting pizza at #1 Brothers so I originally tried to order from the Japanese restaurant in the same plaza, but they failed to answer the phone after we called FOUR times!  Thank goodness.  Went to Ari and got the usual excellent service and good sushi.  What made me feel good---I was explaining to the girl who answered the phone that I had ordered the spicy tuna handroll before and had been disappointed in its consistency and our server had suggested a order it more coarsely chopped.  The young lady on the phone said: \"Oh, yes, that was me---I was your server and I remember.  I know exactly what you want!\"  And she did.  My spicy tuna handroll was exactly what I wanted and I felt good that she had remembered such a trivial incident when she deals with hundreds of customers.  Also, when I explained to her what my favorite specialty roll had been back at my old sushi joint, she was able to suggest a roll that very nearly the same and very good.  Actually, wait.  This was a Four star rather than a three star experience---let me go change my rating.  I feel like I have found my forever sushi place!  Thank you, Ari, for making me feel like a valued customer and not a faceless diner.

"I am reluctant to articulate my thoughts regarding this establishment, as I fear that an influx of patrons may compromise the tranquility and exceptional service I have grown accustomed to experiencing during my frequent visits. Notwithstanding my reservations, I must confess that the ambiance and attention to detail exhibited by the staff, particularly Julie and Tammy, have consistently surpassed my expectations. Although a solitary occurrence of an overly zealous pedicure left me feeling somewhat uncomfortable, Julie promptly adjusted her technique upon my request, thereby exemplifying the salon's commitment to client satisfaction. Additionally, the spotlessness of the facilities and the cordial demeanor of the staff have fostered a sense of comfort and loyalty, leading me to frequent the salon on a regular basis. While the cost of a pedicure has recently increased to $22, a nominal fee considering the quality of service provided, I remain steadfast in my belief that this venue offers an unparalleled value. My consistent patronage and appreciation for the salon's excellence are reflected in the $5 gratuity I customarily offer in addition to the standard $20 fee."

I had great service when I went in to buy paint for my house. The employee working the paint section helped me out a lot. I have never really bought paint for a house before so I needed a little guidance. She helped me get the right type and mixed it for me. I had all my questions answered and was out of there pretty quickly. I had great service and was happy with the price I paid.

I profoundly appreciate the proximity of this establishment to my domicile, as it enables me to conveniently acquire an array of fundamental items that cater to my occasional culinary inclinations towards Asian-inspired dishes. Furthermore, I must commend the staff members who work at this location, as they consistently display cordial demeanors and are eager to extend their assistance whenever I am unable to locate specific items within the store. However, I must express some reservations regarding the quality of the fresh produce, meat, and fish available for purchase, which, regrettably, does not meet my expectations. Nonetheless, I generally endorse this business due to its overall satisfactory performance.

Friendly, casual atmosphere with very tasty pizza.  Huge variety of toppings and an excellent olive oil base.  I find the pizzas with tomato sauce to be a little bland, but all of the rest have been fantastic.  Salads are huge and fresh.

"My family and I have been frequent patrons of this establishment for an extended period of time due to its proximity to our domicile. It appears that the restaurant enjoys a substantial local clientele, as evidenced by the numerous take-out orders placed by customers. Although the menu offerings may be somewhat restricted, the quality of the food more than compensates for this limitation, with each dish being meticulously prepared and presented at an optimal temperature. Specifically, my spouse has expressed particular fondness for their sushi. Upon entering the premises, we were promptly acknowledged and seated by the courteous staff. It is advisable to peruse the specials listed on the chalkboard situated near the entrance, as they are subject to change. The ambiance and facilities are pleasing to the eye, and the table settings, cutlery, and glassware are scrupulously maintained. The service was attentive and responsive, with the staff displaying a willingness to accommodate any special requests. While the menu may lack extensive options, it does provide a sufficient variety to cater to most tastes. Additionally, the prices are reasonable and the portion sizes are generous. We intend to revisit this establishment in the future."

"A remarkable eatery with an ambiance that exudes a sense of relaxed sophistication, serving burgers that are meticulously prepared using only the freshest ingredients, thereby ensuring an unparalleled gastronomical experience that is devoid of the typically overpowering flavor associated with establishments of a similar ilk, such as Five Guys; however, it must be noted that the prices charged for these delectable culinary creations tend to be slightly elevated in comparison to those of other esteemed purveyors of fine burgers, specifically In-N-Out, whose offerings, while undoubtedly delicious, possess an unmatched combination of quality and affordability."

Dairy Queen really does not need a review.  Only place better for icecream is your mom and pop stores.  Place was clean, service was quick (oh yeah, we were the only ones in there).  $7.80 seems a little high for 1 wafflecone and 1 icecream in a cup.

"I thoroughly enjoyed my experience at this establishment, as the ambiance was remarkably pleasant and the culinary offerings were of exceptional quality. This dining venue deviated significantly from the conventional diner format, which made it an refreshing alternative. Due to its popularity, I strongly advise making a reservation prior to visiting, especially if you intend to bring a large group of children, as securing a suitable table may prove challenging. The menu catered well to diverse tastes, offering an array of delectable options that garnered widespread approval from both adults and youth. Additionally, the service we received was truly impressive, as the staff demonstrated remarkable proficiency and attentiveness throughout our visit. Overall, this restaurant proved to be an ideal setting for introducing our Cleveland-based acquaintances to the unique essence of Montreal, while also providing a welcoming environment for families."

"Similarly, the ambiance and quality of service at this establishment are comparable to those encountered at the esteemed venue in Scottsdale, Arizona, boasting an impressive array of televisions and an extensive selection of top-notch brews available on tap, ensuring a satisfying experience for patrons seeking a quintessential sports bar atmosphere."

This is my local Salisbury's and where every Monday I do my weekly shop. 

It is a large store, but what bothers me as half the store is not food. This in my eyes defeats the purpose of a supermarket as surely they are food first and TVs second? Clearly it works for them but it does get annoying as choices are limited. The freezer section is very small which for a poor student means I have limited choices in frozen chips. I also find there is a lack of alternatives to brand names i.e. supermarket own brand. On some occasions I would much prefer to just buy the supermarket brand but because this shop has a limited selection of food I can't do this all the time. 

I do enjoy the "Oops!'' section though. As a first year and an Asda shopper, the Oops section was like finding gold. For those who aren't in the know, this is the reduced section. They always have reduced meat which is handy for throwing in the freezer. 

The staff here are very friendly and chatty which is a novelty for supermarket staff.

The selection is pretty vast -- European, upscale specialty brands (up to $24 for a 3 oz bar!), bulk malt balls in 3 flavors that are wonderful, house-brand hot chocolate mix, and lots more. It's fun just to browse around and know all these choices exist.

I have had the privilege of harboring pets throughout my entire existence, and through my perceptive gaze, I have noticed a peculiar phenomenon wherein the quality of service rendered by the front desk personnel and that of the medical practitioners appears to be inversely proportional; that is to say, when the former exhibits exceptional niceness and proficiency, the latter tends to display a lack thereof, and vice versa. However, this anomaly was not manifest at Alta Vista Animal Hospital, as I had the pleasure of experiencing firsthand. Initially, I was impressed by their accommodating schedule, which allowed for a convenient visitation time. Subsequently, I had the pleasure of encountering an exceptionally cordial and polite front desk attendant, Sam, who exemplified the epitome of hospitality. Additionally, the technical staff and Dr. Sean Penn himself displayed an unwavering commitment to friendliness and courtesy, thereby creating a welcoming atmosphere. Furthermore, the cost associated with their services was eminently reasonable, which, in conjunction with the pristine nature of their facilities and the absence of an overpowering canine odor upon entry, made for a remarkably pleasant experience, particularly given the unfortunate necessity of visiting a veterinary clinic on a Sunday afternoon. Thus far, my interactions with Alta Vista have been thoroughly satisfactory.

The view here is amazing. Can't comment on the food but I'm sure it's good. Just sat down at the bar and conversed with our man, Harold?, who served up a few dirty martinis with a twist. Amazing service even after one in our party lost a bit of balance and drink in the process.\n\nJust be nice to the doorman at the elevator and you'll get upstairs to enjoy the view and drinks.

My husband and I loved this place. The staff was very helpful with ordering and allowed us to sample six of their most popular items. We had enough food for leftovers the next day for under $25. It was great to see everything from ties to tatoos having a good time. My only complaint is that the restaurant could be a little cleaner.

"Ambient luminosity prevails, fostering an agreeable ambiance within the establishment, which I find particularly appealing when seated at the bar, whereupon I relish the opportunity to partake in delectable fare such as nachos or enchiladas in the company of my spouse; the attentive and hospitable service complemented by the culinary offerings' quality."

"Three stars for their Bun Bo Hue, indeed. Upon entering this establishment, my expectations were set rather high, considering the positive reviews I had perused prior to my visit. However, upon partaking in their signature dish, I must admit that I was left feeling somewhat underwhelmed. The broth lacked the depth of flavor and spicy kick that I had anticipated, and the pork blood, though sparse in quantity, was surprisingly dry and chalky in texture. Nevertheless, my companion's rice dish proved to be relatively satisfying, and the coffee, with its subtle hint of coconut flavoring, was truly delectable and well worth the price of admission. A Yelp check-in, incidentally, afforded us the opportunity to indulge in said coffee at a discounted rate of two dollars."

Great restaurant located inside the Golden Nugget hotel. Service was excellent- and we had a party of 14 people. The food was pretty good all around. I ordered a "caprese" salad to start and it was delicious. My main course was the Scallops, Brussel sprouts with grits. Fantastic. Hubby ordered the Maine lobster which he thoroughly enjoyed and finished. The king crab legs were amazing.. My nephew had six legs to himself. That 3 year old is one expensive date! 

As for desserts, not amazing but good. We tried the pecan ball, which was a huge ball of vanilla ice cream with pecan nuts on the outside. Nothing special. The bread pudding was better, it came with caramel ice cream on top. I think there's slight rum in the pudding, it was good but nothing blow your mind.

Minus one star because my pineapple juice cup had lipstick stains all over the cup... That's extremely unappetizing and unsanitary. overall, for such a large party- I think the waiters did a fantastic job serving and our food was great overall. Recommend!

"This particular Target store boasts an advantageous geographical positioning, rendering it easily accessible for patrons seeking a wide range of products and services within a convenient setting. During my residency in the surrounding area, I had the pleasure of visiting this Target location on multiple occasions and was consistently satisfied with the quality of customer service and breadth of merchandise available. Its placement within the Surprise Town Center shopping district, surrounded by numerous other esteemed retail establishments, further enhances its appeal to potential customers."

Love the location on 7th st. I passed by it after 5pm and saw that it was closed so I went to this one instead. Ordered an XL bean and cheese burrito America's way! So good. Don't know why this spot only has a 2 star review.

Mama-Mia-American-Pizzeria constitutes a suitable dining establishment for Jungleboy, owing to its vibrant, multilevel structure, replete with alcoves and indoor window openings. The proprietors have embellished the walls with a surrealistic mural, depicting flying mushrooms, chili-pepper butterflies, and a heroic Pepperoni-Man, engaged in a valiant endeavor. Upon entering, we opted for a table designated for two individuals and proceeded to peruse the menu. We elected to order a nine-inch pizza, adorned with three toppings of our choice - specifically, pepperoni, mushrooms, and chili-peppers. Notably, the pizza was generously portioned and boasted an assortment of flavors. Furthermore, the crust was palatable, which is not typically my preference. Our server exhibited a relaxed yet attentive demeanor, ensuring our satisfaction and inquiring about our well-being. Additionally, they offered prompt beverage service and accommodated our request to take leftover slices with us upon departure. Although I experienced a slight chill near the entrance, I observed numerous curious onlookers gazing inside, piqued by their curiosity. In an attempt to convey the quality of the establishment, I smiled and waved at these individuals, only to notice their hasty retreat from the windows. Despite this, I would recommend Mama-Mia-American-Pizzeria for either a brief visit or a leisurely afternoon meal/snack with a group of acquaintances or loved ones, given the availability of a sizeable cartwheel pizza designed to cater to larger gatherings.

The quaint eatery boasts an extensive array of culinary options, ensuring that every patron can find something to suit their gastronomical inclinations. The alfresco seating area provides a tranquil ambiance, which enhances the dining experience. The miniature burgers, or'sliders,' are a particular highlight of the menu, showcasing the chef's skill in creating delectable, bite-sized delights. Such a satisfying dining encounter leaves an indelible mark on one's palate, making it highly likely that repeat visits will occur in the future.

"I decided to visit this establishment in order to reconnect with a familiar acquaintance and indulge in some alcoholic beverages.  Although their assortment of beers may not be particularly extensive, the selection they do offer is impressive.  This eliminates the need for me to spend an excessive amount of time perusing the menu and aimlessly choosing a beverage.  Moving on to the ambiance, the interior of the venue exudes a dim and traditional pub-like atmosphere, while the exterior boasts a more vibrant and lively setting that evokes the feeling of attending a casual backyard gathering.  Patrons can enjoy an array of recreational activities, including oversized Jenga blocks (which resemble 2x4s), a life-size chess set, cornhole, and numerous ping pong tables.  Upon initial observation, I was inclined to believe that the proprietors had merely appropriated someone's outdoor space and juxtaposed a bar alongside it.  However, after engaging in several rounds of games, I came to realize that this unconventional approach actually serves as a unique selling point for the establishment.  All things considered, this venue is an excellent choice, particularly during the afternoon hours."

"We indulged in an exceptional midday repast on a weekend, savoring delectable victuals complemented by an unparalleled selection of fermented beverages, while engaging in convivial conversation with our server, who demonstrated an encyclopedic knowledge of brews. Following a tantalizing tasting experience, we bemused ourselves by exchanging pleasantries centered around the realm of ale. Notwithstanding the ambiance, which could be described as somewhat faded, we were thoroughly entertained, and we anticipate that their nocturnal beer-pairing events would be equally enjoyable."

"I am utterly thrilled about this enhancement to my neighborhood! A stunning refurbishment of a formerly disregarded structurally distinct edifice on Central Avenue has been undertaken. This development signals a positive transformation for our community. Our dining experience at this establishment was nothing short of delightful, with a table originally intended for seven individuals transforming into an impromptu gathering of eight, then nine, all on the auspicious occasion of First Friday. The staff demonstrated exceptional hospitality, warmth, and joviality, ensuring that we felt welcome and well cared for throughout our visit. The proprietor, Dana, graciously took the time to interact with us, guaranteeing that our experience was satisfactory. The culinary offerings were indeed impressive, and we eagerly shared an assortment of dishes among ourselves. Furthermore, the weather conditions were ideally suited for alfresco dining on the patio, contributing to an overall ambiance that was thoroughly enjoyable. These moments serve as a testament to the reasons behind our decision to reside in this captivating locality."

It took us a considerable amount of time, approximately forty minutes, to be seated at our table, despite the fact that it was only nine o'clock on a Tuesday evening. Furthermore, we found the prices to be somewhat high, but then again, this is Las Vegas, after all. We opted for a light dinner consisting of five individual portions, accompanied by two tapas plates per person. Notably, the gin and tonic beverage was truly exceptional, boasting an impressively smooth texture, visually appealing presentation, and uniquely shaped ice cubes that added an extra layer of sophistication to the overall experience. Additionally, we highly recommend the marinated mussels served in a small tin container, as well as the steamed mussels, which were cooked to perfection and paired excellently with a slice of bread to soak up the savory juices. Other notable dishes included the meat platter, featuring a selection of expertly cured meats that were thoroughly enjoyed, a delectable Brussels sprout salad, flavorful sauteed shrimp, tender skirt steak complemented by a grilled bell pepper, and a side of asparagus, albeit slightly pricey at twelve dollars plus, but accompanied by a delicious sauce that paired perfectly with a piece of bread. Lastly, the quail dish was a highlight of the meal, comprising a small yet scrumptious bird that left a lasting impression on our taste buds. Throughout the evening, we received top-notch service and enjoyed a tranquil ambiance, making for a truly memorable dining experience.

I visited this Lenscrafters subsequent to being unable to locate what I sought at the Chandler Mall branch. Upon my arrival, I was acknowledged by Donna, who exhibited exceptional hospitality. I experimented with numerous sets, taking an interlude amidst the process to nourish my infant a bottle. Donna verified my insurance and observed a dilemma. Because of the optometrist where I underwent my eye examination, my insurance implied that I was ineligible for frames. Donna endeavored to address the predicament through a telephone conversation, but her efforts proved futile due to the optometrist's closure. Donna informed me that I would need to await the succeeding day for my insurance to invalidate the matter at the optometrist. We revisited the establishment the following day, and Donna had previously resolved the problem. I acquired my spectacles and experienced immense satisfaction with the assistance I obtained. Donna and Heather were the two luminous individuals at this particular site!

This venue serves as my preferred destination for luncheon meetings and occasional dinners with my spouse, boasting an authentic local ambiance that permeates the atmosphere. The staff exudes cordiality and hospitality, while maintaining a spotless environment, complemented by delectable culinary offerings. My palate particularly relishes the tangy flavors of the green tomatillo salsa, which pairs excellently with the restaurant's signature dishes, such as the salmon and shrimp tacos. Although the service may be somewhat slow due to the inexperienced nature of the youthful servers, this factor contributes to the eatery's charm as a unique local hotspot.

Great food! Friendly environment! Modern decor! Gay! All of these things describe Switch to a tee! I had been telling my wife for months that I had heard great things about this restaurant, especially their brunch menu. Unfortunately for me, she is not a big fan of Sunday Brunch, so when we did finally make it there last Sunday, I had already missed out on the brunch menu and the $3 carafes of Bloody Marys. 

We ordered a carafe anyways... only $6 for approximately 4 good sized Bloodys! They were made well, but for the most part tasted pretty generic, yet still exactly what I expected for only $6!! I ordered one of the tastiest burgers I've ever eaten, topped with guacamole, salsa and jalapenos! Each plate was also served with a small house made ceasar salad, which I thought was a nice touch! Our service was very prompt and friendly!

I will definitely be coming back to Switch for my favorite meal of the week: BRUNCH :)

I like MadHouse, but this actually isn't a review at all--I just wanted to say that when I try to access MadHouse's website, I ALWAYS get a trojan warning from my browser. I think the site is infected. I hope the owners see this!

"Star Nursery is the epitome of excellence in the realm of plant nurseries within the Las Vegas area, offering a wide array of superior quality plants and landscaping materials that cater to the diverse needs of both residential and commercial clients. My personal experience working at a plant nursery during my formative years has instilled in me a profound appreciation for the intrinsic value of such establishments, which has culminated in my pursuit of a degree in landscape architecture and subsequent ownership of a successful landscape company. Upon perambulating the premises of Star Nursery, I am overcome with nostalgia for my former profession, as the verdant splendor of the flora and the meticulous attention to detail accorded to each plant specimen serve as a testament to the exceptional standards upheld by this esteemed institution. The inventory of plants and landscaping supplies available at Star Nursery is truly impressive, encompassing everything from ornamental bedding plants to majestic trees, all of which are fastidiously maintained and presented in a manner that showcases their inherent beauty. Furthermore, the staff at Star Nursery possesses a depth of knowledge and friendliness that is unparalleled, making them an invaluable resource for anyone seeking expert advice and guidance in selecting the most appropriate plants and materials for their specific landscaping needs. Thus, if you are engaged in any sort of landscaping endeavor at your residence or place of business, it would be tremendously beneficial to patronize Star Nursery, as their exceptional quality and commitment to excellence are unmatched by the likes of Walmart and Lowes."

When in Las Vegas, consider partaking in the following activities to initiate an unforgettable evening of entertainment:

1) Acquire a delectable, alcoholic beverage, commonly referred to as an "adult slurpee," in a flavor of your preference, conveniently located outside the esteemed Imperial Palace.
2) Transport the aforementioned beverage into the Imperial Palace Karaoke Club, ensuring its safekeeping and accessibility throughout the duration of your visit.
3) Engage in the act of singing, or if inclined, feigning musical proficiency through the medium of karaoke, accompanied by the optional participation of others, fostering an atmosphere of camaraderie and lighthearted amusement.
4) Experience enjoyment, derived from the combination of the previous activities, culminating in a state of contentment and eagerness for the forthcoming events of the evening.
5) Consider the preliminary phase of your nocturnal exploits to be comprehensive, thereby permitting you to proceed with the main component of your evening's diversion, armed with an enhanced sense of exhilaration and anticipation.

Love this place but giving it a 4 star as it can be somewhat slow and few healthier options to select from. Yeah I know, penalizing them for not "healthy" is probably silly as you know when going to let's say a fast food joint you are not eating so good. That being said the food at Defalco's is very high quality - almost as if you are in Italy and am not comparing it to fast food.

I suggest you wait to try out Defalco's when not in a rush as its worth the wait. There order system is very similar to local places back east (basically avoiding technology) and that probably ties into part of the slower process of ordering and getting your food. I am from back east (NY area) and finding a good Italian deli / grocery store in the Phoenix area is not an easy task. A friend introduced me to Defalco's and anytime I am headed south on Scottsdale road (which is often) and after passing Thomas my stomach seems to pick up we are near Defalco's as it starts giving me the rumble noise.

I have tried many things on the menu such as Eggplant Parmigiana, Chicken Parmigiana, and Cheese steak and three of those are worth a shot. I recommend to bring a friend and each get a different large sandwich and share.

We had the Travel Zoo coupon which gives you the app/entree/dessert. Ordered the combo app of course. Alligator was tough and so were the frog's legs. Crabcake was great. Gumbo is good. jambayala was great...Not quite New Orleans but pretty tasty. Atmosphere was nice and New Orleans looking. Large portions for the money.

Classy, quiet restaurant. You'll see some white haired Montreal politicians every time. The place you'd go for a special birthday or anniversary. The waiters are polite, pleasant, and funny if you get them going. The food is downright perfect, french cuisine. Be sure to get the Escargot.

"We tend to frequent this establishment on Friday evenings, accompanied by my associates who are habitual patrons. The culinary offerings are relatively consistent, specifically the lamb meatballs and Johnny's nachos, which are met with unanimous approval among our gathering. Even their ranch dressing, which I am not particularly fond of, is surprisingly palatable. Additionally, I have a penchant for their Guinness stew. However, the sole drawback preventing this venue from attaining a perfect five-star rating is the somewhat exorbitant prices, as the cost of beverages starts at $6 (I believe) and most menu items surpass the $10 mark, with sandwiches priced at $12. A slight reduction in prices would elevate them to serious contender status for a five-star rating. Notwithstanding, the hospitality extended by the staff is commendable, as they exhibit warmth, maintain an adept handling of large groups and split checks (a challenging task given our diverse party size ranging from 4 to 12 individuals), and engage in playful banter without resorting to dismissive behavior or ejecting us (a feasible outcome considering our unabashed humor and conversational topics)."

"A bowl of rice and an extremely reasonable price point coupled with an abundance of spices is what attracts me to this establishment. Specifically, I can acquire a salmon bowl accompanied by brown rice and an ample amount of fiery seasoning for a mere $7 or less. Upon entering the premises, I noticed a queue leading up to several cash registers and a menu displayed prominently on the wall, featuring an array of traditional Japanese dishes such as chicken teriyaki bowls, providing options for a diverse group of patrons. For my part, I opted for the aforementioned salmon bowl at a cost of $5.99, which represents an excellent value considering it includes fish that has not been deep-fried, thereby making it a suitable choice for a midday repast. However, I must confess that I find the teriyaki sauce to be somewhat overpowering, so I requested that it be applied sparingly. Furthermore, for an additional $0.25, I was able to enhance the nutritional value of my meal by selecting brown rice instead of the standard white variety. After receiving my bowl, I made my way to the condiment station, whereupon I discovered a variety of hot chili powders, sauces, and sliced green onions. The latter particularly caught my attention and appreciation. It is worth mentioning that the negative assessments of this eatery may stem from the fact that Japanese cuisine generally lacks the potent flavors associated with Chinese and Thai culinary traditions."

Since this venue enjoys immense patronage, it is customary for patrons to experience a prolonged waiting period prior to being seated, an unavoidable circumstance, sadly. Notwithstanding, the hosts exhibited commendable attentiveness in clearing our dishes, albeit with a minor drawback. Specifically, they had a tendency to position the cutlery directly on the table surface, a practice I prefer to circumvent due to my inclination to utilize napkins for placement. It would be considerate of them to proffer alternative utensil options, thereby precluding the need for excessive H2O consumption. Moving forward, a diverse array of culinary offerings presented themselves, rendering the $40 per capita cost reasonable. Their selection included decadent delights such as crab legs, lobster ravioli, prime rib, and creme brulee. Additionally, complementary beverages like raspberry iced tea and soda were available.
This place is a wonderfull place to go to... inexpensive and very friendly bartenders and some sexy ones at that... woo hoo!!! Love the screens in there and the food is excellent!!!
This place is wonderful!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Fat free - new, clean place, plenty of parking - nice staff - and did I say fat free?  Great spot!

Marquee is a hot mess, but a glamorous one =)

The lines to get into the club are ridiculous and look completely unorganized but the bouncers/ door guys know exactly what lines are for what. They make a chaotic scene look under controlled! 

There isn't really a dress code. And that is sort of a disappointment. Some girls are in flats and leggings and guys are in tennis shoes and tee. 

Navigating through the club can be a challenge, I admit. The stairs are killers- yes. The dance floor gets too crowed and you feel like your in a can of sardines, yes. But those are things that can be overlooked. Haah. 

The DJ and entertainers are great. The sound system is crazy. And the bartenders are good looking and nice.

I think this is one and only Indo-chinese restaurant in Phoenix area. Nice and clean place. Food was really good. We went on a Thu with reservation and was not crowded. \n\nTry the Manchurian Chicken ... Tasty

"Prior to purchasing tickets, it is imperative that you are cognizant of the fact that the performance will consist of a scathing critique of the audience, with the majority of the jokes relying heavily on stereotypes pertaining to race, gender, sexual orientation, age, and physical characteristics. Therefore, if you are easily offended, it would be advisable to avoid this production altogether. While the material presented is largely novel, there may be some instances of repetition, such as the quip regarding the notion of pondering one's mother's lips performing fellatio on one's father during a familial greeting. As an ardent devotee of comedic entertainment, I have had the privilege of exposure to a vast array of standup routines broadcasted on various platforms, including Comic View, Comedy Central, HBO, and Showtime, thereby increasing the likelihood that I have already encountered such humor. Nonetheless, the show promises to be an amusing experience, albeit not suitable for juvenile audiences due to its explicit nature (rated NC-17/R).\n\nThe venue's intimate setting is reminiscent of academic institutions, wherein attendees will be subject to unwavering scrutiny, analogous to the atmosphere of a high school or college environment. Consequently, it is essential to acknowledge that participation in the performance is mandatory, and individuals must be prepared to assume an active role in the show, as there are no hiding places."

The crab cake is the best in town. If you order the Caesar salad with salmon, request it to be blackened. Game changer. If you are into beef, go for the marinated flank steak. Heaven on a fork. 

The bar is very good sized and has full service for food and lots of TV's. 

Bon apatite.

Decent mocha. Hipster heaven. Loud and angry music. Brought me back to my youth.

The culinary offerings appeared visually appealing, and the beverages were economically priced. I aspire to revisit the establishment for the "remedy," a potion consisting of ginger and whiskey.

"The most advantageous aspect of the Excalibur Hotel and Casino is its comparative economic efficiency in relation to other luxury hotels situated along the Las Vegas Strip. The accommodation cost for a single night's stay was $27, which was booked through the online travel agency Expedia. However, it is important to note that an additional daily resort fee of $15 is charged, which grants access to various amenities, such as wired internet connectivity within the guestroom. The package also included a complimentary $20 food and beverage credit, redeemable at select on-site dining establishments, including primarily bars and the pricier Steakhouse restaurant.
